<div type="translation" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-eng3" xml:lang="eng">
<div type="textpart" subtype="book" n="1">
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:1.1-1.32">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274106" n="1.1-1.2"><milestone n="1" unit="line"/>Sing, goddess, about the wrath of Peleus' son, Achilles, a killing wrath.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274106a" n="1.2">It imposed countless suffering upon the Achaeans.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274106b" n="1.3">It dispatched to Hades many valiant souls of heroes.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274106c" n="1.4-1.5">It made them themselves
spoil for dogs <milestone n="5" unit="line"/> and every bird.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274106d" n="1.5">The plan of Zeus came to be fulfilled.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274106e" n="1.6-1.7">From the time when<note resp="Loeb" anchored="true">1</note> first they parted in strife
Atreus' son, king of men, and brilliant Achilles.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274107" n="1.8">Who then of the gods was it that brought
these two together to contend? </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274108" n="1.9" >The son of Leto and Zeus. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274109" n="1.9-1.10" >For he in anger against the king roused throughout the host an evil
disease.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274109a" n="1.11-1.12" >The people began to perish, <milestone n="10" unit="line"/>because upon the priest Chryses the son of Atreus
had <sic>wrought</sic> dishonour. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274110" n="1.12-1.15">For
he had come to the swift ships of the Achaeans to free his daughter,
bearing ransom past counting; and in his hands he held the wreaths
of Apollo who strikes from afar,<note resp="Loeb" anchored="true" >2</note> on a staff of gold.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274110a" n="1.15-1.16">He began to plead with all the Achaeans,
<milestone n="15" unit="line"/>but most of all the two sons of
Atreus, the marshallers of the people: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2274111" n="1.17-1.19">Sons of Atreus, and other
well-greaved Achaeans, to you may the gods who have homes upon
<placeName key="tgn,7011019">Olympus</placeName> grant that
you sack the city of Priam, and return safe to your homes;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274112" n="1.20-1.21"><milestone n="20" unit="line"/>Release my dear child to me, and accept the
ransom, reverencing the son of Zeus, Apollo who strikes
from afar. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274113" n="1.22-1.23">Then all the rest of the Achaeans
shouted assent, to reverence the priest and accept the glorious
ransom, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274114" n="1.24">But this did
not please the heart of Agamemnon, son of Atreus.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274114a" n="1.25"><milestone n="25" unit="line"/>Instead, he sent him away harshly.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274114b" n="1.25">An in addition<note>this is my attempt to capture the force of epi</note> he laid upon him a
harsh command: </s></p>
<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2274115" n="1.26-1.28">Let me not find you, old man,
by the hollow ships, either hanging around now or coming back later,
so that the staff and the wreath of the god do you now good
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274116" n="1.29">Her I will not set free.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274117" n="1.29-1.31">Sooner will old age
come upon her <milestone n="30" unit="line"/> in our house, in
<placeName key="perseus,Argos">Argos</placeName>, far from
her native land, spending her time at the loom and my bed. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274118" n="1.32">Go!  </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274118a" n="1.32">Do
not anger me, so that you may return the safer<note>I really need to understand the force of the comparative here.</note>. </s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:1.33-1.67">
<p>





<s xml:id="sent2274119" n="1.33">So he spoke.</s>




<s xml:id="sent2274119a" n="1.33">The old man was seized
with fear.</s>




<s xml:id="sent2274119b" n="1.33">He obeyed his word. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274120" n="1.34" >He went in silence to the shore of the loud-resounding
sea, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274121" n="1.35-1.36"><milestone n="35" unit="line"/>and earnestly then, when he had gone apart, the old
man prayed to the lord Apollo, whom fair-haired Leto bore: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2274122" n="1.37-1.38">Hear me, god of the silver
bow, who stand over <placeName key="perseus,Chryse" >Chryse</placeName> and holy Cilla, and rule mightily over
<placeName key="perseus,Tenedos">Tenedos</placeName>.</s>




<s xml:id="sent2274122a" n="1.39-1.41">Sminthian god,<note resp="Loeb" anchored="true">1</note> if ever
I roofed over a temple to your pleasing, or if ever I burned to
you fat thigh-pieces of bulls and goats, <milestone n="40" unit="line"/>fulfill this prayer for me: </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274123" n="1.42">Let the Danaans pay for my tears
with your arrows </s></q></p>
<p>





<s xml:id="sent2274124" n="1.43">So he spoke in prayer.


</s>




<s xml:id="sent2274124a" n="1.43">Phoebus
Apollo heard him.</s>




<s xml:id="sent2274124b" n="1.44-1.45">Down from the peaks of <placeName key="tgn,7011019">Olympus</placeName> he strode, angered at
heart, <milestone n="45" unit="line"/>bearing on his shoulders his
bow and covered quiver. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274125" n="1.46-1.47" >The arrows rattled on the shoulders of the angry god as he moved,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274126" n="1.47">He for his part approached like the
night. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274127" n="1.48">Then he took his position apart
from the ships.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274127a" n="1.48">And he let fly an arrow: </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274128" n="1.49">terrible was the twang of the silver bow. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274129" n="1.50"><milestone n="50" unit="line" />He went after<note>another instance of epoixomai</note> the mules first and the swift dogs.
</s>


<s xml:id="sent2274129a" n="1.51-1.52">Then letting his stinging arrow against the
men themselves he began to strike. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274130" n="1.52">Without stop the pyres of the dead
burned, one after another<note>or many at the same time?</note>.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274131" n="1.53">For nine days the arrows of the
god ranged among the host.</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274131a" n="1.54">On the tenth day Achilles called the
people to assembly.</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274132" n="1.55"><milestone n="55" unit="line"/>The goddess, white-armed Hera, as it happened, had put
it in his heart, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274133" n="1.56">For she
cared about the Danaans, when she saw them dying. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274134" n="1.57-1.58">After they were assembled and
gathered together, among them arose and spoke swift-footed Achilles: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2274135" n="1.59-1.61">Son of Atreus, now I think we
shall return home, beaten back again, should we even escape
death, <milestone n="60" unit="line"/>if indeed both war and plague
alike are to ravage the Achaeans. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274136" n="1.62-1.67">But come, let us ask some seer or priest, or some
reader of dreams—for a dream too is from Zeus—who might say why
Phoebus Apollo is so angry, whether he finds fault with a vow or
a hecatomb; <milestone n="65" unit="line"/>if he may, having
accepted the savour of lambs and unblemished goats, be willing
to ward off the plague from us. </s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:1.68-1.91">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274137" n="1.68">Having thus spoken he sat down,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274138" n="1.68-1.72">Among them arose
Calchas son of Thestor, far the best of bird-diviners, who knew the
things that were, and that were to be, and that had been before,
<milestone n="70" unit="line"/>and who had guided the ships of
the Achaeans to <placeName key="tgn,7002329">Ilios</placeName> by
his own prophetic powers which Phoebus Apollo had bestowed upon him.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274139" n="1.73">He with good intent addressed
the gathering, and spoke among them: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2274140" n="1.74-1.75">Achilles, dear to Zeus, you
order me to declare <milestone n="75" unit="line"/> the wrath of
Apollo, the lord who strikes from afar. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274141" n="1.76">Therefore I will speak. </s>


<s     xml:id="sent2274142" n="1.76-1.77">But you, for your part, take this in.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274142a" n="1.76-1.77">Swear
that you will readily defend me with your words and hands. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274143" n="1.78-1.79">for I think I
shall anger a man who rules mightily over all the Argives, and
whom the Achaeans obey. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274144" n="1.80" ><milestone n="80" unit="line"/>For mightier is a king, when
he is angry at a lesser man. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274145" n="1.81-1.83">Even if he swallows down his wrath <corr n="for that">for</corr> day,
yet afterwards he cherishes resentment in his heart till he
brings it to fulfillment. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274146" n="1.83" >Say then, if you will keep me safe. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274147" n="1.84">In answer to him spoke swift-footed
Achilles: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2274148" n="1.85"><milestone n="85" unit="line"/>Take courage and say whatever oracle you know. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274149" n="1.86-1.91">For by Apollo, dear to Zeus,
to whom you, Calchas, pray when you reveal oracles to the
Danaans, no one, while I live and have sight upon the earth, shall
lay heavy hands on you beside the hollow ships, <milestone n="90" unit="line"/>no one of the whole host of the Danaans,
not even if you name Agamemnon, who now claims to be far the
best of the Achaeans. </s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:1.92-1.129">
<p>





<s xml:id="sent2274150" n="1.92">Then the blameless seer took heart.</s>




<s xml:id="sent2274150a" n="1.92">He spoke: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2274151" n="1.93-1.94">It is not then because of a
vow that he finds fault, nor because of a hecatomb, but because
of the priest whom Agamemnon dishonoured.</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274151a" n="1.95"><milestone n="95" unit="line"/>and did not release his daughter nor accept the
ransom.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274151b" n="1.96">For this reason the god who strikes from afar has given
sufferings and will still give them. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274152" n="1.97-1.100">He will not drive off from the Danaans the
loathsome pestilence, until we give back to her dear father the
bright-eyed maiden, unbought, unransomed, and lead a sacred
hecatomb <milestone n="100" unit="line"/> to <placeName key="perseus,Chryse">Chryse</placeName>. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274153" n="1.100">Then we might appease and
persuade him. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274154" n="1.101">When he had thus spoken he sat down,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274155" n="1.101-1.103">and among them arose the
warrior, son of Atreus, wide-ruling Agamemnon, deeply troubled.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274156" n="1.103-1.104">With rage his black
heart was wholly filled, and his eyes were like blazing fire. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274157" n="1.105"><milestone n="105" unit="line"/>To
Calchas first of all he spoke, and his look threatened evil:
</s></p>
<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2274158" n="1.106">Prophet of evil, never yet have
you spoken to me a pleasant thing; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274159" n="1.107-1.108">ever is evil dear to your heart to prophesy, but
a word of good you have never yet spoken, nor brought to pass.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274160" n="1.109-1.113">And now among the
Danaans you claim in prophecy <milestone n="110" unit="line"/>
that for this reason the god who strikes from afar brings woes
upon them, that I would not accept the glorious ransom for the
girl, the daughter of Chryses, since I much prefer to keep her
in my home. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274161" n="1.113-1.115">For
certainly I prefer her to Clytemnestra, my wedded wife, since
she is not inferior to her, <milestone n="115" unit="line"/>
either in form or in stature, or in mind, or in any handiwork.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274162" n="1.116">Yet even so will I give
her back, if that is better; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274163"    n="1.117">I would rather the people be safe than perish. </s>




<s xml:id="sent2274164" n="1.118-1.119">But provide me with a prize
of honour immediately, so that I alone of the Argives may not be without a prize,
since that would not be proper. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274165" n="1.120"><milestone n="120" unit="line"/>For you all see this, don't you? --
that my prize goes elsewhere. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274166" n="1.121">In answer to him spoke swift-footed
brilliant Achilles: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2274167" n="1.122-1.123">Son of Atreus, most glorious,
most greedy of all, how shall the great-hearted Achaeans give
you a prize? </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274168" n="1.124">We know of no substantial common goods that are available. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274169" n="1.125-1.126"><milestone n="125" unit="line"/>Far from it! Whatever we seized as booty from the cities
has been been divided up. It is certainly not proper to gather these
things, snatched back from the army. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274170" n="1.127" >Instead, you now give back this girl to the go. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274171" n="1.127-1.129">Then, we Achaeans will pay you back three and
four times over, if ever Zeus grants us to sack the well-walled city of
<placeName key="perseus,Troy">Troy</placeName>. </s></q>
<note resp="Loeb" anchored="true">1</note>
</p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:1.130-1.171">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274172" n="1.130"><milestone n="130" unit="line"/>In
answer to him spoke lord Agamemnon: </s></p>
<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2274173" n="1.131-1.132">Do not thus, mighty though
you are, godlike Achilles, try to deceive me with your wit;
for you will not get
by me nor will you change my mind.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274174" n="1.133-1.134">Are you willing, so that your yourself
may keep your prize, that I should sit here idly with nothing?

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274174a" n="1.134">

Are you telling me to give this woman back? </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274175" n="1.135-1.136"><milestone n="135" unit="line"/>Now, if the
great-hearted Achaeans will give me a prize, fashioning it to my interests
so that it will be worth just as much— </s>




<s xml:id="sent2274176" n="1.137-1.139">But if they were not to make such a gift, I
myself would go and seize for myself perhaps your prize, or that of Aias, or I would seize and lead away that
of Odysseus. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274177" n="1.139">That man will be beside himself<note>(1) cholos; (2) this form, which seems to be a future perfect!. I would expect "sad" rather than "angry." What is really going on here?</note>, to whom I may go. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274178" n="1.140"><milestone n="140" unit="line"/>But these things we will consider again
later.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274178a" n="1.141">Let us now drag a black ship to the shining sea.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274178b" n="1.142">Let us quickly gather enough oarsmen into it.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274178c" n="1.142-1.143">Let u place on board a
hecatomb.</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274178d" n="1.144">And let us embark on it the fair-cheeked daughter of Chryses
herself. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274179" n="1.144-1.147">Let one
man who is used to command be its leader, <milestone n="145" unit="line" />either Aias, or Idomeneus, or brilliant Odysseus, or you, son
of Peleus, of all men most extreme, so that on our behalf you
may by offering
sacrifice propitiate the god who strikes from afar. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274180" n="1.148">Glaring from beneath his brows spoke
to him swift-footed Achilles: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2274181" n="1.149-1.151">Ah me, clothed in
shamelessness, thinking of profit, <milestone n="150" unit="line"/>how shall any man of the Achaeans obey your
words with a ready heart either to go on a journey or to fight
against men with force? </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274182" n="1.152-1.153">It was not on account of the Trojan spearmen
that I came here to fight, since they are not liable to me.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274183" n="1.154-1.157">Never have they
driven off my cattle or my horses, <milestone n="155" unit="line"/>nor ever in deep-soiled <placeName key="perseus,Phthia">Phthia</placeName>, nurse of men, did
they lay waste the harvest, for many things lie between
us—shadowy mountains and sounding sea. </s>




<s xml:id="sent2274184" n="1.158-1.160">But you, shameless one, we
followed, so that you might rejoice, with us seeking to win honor
for Menelaus and for yourself, dog-face, <milestone n="160" unit="line"/>from the Trojans. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274185"    n="1.160">To this you pay no attention.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274185b"    n="1.160">You just don't care. </s>




<s xml:id="sent2274186" n="1.161-1.162">And now you threaten that
you yourself will take away from me the prize for which I toiled
so much and which the sons of the Achaeans gave to me. </s>




<s xml:id="sent2274187" n="1.163-1.164">I never have a prize like
yours, whenever the Achaeans sack a well-inhabited citadel of
the Trojans. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274188" n="1.165-1.166" ><milestone n="165" unit="line"/>Of course, the brunt of furious battle
my hands perform.</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274189" n="1.166-1.167">But if ever an apportionment comes, your prize
is far greater.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274189a"    n="1.167-1.168">But I go to my ships having one that small but dear, when I have worn myself out in the fighting. </s>




<s xml:id="sent2274190" n="1.169-1.170">Now will go back to
<placeName key="perseus,Phthia">Phthia</placeName>, since it
is far better <milestone n="170" unit="line"/>to return home
with my beaked ships.

</s>




<s xml:id="sent2274190a" n="1.170-1.171">Nor do I intend while I am here
dishonoured to pile up riches and wealth for you. </s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:1.172-1.205">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274191" n="1.172">Then the king of men, Agamemnon,
answered him: </s>

<q>




<s xml:id="sent2274192" n="1.173">Run away then, if your heart
is determined.</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274192a" n="1.173-1.174">I certainly do not beg you to remain for my sake. </s>




<s xml:id="sent2274193" n="1.174-1.175">With me are others
<milestone n="175" unit="line"/> who will give me honour, and
above all Zeus, the lord of counsel. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274194" n="1.176">Most hateful to me are you of all the kings that Zeus
nurtures. </s>

ask you.

<s xml:id="sent2274423a" n="1.553-1.554" >At your convenience you devise all things whatever you

<s xml:id="sent2274424" n="1.555-1.556"><milestone n="555" unit="line"/>But now I have terrible<note>αἰνῶς here picks up αἰνότατε in 1.552</note> fear in my heart,

<s xml:id="sent2274425" n="1.557">For at

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274425a" n="1.557">And she clasped your knees. </s>

<s xml:id="sent2274427" n="1.560"><milestone n="560" unit="line"/>Then

<s xml:id="sent2274428" n="1.561">What has gotten into you?<note resp="Loeb" anchored="true">1</note> You are always drawing conclusions.

<s xml:id="sent2274429" n="1.562">Yet
you not be able to accomplish anything.

<s xml:id="sent2274431" n="1.564">If this thing is as you say, then it must be pleasing

<s xml:id="sent2274432a" n="1.565-1.567">Obey my plan.

<s xml:id="sent2274436" n="1.573-1.575">Surely this will be sorry

<s xml:id="sent2274529" n="2.123-2.128">For should we

with sacrifice, and to number ourselves, <milestone n="125" unit="line"/>and should the Trojans be gathered together,
even all they that have dwellings in the city, and we Achaeans

the Trojans to pour our wine, then would many tens lack a

<s xml:id="sent2274530" n="2.129-2.130">so far,

dwell in the city. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274531" n="2.130-2.133" ><milestone n="130" unit="line"/>But allies there be out of

<s xml:id="sent2274532" n="2.134-2.135">Already have nine years of great Zeus gone by,

are rotted, and the tackling loosed; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274533" n="2.136-2.137">and our wives, I <mod n="ween:simpsub">believe</mod>, and little children sit

<s xml:id="sent2274534" n="2.137-2.138">yet is our task wholly unaccomplished in
furtherance <sic>whereof</sic> we came <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod>. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274535" n="2.139"><sic>Nay</sic>, come, even as I shall <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod>, let us all obey:
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274536" n="2.140"><milestone n="140" unit="line"/>let us flee with our ships to our dear native
land; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274537" n="2.141">for no more is there
hope that we shall take broad-wayed <placeName key="perseus,Troy">Troy</placeName>. </s></q></p>

<s xml:id="sent2274538" n="2.142-2.143">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he, and roused the

<s xml:id="sent2274539" n="2.144-2.146">And the gathering was stirred like the long

<s xml:id="sent2274540" n="2.147-2.149">And even as when the West Wind at its coming

<s xml:id="sent2274541" n="2.149-2.151">and they with loud shouting

<s xml:id="sent2274542" n="2.151-2.153">And they called each one to his

<s xml:id="sent2274543" n="2.153-2.154">and their shouting went up to

<s xml:id="sent2274544" n="2.154">and they began to take the props from

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:2.155-2.187">

<s xml:id="sent2274556" n="2.182-2.183">So said she, and he knew the

<s xml:id="sent2274574" n="2.211">Now the others <sic>sate</sic> them down and were

<s xml:id="sent2274624" n="2.299-2.300">Endure, my friends, and <mod n="abide:simpsub">remain</mod> for a time, that

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:2.301-2.335">
<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2274625" n="2.301-2.302">For this in truth do we know
well in our hearts, and <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> are all witnesses <sic>thereto</sic>, even as
many as the fates of death have not borne away. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274626" n="2.303-2.307">It was but as yesterday or
the day before, when the ships of the Achaeans were gathering in
Aulis,<note resp="Loeb" anchored="true">1</note> <sic>laden</sic> with
woes for Priam and the Trojans; <milestone n="305" unit="line" />and we round about a spring were offering to the immortals
upon the holy altars hecatombs that bring fulfillment, beneath a
fair plane-tree from whence flowed the bright water; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274627" n="2.308">then appeared a great portent:
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274628" n="2.308-2.310">a serpent, blood-red
on the back, terrible, whom the Olympian himself had sent forth
to the light, <milestone n="310" unit="line"/>glided from

<s xml:id="sent2274629" n="2.311-2.313">Now upon this were the
younglings of a sparrow, tender little ones, on the topmost
bough, cowering beneath the leaves, eight in all, and the mother

<s xml:id="sent2274630" n="2.314">Then the serpent devoured them as they twittered
piteously, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274631" n="2.315"><milestone n="315" unit="line"/>and the mother fluttered around them,
wailing for her dear little ones; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274632" n="2.316"><mod n="howbeit:simpsub">however</mod> he coiled himself and caught her by the wing
as she screamed about him. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274633" n="2.317-2.318">But when he had devoured the sparrow's little
ones and the mother with them, the god, who had brought him to
the light, made him to be unseen; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274634" n="2.319">for the son of crooked-counselling Cronos turned him
to stone; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274635" n="2.320"><milestone n="320" unit="line"/>and we stood there and marveled at what
was <sic>wrought</sic>. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274636" n="2.321-2.322">

<s xml:id="sent2274637" n="2.323" >'Why are <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> thus silent, <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> long-haired Achaeans? </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274638" n="2.324-2.325">To us <mod n="hath:simpsub">has</mod> Zeus the
counsellor <mod n="shewed:simpsub">showed</mod> this great sign, <milestone n="325" unit="line"/>late in coming, late in fulfillment, the fame
<sic>whereof</sic> shall never perish. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274639" n="2.326-2.329">Even as this serpent devoured the sparrow's

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274640" n="2.330">On <corr n="this wise">this way</corr> <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod>

<s xml:id="sent2274641" n="2.330"><milestone n="330" unit="line"/>and now all this is <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> being

<s xml:id="sent2274642" n="2.331-2.332" ><sic>Nay</sic>, come, <mod n="abide:simpsub">remain</mod> <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> all, <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> well-greaved Achaeans, even where
<mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> are, until we take the great city of Priam. </s></q></p>

<s xml:id="sent2274643" n="2.333-2.335">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he, and the Argives

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:2.336-2.368">

<s xml:id="sent2274644" n="2.336">And there <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> among them the

<s xml:id="sent2274646" n="2.339" >What then is to be the end of our compacts and our oaths?
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274647" n="2.340-2.341"><milestone n="340" unit="line"/><sic>Nay</sic>, into the fire let us cast all counsels and

<s xml:id="sent2274648" n="2.342-2.343">For vainly do we wrangle

<s xml:id="sent2274649" n="2.344-2.347" >Son of Atreus, do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> as of old keep unbending purpose,

<s xml:id="sent2274652" n="2.350-2.353"><milestone n="350" unit="line"/>For I declare that Cronos' son, supreme

<s xml:id="sent2274653" n="2.354-2.356" ><mod n="Wherefore:simpsub">For which reason</mod> let no man make haste to depart homewards until each

<s xml:id="sent2274654" n="2.357-2.359"><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod>, if any man is

<s xml:id="sent2274655" n="2.360" ><milestone n="360" unit="line"/>But do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod>, O King,

<s xml:id="sent2274657" n="2.362-2.363">Separate <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> men by tribes, by clans, Agamemnon,

<s xml:id="sent2274658" n="2.364-2.366">If <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> do thus, and the

<s xml:id="sent2274661" n="2.369">Then in answer to him <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> the king,

<s xml:id="sent2274662" n="2.370"><milestone n="370" unit="line" />Aye <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> once more, old sir, <corr n="art thou">are you</corr> pre-eminent in speech

<s xml:id="sent2274665" n="2.375-2.376"><milestone n="375" unit="line"/>But the son of Cronos, even Zeus that <mod n='beareth'>bears</mod>

<s xml:id="sent2274671" n="2.388-2.389">Wet with sweat about the breast of many a man

<s xml:id="sent2274674" n="2.394-2.396">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he, and the Argives

<s xml:id="sent2274676" n="2.398-2.399">And they arose and <mod n="hasted:simpsub">hastened</mod> to scatter among the

<s xml:id="sent2274677" n="2.400-2.401"><milestone n="400" unit="line" />And they made sacrifice one to one of the gods that are for ever,

<s xml:id="sent2274678" n="2.402-2.407">But Agamemnon, king of men, <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> a fat bull of five

<s xml:id="sent2274685" n="2.419-2.420">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he; but not as yet

<s xml:id="sent2274693" n="2.441">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he, and the king of men,

<s xml:id="sent2274696" n="2.445-2.449"><milestone n="445" unit="line"/>The kings, nurtured of Zeus, that were about

<s xml:id="sent2274700" n="2.455-2.458"><milestone n="455" unit="line"/>Even as a consuming fire <mod n='maketh'>makes</mod> a boundless

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:2.459-2.510">

<s xml:id="sent2274701" n="2.459-2.465">And as the many tribes of winged

<s xml:id="sent2274704" n="2.469-2.473">Even as the many tribes of

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274705" n="2.474-2.479">And even as goatherds separate

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274709" n="2.484">Tell me now, <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> Muses that have

<s xml:id="sent2274710" n="2.485-2.486" ><milestone n="485" unit="line"/>for <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> are goddesses and are at

<s xml:id="sent2274712" n="2.488-2.492">But the common <mod n="folk:simpsub">people</mod> I could not tell nor name, <sic>nay</sic>,

<s xml:id="sent2274713" n="2.493">Now will I tell the

<s xml:id="sent2274714" n="2.494-2.508">Of the Boeotians Peneleos

<s xml:id="sent2274715" n="2.509-2.510">Of these there

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:2.511-2.545">

<s xml:id="sent2274716" n="2.511-2.515">And they that dwelt in Aspledon

<s xml:id="sent2274717" n="2.515" ><milestone n="515" unit="line"/>for he lay with her in secret.

thirty hollow ships.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274719" n="2.517-2.523">And of the Phocians Schedius and
Epistrophus were captains, sons of great-souled Iphitus, son of
Naubolus; these were they that held Cyparissus and rocky Pytho,
<milestone n="520" unit="line"/>and sacred Crisa and Daulis and
Panopeus; and that dwelt about Anemoreia and Hyampolis, and that
lived beside the goodly river Cephisus, and that held Lilaea by the
springs of Cephisus. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274720" n="2.524">With
these followed forty black ships. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274721" n="2.525-2.526"><milestone n="525" unit="line"/>And their leaders
busily marshalled the ranks of the Phocians, and made ready for
battle hard by the Boeotians on the left.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274722" n="2.527-2.529">And the Locrians had as leader
the swift son of Oïleus, Aias the less, in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> as great as
Telamonian Aias, but far less. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274723" n="2.529-2.530">Small of stature was he, with corselet of linen,
<milestone n="530" unit="line"/>but with the spear he far
excelled the whole host of Hellenes and Achaeans. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274724" n="2.531-2.533">These were they that dwelt in
Cynus and Opus and Calliarus and Bessa and Scarphe and lovely
Augeiae and Tarphe and Thronium about the streams of Boagrius.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274725" n="2.534-2.535">With Aias followed forty
black ships of <milestone n="535" unit="line"/>the Locrians that
dwell over against sacred Euboea.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274726" n="2.536-2.541">And the Abantes, breathing fury,
that held Euboea and Chalcis and Eretria and Histiaea, rich in
vines, and Cerinthus, hard by the sea, and the steep citadel of
Dios; and that held Carystus and dwelt in Styra,— <milestone n="540" unit="line"/>all these again had as leader Elephenor, scion of
Ares, him that was son of Chalcodon and captain of the great-souled
Abantes. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274727" n="2.542-2.544">And with him
followed the swift Abantes, with hair long at the back, spearmen
eager with outstretched ashen spears to rend the corselets about the
breasts of the foemen. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274728" n="2.545" ><milestone n="545" unit="line"/>And with him there followed
forty black ships. </s></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:2.546-2.580">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274729" n="2.546-2.549">And they that held Athens, the
well-built citadel, the land of great-hearted Erechtheus, whom of
old Athene, daughter of Zeus, fostered, when the earth, the giver of
grain, had borne him; and she made him to dwell in Athens, in her
own rich sanctuary, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274730" n="2.550-2.551" ><milestone n="550" unit="line"/>and there the youths of the
Athenians, as the years roll on in their courses, seek to win his
favour with sacrifices of bulls and rams;— </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274731" n="2.552">these again had as leader Menestheus,
son of Peteos. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274732" n="2.553-2.554">Like <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod>
him was none other man upon the face of the earth for the
marshalling of chariots and of warriors that bear the shield. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274733" n="2.555"><milestone n="555" unit="line"/>Only
Nestor could vie with him, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274734" n="2.555">for
he was the elder. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274735" n="2.556">And with him
there followed fifty black ships.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274736" n="2.557-2.558">And Aias led from Salamis twelve
ships, and stationed them where the battalions of the Athenians
stood.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274737" n="2.559-2.564">And they that held Argos and
Tiryns, famed for its walls, <milestone n="560" unit="line"/>and
Hermione and Asine, that enfold the deep gulf, Troezen and Eïonae
and vine-clad Epidaurus, and the youths of the Achaeans that held
Aegina and Mases,—these again had as leaders Diomedes, good at the
war-cry, and Sthenelus, dear son of glorious Capaneus. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274738" n="2.565-2.566"><milestone n="565" unit="line" />And with them came a third, Euryalus, a godlike warrior, son of
king Mecisteus, son of Talaus; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274739" n="2.567" >but leader over them all was Diomedes, good at the war-cry. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274740" n="2.568">And with these there followed eighty
black ships.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274741" n="2.569-2.577">And they that held Mycenae, the
well-built citadel, <milestone n="570" unit="line"/>and wealthy
Corinth, and well-built Cleonae, and dwelt in Orneiae and lovely
Araethyrea and Sicyon, <mod n="wherein:simpsub">in which</mod> at the first Adrastus was king; and
they that held Hyperesia and steep Gonoessa and Pellene, <milestone n="575" unit="line"/>and that dwelt about Aegium and throughout
all Aegialus, and about broad Helice,—of these was the son of
Atreus, lord Agamemnon, captain, with an hundred ships. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274742" n="2.577-2.578">With him followed most people
by far and goodliest; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274743" n="2.578-2.580" >and among them he himself did on his gleaming bronze, a king
all-glorious, and was pre-eminent among all the warriors, <milestone n="580" unit="line"/><corr n="for that">for</corr> he was noblest, and led a people
far the most in number. </s></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:2.581-2.614">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274744" n="2.581-2.587">And they that held the hollow
land of Lacedaemon with its many ravines, and Pharis and Sparta and
Messe, the haunt of doves, and that dwelt in Bryseiae and lovely
Augeiae, and that held Amyclae and Helus, a citadel hard by the sea,
<milestone n="585" unit="line"/>and that held Laas, and dwelt
about Oetylus,—these were led by Agamemnon's brother, even Menelaus,
good at the war-cry, with sixty ships; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274745" n="2.587">and they were marshalled apart. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274746" n="2.588-2.589">And himself he moved among
them, confident in his zeal, urging his men to battle; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274747" n="2.589-2.590">and above all others was his
heart fain <milestone n="590" unit="line"/>to get him requital for
his strivings and groanings for Helen's sake.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274748" n="2.591-2.596">And they that dwelt in Pylos and
lovely Arene and Thryum, the ford of Alpheius, and fair-founded
Aepy, and that had their abodes in Cyparisseïs and Amphigeneia and
Pteleos and Helus and Dorium, <milestone n="595" unit="line"/>where
the Muses met Thamyris the Thracian and made an end of his singing,
even as he was journeying from Oechalia, from the house of Eurytus
the Oechalian: </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274749" n="2.597-2.598">for he
vaunted with boasting that he would conquer, were the Muses
themselves to sing against him, the daughters of Zeus that <mod n='beareth'>bears</mod>
the aegis; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274750" n="2.599-2.600">but they in
their wrath maimed him, <milestone n="600" unit="line"/>and took
from him his wondrous song, and made him forget his minstrelsy;—
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274751" n="2.601">all these <mod n="folk:simpsub">people</mod> again had as
leader the horseman, Nestor of Gerenia. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274752" n="2.602">And with him were ranged ninety hollow ships.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274753" n="2.603-2.610">And they that held Arcadia
beneath the steep mountain of Cyllene, beside the tomb of Aepytus,
where are warriors that fight in close combat; <milestone n="605" unit="line"/>and they that dwelt in Pheneos and Orchomenus, rich
in flocks, and Rhipe and Stratia and wind-swept Enispe; and that
held Tegea and lovely Mantineia; and that held Stymphalus and dwelt
in Parrhasia, —all these were led by the son of Ancaeus, Lord
Agapenor, <milestone n="610" unit="line"/>with sixty ships; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274754" n="2.610-2.611">and on each ship embarked full
many Arcadian warriors well-skilled in fight. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274755" n="2.612-2.614">For of himself had the king of
men, Agamemnon, given them benched ships wherewith to cross over the
wine-dark sea, even the son of Atreus, for with matters of seafaring
had they <mod n="naught:simpsub">nothing</mod> to do. </s></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:2.615-2.652">
<p>
<milestone n="615" unit="line"/>




<s xml:id="sent2274756" n="2.615-2.619">And they that dwelt in Buprasium
and <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Elis, all that part <sic>thereof</sic> that Hyrmine and Myrsinus on
the seaboard and the rock of Olen and Alesium enclose between

one, and many Epeians embarked thereon. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274757" n="2.620-2.621"><milestone n="620" unit="line"/>Of these some were

<s xml:id="sent2274758" n="2.622">and of some was the son of Amarynceus captain, even mighty
Diores; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274759" n="2.623-2.624">and of the
fourth company godlike Polyxeinus was captain, son of king
Agasthenes, Augeias' son. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274760" n="2.625-2.629"><milestone n="625" unit="line"/>And those from
Dulichiuni and the Echinae, the holy isles, that lie across the sea,
over against Elis, these again had as leader Meges, the peer of
Ares, even the son of Phyleus, whom the horseman Phyleus, dear to
Zeus, begat—he that of old had gone to dwell in Dulichium in wrath
against his father. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274761" n="2.630"><milestone n="630" unit="line"/>And with Meges there followed forty black
ships.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274762" n="2.631-2.635">And Odysseus led the
great-souled Cephallenians that held Ithaca and Neritum, covered
with waving forests, and that dwelt in Crocyleia and rugged
Aegilips; and them that held Zacynthus, and that dwelt about Samos,
<milestone n="635" unit="line"/>and held the mainland and dwelt
on the shores over against the isles. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274763" n="2.636">Of these was Odysseus captain, the peer of Zeus in
counsel. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274764" n="2.637">And with him there
followed twelve ships with vermilion prows.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274765" n="2.638-2.640">And the Aetolians were led by
Thoas, Andraemon's son, even they that dwelt in Pleuron and Olenus
and Pylene and Chalcis, hard by the sea, and rocky Calydon. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274766" n="2.641-2.642">For the sons of great-hearted
Oeneus were no more, neither did he himself still live, and
fair-haired Meleager was dead, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274767" n="2.643" >to whom had commands been given that he should bear full sway among
the Aetolians. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274768" n="2.644">And with Thoas
there followed forty black ships. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274769" n="2.645-2.649"><milestone n="645" unit="line"/>And the Cretans had
as leader Idomeneus, famed for his spear, even they that held Cnosus
and Gortys, famed for its walls, Lyctus and Miletus and Lycastus,
white with chalk, and Phaestus and Rhytium, well-peopled cities; and
all they beside that dwelt in Crete of the hundred cities. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274770" n="2.650-2.651"><milestone n="650" unit="line" />Of all these was Idomeneus, famed for his spear, captain, and
Meriones, the peer of Enyalius, slayer of men. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274771" n="2.652">And with these there followed eighty
black ships. </s></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:2.653-2.694">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274772" n="2.653-2.656">And Tlepolemus, son of Heracles,
a valiant man and tall, led from Rhodes nine ships of the lordly
Rhodians, <milestone n="655" unit="line"/>that dwelt in Rhodes
sundered in three divisions—in Lindos and Ialysus and Cameirus,
white with chalk. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274773" n="2.657-2.660">These
were led by Tlepolemus, famed for his spear, he that was born to
mighty Heracles by Astyocheia, whom he had led forth out of Ephyre
from the river Selleïs, <milestone n="660" unit="line"/>when he had
laid waste many cities of warriors fostered of Zeus. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274774" n="2.661-2.663">But when Tlepolemus had grown
to manhood in the well-fenced palace, <sic>forthwith</sic> he <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> his own
father's dear uncle, Licymnius, scion of Ares, who was then waxing
old. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274775" n="2.664-2.665">So he straightway
built him ships, and when he had gathered together much people,
<milestone n="665" unit="line"/>went forth in flight over the
sea, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274776" n="2.665-2.666"><corr n="for that">for</corr> the other
sons and grandsons of mighty Heracles threatened him. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274777" n="2.667">But he came to Rhodes in his
wanderings, suffering woes, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274778" n="2.668-2.670">and there his people settled in three divisions by
tribes, and were loved of Zeus that is king among gods and men;
<milestone n="670" unit="line"/>and upon them was wondrous
wealth poured by the son of Cronos.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274779" n="2.671-2.674">Moreover Nireus led three
shapely ships from Syme, Nireus that was son of Aglaïa and Charops
the king, Nireus the comeliest man that came beneath Ilios of all
the Danaans after the fearless son of Peleus. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274780" n="2.675"><milestone n="675" unit="line" /><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod> he was a weakling, and but few people followed with
him.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274781" n="2.676-2.679">And they that held Nisyrus and
Crapathus and Casus and Cos, the city of Eurypylus, and the
Calydnian isles, these again were led by Pheidippus and Antiphus,
the two sons of king Thessalus, son of Heracles. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274782" n="2.680"><milestone n="680" unit="line"/>And
with them were ranged thirty hollow ships.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274783" n="2.681-2.685">Now all those again that
inhabited Pelasgian Argos, and dwelt in Alos and Alope and Trachis,
and that held Phthia and Hellas, the land of fair women, and were
called Myrmidons and Hellenes and Achaeans— of the fifty ships of
these men was Achilles captain. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274784" n="2.686"><milestone n="685" unit="line"/><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod> they bethought
them not of dolorous war, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274785" n="2.687" >since there was no man to lead them forth into the ranks. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274786" n="2.688-2.693">For he lay in idleness among
the ships, the swift-footed, <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Achilles, in wrath because of
the fair-haired girl Briseïs, <milestone n="690" unit="line"/>whom
he had taken out of Lyrnessus after <sic>sore</sic> toil, when he wasted
Lyrnessus and the walls of Thebe, and laid low Mynes and
Epistrophus, warriors that raged with the spear, sons of king
Evenus, Selepus' son. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274787" n="2.694">In <sic>sore</sic>
grief for her lay Achilles idle; but soon was he to arise again.
</s></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:2.695-2.733">
<p>
<milestone n="695" unit="line"/>




<s xml:id="sent2274788" n="2.695-2.699">And they that held Phylace and
flowery Pyrasus, the sanctuary of Demeter, and Iton, mother of
flocks, and Antron, hard by the sea, and Pteleos, couched in grass,
these again had as leader warlike Protesilaus, while yet he lived;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274789" n="2.699"><mod n="howbeit:simpsub">however</mod> <mod n="ere:simpsub">before</mod> now the black
earth held him fast. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274790" n="2.700-2.701" ><milestone n="700" unit="line"/>His wife, her two cheeks torn
in wailing, was left in Phylace and his house but half
established,<note resp="Loeb" anchored="true">1</note>
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274791" n="2.701-2.702">while, for himself, a
Dardanian warrior <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> him as he leapt forth from his ship by far
the first of the Achaeans. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274792" n="2.703">Yet
neither were his men leaderless, though they longed for their

<s xml:id="sent2274793" n="2.704-2.707">for Podarces,

to great-souled Protesilaus, and younger-born; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274794" n="2.707-2.708">but the other was the elder and
the better man, even the warrior, valiant Protesilaus. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274795" n="2.708-2.709">So the host in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> lacked a
leader, though they longed for the noble man they had lost. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274796" n="2.710"><milestone n="710" unit="line"/>And
with him there followed forty black ships.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274797" n="2.711-2.715">And they that dwelt in Pherae
beside the lake Boebeïs, and in Boebe, and Glaphyrae, and well-built

even by Eumelus, whom Alcestis, queenly among women, bare to
Admetus, <milestone n="715" unit="line"/>even she, the comeliest of
the daughters of Pelias.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274798" n="2.716-2.719">And they that dwelt in Methone
and Thaumacia, and that held Meliboea and rugged Olizon, these with
their seven ships were led by Philoctetes, well-skilled in archery,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274799" n="2.719-2.720"><milestone n="720" unit="line"/>and on each ship embarked fifty oarsmen well
skilled to fight amain with the bow. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274800" n="2.721-2.723">But Philoctetes lay suffering grievous pains in an
island, even in sacred Lemnos, where the sons of the Achaeans had
left him in anguish with an evil wound from a deadly water-snake.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274801" n="2.724">There he lay suffering; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274802" n="2.724-2.725"><milestone n="725" unit="line" />yet full soon were the Argives beside their ships to <sic>bethink</sic> them
of king Philoctetes. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274803" n="2.726"><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod>
neither were these men leaderless, though they longed for their

<s xml:id="sent2274804" n="2.727-2.728">but Medon

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274805" n="2.729-2.732">And they that held Tricca and
Ithome of the crags, <milestone n="730" unit="line"/>and Oechalia,

<s xml:id="sent2274806" n="2.733">And with these were ranged thirty
hollow ships. </s></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:2.734-2.779">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274807" n="2.734-2.736">And they that held Ormenius and
the fountain Hypereia, <milestone n="735" unit="line"/>and that held
Asterium and the white crests of Titanus, these were led by

<s xml:id="sent2274808" n="2.737">And with him there followed forty black ships.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274809" n="2.738-2.741">And they that held Argissa, and
dwelt in Gyrtone, Orthe, and Elone, and the white city of Oloösson,
<milestone n="740" unit="line"/>these again had as leader

<s xml:id="sent2274810" n="2.742-2.744">whom immortal Zeus begat— even
him whom glorious Hippodameia conceived to Peirithous on the day
when he got him vengeance on the shaggy centaurs, and thrust them
forth from Pelium, and <mod n="drave:simpsub">drove</mod> them to the Aethices. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274811" n="2.745-2.746"><milestone n="745" unit="line" />Not alone was he, but with him was Leonteus, scion of Ares, the
son of Caenus' son, Coronus, high of heart. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274812" n="2.747">And with them there followed forty
black ships.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274813" n="2.748">And Gouneus led from Cyphus two and
twenty ships, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274814" n="2.749-2.754">and with
him followed the Enienes and the Peraebi, staunch in fight,
<milestone n="750" unit="line"/>that had set their dwellings
about wintry Dodona, and dwelt in the ploughland about lovely
Titaressus, that <mod n='poureth'>pours</mod> his fair-flowing streams into Peneius; yet
<mod n="doth:simpsub">does</mod> he not mingle with the silver eddies of Peneius, but <mod n='floweth'>flows</mod> on
over his waters <corr n="like unto">like</corr> olive oil; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274815" n="2.755"><milestone n="755" unit="line"/><corr n="for that">for</corr> he is a branch of
the water of Styx, the <sic>dread</sic> river of oath.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274816" n="2.756-2.758">And the Magnetes had as captain
Prothous, son of Tenthredon. These were they that dwelt about
Peneius and Pelion, covered with waving forests. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274817" n="2.758-2.759">Of these was swift Prothous
captain; and with him there followed forty black ships. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274818" n="2.760"><milestone n="760" unit="line"/>These
were the leaders of the Danaans and their lords. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274819" n="2.761-2.762">But who was far the best among
them do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> tell me, Muse— best of the warriors and of the horses
that followed with the sons of Atreus.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274820" n="2.763-2.765">Of horses best by far were the
mares of the son of Pheres, those that Eumelas <mod n="drave:simpsub">drove</mod>, swift as
birds, <milestone n="765" unit="line"/>like of coat, like of age,
their backs as even as a levelling line could make. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274821" n="2.766-2.767">These had Apollo of the silver
bow reared in Pereia, both of them mares, bearing with them the
panic of war. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274822" n="2.768-2.769">And of
warriors far best was Telamonian Aias, while yet Achilles cherished
his wrath; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274823" n="2.769-2.770">for Achilles
was far the mightiest, <milestone n="770" unit="line"/>he and the
horses that bare the peerless son of Peleus. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274824" n="2.771-2.773"><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod> he <sic>abode</sic> <mod n="amid:simpsub">among</mod> his
beaked, seafaring ships in utter wrath against Agamemnon, Atreus'
son, shepherd of the host; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274825" n="2.773-2.775">and his people along the sea-shore took their joy in
casting the discus and the javelin, and in archery; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274826" n="2.775-2.777"><milestone n="775" unit="line" />and their horses each beside his own <mod n="car:simpsub">chariot</mod>, eating lotus and parsley
of the marsh, stood idle, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274827" n="2.777-2.778">while the chariots were set, well covered up, in the
huts of their masters. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274828" n="2.778-2.779" >But the men, longing for their captain, dear to Ares, roared <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod>
and thither through the camp, and fought not. </s></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:2.780-2.818">
<p>
<milestone n="780" unit="line"/>




<s xml:id="sent2274829" n="2.780">So marched they then as though all the
land were swept with fire; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274830" n="2.781-2.783">and the earth groaned beneath them, as beneath Zeus
that <mod n='hurleth'>hurls</mod> the thunderbolt in his wrath, when he <mod n='scourgeth'>scourges</mod> the
land about Typhoeus in the country of the Arimi, where men say is
the couch of Typhoeus. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274831" n="2.784-2.785" >Even so the earth groaned greatly beneath their tread as they went;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274832" n="2.785"><milestone n="785" unit="line" />and full swiftly did they speed across the plain.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274833" n="2.786-2.787">And to the Trojans went, as a
messenger from Zeus that <mod n='beareth'>bears</mod> the aegis, wind-footed, swift Iris
with a grievous message. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274834" n="2.788-2.789" >These were holding assembly at Priam's gate, all gathered in one
body, the young men alike and the elders. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274835" n="2.790"><milestone n="790" unit="line"/>And
swift-footed Iris stood near and <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> to them; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274836" n="2.791-2.794">and she made her voice like to
that of Polites, son of Priam, who was <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to sit as a sentinel of
the Trojans, trusting in his fleetness of foot, on the topmost part
of the barrow of aged Aesyetes, awaiting until the Achaeans should
sally forth from their ships. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274837" n="2.795" ><milestone n="795" unit="line"/>Likening herself to him
swifted-footed Iris <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> to Priam, saying: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2274838" n="2.796-2.797">Old sir, ever are endless
words dear to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, now even as of yore in time of peace; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274839" n="2.797">but war unabating is afoot.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274840" n="2.798-2.799"><mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod> full often
have I entered <mod n="ere:simpsub">before</mod> now into battles of warriors, but never yet
have I seen a host so goodly and so great; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274841" n="2.800-2.801"><milestone n="800" unit="line"/>for most like to the leaves or the sands are
they, as they march over the plain to fight against the city.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274842" n="2.802">Hector, to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> beyond all
others do I give command, and do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> even according to my word.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274843" n="2.803-2.804">Inasmuch as there
are allies full many throughout the great city of Priam, and
tongue differs from tongue among men that are scattered abroad;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2274844" n="2.805-2.806"><milestone n="805" unit="line"/>let each one therefore give the word to those
whose captain he is, and these let him lead forth, when he has
marshalled the men of his own city. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274845" n="2.807-2.808">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> she, and Hector in no
wise failed to know the voice of the goddess, but <sic>forthwith</sic> <mod n="brake:simpsub">broke</mod> up
the gathering; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274846" n="2.808">and they rushed
to arms. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274847" n="2.809-2.810">The gates one
and all were opened wide, and forth the <mod n="folk:simpsub">people</mod> <mod n="hasted:simpsub">hastened</mod>, <milestone n="810" unit="line"/>both footmen and charioteers; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274848" n="2.810">and a great din arose.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274849" n="2.811-2.814">Now there is before the city a
steep mound afar out in the plain, with a clear space about it on
this side and on that; this do men <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> call Batieia, but the
immortals call it the barrow of Myrine, light of step. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274850" n="2.815"><milestone n="815" unit="line"/>There
on this day did the Trojans and their allies separate their
companies.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274851" n="2.816-2.817">The Trojans were led by great
Hector of the flashing helm, the son of Priam, </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274852" n="2.817-2.818">and with him were marshalled
the greatest hosts by far and the goodliest, raging with the spear.
</s></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:2.819-2.857">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274853" n="2.819-2.823">Of the Dardanians again the
valiant son of Anchises was captain, <milestone n="820" unit="line" />even Aeneas, whom fair Aphrodite conceived to Anchises <mod n="amid:simpsub">among</mod> the

skilled in all manner of fighting.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274854" n="2.824-2.827">And they that dwelt in Zeleia
beneath the nethermost foot of Ida, <milestone n="825" unit="line" />men of wealth, that drink the dark water of Aesepus, even the

to whom Apollo himself gave the bow.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274855" n="2.828-2.833">And they that held Adrasteia and

and Araphius, with corslet of linen, sons <mod n="twain:simpsub">two</mod> of Merops of

<s xml:id="sent2274856" n="2.833-2.834">But the <mod n="twain:simpsub">two</mod> would in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr>
<mod n="hearken:simpsub">listen</mod>, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274857" n="2.834">for the fates of

<s xml:id="sent2274858" n="2.835-2.839"><milestone n="835" unit="line"/>And they that dwelt

<s xml:id="sent2274859" n="2.840-2.841"><milestone n="840" unit="line" />And Hippothous led the tribes of the Pelasgi, that rage with the

<s xml:id="sent2274860" n="2.842-2.843">these were led by Hippothous

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274861" n="2.844-2.845">But the Thracians Acamas led and
Peirous, the warrior, <milestone n="845" unit="line"/>even all them
that the strong stream of the Hellespont <mod n='encloseth'>encloses</mod>.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274862" n="2.846-2.847">And Euphemus was captain of the
Ciconian spearmen, the son of Ceas' son Troezenus, nurtured of

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274863" n="2.848-2.850">But Pyraechmes led the
Paeonians, with curved bows, from afar, out of Amydon from the

<sic>whereof</sic> <mod n='floweth'>flows</mod> the fairest over the face of the earth.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274864" n="2.851-2.855">And the Paphlagonians did

<milestone n="855" unit="line"/>and Cromna and Aegialus and
lofty Erythini.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274865" n="2.856-2.857">But of the Halizones Odius and

</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:2.858-2.877">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274866" n="2.858">And of the Mysians the captains were

<s xml:id="sent2274867" n="2.859-2.861"><mod n="howbeit:simpsub">however</mod> with his auguries he warded not off black

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274868" n="2.862-2.863">And Phorcys and godlike Ascanius
led the Phrygians from afar, from Ascania, </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274869" n="2.863">and were eager to fight in the press
of battle.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274870" n="2.864-2.866">And the Maeonians had captains
<mod n="twain:simpsub">two</mod>, Mesthles and Antiphus, <milestone n="865" unit="line"/>the

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274871" n="2.867-2.869">And Nastes again led the

<s xml:id="sent2274872" n="2.870-2.875"><milestone n="870" unit="line"/>These were led by

glorious children of Nomion. And he<note resp="Loeb" anchored="true" >1</note> came to the war all decked with gold, like a girl,
fool that he was; but his gold in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> availed to ward off woeful
destruction; <sic>nay</sic>, he was slain in the river beneath the hands of the
son of Aeacus, swift of foot; <milestone n="875" unit="line"/>and

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274873" n="2.876-2.877">And Sarpedon and peerless
Glaucus were captains of the Lycians from afar out of Lycia, from

<div type="textpart" subtype="book" n="3">
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:3.1-3.37">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274874" n="3.1-3.3"><milestone n="1" unit="line"/>Now
when they were marshalled, the several companies with their
captains, the Trojans came on with clamour and with a cry like
birds, even as the clamour of cranes <mod n='ariseth'>arises</mod> before the face of
heaven, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274875" n="3.4-3.6">when they flee from
wintry storms and measureless rain, <milestone n="5" unit="line" />and with clamour fly toward the streams of Ocean, bearing
slaughter and death to Pigmy men, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274876" n="3.7">and in the early dawn they offer evil battle. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274877" n="3.8-3.9">But the Achaeans came on in
silence, breathing fury, eager at heart to bear aid each man to his
fellow. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274878" n="3.10-3.12"><milestone n="10" unit="line"/>Even as when the South Wind <mod n='sheddeth'>sheds</mod> a mist over
the peaks of a mountain, a mist that the shepherd <mod n='loveth'>loves</mod> not, but
that to the robber is better than night, and a man can see only so
far as he <mod n='casteth'>casts</mod> a stone; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274879" n="3.13-3.14" >even in such wise rose the dense dust-cloud from beneath their feet
as they went; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274880" n="3.14">and full swiftly
did they speed across the plain. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274881" n="3.15-3.18"><milestone n="15" unit="line"/>Now when they were come
near, as they advanced one host against the other, among the Trojans
there stood forth as champion godlike Alexander, bearing upon his
shoulders a panther skin and his curved bow, and his sword; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274882" n="3.18-3.20">and brandishing two spears tipped
with bronze he challenged all the best of Argives <milestone n="20" unit="line"/>to fight with him face to face in <sic>dread</sic>
combat.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274883" n="3.21-3.25">But when Menelaus, dear to Ares,
was <mod n="ware:simpsub">aware</mod> of him as he came forth before the throng with long
strides, then even as a lion is glad when he <mod n='lighteth'>lights</mod> on a great
carcase, having found a horned stag or a wild goat <milestone n="25" unit="line"/>when he is hungry; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274884" n="3.25-3.26">for greedily <mod n="doth:simpsub">does</mod> he devour it, even though swift dogs
and lusty youths set upon him: </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274885" n="3.27-3.28">even so was Menelaus glad when his eyes beheld godlike
Alexander; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274886" n="3.28">for he thought that
he had gotten him vengeance<note resp="Loeb" anchored="true" >1</note> on the sinner. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274887" n="3.29" >And <sic>forthwith</sic> he leapt in his armour from his chariot to the
ground. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274888" n="3.30-3.32"><milestone n="30" unit="line"/>But when godlike Alexander was <mod n="ware:simpsub">aware</mod> of him as he
appeared among the champions, his heart was <mod n="smitten:simpsub">struck</mod>, and back he
shrank into the throng of his comrades, avoiding fate. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274889" n="3.33-3.37">And even as a man at sight of a
snake in the glades of a mountain <mod n='starteth'>starts</mod> back, and trembling
<mod n='seizeth'>seizes</mod> his limbs beneath him, <milestone n="35" unit="line"/>and he
<mod n='withdraweth'>withdraws</mod> back again and pallor <mod n='layeth'>lays</mod> hold of his cheeks; even so
did godlike Alexander, seized with fear of Atreus' son, shrink back
into the throng of the lordly Trojans. </s></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:3.38-3.75">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274890" n="3.38">But Hector saw him, and chid him with
words of shame: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2274891" n="3.39-3.40">Evil Paris, most fair to look
upon, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> that art mad after women, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> beguiler, <milestone n="40" unit="line"/>would that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hadst:simpsub">had</mod> ne'er been
born<note resp="Loeb" anchored="true">2</note> and <mod n="hadst:simpsub">had</mod>
died unwed. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274892" n="3.41-3.42">Aye, of
that were I fain, and it had been better far than that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod>
<mod n='shouldest'>should</mod> thus be a reproach, and that men should look upon <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>
in scorn. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274893" n="3.43-3.45"><mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod>,
methinks, will the long-haired Achaeans laugh aloud, deeming
that a prince is our champion because a comely <milestone n="45" unit="line"/>form is his, while there is no strength in his
heart nor any valour. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274894" n="3.46-3.51" >Was it in such strength as this that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> sail over the
main in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> seafaring ships, when <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hadst:simpsub">had</mod> gathered <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> trusty
comrades, and, coming to an alien <mod n="folk:simpsub">people</mod>, <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> bring back a
comely woman from a distant land, even a daughter of<note resp="Loeb" anchored="true">1</note> warriors who wield the
spear, <milestone n="50" unit="line"/>but to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> father and city
and all the people a grievous bane—to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> foes a joy, but to
<mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> own self a hanging down of the head? </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274895" n="3.52">Wilt <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> indeed not <mod n="abide:simpsub">remain</mod>
Menelaus, dear to Ares? </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274896" n="3.53" >Thou <mod n='wouldest'>would</mod> learn what manner of warrior he is whose lovely
wife <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod>. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274897" n="3.54-3.55">Then
will <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> lyre help <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> not, neither the gifts of Aphrodite,
<milestone n="55" unit="line"/><mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> locks and <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> comeliness,
when <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> lie low in the dust. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274898" n="3.56"><sic>Nay</sic>, <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod>, the Trojans are utter cowards: </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274899" n="3.56-3.57">else <mod n='wouldest'>would</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="ere:simpsub">before</mod> this
have donned a coat of stone<note resp="Loeb" anchored="true" >2</note> by reason of all the evil <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> <sic>wrought</sic>.
</s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274900" n="3.58">And to him did godlike Alexander make
answer, saying: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2274901" n="3.59">Hector, seeing that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> chide
me duly, and not beyond what is due— </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274902" n="3.60-3.62"><milestone n="60" unit="line"/>ever is <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> heart
unyielding, even as an axe that is driven through a beam by the
hand of man that skilfully <mod n='shapeth'>shapes</mod> a ship's timber, and it
<mod n='maketh'>makes</mod> the force of his blow to wax; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274903" n="3.63">even so is the heart in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> breast undaunted— </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274904" n="3.64">cast not in my teeth the lovely
gifts of golden Aphrodite. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274905" n="3.65-3.66"><milestone n="65" unit="line"/>Not to be flung
aside, look you, are the glorious gifts of the gods, even all
that of themselves they give, whereas by his own will could no

<s xml:id="sent2274906" n="3.67-3.70">But now,
if <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wilt:simpsub">will</mod> have me war and do battle, make the other Trojans
to sit down and all the Achaeans, but set <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> me in the midst and
Menelaus, dear to Ares, <milestone n="70" unit="line"/>to do

<s xml:id="sent2274907" n="3.71-3.72">And whichsoever of us <mod n="twain:simpsub">two</mod>
shall win, and prove him the better man, let him duly take all
the wealth and the woman, and bear them to his home. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2274908" n="3.73-3.75">But for you others, do <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod>
swear friendship and oaths of faith with sacrifice. So should <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod>
dwell in deep-soiled Troyland, and let them return <milestone n="75" unit="line"/>to Argos, pasture-land of horses, and to
Achaea, the land of fair women. </s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:3.76-3.110">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2274909" n="3.76-3.78">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he, and Hector rejoiced
greatly when he heard his words; and he went into the midst, and
kept back the battalions of the Trojans with his spear grasped by
the middle; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274910" n="3.78">and they all <sic>sate</sic>
them down. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274911" n="3.79-3.80">But the
long-haired Achaeans sought the while to aim their arrows at him,
<milestone n="80" unit="line"/> and to <mod n="smite:simpsub">strike</mod> him, and to cast at
him with stones. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2274912" n="3.81">But aloud
shouted Agamemnon, king of men: </s><q>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:3.264-3.301">

Menelaus, dear to Ares; do <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> therefore give up Argive Helen and

<mod n='beseemeth'>suits</mod>, <milestone n="460" unit="line"/>even such as shall
<mod n="abide:simpsub">remain</mod> in the minds of men that are yet to be. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2275122" n="3.461">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> the son of Atreus, and all
the Achaeans shouted assent.</s></p>

<s xml:id="sent2275123" n="4.1-4.3"><milestone n="1" unit="line"/>Now

<s xml:id="sent2275125" n="4.5-4.6"><milestone n="5" unit="line"/>And <sic>forthwith</sic> the son of Cronos made <sic>essay</sic> to

<s xml:id="sent2275126" n="4.7-4.8">Twain of the goddesses <mod n="hath:simpsub">has</mod>

<s xml:id="sent2275127" n="4.9-4.10"><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod> these <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> sit apart

<s xml:id="sent2275141" n="4.30"><milestone n="30" unit="line"/>Then,

<s xml:id="sent2275165" n="4.73-4.74">So saying, he stirred on Athene

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:4.127-4.182">

<s xml:id="sent2275193" n="4.127-4.129">Then, O Menelaus, the blessed

<s xml:id="sent2275208" n="4.155-4.157"><milestone n="155" unit="line"/>Dear brother, it was for <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> death,

<s xml:id="sent2275218" n="4.174-4.175" >And <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> bones shall the earth rot <milestone n="175" unit="line"/>as <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='liest'>lie</mod> in the land of Troy with <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod>

<s xml:id="sent2275219" n="4.176-4.177" >and thus shall many a one of the overweening Trojans say,

<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2275220" n="4.178-4.181">Would that in every
matter it may be thus that Agamemnon may fulfill his
wrath, even as now he led <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod> a host of the Achaeans
to no purpose, and <sic>lo</sic>! <milestone n="180" unit="line" />he <mod n="hath:simpsub">has</mod> departed home to his dear native land with
empty ships, and <mod n="hath:simpsub">has</mod> left here noble Menelaus.
</s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2275221" n="4.182">So shall some man speak in
aftertime; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2275222" n="4.182">in that day
let the wide earth gape for me. </s></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:4.183-4.222">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2275223" n="4.183">But fair-haired Menelaus <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> and
heartened him, saying: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2275224" n="4.184">Be <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> of good cheer, neither
affright in any wise the host of the Achaeans. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2275225" n="4.185-4.187"><milestone n="185" unit="line"/>Not in a fatal spot <mod n="hath:simpsub">has</mod> the shaft been fixed;
<mod n="ere:simpsub">before</mod> that my flashing belt stayed it, and the kilt beneath, and
the taslet that the coppersmiths fashioned. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2275226" n="4.188">Then in answer to him <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> lord
Agamemnon: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2275227" n="4.189">Would it may be so, dear Menelaus.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2275228" n="4.190-4.191"><milestone n="190" unit="line"/>But the leech shall search the wound and lay
thereon simples that shall make <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> cease from dark pains.
</s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2275229" n="4.192">Therewith he <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> to Talthybius, the
godlike herald: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2275230" n="4.193-4.197">Talthybius, make haste to
call <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod> Machaon, son of Asclepius, the peerless leech,
<milestone n="195" unit="line"/>to see warlike Menelaus, son
of Atreus, whom some man well skilled in archery <mod n="hath:simpsub">has</mod> <mod n="smitten:simpsub">struck</mod>
with an arrow, some Trojan or Lycian, compassing glory for
himself but for us sorrow. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2275231" n="4.198-4.200">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he, and the herald

host of the brazen-coated Achaeans, <milestone n="200" unit="line" />glancing this way and that for the warrior Machaon; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2275232" n="4.200-4.201">and he marked him as he stood,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2275233" n="4.201-4.202">and round about him were

<mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> winged words, saying: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2275234" n="4.203">Rouse <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, son of Asclepius;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2275235" n="4.204-4.207">lord Agamemnon
<mod n='calleth'>calls</mod> <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> <milestone n="205" unit="line"/>to see warlike

in archery, <mod n="hath:simpsub">has</mod> <mod n="smitten:simpsub">struck</mod> with an arrow, some Trojan or Lycian,

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2275236" n="4.208">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he, and roused the heart in

<s xml:id="sent2275237" n="4.209">and they went

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2275238" n="4.210-4.213"><milestone n="210" unit="line"/>And when they were come where was fair-haired

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2275239" n="4.214">and as it was drawn forth the

<s xml:id="sent2275240" n="4.215-4.216">And he loosed the flashing belt and the kilt beneath

<s xml:id="sent2275241" n="4.217-4.219">But when he saw the wound where

<s xml:id="sent2275242" n="4.220-4.221"><milestone n="220" unit="line"/>While they were thus

<s xml:id="sent2275243" n="4.222">and the Achaeans again did on their battle-gear, and

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:4.223-4.264">

<s xml:id="sent2275244" n="4.223-4.225">Then wouldst <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> not have seen

<s xml:id="sent2275254" n="4.243-4.245">Why is it that <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> stand thus dazed, like fawns

<s xml:id="sent2275257" n="4.250"><milestone n="250" unit="line"/>Thus

<s xml:id="sent2275261" n="4.255-4.256"><milestone n="255" unit="line" />At sight of them Agamemnon, king of men, <mod n="waxed:simpsub">became</mod> glad, and <sic>forthwith</sic>

<s xml:id="sent2275262" n="4.257-4.260">Idomeneus, beyond all the

<s xml:id="sent2275272" n="4.275-4.276"><milestone n="275" unit="line" />Even as when from some place of outlook a goatherd <mod n='seeth'>sees</mod> a cloud

<s xml:id="sent2275276" n="4.285-4.286"><milestone n="285" unit="line"/><mod n="Ye:simpsub">You</mod> Aiantes, leaders of the brazen-coated

<s xml:id="sent2275321" n="4.356-4.357">Then lord Agamemnon <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> to him

<s xml:id="sent2275322" n="4.357">and took back his words: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2275323" n="4.358-4.359">Zeus-born son of Laertes,

<s xml:id="sent2275324" n="4.360-4.361" ><milestone n="360" unit="line"/>for I know that the heart

<s xml:id="sent2275325" n="4.361">seeing <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> minded even as I

<s xml:id="sent2275326" n="4.362-4.363"><sic>Nay</sic>, come, these

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2275327" n="4.364">So saying he left them there and went

<s xml:id="sent2275328" n="4.365-4.366"><milestone n="365" unit="line"/>Then found he the son of Tydeus, Diomedes

<s xml:id="sent2275329" n="4.367">and by his side stood Sthenelus, son

<s xml:id="sent2275330" n="4.368-4.369">At sight of

<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2275331" n="4.370-4.371"><milestone n="370" unit="line"/>Ah me, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> son of wise-hearted Tydeus, tamer

<s xml:id="sent2275332" n="4.372-4.374">Tydeus <corr n="of a surety">surely</corr> was

<s xml:id="sent2275333" n="4.374-4.375">for I never

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2275334" n="4.375">but men say that he was

<s xml:id="sent2275335" n="4.376-4.377">Once <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> he came to Mycenae, not as an enemy,

<s xml:id="sent2275336" n="4.378-4.379">for in that

<s xml:id="sent2275337" n="4.380"><milestone n="380" unit="line"/>and the men of Mycenae were minded to

<s xml:id="sent2275339" n="4.382-4.384">So when they had departed and were got forth

<s xml:id="sent2275340" n="4.385-4.386" ><milestone n="385" unit="line"/>And he went his way, and

<s xml:id="sent2275341" n="4.387-4.390">Then, for

<s xml:id="sent2275343" n="4.391-4.393">But the Cadmeians,

<s xml:id="sent2275348" n="4.399">Such a man was Tydeus of Aetolia;

<s xml:id="sent2275349" n="4.399-4.400"><mod n="howbeit:simpsub">however</mod> the son

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:4.401-4.445">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2275350" n="4.401-4.402">So he <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod>, and stalwart

<s xml:id="sent2275351" n="4.403">But the son

<s xml:id="sent2275352" n="4.404">Son of Atreus, utter not lies,

<s xml:id="sent2275353" n="4.405"><milestone n="405" unit="line" />We declare ourselves to be better men by far than our fathers:
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2275354" n="4.406-4.408">we took the seat of

<s xml:id="sent2275356" n="4.410"><milestone n="410" unit="line"/><mod n="Wherefore:simpsub">For which reason</mod> I <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> put not our fathers in

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2275357" n="4.411">Then with an angry glance from beneath

<s xml:id="sent2275359" n="4.413-4.414" >I count it not shame that Agamemnon, shepherd of the host,

<s xml:id="sent2275361" n="4.418"><sic>Nay</sic>, come, let us <mod n="twain:simpsub">two</mod>

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2275362" n="4.419">He <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod>, and leapt in his armour from
his chariot to the ground, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2275363" n="4.420-4.421"><milestone n="420" unit="line"/>and terribly rang

<s xml:id="sent2275364" n="4.421"><sic>thereat</sic> might terror have seized even

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2275365" n="4.422-4.423">As when on a sounding beach the

<s xml:id="sent2275366" n="4.424-4.426">out on the

<mod n='thundereth'>thunders</mod> aloud, and round about the headlands it <mod n='swelleth'>swells</mod> and
<mod n='reareth'>rears</mod> its head, and <mod n='speweth'>spews</mod> forth the salt brine: </s>


<s xml:id="sent2275367" n="4.427-4.428">even in such wise on that day

<s xml:id="sent2275368" n="4.428-4.429">and

<s xml:id="sent2275369" n="4.429-4.431">and the rest marched on in silence; <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> wouldst not

<s xml:id="sent2275371" n="4.433-4.436">But for the Trojans, even as ewes stand in throngs

<s xml:id="sent2275372" n="4.437-4.438">even so arose the clamour of

<s xml:id="sent2275373" n="4.439-4.443">These were urged on by Ares, and the Greeks by

<s xml:id="sent2275374" n="4.444-4.445">She it was that

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:4.446-4.487">

<s xml:id="sent2275375" n="4.446-4.448">Now when they were met together

<s xml:id="sent2275376" n="4.448-4.449">and the bossed shields closed

<s xml:id="sent2275377" n="4.450-4.451"><milestone n="450" unit="line"/>Then were heard

<s xml:id="sent2275378" n="4.452-4.455">As when winter torrents,

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2275380" n="4.457-4.458">Antilochus was first to <mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod> a
