<s xml:id="sent2275382" n="4.461-4.462">and darkness enfolded his eyes, and he crashed as

<s xml:id="sent2275383" n="4.463-4.466">As he fell lord Elephenor caught him by the feet,

<s xml:id="sent2275385" n="4.467-4.469">for

<s xml:id="sent2275386" n="4.470-4.471" ><milestone n="470" unit="line"/>So his spirit left him, and

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2275388" n="4.473-4.476">Then Telamonian Aias <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod>

<s xml:id="sent2275391" n="4.480-4.481" ><milestone n="480" unit="line"/>For, as he strode <mod n="amid:simpsub">among</mod> the

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2275392" n="4.481-4.482">and clean through his

<s xml:id="sent2275393" n="4.482-4.484">and he fell to the ground in the dust like a poplar

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:4.488-4.516">

<s xml:id="sent2275396" n="4.488-4.489">Even in such wise did Zeus-born

<s xml:id="sent2275400" n="4.494-4.497" >For his slaying <mod n="waxed:simpsub">became</mod> Odysseus mightily <mod n="wroth:simpsub">angry</mod> at heart, <milestone n="495" unit="line"/>and strode <mod n="amid:simpsub">among</mod> the foremost warriors,

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:4.517-4.544">

<s xml:id="sent2275413" n="4.517">Then was Amarynceus' son, Diores,

<s xml:id="sent2275425" n="4.536-4.538" >Thus the <mod n="twain:simpsub">two</mod> lay stretched in the dust each by the other,

<s xml:id="sent2275427" n="4.539-4.542">Then could no man any more enter

<s xml:id="sent2275428" n="4.543-4.544">for multitudes of

<div type="textpart" subtype="book" n="5">
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:5.1-5.42">

<s xml:id="sent2275429" n="5.1-5.3"><milestone n="1" unit="line"/>And

<s xml:id="sent2275430" n="5.4-5.6">She

above all others when he <mod n="hath:simpsub">has</mod> bathed him in the stream of Ocean.
</s>

<s xml:id="sent2275432" n="5.9-5.10">Now there was <mod n="amid:simpsub">among</mod> the Trojans one

<s xml:id="sent2275522" n="5.180-5.183"><milestone n="180" unit="line"/>Aeneas, counsellor of the brazen-coated

<s xml:id="sent2275834" n="5.764">Then in answer <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> to her Zeus, the
cloud-gatherer: </s></p>
<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2275835" n="5.765-5.766"><milestone n="765" unit="line"/><sic>Nay</sic>, come now, rouse against him Athene, driver
of the spoil, who has ever been <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> above others to bring <sic>sore</sic>
pain upon him. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2275836" n="5.767-5.768">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he, and the goddess,
white-armed Hera, failed not to <mod n="hearken:simpsub">listen</mod>, but touched her horses with
the the lash; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2275837" n="5.768-5.769">and
nothing loath the pair flew on between earth and starry heaven.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2275838" n="5.770-5.772"><milestone n="770" unit="line"/>As far as a man <mod n='seeth'>sees</mod> with his eyes into the haze
of distance as he <mod n='sitteth'>sits</mod> on a place of outlook and <mod n='gazeth'>gazes</mod> over the
wine-dark deep, even so far do the loud-neighing horses of the gods
spring at a bound. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2275839" n="5.773-5.776">But
when they were come to the land of Troy and the two flowing rivers,
where the Simoïs and Scamander join their streams, <milestone n="775" unit="line"/>there the goddess, white-armed Hera, stayed
her horses, and loosed them from the <mod n="car:simpsub">chariot</mod>, and shed thick mist about
them; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2275840" n="5.777">and Simoïs made ambrosia
to spring up for them to graze upon.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2275841" n="5.778-5.779">Then the goddesses <mod n="twain:simpsub">two</mod> went
their way with steps like those of timorous doves, eager to bring
aid to the Argive warriors. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2275842" n="5.780-5.786"><milestone n="780" unit="line"/>And when they were
come where the most and the bravest stood close thronging about
mighty Diomedes, tamer of horses, in semblance like ravening lions
or wild boars, whose is no weakling strength, there the goddess,
white-armed Hera, <milestone n="785" unit="line"/>stood and shouted
in the likeness of great-hearted Stentor of the brazen voice, whose
voice is as the voice of fifty other men: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2275843" n="5.787">Fie, <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> Argives, base things of
shame fair in semblance only! </s>



<s xml:id="sent2275844" n="5.788-5.790">So long as <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Achilles was <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to fare into
battle, never would the Trojans come forth even before the
Dardanian gate; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2275845" n="5.790"><milestone n="790" unit="line"/>for of his mighty spear had they <sic>dread</sic>;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2275846" n="5.791">but now far from the city
they are fighting at the hollow ships. </s></q></p>

<s xml:id="sent2275847" n="5.792">So saying she roused the strength and
spirit of every man. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2275848" n="5.793">And to
the side of Tydeus' son sprang the goddess, flashing-eyed Athene.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2275849" n="5.794-5.795">She found that prince
beside his horses and <mod n="car:simpsub">chariot</mod>, <milestone n="795" unit="line"/>cooling
the wound that Pandarus had dealt him with his arrow. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2275850" n="5.796-5.797">For the sweat vexed him beneath
the broad baldric of his round shield; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2275851" n="5.797-5.798">therewith was he vexed and his arm grew weary, so he
was lifting up the baldric and wiping away the dark blood. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2275852" n="5.799">Then the goddess laid hold of the
yoke of his horses, and said: </s></p>
<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2275853" n="5.800"><milestone n="800" unit="line" /><mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod> little like himself was the son that Tydeus begat.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2275854" n="5.801">Tydeus was small in
stature, but a warrior. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2275855" n="5.802-5.804">Even when I would not suffer him to fight or

Cadmeians— </s>



<s xml:id="sent2275856" n="5.805"><milestone n="805" unit="line"/>I <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> him feast in their halls in

<s xml:id="sent2275857" n="5.806-5.808">yet he having

<s xml:id="sent2275858" n="5.808">so present a helper was I to him.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2275859" n="5.809-5.810">But as for <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, I
<mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> stand by <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> side and guard <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, <milestone n="810" unit="line"/>and of a ready heart I <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> fight with the

<s xml:id="sent2275860" n="5.811-5.812">yet either
<mod n="hath:simpsub">has</mod> weariness born of <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> many onsets entered into <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> limbs,
or <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> spiritless terror <mod n='possesseth'>possesses</mod> <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2275861" n="5.812-5.813">Then <corr n="art thou">are you</corr> no offspring
of Tydeus, the wise-hearted son of Oeneus. </s></q></p>

<s xml:id="sent2275862" n="5.814">Then in answer to her <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> mighty

<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2275863" n="5.815"><milestone n="815" unit="line"/>I

<s xml:id="sent2275865" n="5.817-5.818">In <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> <mod n="doth:simpsub">does</mod> spiritless

<s xml:id="sent2275866" n="5.819-5.820">Thou <mod n='wouldest'>would</mod> not suffer me

<s xml:id="sent2275867" n="5.820-5.821"><milestone n="820" unit="line"/>but if Aphrodite the daughter of Zeus should

<s xml:id="sent2275868" n="5.822-5.823">Therefore it

<s xml:id="sent2275869" n="5.824">for I discern Ares lording it

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2275870" n="5.825"><milestone n="825" unit="line"/>And

<s xml:id="sent2275871" n="5.826-5.828">Son of Tydeus, Diomedes,

<s xml:id="sent2275873" n="5.835-5.836"><milestone n="835" unit="line" />So saying, with her hand she drew back Sthenelus, and thrust him

<s xml:id="sent2275875" n="5.838-5.839">Loudly did the oaken axle creak

<s xml:id="sent2275876" n="5.839">for it

<s xml:id="sent2275877" n="5.840"><milestone n="840" unit="line"/>Then

<s xml:id="sent2275879" n="5.842-5.843">He was stripping of his armour huge Periphas that

<s xml:id="sent2275882" n="5.846-5.849">Now when Ares, the bane of

<s xml:id="sent2275883" n="5.850-5.852"><milestone n="850" unit="line"/>And when they were now come near as they advanced

<s xml:id="sent2275884" n="5.853-5.854">but the

<s xml:id="sent2275885" n="5.855-5.856"><milestone n="855" unit="line" />Next Diomedes, good at the war-cry, <mod n="drave:simpsub">drove</mod> at Ares with his spear

<s xml:id="sent2275886" n="5.856-5.857">and Pallas

<s xml:id="sent2275887" n="5.858-5.859" >There did he thrust and <mod n="smite:simpsub">strike</mod> him, rending the fair flesh, and

<s xml:id="sent2275888" n="5.859-5.861">Then brazen Ares bellowed <milestone n="860" unit="line"/>loud as nine thousand warriors or ten thousand cry

<s xml:id="sent2275889" n="5.862-5.863">and <sic>thereat</sic> trembling came upon

<s xml:id="sent2275891" n="5.864-5.867">Even as a black darkness

<s xml:id="sent2275892" n="5.868-5.871">Speedily

<mod n="shewed:simpsub">showed</mod> the immortal blood flowing from the wound, <milestone n="870" unit="line"/>and with wailing <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> to him winged words: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2275893" n="5.872">Father Zeus, <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> no

<s xml:id="sent2275894" n="5.873-5.874">Ever do we gods continually

<s xml:id="sent2275895" n="5.875"><milestone n="875" unit="line"/>With <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> are we all at strife, </s>


<s xml:id="sent2275896" n="5.875-5.876">for <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> father to that

<s xml:id="sent2275897" n="5.877-5.878">For all

<s xml:id="sent2275898" n="5.879-5.880">but to her <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='payest'>pay</mod> no heed whether in word

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2275899" n="5.881-5.882">Now <mod n="hath:simpsub">has</mod> she set on

<s xml:id="sent2275900" n="5.883-5.884" >Cypris first he wounded with a thrust in close fight upon the

<s xml:id="sent2275901" n="5.885" ><milestone n="885" unit="line"/><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod> my swift feet bare

<s xml:id="sent2275902" n="5.885-5.887">otherwise had I long suffered woes there <mod n="amid:simpsub">among</mod>

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2275903" n="5.888">Then with an angry glance from beneath
his brows <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> to him Zeus, the cloud-gatherer: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2275904" n="5.889">Sit <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> not in any wise by me and

<s xml:id="sent2275905" n="5.890" ><milestone n="890" unit="line"/>Most hateful to me <corr n="art thou">are you</corr>

<s xml:id="sent2275906" n="5.891">for ever is strife dear to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> and wars and

<s xml:id="sent2275907" n="5.892-5.893">Thou <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod>

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2275909" n="5.894"><mod n="Wherefore:simpsub">For which reason</mod> it

<s xml:id="sent2275915" n="5.901">for <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> he

<s xml:id="sent2275917" n="5.905"><milestone n="905" unit="line"/>And

<s xml:id="sent2275918" n="5.906">and he <corr n="sate him">sat</corr> down by the side of

<s xml:id="sent2275919" n="5.907-5.909">Then back to the palace of great

<div type="textpart" subtype="book" n="6">
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:6.1-6.36">
<p>
<milestone n="1" unit="line"/>




<s xml:id="sent2275920" n="6.1">So was the <sic>dread</sic> strife of the Trojans
and Achaeans left to itself, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2275921" n="6.2-6.4" >and oft to this side and to that surged the battle over the plain,
as they aimed one at the other their bronze-tipped spears between
the Simoïs and the streams of Xanthus. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2275922" n="6.5-6.8"><milestone n="5" unit="line"/>Aias, son of Telamon,
bulwark of the Achaeans was first to break a battalion of the
Trojans, and to bring a light of deliverance to his comrades, for he
<mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> a man that was chiefest among the Thracians, even Eüssorus'
son Acamas, a valiant man and tall. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2275923" n="6.9-6.11">Him he was first to <mod n="smite:simpsub">strike</mod> upon the horn of his helmet
with thick crest of horse-hair, <milestone n="10" unit="line"/>and
<mod n="drave:simpsub">drove</mod> the spear into his forehead so that the point of bronze
pierced within the bone; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2275924" n="6.11">and
darkness enfolded his eyes.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2275925" n="6.12-6.14">And Diomedes, good at the war-cry,
<mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> Axylus, Teuthras' son, that dwelt in well-built Arisbe, a man
rich in substance, that was beloved of all men; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2275926" n="6.15"><milestone n="15" unit="line"/>for he
dwelt in a home by the high-road and was <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to give entertainment
to all. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2275927" n="6.16-6.19"><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod> of all
these was there not one on this day to meet the foe before his face,
and ward from him woeful destruction; but Diomedes robbed the <mod n="twain:simpsub">two</mod>
of life, himself and his squire Calesius, that was then the driver
of his <mod n="car:simpsub">chariot</mod>; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2275928" n="6.19">so they two passed
beneath the earth. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2275929" n="6.20"><milestone n="20" unit="line"/>Then Euryalus <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> Dresus and Opheltius,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2275930" n="6.21-6.22">and went on after Aesepus
and Pedasus, whom on a time the fountain-nymph Abarbarea bare to
peerless Bucolion. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2275931" n="6.23-6.24">Now
Bucolion was son of lordly Laomedon, his eldest born, though the
mother that bare him was unwed; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2275932" n="6.25-6.26"><milestone n="25" unit="line"/>he while shepherding
his flocks lay with the nymph in love, and she conceived and bare
twin sons. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2275933" n="6.27-6.28">Of these did
the son of Mecisteus loose the might and the glorious limbs and
strip the armour from their shoulders.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2275934" n="6.29">And Polypoetes staunch in fight <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod>
Astyalus, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2275935" n="6.30-6.31"><milestone n="30" unit="line"/>and Odysseus with his spear of bronze laid

<s xml:id="sent2275936" n="6.32-6.33">And Antilochus, son of Nestor,

<s xml:id="sent2276056" n="6.261-6.262">When a man is spent with toil wine greatly

ground he seized with stout hand a stone <milestone n="265" unit="line"/>that lay upon the plain, black and jagged and
great; </s>

boss; </s>

<s xml:id="sent2276335" n="7.273-7.276">And now had they

<s xml:id="sent2276438" n="7.448-7.450"><mod n='Seest'>See</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> not that now

defend their ships, and about it have drawn a trench, <milestone n="450" unit="line"/>but gave not glorious hecatombs to the
gods? </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276439" n="7.451">Of a surety shall
the fame <sic>thereof</sic> reach as far as the dawn <mod n='spreadeth'>spreads</mod>, </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276440" n="7.452-7.453">and men will forget the
wall that I and Phoebus Apollo built with toil for the warrior
Laomedon. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2276441" n="7.454">Then greatly troubled, Zeus, the
cloud-gatherer, <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> to him: </s></p>
<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2276442" n="7.455"><milestone n="455" unit="line"/>Ah
me, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> Shaker of Earth, wide of sway, what a thing <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod>
said! </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276443" n="7.456-7.457">Another of the
gods might <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> fear this device, whoso was feebler far than
<mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> in hand and might; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276444" n="7.458" >whereas <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> fame shall <corr n="of a surety">surely</corr> reach as far as the dawn
<mod n='spreadeth'>spreads</mod>. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276445" n="7.459-7.463">Go to
now, when once the long-haired Achaeans have gone with their
ships to their dear native land, <milestone n="460" unit="line" />then do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> burst apart the wall and sweep it all into the
sea, and cover the great beach again with sand, that so the
great wall of the Achaeans may be brought to <mod n="naught:simpsub">nothing</mod> of <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>.
</s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2276446" n="7.464-7.466">On <corr n="this wise">this way</corr> <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> they, one to
the other, <milestone n="465" unit="line"/>and the sun set, and the
work of the Achaeans was accomplished; and they slaughtered oxen
throughout the huts and took supper. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276447" n="7.467-7.469">And ships full many were at hand from Lemnos,
bearing wine, sent forth by Jason's son, Euneus, whom Hypsipyle bare
to Jason, shepherd of the host. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276448" n="7.470-7.471"><milestone n="470" unit="line"/>And for themselves
alone <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod> the sons of Atreus, Agamemnon and Menelaus, had Euneus
given wine to be brought them, even a thousand measures. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276449" n="7.472-7.475">From these ships the
long-haired Achaeans bought them wine, some for bronze, some for

<s xml:id="sent2276450" n="7.475">and they made them a rich feast.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2276451" n="7.476-7.477">So the whole night
through the long-haired Achaeans feasted, and the Trojans likewise
in the city, and their allies; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276452" n="7.478-7.479">and all night long Zeus, the counsellor, devised
them evil, thundering in terrible wise. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276453" n="7.479">Then pale fear <mod n="gat:simpsub">got</mod> hold of them, </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276454" n="7.480-7.481"><milestone n="480" unit="line" />and they let the wine flow from their cups upon the ground,

the son of Cronos, supreme in might. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276455" n="7.482">Then they laid them down, and took the gift of
sleep.</s></p>

<s xml:id="sent2276456" n="8.1-8.3"><milestone n="1" unit="line"/>Now

<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2276458" n="8.5-8.6"><milestone n="5" unit="line" /><mod n="Hearken:simpsub">Listen</mod> <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod> me, all <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> gods and goddesses, that I may speak

<s xml:id="sent2276463" n="8.18"><sic>Nay</sic>, come, make

<s xml:id="sent2276542" n="8.151">And in answer to him <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> the
horseman, Nestor of Gerenia: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2276543" n="8.152">Ah me, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> son of wise-hearted
Tydeus, what a thing <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> said! </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276544" n="8.153-8.156">For though Hector shall call <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> coward and
weakling, yet will not the Trojans or the Dardanians <mod n="hearken:simpsub">listen</mod> to
him, <milestone n="155" unit="line"/>nor the wives of the
great-souled Trojans, bearers of the shield, they whose lusty
husbands <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> hurled in the dust. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2276545" n="8.157-8.158">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he, and turned in
flight his single-hooved horses, back through the tumult; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276546" n="8.158-8.159">and the Trojans and Hector with
wondrous shouting poured forth upon them their missiles fraught with
groanings. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276547" n="8.160"><milestone n="160" unit="line"/>Over him then shouted aloud great Hector of the
flashing helm: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2276548" n="8.161-8.162">Son of Tydeus, above all
others were the Danaans with swift steeds <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to honour <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>
with a seat of honour and meats and full cups, </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276549" n="8.163">but now will they scorn <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2276550" n="8.163"><corr n="thou art">you are</corr>, it <mod n='appeareth'>appears</mod>, no
better than a woman. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276551" n="8.164-8.166" >Begone, cowardly puppet; since through no flinching of mine
<milestone n="165" unit="line"/><mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> mount upon our
walls, and carry away our women in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> ships; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276552" n="8.166"><mod n="ere:simpsub">before</mod> that will I deal <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod>
doom. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2276553" n="8.167-8.168">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he, and the son of
Tydeus was divided in counsel whether he should not wheel his horses
and fight him face to face. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276554" n="8.169-8.171"><mod n="Thrice:simpsub">Three times</mod> he wavered in heart and soul <milestone n="170" unit="line"/>and <mod n="thrice:simpsub">three times</mod> from the mountains of Ida Zeus
the counsellor thundered, giving to the Trojans a sign and victory
to turn the tide of battle. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276555" n="8.172" >And Hector shouted aloud and called to the Trojans: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2276556" n="8.173-8.174"><mod n="Ye:simpsub">You</mod> Trojans and Lycians and
Dardanians, that fight in close combat, be men, my friends, and
<sic>bethink</sic> you of furious valour. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276557" n="8.175-8.176"><milestone n="175" unit="line"/>I perceive that
of a ready heart the son of Cronos <mod n="hath:simpsub">has</mod> given <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod> me victory
and great glory, and to the Danaans woe. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276558" n="8.177-8.178">Fools they are, that
contrived <sic>forsooth</sic> these walls, weak and of none account; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276559" n="8.178">these shall not withhold our
might, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276560" n="8.179">and our horses
shall lightly leap over the digged ditch. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276561" n="8.180-8.183"><milestone n="180" unit="line"/>But when I be at length come <mod n="amid:simpsub">among</mod> the hollow
ships, then see <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> that consuming fire be not forgotten, that
with fire I may burn the ships and furthermore <mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod> the men,
even the Argives beside their ships, distraught by reason of the
smoke. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2276562" n="8.184">So saying he shouted to his horses,
and said: </s><q>
<milestone xml:id="sent2276563" n="185" unit="line"/>


<s n="8.185-8.190">Xanthus, and <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> Podargus, and Aethon, and
<mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Lampus, now pay me back your tending wherewith in
abundance Andromache, daughter of great-hearted Eëtion, set
before you honey-hearted wheat, and mingled wine for you to
drink when your souls <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> you, <milestone n="190" unit="line" />sooner than for me, that avow me to be her stalwart husband.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2276564" n="8.191-8.195"><sic>Nay</sic>, haste <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> in
pursuit, that we may take the shield of Nestor, the fame <sic>whereof</sic>
now <mod n='reacheth'>reaches</mod> <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod> heaven, that it is all of gold, the rods alike
and the shield itself; and may take moreover from the shoulders
of horse-taming Diomedes <milestone n="195" unit="line"/>his
breastplate richly-dight, which Hephaestus <sic>wrought</sic> with toil.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2276565" n="8.196-8.197">Could we but take
these <mod n="twain:simpsub">two</mod>, then might I hope to make the Achaeans this very
night embark upon their swift ships. </s></q></p>

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2276566" n="8.198-8.200">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he vauntingly, and
queenly Hera had indignation <sic>thereat</sic>; she shook herself on her
throne and made high Olympus to quake, <milestone n="200" unit="line"/>and to the mighty god Poseidon she <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod>, saying: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2276567" n="8.201-8.202">Ah me, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> Shaker of Earth,
wide of sway, not even <mod n="hath:simpsub">has</mod> the heart in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> breast pity of the
Danaans that are perishing. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276568" n="8.203-8.204">Yet in <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> honour do they bring to Helice and
Aegae offerings many and gracious </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276569" n="8.204">and hitherto <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> wish them victory. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276570" n="8.205-8.207"><milestone n="205" unit="line"/>For did we but will, all we that are aiders of
the Danaans, to drive back the Trojans and to withhold Zeus
whose voice is borne afar, then, in vexation of spirit, would he
sit alone there upon Ida. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2276571" n="8.208">Then, his heart <sic>sore</sic> troubled, the
lord, the Shaker of Earth, <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> to her: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2276572" n="8.209">Hera, reckless in speech, what a
word <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> spoken! </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276573" n="8.210-8.211"><milestone n="210" unit="line"/>It is not I that
were fain to see us all at strife with Zeus, son of Cronos, for
he <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> is mightier far. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2276574" n="8.212">On <corr n="this wise">this way</corr> <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> they, one to the
other; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276575" n="8.213-8.215">and now was all
the space that the moat of the wall enclosed on the side of the
ships filled alike with chariots and shield-bearing men <milestone n="215" unit="line"/>huddled together: </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276576" n="8.215-8.216">and huddled they were by
Hector, Priam's son, the peer of swift Ares, now that Zeus
<mod n="vouchsafed:simpsub">promised</mod> him glory. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276577" n="8.217-8.219" >And now would he have burned the shapely ships with blazing fire,
had not queenly Hera put it in Agamemnon's mind himself to bestir
him, and speedily rouse on the Achaeans. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276578" n="8.220-8.226"><milestone n="220" unit="line"/>So he went his way
along the huts and ships of the Achaeans, bearing his great purple
cloak in his stout hand, and took his stand by Odysseus' black ship,
huge of hull, that was in the midst so that a shout could reach to
either end, both to the huts of Aias, son of Telamon, <milestone n="225" unit="line"/>and to those of Achilles; for these had
drawn up their shapely ships at the furthermost ends, trusting in
their valour and in the strength of their hands. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276579" n="8.227">There uttered he a piercing shout,
calling aloud to the Danaans: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2276580" n="8.228">Fie, <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> Argives, base things of
shame fair in semblance only. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276581" n="8.229-8.234"><mod n="Whither:simpsub">Where</mod> are gone our boastings, when <sic>forsooth</sic> we
declared that we were bravest, the boasts <milestone n="230" unit="line"/> that when <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> were in Lemnos <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> uttered
vaingloriously as <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> ate abundant flesh of straight-horned <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod>
and drank bowls brim full of wine, saying that each man would
stand to face in battle an hundred, aye, two hundred Trojans!
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2276582" n="8.234-8.235">whereas now can we
match not even one, <milestone n="235" unit="line"/>this Hector,
that soon will burn our ships with blazing fire. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276583" n="8.236-8.237">Father Zeus, was there ever
<mod n="ere:simpsub">before</mod> now one among mighty kings whose soul <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> blind with
blindness such as this, and rob him of great glory? </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276584" n="8.238-8.241">Yet <corr n="of a surety">surely</corr> do I <mod n="deem:simpsub">think</mod>
that never in my benched ship did I pass by fair altar of <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod>
on my ill-starred way <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod>, <milestone n="240" unit="line" />but upon all I burned the fat and the thighs of bulls, in my
eagerness to lay waste well-walled Troy. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276585" n="8.242"><sic>Nay</sic>, Zeus, this desire fulfill
<mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> me: </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276586" n="8.243-8.244">ourselves
at least do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> suffer to flee and escape, and permit not the

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:8.245-8.291">

<s xml:id="sent2276587" n="8.245-8.246"><milestone n="245" unit="line" />So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he, and the Father had pity on him as he wept, and
<mod n="vouchsafed:simpsub">promised</mod> him that his <mod n="folk:simpsub">people</mod> should be saved and not perish. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276588" n="8.247-8.248"><sic>Forthwith</sic> he sent an eagle,
surest of omens among winged birds, holding in his talons a fawn,
the young of a swift hind. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276589" n="8.249-8.250">Beside the fair altar of Zeus he let fall the fawn,
<milestone n="250" unit="line"/>even where the Achaeans were
<mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to offer sacrifice to Zeus from whom all omens come. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276590" n="8.251-8.252">So they, when they saw that it
was from Zeus that the bird was come, leapt the more upon the
Trojans and bethought them of battle.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2276591" n="8.253-8.257">Then might no man of the
Danaans, for all they were so many, vaunt that he before the son of
Tydeus guided his swift horses <milestone n="255" unit="line"/>to
drive them forth across the trench and to fight man to man; <sic>nay</sic> he
was first by far to <mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod> a mailed warrior of the Trojans, even
Agelaus, Phradraon's son. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276592" n="8.257">He
in <mod n="sooth:simpsub">truth</mod> had turned his horses to flee, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276593" n="8.258-8.259">but as he wheeled about Diomedes fixed his spear in
his back between the shoulders, and <mod n="drave:simpsub">drove</mod> it through his breast;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2276594" n="8.260"><milestone n="260" unit="line" />so he fell <corr n="from out">out of</corr> the <mod n="car:simpsub">chariot</mod>, and upon him his armour
clanged.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2276595" n="8.261-8.265">And after him came the sons of
Atreus, Agamemnon and Menelaus, and after them the Aiantes, clothed
in furious valour, and after them Idomeneus and Idomeneus' comrade,
Meriones, peer of Enyalius, slayer of men, <milestone n="265" unit="line"/>and after them Eurypylus, the glorious son of
Euaemon; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276596" n="8.266-8.267">and Teucer came
as the ninth, stretching his back-bent bow, and took his stand
beneath the shield of Aias, son of Telamon. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276597" n="8.268">Then would Aias move his shield aside
from over him, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276598" n="8.268-8.272">and the
warrior would spy his chance; and when he had shot his bolt and had
<mod n="smitten:simpsub">struck</mod> one in the throng, <milestone n="270" unit="line"/>then
would that man fall where he was and give up his life, and Teucer
would <sic>hie</sic> him back, and as a child beneath his mother, so betake him
for shelter to Aias; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276599" n="8.272">and Aias
would ever hide him with his shining shield.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2276600" n="8.273">Whom first then of the Trojans did
peerless Teucer <mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod>? </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276601" n="8.274-8.277" >Orsilochus first and Ormenus and Ophelestes and <milestone n="275" unit="line"/>Daetor and Chromius and godlike Lycophontes and
Amopaon, Polyaemon's son, and Melanippus. All these, one after
another, he brought down to the bounteous earth. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276602" n="8.278-8.279">And at sight of him Agamemnon,
king of men, <mod n="waxed:simpsub">became</mod> glad, as with his mighty bow he made havoc of the
battalions of the Trojans; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276603" n="8.280" ><milestone n="280" unit="line"/>and he came and stood by his
side and <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> to him, saying: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2276604" n="8.281-8.284">Teucer, beloved, son of
Telamon, captain of hosts, shoot on in <corr n="this wise">this way</corr>, if so be <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod>
<mod n='mayest'>may</mod> prove a light of deliverance to the Danaans and a glory
to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> father Telamon, who reared <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> when <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wast:simpsub">were</mod> a babe,
and for all <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wast:simpsub">were</mod> a bastard cherished <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> in his own house;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2276605" n="8.285"><milestone n="285" unit="line"/>him, far away though he be, do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> bring to
honour. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276606" n="8.286">Moreover, I will
declare to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> as it <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> shall be brought to pass. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276607" n="8.287-8.291">If Zeus that <mod n='beareth'>bears</mod> the
aegis, and Athene shall <mod n="vouchsafe:simpsub">promise</mod> me to lay waste the well-built
citadel of Ilios, in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> hand first after <corr n="mine own">my own</corr> self will I
place a <sic>meed</sic> of honour, <milestone n="290" unit="line"/>either a
tripod or two horses with their <mod n="car:simpsub">chariot</mod>, or a woman that shall go up

<s xml:id="sent2276608" n="8.292">Then in answer to him <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> peerless
Teucer: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2276609" n="8.293-8.294">Most glorious son of Atreus,
why <mod n='urgest'>urge</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> me on, that of myself am eager? </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276610" n="8.294-8.296"><mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod> I forbear not so far
as might is in me, <milestone n="295" unit="line"/>but from the
time when we <mod n="drave:simpsub">drove</mod> them toward Ilios, even from that moment I
lie in wait with my bow and <mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod> the men. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276611" n="8.297-8.298">Eight long-barbed arrows
have I now let fly, and all are lodged in the flesh of youths
swift in battle; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276612" n="8.299">only this
mad dog can I not <mod n="smite:simpsub">strike</mod>. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2276613" n="8.300-8.301"><milestone n="300" unit="line" />He <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod>, and shot another arrow from the string straight against
Hector; and his heart <corr n="was fain">wanted</corr> to <mod n="smite:simpsub">strike</mod> him. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276614" n="8.302-8.305"><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod> him he missed, but
peerless Gorgythion he <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> in the breast with his arrow, Priam's
valiant son, that a mother wedded from Aesyme had born, <milestone n="305" unit="line"/>even fair Castianeira, in form like to the
goddesses. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276615" n="8.306-8.308">And he bowed
his head to one side like a poppy that in a garden is <sic>laden</sic> with its
fruit and the rains of spring; so bowed he to one side his head,
<sic>laden</sic> with his helmet.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2276616" n="8.309-8.310">And Teucer shot another arrow
from the string <milestone n="310" unit="line"/>straight against
Hector, and his heart <corr n="was fain">wanted</corr> to <mod n="smite:simpsub">strike</mod> him. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276617" n="8.311"><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod> he missed him once again,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2276618" n="8.311">for Apollo made his dart to
swerve, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276619" n="8.312-8.313">but
Archeptolemus, the bold charioteer of Hector, as he <mod n="hasted:simpsub">hastened</mod> into
battle he <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> on the breast beside the nipple. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276620" n="8.314-8.315">So he fell <corr n="from out">out of</corr> the <mod n="car:simpsub">chariot</mod>,
and the swift-footed horses swerved aside <sic>thereat</sic>; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276621" n="8.315"><milestone n="315" unit="line"/>and
there his spirit and his strength were undone. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276622" n="8.316">Then was the soul of Hector clouded
with <sic>dread</sic> sorrow for his charioteer. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276623" n="8.317-8.319">Yet left he him to lie there, though he sorrowed for
his comrade, and <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> Cebriones, his own brother, that was <mod n="nigh:simpsub">near</mod> at
hand, take the reins of the horses; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276624" n="8.319">and he heard and failed not to <mod n="hearken:simpsub">listen</mod>. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276625" n="8.320-8.321"><milestone n="320" unit="line" />And himself Hector leapt to the ground from his gleaming <mod n="car:simpsub">chariot</mod>
crying a terrible cry, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276626" n="8.321-8.322" >and seizing a stone in his hand made right at Teucer, and his heart
<mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> him <mod n="smite:simpsub">strike</mod> him. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276627" n="8.323-8.324">Now
Teucer had drawn forth from the quiver a bitter arrow, and laid it
upon the string, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276628" n="8.324-8.328">but
even as he was drawing it back Hector of the flashing helm
<milestone n="325" unit="line"/><mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> him beside the shoulder
where the collar-bone parts the neck and the breast, where is the
deadliest spot; even there as he aimed eagerly against him he <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod>
him with the jagged stone, and he <mod n="brake:simpsub">broke</mod> the bow-string; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2276629" n="8.328-8.329">but his hand grew numb at the
wrist, and he sank upon his knees and thus <sic>abode</sic>, and the bow fell
from his hand. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276630" n="8.330-8.331" ><milestone n="330" unit="line"/><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod> Aias was not unmindful
of his brother's fall, but ran and bestrode him and flung before him
his shield as a cover. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276631" n="8.332-8.334" >Then two trusty comrades stooped beneath him, even Mecisteus, son
of Echius, and <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Alastor, and bare him, groaning heavily, to
the hollow ships. </s></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:8.335-8.380">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2276632" n="8.335"><milestone n="335" unit="line"/>Then
once again the Olympian aroused might in the hearts of the Trojans;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2276633" n="8.336">and they thrust the Achaeans
straight toward the deep ditch; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2276634" n="8.337">and <mod n="amid:simpsub">among</mod> the foremost went Hector exulting in his might.

<s xml:id="sent2276925" n="9.321-9.322">Neither have I

<s xml:id="sent2276926" n="9.323-9.327">Even as a bird <mod n='bringeth'>brings</mod> in her bill to her

<s xml:id="sent2277431" n="10.536-10.537">I would
that Odysseus and the valiant Diomedes may even thus speedily
have driven forth from among the Trojans single-hooved horses;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2277432" n="10.538-10.539">but wondrously do
I fear at heart lest those bravest of the Argives have suffered
some ill through the battle din of the Trojans. </s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:10.540-10.579">
<p>
<milestone n="540" unit="line"/>




<s xml:id="sent2277433" n="10.540">Not yet was the word fully uttered,
when they came themselves. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2277434" n="10.541-10.542">Down they leapt to earth, and the others were
seized with joy and welcomed them with hand-clasps and with gentle
words. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2277435" n="10.543">And the horseman,
Nestor of Gerenia, was first to question them: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2277436" n="10.544-10.546">Come tell me now,
Odysseus, greatly to be praised, great glory of the Achaeans,
<milestone n="545" unit="line"/>how <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="twain:simpsub">two</mod> took these
horses. Was it by entering the throng of the Trojans? Or did
some god that met you give you them? </s>



<s xml:id="sent2277437" n="10.547">Wondrous like are they to rays of the sun. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2277438" n="10.548-10.549">Ever do I mingle in
battle with the Trojans and <mod n="nowise:simpsub">in no way</mod> methinks do I <mod n="tarry:simpsub">wait</mod> by the
ships, old warrior though I be; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2277439" n="10.550"><milestone n="550" unit="line"/><mod n="howbeit:simpsub">however</mod> never yet saw
I such horses neither thought of such. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2277440" n="10.551"><sic>Nay</sic>, methinks some god <mod n="hath:simpsub">has</mod> met
you and given you them; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2277441" n="10.552-10.553">for both of you <mod n="twain:simpsub">two</mod> <mod n="doth:simpsub">does</mod> Zeus the
cloud-gatherer love and the daughter of Zeus that <mod n='beareth'>bears</mod> the
aegis, even flashing-eyed Athene. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2277442" n="10.554">Then in answer <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod> him
Odysseus of many wiles: </s></p>
<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2277443" n="10.555-10.557"><milestone n="555" unit="line"/>Nestor, son of Neleus, great glory of the
Achaeans, easily might a god that willed it bestow even better
horses than these, for the gods are mightier far. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2277444" n="10.558-10.559">But these horses, old
sir, <sic>whereof</sic> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='askest'>ask</mod>, are newly come from Thrace, </s>


<s xml:id="sent2277445" n="10.559-10.560">and their lord did brave
Diomedes <milestone n="560" unit="line"/><mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod>, and beside him
twelve of his comrades, all them that were the best. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2277446" n="10.561-10.563">And for the thirteenth we
<mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> a scout near the ships, one that Hector and the other

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2277447" n="10.564-10.565">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he, and <mod n="drave:simpsub">drove</mod> the
single-hooved horses through the trench, <milestone n="565" unit="line"/>exultingly, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2277448" n="10.565" >and with him went joyously the rest of the Achaeans. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2277449" n="10.566-10.569">But when they were come to
the well-builded hut of the son of Tydeus, the horses they bound
with shapely thongs at the manger where stood the swift-footed
horses of Diomedes, eating honey-sweet corn. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2277450" n="10.570-10.571"><milestone n="570" unit="line"/>And on the stern of his ship did Odysseus place the
bloody spoils of Dolon until they should make ready a sacred
offering to Athene. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2277451" n="10.572-10.573" >But for themselves they entered the sea and washed away the
abundant sweat from shins and necks and thighs. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2277452" n="10.574-10.576">And when the wave of the sea
had washed the abundant sweat <milestone n="575" unit="line"/>from

<s xml:id="sent2277453" n="10.577-10.579">But

<s xml:id="sent2277454" n="11.1-11.2">Now Dawn rose from her couch from

<s xml:id="sent2277455" n="11.3-11.4">and Zeus sent forth

<s xml:id="sent2277456" n="11.5-11.12"><milestone n="5" unit="line"/>And she took her hand

<s xml:id="sent2277457" n="11.13-11.14">And to them <sic>forthwith</sic> war

<s xml:id="sent2277458" n="11.15-11.16"><milestone n="15" unit="line"/>But the son of Atreus shouted aloud, and

<s xml:id="sent2277460" n="11.17-11.18">The greaves first he set about

<s xml:id="sent2277462" n="11.21-11.22">For he heard afar in Cyprus the great rumour that

<s xml:id="sent2277463" n="11.23"><mod n="wherefore:simpsub">for which reason</mod> he gave him the breastplate

<s xml:id="sent2277464" n="11.24-11.25">Thereon <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> were ten bands of dark cyanus,

<s xml:id="sent2277465" n="11.26-11.28">and serpents of

<s xml:id="sent2277466" n="11.29">And about his

<s xml:id="sent2277468" n="11.32-11.35">And he

<s xml:id="sent2277477" n="11.47-11.50">Then on his own charioteer each

<s xml:id="sent2277480" n="11.52-11.55">And among them the son of Cronos roused an evil din,

<s xml:id="sent2277481" n="11.56-11.60">And the Trojans over against

<s xml:id="sent2277482" n="11.61-11.65" >And Hector <mod n="amid:simpsub">among</mod> the foremost bare his shield that was well balanced

<s xml:id="sent2277484" n="11.67-11.69">And as reapers over against each

<s xml:id="sent2277486" n="11.70-11.71"><milestone n="70" unit="line"/>even so the Trojans and Achaeans leapt upon

<s xml:id="sent2277493" n="11.84">Now as long as it was morn and the

<s xml:id="sent2277496" n="11.91-11.93">And among them Agamemnon rushed

<s xml:id="sent2277497" n="11.94">Oïleus <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> leapt down from

<s xml:id="sent2277507" n="11.113-11.115">And as a lion

<s xml:id="sent2277521" n="11.143-11.144">He <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod>, and thrust Peisander

<s xml:id="sent2277529" n="11.155-11.157"><milestone n="155" unit="line"/>And as when

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:11.163-11.209">

<s xml:id="sent2277532" n="11.163-11.164">But Hector did Zeus draw forth

<s xml:id="sent2277533" n="11.165"><milestone n="165" unit="line"/>but the son of Atreus followed after,

<s xml:id="sent2277534" n="11.166-11.168">And past the tomb of ancient Ilos, son of

<s xml:id="sent2277536" n="11.170-11.171"><milestone n="170" unit="line"/>But when they were come to the Scaean gates and the

<s xml:id="sent2277537" n="11.172-11.174"><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod> some

<s xml:id="sent2277560" n="11.218-11.220">Tell me now, <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> Muses, that

<s xml:id="sent2277561" n="11.221-11.222">It was Iphidamas, son of Antenor, a valiant man

<s xml:id="sent2277567" n="11.232-11.235">And when they were

<s xml:id="sent2277596" n="11.291">So saving he aroused the strength and

<s xml:id="sent2277597" n="11.292-11.295" >And even as when a huntsman sets his white-toothed hounds upon a

<s xml:id="sent2277611" n="11.320-11.321"><milestone n="320" unit="line" />He <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod>, and thrust Thymbraeus from his chariot to the ground,

<s xml:id="sent2277629" n="11.345-11.346"><milestone n="345" unit="line"/>At sight of him Diomedes, good at the war-cry,

<s xml:id="sent2277632" n="11.349-11.351">He <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> and poised his

<s xml:id="sent2277637" n="11.357-11.360">But while the son of Tydeus

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:12.277-12.328">

<s xml:id="sent2278029" n="12.277">So shouted forth the <mod n="twain:simpsub">two</mod>, and

<s xml:id="sent2278035" n="12.290-12.293"><milestone n="290" unit="line"/>Yet not even then would the Trojans and glorious

<s xml:id="sent2278036" n="12.294-12.297"><sic>Forthwith</sic> he held before him his shield that was

<s xml:id="sent2278038" n="12.302-12.306">For even though he find thereby the herdsmen with

<s xml:id="sent2278040" n="12.309">Straightway then he <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> to

<s xml:id="sent2278042" n="12.315-12.317"><milestone n="315" unit="line"/>Therefore now it <mod n='behoveth'>behooves</mod> us to take our

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2278045" n="12.322-12.325">Ah friend, if once

<div type="textpart" subtype="book" n="13">
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:13.1-13.31">
<p>
<milestone n="1" unit="line"/>




<s xml:id="sent2278122" n="13.1-13.6">Now Zeus, when he had brought the

<s xml:id="sent2278123" n="13.7">To Troy he no longer in any wise
turned his bright eyes, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2278124" n="13.8-13.9" >for he <mod n="deemed:simpsub">thought</mod> not in his heart that any of the immortals would draw
<mod n="nigh:simpsub">near</mod> to aid either Trojans or Danaans. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2278125" n="13.10"><milestone n="10" unit="line"/>But the lord, the Shaker of

<s xml:id="sent2278126" n="13.11-13.13">for he sat marvelling at the war and the battle,

<s xml:id="sent2278127" n="13.13-13.14" >and plain to see were the city of Priam, and the ships of the

<s xml:id="sent2278128" n="13.15-13.16"><milestone n="15" unit="line"/>There he sat, being come forth from the sea,

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2278129" n="13.17-13.18"><sic>Forthwith</sic> then he went down from
the rugged mount, striding forth with swift footsteps, </s>


<s xml:id="sent2278130" n="13.18-13.19">and the high mountains trembled
and the woodland beneath the immortal feet of Poseidon as he went.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2278131" n="13.20-13.22"><milestone n="20" unit="line"/><mod n="Thrice:simpsub">Three times</mod> he strode in his course, and with the fourth

<mod n="builded:simpsub">built</mod> in the depths of the mere, golden and gleaming, imperishable

<s xml:id="sent2278132" n="13.23-13.27">Thither came
he, and let harness beneath his <mod n="car:simpsub">chariot</mod> his two bronze hooved horses,
swift of flight, with flowing manes of gold; <milestone n="25" unit="line"/>and with gold he clad himself about his body, and
grasped the well-wrought whip of gold, and stepped upon his <mod n="car:simpsub">chariot</mod>, and
set out to drive over the waves. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2278133" n="13.27-13.28">Then gambolled the sea-beasts beneath him on every

<s xml:id="sent2278137" n="13.32-13.33">There is a wide cavern in the

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:13.195-13.230">

<s xml:id="sent2278290" n="13.311">And to him again Idomeneus, leader of

<s xml:id="sent2278436" n="13.593-13.594">But the son of Atreus, Menelaus, good at the

<s xml:id="sent2278530" n="13.778-13.780">For

<s xml:id="sent2278532" n="13.781-13.783">Only Deïphobus and the valiant prince Helenus

<s xml:id="sent2278534" n="13.784">But now

<s xml:id="sent2278548" n="13.810"><milestone n="810" unit="line" />Good sir, draw <mod n="nigh:simpsub">near</mod>; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2278549" n="13.810-13.811"><mod n="wherefore:simpsub">for which reason</mod> <mod n='seekest'>seek</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> thus vainly to affright

<s xml:id="sent2278568" n="14.5-14.7"><milestone n="5" unit="line"/><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod> do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> now sit where <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> and

<s xml:id="sent2278572" n="14.12-14.15">And he grasped a valorous spear, tipped with sharp

<s xml:id="sent2278573" n="14.15"><milestone n="15" unit="line"/>and the wall of the Achaeans was broken

<s xml:id="sent2278574" n="14.16-14.22">And as when the

<s xml:id="sent2278575" n="14.23-14.24">And as he pondered, this thing

<s xml:id="sent2278576" n="14.24-14.25">But the others meanwhile were

<s xml:id="sent2278582" n="14.35-14.36"><milestone n="35" unit="line"/><mod n="wherefore:simpsub">for which reason</mod> they had drawn up the ships row

<s xml:id="sent2278586" n="14.41">Then lord Agamemnon

<s xml:id="sent2278589" n="14.48">On <corr n="this wise">this way</corr> <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he,

<s xml:id="sent2278592" n="14.52">Then made answer to him the horseman

<s xml:id="sent2278601" n="14.65-14.68"><milestone n="65" unit="line"/>Nestor, seeing they are fighting at the sterns

<s xml:id="sent2278607" n="14.80"><milestone n="80" unit="line"/>For in <mod n="sooth:simpsub">truth</mod> I count it not shame to

<s xml:id="sent2278613" n="14.90-14.94"><milestone n="90" unit="line"/>Be silent, lest

<s xml:id="sent2278614" n="14.95"><milestone n="95" unit="line" />But now have I altogether scorn of <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> wits, that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod>

<s xml:id="sent2278615" n="14.96-14.99" >seeing <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='biddest'>command</mod> us, when war and battle are afoot, draw

<s xml:id="sent2278616" n="14.99-14.101">For the Achaeans

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:14.103-14.153">

<s xml:id="sent2278618" n="14.103">To him then made answer, Agamemnon,

<s xml:id="sent2278621" n="14.107-14.108">But now I would there

<s xml:id="sent2278623" n="14.109">Then among them <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> also Diomedes,

<s xml:id="sent2278624" n="14.110"><milestone n="110" unit="line" />Near by is that man; </s>

<s xml:id="sent2278626" n="14.110-14.112">if so be <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> are minded to <corr n="give ear">listen</corr>, and be no

<s xml:id="sent2278627" n="14.113-14.114"><sic>Nay</sic>, but of a goodly father do I too declare

<s xml:id="sent2279000" n="15.307-15.310">while before him went

aegis, girt with shaggy fringe, awful, gleaming bright, that the
smith <milestone n="310" unit="line"/>Hephaestus gave to Zeus to
bear for the putting to rout of warriors; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279001" n="15.311">this Apollo bare in his hands as he
led on the host. </s></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:15.312-15.342">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279002" n="15.312-15.314">And the Argives in close
throng <sic>abode</sic> their coming, and the war-cry rose shrill from either
side, and the arrows leapt from the bow-string, </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279003" n="15.314-15.317">and many spears, hurled by
bold hands, <milestone n="315" unit="line"/>were some of them lodged
in the flesh of youths swift in battle, and many of them, or ever
they reached the white flesh, stood fixed midway in the earth, fain
to glut themselves with flesh. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279004" n="15.318-15.319">Now so long as Phoebus Apollo held the aegis
moveless in his hands, even so long the missiles of either side
reached their mark and the <mod n="folk:simpsub">people</mod> kept falling; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279005" n="15.320-15.322"><milestone n="320" unit="line"/>but when he looked full in the faces of the Danaans
of swift horses, and shook the aegis, and himself shouted mightily
<sic>withal</sic>, then made he their hearts to faint within their breasts, and
they forgat their furious might. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279006" n="15.323-15.326">And as when two wild beasts drive in confusion a
herd of <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod> or a great flock of sheep in the darkness of black
night, <milestone n="325" unit="line"/>when they have come upon them
suddenly, and a herdsman is not by, even so were the Achaeans driven
in rout with no might in them; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279007" n="15.326-15.327">for upon them Apollo had sent panic, and <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod> the
Trojans and Hector was he giving glory.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279008" n="15.328">Then man <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> man as the fight was
scattered. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279009" n="15.329-15.331">Hector laid
low Stichius and Arcesilaus, <milestone n="330" unit="line"/>the one
a leader of the brazen-coated Boeotians, and the other a trusty
comrade of great-souled Menestheus; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279010" n="15.332">and Aeneas <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> Medon and Iasus. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279011" n="15.333-15.334">The one <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod>, Medon, was a
bastard son of godlike Oïleus, and brother of Aias, </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279012" n="15.334-15.336">but he dwelt <milestone n="335" unit="line"/>in Phylace far from his native land, for
that he had slain a man of the kin of his stepmother, Eriopis that
Oïleus had to wife; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279013" n="15.337-15.338" >and Iasus was a captain of the Athenians, and was called the son of
Sphelus, son of Bucolus. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279014" n="15.339-15.340">And Mecisteus did Polydamas <mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod>, and Polites <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod>
Echius <milestone n="340" unit="line"/>in the forefront of the
fight, and Clonius was slain of <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Agenor. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279015" n="15.341-15.342">And Deïochus did Paris <mod n="smite:simpsub">strike</mod>
from behind, as he fled <mod n="amid:simpsub">among</mod> the foremost fighters, upon the base of
the shoulder, and <mod n="drave:simpsub">drove</mod> the bronze clean through. </s></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:15.343-15.378">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279016" n="15.343-15.345">While they were stripping the
armour from these, meanwhile the Achaeans were flinging themselves
into the digged trench and against the palisade, <milestone n="345" unit="line"/>fleeing this way and that, and were getting them
within their wall perforce. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279017" n="15.346-15.347">And Hector shouted aloud, and called to the
Trojans: Speed <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> against the ships, and let be the blood-stained
spoils. </s><q>



<s xml:id="sent2279018" n="15.348-15.351">Whomsoever
I shall mark holding aloof from the ships on the further side,
on the very spot shall I devise his death, nor shall his
<milestone n="350" unit="line"/>kinsmen and kinswomen give
him his due <sic>meed</sic> of fire in death, but the dogs shall rend him
in front of our city. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279019" n="15.352-15.353">So saying, with a downward
sweep of his arm he <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> his horses with the lash, and called aloud
to the Trojans along the ranks; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279020" n="15.353-15.355">and they all raised a shout, and even with him
<mod n="drave:simpsub">drove</mod> the steeds that drew their chariots, <milestone n="355" unit="line"/> with a wondrous din; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279021" n="15.355-15.359">and before them Phoebus Apollo lightly dashed down
with his feet the banks of the deep trench, and cast them into the

as far as a spear-cast, when a man <mod n='hurleth'>hurls</mod>, making trial of his
strength. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279022" n="15.360-15.361"><milestone n="360" unit="line"/>Therethrough they poured forward rank on
rank, and before them went Apollo, bearing the priceless aegis.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2279023" n="15.361-15.364">And full easily did he
cast down the wall of the Achaeans, even as when a boy <mod n='scattereth'>scatters</mod>
the sand by the sea, one that makes of it a plaything in his
childishness, and then again confounds it with hands and feet as he
<mod n='maketh'>makes</mod> sport: </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279024" n="15.365-15.366" ><milestone n="365" unit="line"/>so lightly <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod>, O
archer<note resp="Loeb" anchored="true">133.1</note> Phoebus,
confound the long toil and labour of the Achaeans, and on themselves

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279025" n="15.367-15.369">So then beside their ships the
Danaans halted, and were stayed, calling one upon the other, and
lifting up their hands to all the gods they made fervent prayer,
each man of them; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279026" n="15.370-15.371" ><milestone n="370" unit="line"/>and most of all prayed Nestor
of Gerenia, the warder of the Achaeans, stretching forth his two

<s xml:id="sent2279027" n="15.372-15.376">O father Zeus, if ever any
man of us in wheat-bearing Argos burned to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> fat thigh-pieces

<mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> promise and nod <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> head <sic>thereto</sic>, <milestone n="375" unit="line"/>be <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> now mindful of these things, and ward
from us, O Olympian god, the pitiless day of doom, nor suffer
the Achaeans thus to be vanquished by the Trojans. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279028" n="15.377-15.378">So he <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> in prayer, and
Zeus the counsellor thundered aloud, hearing the prayer of the aged
son of Neleus. </s></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:15.379-15.404">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279029" n="15.379-15.380">But the Trojans, when they
heard the thunder of Zeus that <mod n='beareth'>bears</mod> the aegis, <milestone n="380" unit="line"/>leapt yet the more upon the Argives and bethought

<s xml:id="sent2279030" n="15.381-15.383">And as
when a great billow of the broad-wayed sea <mod n='sweepeth'>sweeps</mod> down over the
bulwarks of a ship, <mod n="whenso:simpsub">whenever</mod> it is driven on by the might of the wind,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2279031" n="15.383">which above all <mod n='maketh'>makes</mod> the
waves to swell; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279032" n="15.384-15.389">even

<milestone n="385" unit="line"/>they in their cars, but the
Achaeans high up on the decks of their black ships to which they had

<s xml:id="sent2279033" n="15.390-15.394" ><milestone n="390" unit="line"/>And Patroclus, so long as the

<s xml:id="sent2279034" n="15.395-15.398"><milestone n="395" unit="line"/>But when he saw the Trojans rushing upon the wall,
while the Danaans with loud cries turned in flight, then he uttered
a groan, and <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> his two thighs with the flat of his hands, and
with wailing <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod>, saying: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2279035" n="15.399-15.400">Eurypylus, in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> may
I <mod n="abide:simpsub">remain</mod> longer with <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> here, <milestone n="400" unit="line" /><mod n="albeit:simpsub">although</mod> <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> need is <sic>sore</sic>; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279036" n="15.400">for <sic>lo</sic>, a mighty struggle <mod n="hath:simpsub">has</mod> arisen. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279037" n="15.401-15.402"><sic>Nay</sic>, as for <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, let <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod>
squire bring <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> comfort, but I will hasten to Achilles, that I
may urge him on to do battle. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279038" n="15.403-15.404">Who knows but that, heaven helping, I may
rouse his spirit with my persuading? </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279039" n="15.404">A good thing is the persuasion of a comrade.
</s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:15.405-15.441">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279040" n="15.405"><milestone n="405" unit="line"/>When
he had thus spoken his feet bare him on; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279041" n="15.405-15.407">but the Achaeans firmly <sic>abode</sic> the oncoming of the

<s xml:id="sent2279042" n="15.408-15.409">nor
ever could the Trojans break the battalions of the Danaans and make

<s xml:id="sent2279043" n="15.410-15.413"><milestone n="410" unit="line"/>But as the carpenter's line <mod n='maketh'>makes</mod> straight a

<s xml:id="sent2279044" n="15.414-15.415">So fought they on, divers of

made straight for glorious Aias. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279045" n="15.416-15.418">They <mod n="twain:simpsub">two</mod> were labouring in the toil of war about

<s xml:id="sent2279046" n="15.419-15.420">Then
did glorious Aias cast his spear and <mod n="smite:simpsub">strike</mod> upon the breast Caletor,

<s xml:id="sent2279047" n="15.421">and he
fell with a thud, and the torch dropped <corr n="from out">out of</corr> his hand. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279048" n="15.422-15.424">But Hector, when his eyes
beheld his cousin fallen in the dust in front of the black ship,
called to the Trojans and Lycians with a loud shout: </s></p>
<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2279049" n="15.425-15.428"><milestone n="425" unit="line"/><mod n="Ye:simpsub">You</mod> Trojans and Lycians and Dardanians that
fight in close combat, in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> give <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> ground from battle in
this strait: <sic>nay</sic>, save <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> the son of Clytius, lest so be the

gathering of the ships. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279050" n="15.429">So saying, he hurled at Aias with his
bright spear; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279051" n="15.430-15.434" ><milestone n="430" unit="line"/>him he missed, but Lycophron,

<s xml:id="sent2279052" n="15.434-15.435">and backward in
the dust <milestone n="435" unit="line"/>he fell to the ground from
off the stern of the ship and his limbs were loosed. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279053" n="15.436">And Aias shuddered, and <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod>
his brother: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2279054" n="15.437-15.439">Good Teucer, <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> a true

<s xml:id="sent2279055" n="15.440"><milestone n="440" unit="line" />Him <mod n="hath:simpsub">has</mod> great-souled Hector slain. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279056" n="15.440-15.441">Where now are <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> arrows
that bring swift death, and the bow that Phoebus Apollos gave
<mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>? </s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:15.442-15.477">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279057" n="15.442-15.444">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he, and the other

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2279058" n="15.444">and full swiftly did he let

<s xml:id="sent2279059" n="15.445-15.447"><milestone n="445" unit="line"/>And he <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod>

<s xml:id="sent2279061" n="15.448-15.449">for thither

<s xml:id="sent2279062" n="15.449-15.450">But full swiftly <milestone n="450" unit="line"/>upon himself came evil that not one of them

<s xml:id="sent2279063" n="15.451">For upon the back of his neck

<s xml:id="sent2279064" n="15.452-15.453">and he fell from the chariot,

<s xml:id="sent2279065" n="15.453-15.454">And the prince Polydamas

<s xml:id="sent2279066" n="15.455-15.457"><milestone n="455" unit="line"/>These he gave to Astynous, son of Protiaon, and

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279068" n="15.458-15.460">Then Teucer drew forth another

<s xml:id="sent2279069" n="15.461-15.464">But he was not unmarked of the wise mind of Zeus,
who guarded Hector, and took the glory from Teucer, son of Telamon.

<s xml:id="sent2279070" n="15.464-15.465">and his arrow <milestone n="465" unit="line" />heavy with bronze was turned aside, and the bow fell from his

<s xml:id="sent2279071" n="15.466">Then Teucer shuddered,
and <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> to his brother: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2279072" n="15.467-15.470">Now look you, in good
<mod n="sooth:simpsub">truth</mod> a god is utterly bringing to <mod n="naught:simpsub">nothing</mod> the counsels of our

</s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279073" n="15.471">Then great Telamonian Aias answered
him: </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2279074" n="15.472-15.473">Aye, friend, but leave
<mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> bow and <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> many arrows to lie where they are, seeing

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2279075" n="15.474-15.475">but take <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> in
<mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> hand a long spear and a shield upon <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> shoulder, <milestone n="475" unit="line"/>and do battle with the Trojans, and

<s xml:id="sent2279076" n="15.476-15.477"><mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod> not without a struggle, for all they

<sic>nay</sic>, let us <sic>bethink</sic> us of battle. </s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:15.478-15.513">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279077" n="15.478-15.481">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he, and Teucer laid

<s xml:id="sent2279078" n="15.482-15.483" >and he took a valorous spear, tipped with sharp bronze, and went
his way, and swiftly ran and took his stand by the side of
Aias.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279079" n="15.484-15.485">But when Hector saw that
Teucer's shafts had been brought to <mod n="naught:simpsub">nothing</mod>, <milestone n="485" unit="line"/>to Trojans and Lycians he called with a loud shout, </s><q>




<s xml:id="sent2279080" n="15.486-15.488"><mod n="Ye:simpsub">You</mod> Trojans and Lycians and
Dardanians that fight in close combat, be men, my friends, and
<sic>bethink</sic> you of furious valour <mod n="amid:simpsub">among</mod> the hollow ships; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279081" n="15.488-15.489">for <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> mine eyes have
seen how Zeus <mod n="hath:simpsub">has</mod> brought to <mod n="naught:simpsub">nothing</mod> the shafts of a man that is

<s xml:id="sent2279082" n="15.490-15.493" ><milestone n="490" unit="line"/>Full easy to discern is the
aid Zeus <mod n='giveth'>gives</mod> to men, both to whomso he <mod n='vouchsafeth'>promises</mod> the glory
of victory, and whomso again he <mod n='minisheth'>diminishes</mod>, and <mod n="hath:simpsub">has</mod> no mind to

<mod n='beareth'>bears</mod> aid to us. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279083" n="15.494"><sic>Nay</sic>,

<s xml:id="sent2279084" n="15.494-15.496">and if so be any of you,
<milestone n="495" unit="line"/><mod n="smitten:simpsub">struck</mod> by dart or thrust,

<s xml:id="sent2279085" n="15.496-15.497">No unseemly thing is it
for him to die while fighting for his country. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279086" n="15.497-15.499"><sic>Nay</sic>, but his wife is safe
and his children after him, and his house and his portion of

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279087" n="15.500"><milestone n="500" unit="line"/>So
saying, he aroused the strength and spirit of every man. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279088" n="15.501">And Aias again, over against him

<s xml:id="sent2279089" n="15.502">Shame on you, Argives, </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279090" n="15.502-15.503">now is it sure that we
must either perish utterly or find deliverance by thrusting back
the peril from the ships. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279091" n="15.504-15.505">Think <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> that if Hector of the flashing
helm take the ships, <milestone n="505" unit="line"/><mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> shall
come afoot each man of you to his own native land? </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279092" n="15.506-15.507">Hear <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> not Hector urging
on all his host in his fury to burn the ships? </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279093" n="15.508"><mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod> it is not to the dance
that he <mod n='biddeth'>bids</mod> them come, but to battle. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279094" n="15.509-15.510">And for us there is no
counsel or device better than this, <milestone n="510" unit="line"/>that in close combat we bring our hands and our
might against theirs. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279095" n="15.511-15.513">Better is it once for all either to die or

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:15.592-15.652">

<s xml:id="sent2279147" n="15.592-15.595">But the Trojans, like ravening

<s xml:id="sent2279148" n="15.596-15.599">For his heart was set on

<s xml:id="sent2279157" n="15.615-15.616"><milestone n="615" unit="line"/>But fain was he to

<s xml:id="sent2279161" n="15.623-15.625">But Hector shining all

<s xml:id="sent2279187" n="15.674-15.675">Now was it no more pleasing to

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:15.696-15.746">

<s xml:id="sent2279196" n="15.696">Then again keen battle was set afoot

<s xml:id="sent2279197" n="15.697-15.698">Thou

<s xml:id="sent2279199" n="15.699-15.702">The

<s xml:id="sent2279200" n="15.703">Such were their thoughts as they

<s xml:id="sent2279201" n="15.704-15.706">But Hector laid hold of the stern of a seafaring
ship, <milestone n="705" unit="line"/>a fair ship, swift upon the

again to his native land. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279202" n="15.707-15.708">About his ship Achaeans and Trojans were slaying
one another in close combat, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279203" n="15.708-15.712">nor did they longer hold aloof and thus endure the
flight of arrows and darts, <milestone n="710" unit="line"/>but

battle-axes and hatchets, and with great swords and two-edged

<s xml:id="sent2279204" n="15.713-15.715">And many
goodly blades, bound with dark thongs at the hilt, fell to the

<s xml:id="sent2279205" n="15.715">and the black earth flowed with
blood. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279206" n="15.716-15.717">But Hector,

<s xml:id="sent2279207" n="15.718">Bring fire, and <sic>therewithal</sic> raise
<mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> the war-cry all with one voice; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279208" n="15.719-15.723">now <mod n="hath:simpsub">has</mod> Zeus <mod n="vouchsafed:simpsub">promised</mod> us a day that is

<s xml:id="sent2279209" n="15.724-15.725" >But if Zeus, whose voice is borne afar, then dulled our wits,
<milestone n="725" unit="line"/>now of himself he <mod n='urgeth'>urges</mod> and
<mod n='giveth'>gives</mod> command. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279210" n="15.726">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he, and they leapt the more

<s xml:id="sent2279211" n="15.727">But Aias no

<s xml:id="sent2279214" n="15.730-15.731"><milestone n="730" unit="line"/>There stood he on the watch, and with his spear he

<s xml:id="sent2279215" n="15.732">and ever with

<s xml:id="sent2279217" n="15.735-15.736"><milestone n="735" unit="line"/>Do we <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> <mod n="deem:simpsub">think</mod> that there are other

<s xml:id="sent2279219" n="15.739-15.740"><sic>nay</sic>, it is

<s xml:id="sent2279221" n="15.742">He <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod>, and kept driving furiously

<s xml:id="sent2279222" n="15.743-15.745">And whoso of the Trojans would rush upon the

<s xml:id="sent2279301" n="16.137-16.138">and upon his mighty head he

<s xml:id="sent2279302" n="16.138">and terribly did the plume nod from
above; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279303" n="16.139">and he took two
valorous spears, that fitted his grasp. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279304" n="16.140-16.141"><milestone n="140" unit="line"/>Only the spear of
the peerless son of Aeacus he took not, the spear heavy and huge and
strong; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279305" n="16.141-16.144">this none
other of the Achaeans could wield, but Achilles alone was skilled to
wield it, even the Pelian spear of ash, that Cheiron had given to
his dear father from the peak of Pelion, to be for the slaying of

<s xml:id="sent2279306" n="16.145-16.147"><milestone n="145" unit="line"/>And the horses he <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> Automedon yoke

<mod n="abide:simpsub">remain</mod> his call in battle. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279307" n="16.148-16.151">At his bidding then Automedon led beneath the yoke

conceived to the West Wind, as she grazed on the meadow beside the
stream of Oceanus. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279308" n="16.152-16.154">And
in the side-traces he set the <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Pedasus that on a time Achilles

mortal, kept pace with immortal steeds. </s></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:16.155-16.199">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279309" n="16.155-16.156"><milestone n="155" unit="line" />But Achilles went to and fro throughout the huts and let harness
in their armour all the Myrmidons, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279310" n="16.156-16.159">and they rushed forth like ravening wolves in

a great horned stag, and rend him, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279311" n="16.159">and the jaws of all are red with gore; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279312" n="16.160-16.162"><milestone n="160" unit="line"/>and in a pack they go to lap with their slender
tongues the surface of the black water from a dusky spring, belching

<s xml:id="sent2279313" n="16.162-16.163">the heart in their breasts unflinching, and their
bellies gorged full; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279314" n="16.164-16.166" >even in such wise the leaders and rulers of the Myrmidons sped
forth <milestone n="165" unit="line"/>round about the valiant squire
of the swift-footed son of Aeacus. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279315" n="16.166-16.167">And among them all stood warlike Achilles, urging
on both horses and men that bear the shield.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279316" n="16.168-16.169">Fifty were the swift ships
which Achilles, dear to Zeus, led to Troy, </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279317" n="16.169-16.170">and in each ship <milestone n="170" unit="line"/> at the thole-pins were fifty men, his

<s xml:id="sent2279318" n="16.171-16.172">and five
leaders had he appointed in whom he trusted to give command, </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279319" n="16.172">and himself in his great might was

<s xml:id="sent2279320" n="16.173-16.174">The one

<s xml:id="sent2279321" n="16.175-16.178"><milestone n="175" unit="line"/>Him did fair

<s xml:id="sent2279322" n="16.179-16.181">And of
the next company warlike Eudorus was captain, <milestone n="180" unit="line"/>the son of a girl unwed, and him did Polymele, fair

<s xml:id="sent2279323" n="16.181-16.183">Of her the strong Argeiphontes became enamoured,
when his eyes had sight of her <mod n="amid:simpsub">among</mod> the singing maidens, in the

<s xml:id="sent2279324" n="16.184-16.186" ><sic>Forthwith</sic> then he went up into her upper chamber, and lay with her
secretly, <milestone n="185" unit="line"/>even Hermes the
helper,<note resp="Loeb" anchored="true">1</note> and she gave

<s xml:id="sent2279325" n="16.187-16.192">But when at

<s xml:id="sent2279326" n="16.193-16.195">And of the third company warlike Peisander was
captain, son of Maemalus, a man pre-eminent among all the Myrmidons
<milestone n="195" unit="line"/>in fighting with the spear,
after the comrade of the son of Peleus. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279327" n="16.196-16.197">And the fourth company did the old knight Phoenix
lead, and the fifth Alcimedon, the peerless son of Laerces. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279328" n="16.198-16.199">But when at length Achilles
had set them all in array with their leaders, duly parting company
from company, he laid upon them a stern command: </s></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:16.200-16.248">
<p><q><p>




<s xml:id="sent2279329" n="16.200-16.202"><milestone n="200" unit="line"/>Myrmidons, let no man, I <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> you, be

<mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> threatened the Trojans throughout all the time of my

<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2279330" n="16.203-16.204">Cruel son of
Peleus, surely it was on gall that <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> mother reared
<mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> pitiless one, seeing that in their own
despite <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='holdest'>hold</mod> back <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> comrades beside the ships.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2279331" n="16.205-16.206"><milestone n="205" unit="line"/><sic>Nay</sic>, homeward let us return
again with our seafaring ships, since in <corr n="this wise">this way</corr> evil
wrath <mod n="hath:simpsub">has</mod> fallen upom <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> heart. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279332" n="16.207">With such words would <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod>

<s xml:id="sent2279333" n="16.207-16.208">but now is set before
you a great work of war, <sic>whereof</sic> in time past <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> were

<s xml:id="sent2279334" n="16.209">Therefore

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279335" n="16.210"><milestone n="210" unit="line"/>So
saying, he aroused the strength and spirit of every man, </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279336" n="16.211">and yet closer were their ranks
