<s xml:id="sent2279337" n="16.212-16.214">And as when a man <mod n='buildeth'>builds</mod> the wall of a high

<s xml:id="sent2279338" n="16.215"><milestone n="215" unit="line" />buckler pressed on buckler, helm upon helm, and man on man. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279339" n="16.216-16.217">The horse-hair crests on the

<s xml:id="sent2279340" n="16.218-16.220">And in the front of all two

<s xml:id="sent2279341" n="16.220-16.224">But Achilles went into his hut, and opened the lid

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2279342" n="16.225-16.227"><milestone n="225" unit="line"/>Therein had he a fair-fashioned cup, <mod n="wherefrom:simpsub">from which</mod>

<mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to pour drink offerings to any other of the gods save only to
father Zeus. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2279343" n="16.228-16.230">This cup

<s xml:id="sent2279344" n="16.231-16.232">Then he made

<s xml:id="sent2279345" n="16.232" >and not unmarked was he of Zeus, that <mod n='hurleth'>hurls</mod> the

<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2279346" n="16.233-16.238">Zeus, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> king,

<s xml:id="sent2279347" n="16.239-16.241">Myself <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> will I <mod n="abide:simpsub">remain</mod> in the gathering of

<s xml:id="sent2279348" n="16.241-16.245">with him do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> send

<s xml:id="sent2279349" n="16.246-16.248">But when away from the ships he <mod n="hath:simpsub">has</mod> driven

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:16.249-16.283">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279350" n="16.249">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he in prayer, and Zeus, the

<s xml:id="sent2279351" n="16.250" ><milestone n="250" unit="line"/>and a part the Father granted

<s xml:id="sent2279352" n="16.251-16.252">That Patroclus should thrust back the war and

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279353" n="16.253-16.256">Achilles then, when he had

<milestone n="255" unit="line"/>stood in front of the hut; for

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279354" n="16.257-16.258">But they that were arrayed

<s xml:id="sent2279355" n="16.259-16.262">Straightway they poured forth like wasps

<s xml:id="sent2279356" n="16.262">and a common evil

<s xml:id="sent2279357" n="16.263-16.265" >And the wasps, if so be some wayfaring ran as he <mod n='passeth'>passes</mod> by rouse

<s xml:id="sent2279358" n="16.266-16.267">having a heart

<s xml:id="sent2279360" n="16.268">But Patroclus called

<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2279361" n="16.269-16.274">Myrmidons, <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> comrades of

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279362" n="16.275-16.276"><milestone n="275" unit="line" />So saying, he roused the strength and spirit of every man, and on

<s xml:id="sent2279364" n="16.278-16.282">But when the Trojans saw the valiant son of

<s xml:id="sent2279365" n="16.283" >and each man gazed about to see how he might escape utter

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:16.284-16.305">

<s xml:id="sent2279366" n="16.284-16.288">Then Patroclus was first to

<s xml:id="sent2279368" n="16.289-16.291">and backward in the dust <milestone n="290" unit="line"/>he fell with a groan, and about him his comrades

<s xml:id="sent2279369" n="16.291-16.292">for upon them all had Patroclus sent panic, when

<s xml:id="sent2279375" n="16.297-16.302">And as when from the high crest of a great

<s xml:id="sent2279376" n="16.303-16.305">For not yet were the Trojans

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:16.306-16.350">

<s xml:id="sent2279380" n="16.311-16.312" >And warlike Menelaus thrust and <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> Thoas on the breast, where it

<s xml:id="sent2279400" n="16.342-16.343">And

<s xml:id="sent2279402" n="16.345-16.346"><milestone n="345" unit="line"/>Then Idomeneus

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:16.351-16.393">

<s xml:id="sent2279407" n="16.351">These, then, leaders of the Damans,

<s xml:id="sent2279418" n="16.370-16.373"><milestone n="370" unit="line"/>And in the trench many pairs of swift horses,

<s xml:id="sent2279426" n="16.384-16.388">And even

<s xml:id="sent2279600" n="16.715-16.719"><milestone n="715" unit="line"/>And while he

<s xml:id="sent2279601" n="16.720"><milestone n="720" unit="line"/>In

<s xml:id="sent2279602" n="16.721">Hector, <mod n="wherefore:simpsub">for which reason</mod> <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> cease

<s xml:id="sent2279613" n="16.740-16.742"><milestone n="740" unit="line"/>And both his brows

<s xml:id="sent2279627" n="16.765-16.771"><milestone n="765" unit="line"/>And as the East Wind and the South strive

<s xml:id="sent2279628" n="16.772-16.775">And

<s xml:id="sent2279885" n="17.395-17.397"><milestone n="395" unit="line"/>and their hearts within them were full of

<s xml:id="sent2279886" n="17.397-17.398">and around him the battle <mod n="waxed:simpsub">became</mod> wild, </s>


<s xml:id="sent2279887" n="17.398-17.399">nor could even Ares, rouser

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:17.400-17.422">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2279888" n="17.400-17.401"><milestone n="400" unit="line" />Such evil toil of men and horses did Zeus on that day strain taut

<s xml:id="sent2279889" n="17.401-17.402">Nor as

<s xml:id="sent2279891" n="17.404-17.407"><mod n="Wherefore:simpsub">For which reason</mod> Achilles never

<s xml:id="sent2279893" n="17.410-17.411"><milestone n="410" unit="line"/><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod> then his mother told him not how great an

<s xml:id="sent2279894" n="17.412-17.413">But the others round about the

<s xml:id="sent2279896" n="17.415-17.417"><milestone n="415" unit="line"/>Friends, no fair fame <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> were it for us to

<s xml:id="sent2279897" n="17.417-17.419"><sic>nay</sic>, even here let the black earth gape for us

<s xml:id="sent2279898" n="17.420"><milestone n="420" unit="line"/>And

<s xml:id="sent2279899" n="17.421-17.422">Friends, though it be our

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:17.423-17.455">

<s xml:id="sent2279900" n="17.423">Thus would one speak and arouse the

<s xml:id="sent2279903" n="17.429-17.431">In <mod n="sooth:simpsub">truth</mod> Automedon, valiant son of Diores,

<s xml:id="sent2279913" n="17.450"><milestone n="450" unit="line"/><mod n='Sufficeth'>Suffices</mod> it not that he <mod n="hath:simpsub">has</mod> the

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:17.491-17.515">

<s xml:id="sent2279935" n="17.491">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he, and the valiant son of

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:17.516-17.542">

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:17.543-17.566">

<s xml:id="sent2279962" n="17.543-17.545">Then again over Patroclus was

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:17.567-17.596">

<s xml:id="sent2279977" n="17.567-17.568">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he, and the goddess,

<s xml:id="sent2279980" n="17.575-17.576"><milestone n="575" unit="line"/>Now among the Trojans was one Podes, son of Eetion,

<s xml:id="sent2279981" n="17.576-17.577">and Hector honoured him above all the people, for

<s xml:id="sent2279982" n="17.578-17.579">Him, fair-haired Menelaus

<s xml:id="sent2279984" n="17.580-17.581">But Menelaus, son of

<s xml:id="sent2279986" n="17.585"><milestone n="585" unit="line"/>In his likeness Apollo that <mod n='worketh'>works</mod> afar <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod>

<s xml:id="sent2280012" n="17.626-17.627">Nor were great-hearted Aias

<s xml:id="sent2280013" n="17.628" >and of them great Telamonian Aias was first to speak,

<s xml:id="sent2280018" n="17.634-17.639"><sic>Nay</sic>, come,

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:17.735-17.761">

<s xml:id="sent2280066" n="17.735-17.736"><milestone n="735" unit="line" />Thus the <mod n="twain:simpsub">two</mod> were hasting to bear the corpse forth <corr n="from out">out of</corr> the

<s xml:id="sent2280070" n="17.742-17.744">But as mules that, putting

<s xml:id="sent2280077" n="17.755-17.759" ><milestone n="755" unit="line"/>And as <mod n='flieth'>flies</mod> a cloud of

<s xml:id="sent2280078" n="17.760-17.761"><milestone n="760" unit="line"/>And fair arms full

<s xml:id="sent2280087" n="18.15-18.17"><milestone n="15" unit="line" />While he pondered thus in mind and heart, there drew <mod n="nigh:simpsub">near</mod> <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod> him

<s xml:id="sent2280178" n="18.180"><milestone n="180" unit="line"/>Thine were the shame, if <mod n="anywise:simpsub">in any way</mod> he come, a

<s xml:id="sent2280190" n="18.194-18.195"><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod> himself, I <mod n="ween:simpsub">believe</mod>,

<s xml:id="sent2280195" n="18.202-18.203">When she had thus spoken

<s xml:id="sent2280284" n="18.360"><milestone n="360" unit="line"/>Then
made answer to him the ox-eyed, queenly Hera:</s></p>
<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2280285" n="18.361">Most <sic>dread</sic> son of Cronos, what a
word <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> said. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2280286" n="18.362-18.363"><sic>Lo</sic>, even a man, I <mod n="ween:simpsub">believe</mod>, is like to accomplish
what he can for another man, one that is but mortal, and <mod n='knoweth'>knows</mod>
not all the wisdom that is mine. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2280287" n="18.364-18.367">How then was I, that avow me to be highest of
goddesses <milestone n="365" unit="line"/>in twofold wise, for
that I am eldest and am called <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> wife, and <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> king among
all the immortals—how was I not in my wrath against the Trojans
to devise against them evil? </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2280288" n="18.368">On <corr n="this wise">this way</corr> <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> they one to the
other; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2280289" n="18.369-18.371">but
silver-footed Thetis came <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod> the house of Hephaestus, <milestone n="370" unit="line"/>imperishable, decked with stars, preeminent
among the houses of immortals, <sic>wrought</sic> all of bronze, that the
crook-foot god himself had built him. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2280290" n="18.372-18.373">Him she found sweating with toil as he moved to
and fro about his bellows in eager haste; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2280291" n="18.373-18.377">for he was fashioning
tripods, twenty in all, to stand around the wall of his well-builded
hall, <milestone n="375" unit="line"/>and golden wheels had he set
beneath the base of each that of themselves they might enter the
gathering of the gods at his wish and again return to his house, a
wonder to behold. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2280292" n="18.378-18.379">Thus
much were they fully <sic>wrought</sic>, that not yet were the cunningly
fashioned ears set thereon; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2280293" n="18.379" >these was he making ready, and was forging the rivets. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2280294" n="18.380-18.381"><milestone n="380" unit="line"/>And while he laboured <sic>thereat</sic> with cunning skill,
meanwhile there drew <mod n="nigh:simpsub">near</mod> to him the goddess, silver-footed Thetis.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2280295" n="18.382-18.383">And Charis of the
gleaming veil came forward and marked her—fair Charis, whom the
famed god of the two strong arms had wedded. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2280296" n="18.384">And she clasped her by the hand, and
<mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod>, and addressed her: </s></p>
<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2280297" n="18.385-18.386"><milestone n="385" unit="line"/><mod n="Wherefore:simpsub">For which reason</mod>, long-robed Thetis, <corr n="art thou">are you</corr> come to

<s xml:id="sent2280298" n="18.386">Heretofore <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> not been
<mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to come. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2280299" n="18.387">But follow
me further, that I may set before <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> entertainment.

<s xml:id="sent2280301" n="18.389-18.390">Then she made her

<s xml:id="sent2280303" n="18.391">and she called to Hephaestus, the

<s xml:id="sent2280304" n="18.392">Hephaestus, come forth <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod>;

<s xml:id="sent2280306" n="18.393">And the famous god of the two strong

<s xml:id="sent2280307" n="18.394-18.397"><mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod> then a <sic>dread</sic> and

<s xml:id="sent2280308" n="18.397-18.399">Then had I

<s xml:id="sent2280309" n="18.400-18.402"><milestone n="400" unit="line"/>With them then for nine years' space I forged

<s xml:id="sent2280310" n="18.402-18.403">and round about me

<s xml:id="sent2280311" n="18.403-18.405" >Neither did any other know <sic>thereof</sic>, either of gods or of mortal

<s xml:id="sent2280312" n="18.406">And now is Thetis come to my house; </s>

<s xml:id="sent2280315" n="18.410-18.411"><milestone n="410" unit="line" />He <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod>, and from the anvil rose, a huge, panting<note resp="Loeb" anchored="true">319.2</note> bulk, halting the

<s xml:id="sent2280320" n="18.419-18.420">In them is understanding in their hearts, and in

<s xml:id="sent2280323" n="18.424-18.425"><mod n="Wherefore:simpsub">For which reason</mod>, long-robed

<s xml:id="sent2280327" n="18.428">And Thetis made answer to him,

<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2280328" n="18.429-18.431">Hephaestus, is there now

<s xml:id="sent2280329" n="18.432-18.434">Of all the daughters of the sea he subdued me

the bed of a mortal <mod n="albeit:simpsub">although</mod> <sic>sore</sic> against my will. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2280330" n="18.434-18.437">And <sic>lo</sic>, he <mod n='lieth'>lies</mod>
<milestone n="435" unit="line"/>in his halls <mod n="fordone:simpsub">done in</mod> with

<s xml:id="sent2280331" n="18.437">and he shot up like a sapling;

<s xml:id="sent2280332" n="18.438-18.440">then when I had

<s xml:id="sent2280335" n="18.444-18.445">The girl that the

<s xml:id="sent2280336" n="18.446"><mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod>

<s xml:id="sent2280337" n="18.446-18.448">but the Achaeans were the

<s xml:id="sent2280338" n="18.448-18.449" >And to him the elders of the Argives made prayer, and named

<s xml:id="sent2280339" n="18.450-18.452"><milestone n="450" unit="line"/>Then <mod n="albeit:simpsub">although</mod> he

<s xml:id="sent2280340" n="18.453">All day long

<s xml:id="sent2280341" n="18.454-18.456">and on that selfsame day had laid the city

<s xml:id="sent2280342" n="18.457-18.460">Therefore am I now come

<s xml:id="sent2280343" n="18.460-18.461" >For the harness that was his aforetime his trusty comrade lost,

<s xml:id="sent2280344" n="18.461">and my son <mod n='lieth'>lies</mod> on the ground in anguish of heart.

<s xml:id="sent2280345" n="18.462">Then the famous god of the two strong

<s xml:id="sent2280346" n="18.463">Be of good cheer, </s>


<s xml:id="sent2280347" n="18.463">neither let these things

<s xml:id="sent2280348" n="18.464-18.467">Would that I might so surely avail to hide him

<s xml:id="sent2280349" n="18.468">So saying he left her there and went

<s xml:id="sent2280351" n="18.470-18.473"><milestone n="470" unit="line"/>And the bellows, twenty in all, blew upon the

<s xml:id="sent2280352" n="18.474-18.475">And on the fire he put

<s xml:id="sent2280353" n="18.475-18.477">and

<s xml:id="sent2280354" n="18.478-18.480">First fashioned he a shield,

<s xml:id="sent2280355" n="18.481">Five were the layers of the shield

<s xml:id="sent2280356" n="18.481-18.482">and on it he
<sic>wrought</sic> many curious devices with cunning skill.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2280357" n="18.483-18.489">Therein he <sic>wrought</sic> the earth,

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:18.490-18.526">

<s xml:id="sent2280358" n="18.490-18.491"><milestone n="490" unit="line" />Therein fashioned he also two cities of mortal men exceeding fair.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2280359" n="18.491-18.493">In the one there were

<s xml:id="sent2280360" n="18.494-18.495">And young men were whirling in the dance, and in
their midst <milestone n="495" unit="line"/>flutes and lyres sounded
continually; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2280361" n="18.495-18.496">and there

<s xml:id="sent2280362" n="18.497">But the <mod n="folk:simpsub">people</mod> were gathered in the

<s xml:id="sent2280363" n="18.497-18.499">for

<s xml:id="sent2280364" n="18.499-18.500">the one avowed that he had paid all, <milestone n="500" unit="line"/>declaring his cause to the people, but the

<s xml:id="sent2280365" n="18.501">and each <corr n="was fain">wanted</corr> to win the

<s xml:id="sent2280366" n="18.502">Moreover, the <mod n="folk:simpsub">people</mod> were cheering both, shewing favour to

<s xml:id="sent2280367" n="18.503">And

<s xml:id="sent2280368" n="18.503-18.505">and the elders were sitting upon polished stones

<s xml:id="sent2280370" n="18.507-18.508">And in the midst lay two talents of gold, to be

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2280371" n="18.509-18.510">But around the other city lay

<s xml:id="sent2280372" n="18.510-18.512" >And twofold plans found favour with them, either to lay waste the

<s xml:id="sent2280373" n="18.513"><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod> the besieged would <mod n="nowise:simpsub">in no way</mod>

<s xml:id="sent2280374" n="18.514-18.515">The wall were their

<s xml:id="sent2280378" n="18.520-18.522"><milestone n="520" unit="line"/>But when they were

<s xml:id="sent2280379" n="18.523-18.524">Thereafter were two

<s xml:id="sent2280380" n="18.525-18.526"><milestone n="525" unit="line"/>And these came presently, and two herdsmen followed

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:18.527-18.560">

<s xml:id="sent2280382" n="18.527-18.529">But the liers-in-wait, when

<s xml:id="sent2280383" n="18.530-18.532"><milestone n="530" unit="line"/>But the besiegers,

<s xml:id="sent2280384" n="18.533-18.534">Then set they their battle in

<s xml:id="sent2280385" n="18.535-18.537"><milestone n="535" unit="line"/>And <mod n="amid:simpsub">among</mod> them

<s xml:id="sent2280386" n="18.538">and the raiment that she had about

<s xml:id="sent2280387" n="18.539-18.540">Even as living mortals joined

<p>




<s xml:id="sent2280388" n="18.541-18.542">Therein he set also soft

<s xml:id="sent2280389" n="18.542-18.543">and ploughers full

<s xml:id="sent2280390" n="18.544-18.546">And whensoever

<s xml:id="sent2280391" n="18.546-18.547">and the ploughmen would turn

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2280392" n="18.548-18.549">And the field grew

<s xml:id="sent2280393" n="18.549">herein was

<s xml:id="sent2280394" n="18.550" ><milestone n="550" unit="line"/>Therein he set also a king's
demesne-land, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2280395" n="18.550-18.551"><mod n="wherein:simpsub">in which</mod>

<s xml:id="sent2280396" n="18.552-18.553">Some handfuls were falling in

<s xml:id="sent2280397" n="18.554">Three binders stood hard by them,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2280398" n="18.554-18.556">while behind them

<s xml:id="sent2280399" n="18.556-18.557">and among

<s xml:id="sent2280400" n="18.558-18.559" >And heralds apart beneath an oak were making ready a feast, and

<s xml:id="sent2280401" n="18.559-18.560">and the women <milestone n="560" unit="line"/>sprinkled the flesh with white barley in

<s xml:id="sent2280402" n="18.561-18.562">Therein he set also a vineyard

<s xml:id="sent2280404" n="18.564-18.565">And around it he <mod n="drave:simpsub">drove</mod> a

<s xml:id="sent2280409" n="18.573">And therein he <sic>wrought</sic> a herd of

<s xml:id="sent2280411" n="18.577-18.578">And golden were the herdsmen

<s xml:id="sent2280412" n="18.579-18.580">But two <sic>dread</sic> lions <mod n="amid:simpsub">among</mod> the foremost <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod>

<s xml:id="sent2280418" n="18.587-18.589">Therein also the famed god of

<s xml:id="sent2280431" n="19.1-19.2"><milestone n="1" unit="line"/>Now

<s xml:id="sent2280599" n="19.312-19.313">but no whit would his heart be comforted until he

<s xml:id="sent2280600" n="19.314">And as he thought thereon he heaved a heavy sigh and

<s xml:id="sent2280602" n="19.319-19.321">But now <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='liest'>lie</mod>

<s xml:id="sent2280608" n="19.338-19.339">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he weeping, and

<s xml:id="sent2280620" n="19.357-19.361">As when

<s xml:id="sent2280624" n="19.365-19.367"><milestone n="365" unit="line"/>There was a

<s xml:id="sent2280629" n="19.373-19.374">and thereafter grasped the shield great and

<s xml:id="sent2280630" n="19.375-19.377"><milestone n="375" unit="line"/>And as when forth ower the sea there <mod n='appeareth'>appears</mod> to

<s xml:id="sent2280635" n="19.384-19.385">And <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Achilles made

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:20.242-20.272">

<s xml:id="sent2280793" n="20.248-20.249">Glib is

<s xml:id="sent2280794" n="20.250"><milestone n="250" unit="line"/>Whatsoever word <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='speakest'>speak</mod>, such <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod>

<s xml:id="sent2281670" n="23.205-23.207">for I
must go back <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod> the streams of Oceanus, <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod> the land of the
Ethiopians, where they are sacrificing hecatombs to the
immortals, that I too may share in the sacred feast. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2281671" n="23.208-23.211">But Achilles <mod n='prayeth'>prays</mod> the

fair offerings, that so <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> may rouse the pyre to burn <mod n="whereon:simpsub">on which</mod>
<mod n='lieth'>lies</mod> <milestone n="210" unit="line"/>Patroclus, for whom all
the Achaeans groan aloud. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2281672" n="23.212-23.213">When she had thus departed,
and they arose with a wondrous din, driving the clouds tumultuously
before them. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2281673" n="23.214-23.215">And

<s xml:id="sent2281674" n="23.215-23.216">and they came to deep-soiled
Troyland, and fell upon the pyre, and mightily roared the wordrous
blazing fire. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2281675" n="23.217-23.218">So the
whole night long as with one blast they beat upon the flame of the

<s xml:id="sent2281676" n="23.218-23.221" >and the whole night long swift Achilles, taking a two-handled cup
in hand, <milestone n="220" unit="line"/>drew wine from a golden
howl and poured it upon the earth, and wetted the ground, calling
ever upon the spirit of hapless Patroclus. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2281677" n="23.222-23.225">As a father <mod n='waileth'>wails</mod> for his
son, as he <mod n='burneth'>burns</mod> his bones, a son newly wed whose death has

comrade as he burned his bones, <milestone n="225" unit="line" />going heavily about the pyre with ceaseless groaning. </s></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:23.226-23.261">

<s xml:id="sent2281678" n="23.226-23.228">But at the hour when the star

<s xml:id="sent2281679" n="23.229-23.230">And the winds went back again to return to their

<s xml:id="sent2281681" n="23.231-23.232">Then the son of Peleus

<s xml:id="sent2281682" n="23.233">But they that were with the son of

<s xml:id="sent2281683" n="23.234-23.235">Sand the noise and din of their oncoming aroused

<s xml:id="sent2281684" n="23.236-23.238">Son of Atreus, and <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod>

<s xml:id="sent2281685" n="23.238-23.240" >Sand thereafter let us gather the bones of Patroclus,

<s xml:id="sent2281686" n="23.240" >and easy they are to discern, </s>

<s xml:id="sent2281688" n="23.243-23.244">Then let

<s xml:id="sent2281689" n="23.245-23.246"><milestone n="245" unit="line"/><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod> no huge barrow do I <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> you rear with

<s xml:id="sent2281691" n="23.249">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he, and they <mod n="hearkened:simpsub">listened</mod> to

<s xml:id="sent2281692" n="23.250-23.251"><milestone n="250" unit="line"/>First they

<s xml:id="sent2281693" n="23.252-23.254">and with weeping they gathered up the white bones

<s xml:id="sent2281694" n="23.255-23.256"><milestone n="255" unit="line"/>Then they traced

<s xml:id="sent2281695" n="23.256-23.257" >and <sic>forthwith</sic> they piled the up-piled earth. And when they had

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:23.388-23.428">

<s xml:id="sent2282090" n="24.1-24.2">Then was the gathering broken up,

<s xml:id="sent2282091" n="24.2-24.3">The rest bethought them of supper

<s xml:id="sent2282093" n="24.9-24.11">Thinking

<s xml:id="sent2282095" n="24.12-24.13">Neither would he fail to

Troy, and behold Hector, <milestone n="705" unit="line"/>if ever
while yet he lived <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> had joy of his coming back from battle;
since great joy was he to the city and to all the <mod n="folk:simpsub">people</mod>.
</s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:24.707-24.745">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2282468" n="24.707-24.708">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> she, nor was any man
left there within the city, neither any woman, </s>


<s xml:id="sent2282469" n="24.708">for upon all had come grief that
might not be borne; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2282470" n="24.709">and hard
by the gates they met Priam, as he bare home the dead. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2282471" n="24.710-24.712"><milestone n="710" unit="line"/>First Hector's dear wife and queenly mother flung
themselves upon the light-running waggon, and clasping his head the
while, wailed and tore their hair; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2282472" n="24.712">and the <mod n="folk:simpsub">people</mod> thronged about and wept. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2282473" n="24.713-24.715">And now the whole day long
until set of sun had they made lament for Hector with shedding of
tears there without the gates, <milestone n="715" unit="line"/>had
not the old man spoken <mod n="amid:simpsub">among</mod> the <mod n="folk:simpsub">people</mod> <corr n="from out">out of</corr> the <mod n="car:simpsub">chariot</mod>:</s></p>
<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2282474" n="24.716">Make me way for the mules to pass
through; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2282475" n="24.716-24.717" >thereafter shall <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> take your fill of wailing, when I have
brought him to the house. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2282476" n="24.718">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he, and they stood apart and
made way for the waggon. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2282477" n="24.719-24.722">But the others, when they had brought him to the
glorious house, <milestone n="720" unit="line"/>laid him on a corded
bedstead, and by his side set singers, leaders of the dirge, who led
the song of lamentation—they chanted the dirge, and <sic>thereat</sic> the
women made lament. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2282478" n="24.723-24.724">And
<mod n="amid:simpsub">among</mod> these white-armed Andromache led the wailing, holding in her
arms the while the head of man-slaying Hector: </s></p>
<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2282479" n="24.725-24.726"><milestone n="725" unit="line"/>Husband, perished <corr n="from out">out of</corr> of life <corr n="art thou">are you</corr>,
yet in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> youth, and <mod n='leavest'>leave</mod> me a widow in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> halls; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2282480" n="24.726-24.728">and <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> son is still but
a babe, the son born of <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> and me in our haplessness; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2282481" n="24.728-24.729">neither do I <mod n="deem:simpsub">think</mod> that he
will come to manhood, for <mod n="ere:simpsub">before</mod> that shall this city be wasted
utterly. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2282482" n="24.729-24.732">For <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod>
<mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> perished that <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> watch thereover, <milestone n="730" unit="line"/><mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> that <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> guard it, and keep safe its
noble wives and little children. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2282483" n="24.732-24.738">These, I <mod n="ween:simpsub">believe</mod>, shall soon be riding upon the
hollow ships, and I among them; and <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod>, my child, <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> follow
with me to a place where <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> labour at unseemly tasks,
toiling before the face of some ungentle master, or else some
Achaean shall seize <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> by the arm <milestone n="735" unit="line"/>and hurl <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> from the wall, a woeful death,
being <mod n="wroth:simpsub">angry</mod> <corr n="for that">for</corr> Hector <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> his brother <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod>, or his
father, or his son, seeing that full many Achaeans at the hands
of Hector have bitten the vast earth with their teeth; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2282484" n="24.739">for <mod n="nowise:simpsub">in no way</mod> gentle was <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> father
in woeful war. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2282485" n="24.740-24.742" ><milestone n="740" unit="line"/>Therefore the <mod n="folk:simpsub">people</mod> wail for
him throughout the city, and grief unspeakable and sorrow <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod>
<mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> brought upon <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> parents, Hector; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2282486" n="24.742">and for me beyond all others
shall grievous woes be left. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2282487" n="24.743-24.745">For at <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> death <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> neither stretch
out <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> hands to me from <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> bed, nor speak to me any word of
wisdom <mod n="whereon:simpsub">on which</mod> <milestone n="745" unit="line"/>I might have
pondered night and day with shedding of tears. </s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:24.746-24.775">
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2282488" n="24.746">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> she wailing, and <sic>thereat</sic> the
women made lament. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2282489" n="24.747">And among
them Hecabe in turns led the vehement wailing:</s></p>
<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2282490" n="24.748-24.749">Hector, far dearest to my
heart of all my children, <sic>lo</sic>, when <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> livedst <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wast:simpsub">were</mod> dear
to the gods, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2282491" n="24.750"><milestone n="750" unit="line"/>and therefore have they had care of
<mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> for all <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> in the doom of death. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2282492" n="24.751-24.753">For of other sons of mine
<mod n="whomsoever:simpsub">whoever</mod> he took would swift-footed Achilles sell beyond the
unresting sea, <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod> Samos and Imbros and Lemnos, shrouded in
smoke, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2282493" n="24.754-24.756">but, when
from <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> he had taken away <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> life with the long-edged bronze
<milestone n="755" unit="line"/>oft would he drag <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> about
the barrow of his comrade, Patroclus, whom <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> <mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod>;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2282494" n="24.756"><mod n="howbeit:simpsub">however</mod> even so might he
not raise him up. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2282495" n="24.757-24.759" >all dewy-fresh <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='liest'>lie</mod> in my halls as wert <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> g newly
slain, like as one whom Apollo of the silver bow <mod n='assaileth'>assails</mod> with
his gentle shafts and <mod n='slayeth'>slays</mod>. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2282496" n="24.760"><milestone n="760" unit="line"/>So
<mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> she wailing, and roused unabating lament. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2282497" n="24.761">And thereafter Helen was the third
to lead the wailing:</s></p>
<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2282498" n="24.762-24.764">Hector, far dearest to my
heart of all my husband's brethren! In <mod n="sooth:simpsub">truth</mod> my husband is
godlike Alexander, that brought me to Troy-land — </s>


<s xml:id="sent2282499" n="24.764">would I died <mod n="ere:simpsub">before</mod> then! </s>


<s xml:id="sent2282500" n="24.765-24.766"><milestone n="765" unit="line"/>For this is now the twentieth year from the
time when I went from thence and am gone from my native land,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2282501" n="24.767">but never yet heard I
evil or despiteful word from <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2282502" n="24.768-24.772"><sic>nay</sic>, if so be any other <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> reproachfully of
me in the halls, a brother of <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> or a sister, or brother's
fair-robed wife, <milestone n="770" unit="line"/>or <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod>
mother—but <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> father was ever gentle as he had been mine
own—yet wouldst <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> turn them with speech and restrain them by
the gentleness of <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> spirit and <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> gentle words. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2282503" n="24.773"><mod n="Wherefore:simpsub">For which reason</mod> I wail alike for <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>
and for my hapless self with grief at heart; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2282504" n="24.774-24.775">for no longer have I
anyone beside in broad Troy <milestone n="775" unit="line"/>that
is gentle to me or kind; but all men shudder at me. </s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc2:24.776-24.804">
<p>



<s xml:id="sent2282505" n="24.776">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> she wailing, and <sic>thereat</sic> the
countless throng made moan. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2282506" n="24.777" >But the old man Priam <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> among the <mod n="folk:simpsub">people</mod>, saying:</s></p>
<p><q>




<s xml:id="sent2282507" n="24.778-24.779">Bring wood now, <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> men of
Troy, <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod> the city, neither have <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="anywise:simpsub">in any way</mod> fear at heart of a
cunning ambush of the Argives; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2282508" n="24.779-24.781">for <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> Achilles laid upon me this word
<milestone n="780" unit="line"/>when he sent me forth from
the black ships, that he would do us no hurt until the twelfth
dawn be come. </s></q></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2282509" n="24.782-24.783">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> he, and they yoked
oxen and mules to waggons, and speedily thereafter gathered together
before the city. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2282510" n="24.784">For nine
days' space they brought in measureless store of wood, </s>


<s xml:id="sent2282511" n="24.785-24.787"><milestone n="785" unit="line"/>but when the tenth Dawn arose, giving light <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod>
mortals, then bare they forth bold Hector, shedding tears the while,
and on the topmost pyre they laid the dead man, and cast fire
thereon.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2282512" n="24.788-24.789">But soon as early Dawn
appeared, the rosy-fingered, then gathered the <mod n="folk:simpsub">people</mod> about the pyre
of glorious Hector. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2282513" n="24.790-24.792" ><milestone n="790" unit="line"/>And when they were assembled
and met together, first they quenched with flaming wine all the
pyre, so far as the fire's might had come upon it, </s>


<s xml:id="sent2282514" n="24.792-24.794">and thereafter his brethren
and his comrades gathered the white bones, mourning, and big tears
flowed ever down their cheeks. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2282515" n="24.795-24.796"><milestone n="795" unit="line"/>The bones they
took and placed in a golden urn, covering them over with soft purple
robes, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2282516" n="24.797-24.798">and quickly
laid the urn in a hollow grave, and covered it over with great
close-set stones. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2282517" n="24.799-24.800">Then
with speed heaped they the mound, and round about were watchers set
on every side, <milestone n="800" unit="line"/>lest the well-greaved
Achaeans should set upon them before the time. </s>


<s xml:id="sent2282518" n="24.801">And when they had piled the barrow
they went back, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2282519" n="24.801-24.803">and
gathering together duly feasted a glorious feast in the palace of
Priam, the king fostered of Zeus.</s></p>
<p>




<s xml:id="sent2282520" n="24.804">On <corr n="this wise">this way</corr> held they funeral for
horse-taming Hector.</s></p>

<body>
<div type="translation" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-eng3" xml:lang="eng">
<div type="textpart" subtype="book" n="1">
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:1.1-1.43">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2185541" n="1.1-1.2"><milestone ed="p" n="1" unit="line"/>Tell me, O Muse, of the man of many devices, who wandered so very much after he had sacked the sacred citadel of <placeName key="tgn,7002329">Troy</placeName>. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185542" n="1.3-1.5">Many were the men whose cities he saw and whose mind he learned, and many the woes he suffered in his heart upon the sea, <milestone ed="p" n="5" unit="line"/>seeking after his own life and the homecoming of his comrades. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185543" n="1.6">Yet even so he did not save his comrades, though he struggled hard,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185544" n="1.7-1.9">for through their own blind folly they perished—fools, who devoured the cattle of Helios Hyperion.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185545" n="1.9">And so he took from them the day of their homecoming. <milestone ed="p" n="10" unit="line"/>


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185546" n="1.10">Of these things, goddess, daughter of Zeus, beginning where you will, tell also to us.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185547" n="1.11-1.12">Now all the rest, as many as had escaped sheer destruction, were at home, having escaped from both war and sea. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185548" n="1.13-1.15">Odysseus alone, filled with longing for his return and for his wife, the queenly nymph Calypso, that bright goddess, <milestone ed="p" n="15" unit="line"/> kept back in her hollow caves, yearning that he should be her husband. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185549" n="1.16-1.19">But when, as the seasons revolved, the year came in which the gods had ordained that he should return home to <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName>, not even there had he made his escape from toils, even among his own people. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185550" n="1.19-1.20">The gods felt pity, all <milestone ed="p" n="20" unit="line"/> except Poseidon; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185551" n="1.20-1.21">but he continued to rage unceasingly against godlike Odysseus until he reached his own land.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185552" n="1.22-1.25">Poseidon had, however, gone among the far-off Ethiopians—the Ethiopians who dwell split in two, the farthermost of men, some where Hyperion sets and some where he rises, <milestone ed="p" n="25" unit="line"/> there to receive a hecatomb of bulls and rams,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185553" n="1.26">and there he was taking his pleasure, sitting at the feast;

</s> 



<s xml:id="sent2185554" n="1.26-1.27">but the other gods were gathered together in the halls of Olympian Zeus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185555" n="1.28">Among them the father of gods and men was first to speak, 

</s>


<s xml:id="sent2185556" n="1.29-1.30">for in his heart he thought of blameless Aegisthus, <milestone ed="p" n="30" unit="line"/> whom far-famed Orestes, Agamemnon's son, had slain. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185557" n="1.31">Remembering him he spoke among the immortals:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2185558" n="1.32">I can't believe, how ridiculously ready mortals are to blame the gods. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185559" n="1.33-1.39">It is from us, they say, that evils come, but they even themselves, through their own blind folly, have sorrows beyond that which is ordained. <milestone ed="p" n="35" unit="line"/> <milestone unit="para"/> So even now Aegisthus, beyond that which was ordained, took to himself the wedded wife of the son of Atreus, and killed him on his homecoming, although well he knew of sheer destruction, seeing that we told him beforehand, having sent Hermes, the keen-sighted Argeiphontes,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> that he should neither <mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod> the man nor woo his wife;


</s> <milestone ed="p" n="40" unit="line"/>


<s xml:id="sent2185560" n="1.40-1.41">for from Orestes shall come vengeance for the son of Atreus when once he has come to manhood and longs for his own land. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185561" n="1.42-1.43">So Hermes spoke, but for all his good intent he did not persuade the heart of Aegisthus;


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185562" n="1.43">and now he has paid the full price of all.</s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:1.44-1.79">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2185563" n="1.44">Then the goddess, flashing-eyed<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> Athena, answered him: <milestone ed="p" n="45" unit="line"/>


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2185564" n="1.45-1.46">Father of us all, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> son of Cronos, high above all lords, aye, <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> that man lies low in a destruction that is his due; 


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185565" n="1.47">so, too, may any other also be destroyed who does such deeds. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185566" n="1.48-1.50">But my heart is torn for wise Odysseus, hapless man, who far from his friends has long been suffering woes <milestone ed="p" n="50" unit="line"/> in a sea-girt isle, where is the navel of the sea.
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185567" n="1.51-1.54">'Tis a wooded isle, and therein dwells a goddess, daughter of Atlas of <sic>baneful</sic> mind, who knows the depths of every sea, and himself holds the tall pillars which keep earth and heaven apart. <milestone ed="p" n="55" unit="line"/>


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185568" n="1.55-1.57">His daughter it is that keeps back that wretched, sorrowing man; and ever with soft and wheedling words she beguiles him that he may forget <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName>. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185569" n="1.57-1.59">But Odysseus, in his longing to see were it but the smoke leaping up from his own land, yearns to die. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185570" n="1.59-1.60">Yet <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> <milestone ed="p" n="60" unit="line"/> heart <mod n="doth:simpsub">does</mod> not regard it, Olympian. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185571" n="1.60-1.62">Did not Odysseus beside the ships of the Argives offer <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> sacrifice without stint in the broad land of <placeName key="perseus,Troy">Troy</placeName>? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185572" n="1.62"><mod n="Wherefore:simpsub">For which reason</mod> then <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> conceive such wrath<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">2</note> against him, O Zeus?

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2185573" n="1.63">Then Zeus, the cloud-gatherer, answered her and said: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2185684" n="1.280-1.283">Man with twenty rowers the best ship <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod>, and go to seek tidings of <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> father, that has long been gone, if <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> any mortal may tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, or <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='mayest'>may</mod> hear a voice from Zeus, which oftenest brings tidings to men.

<s xml:id="sent2185733" n="1.368-1.371">Wooers of my mother, overweening in your insolence, for the present let us make merry with feasting, <milestone ed="p" n="370" unit="line"/> but let there be no brawling; for this is a goodly thing, to listen to a minstrel such as this man is, like to the gods in voice.

<s xml:id="sent2185763" n="1.420"><milestone ed="p" n="420" unit="line"/>So spoke Telemachus, but in his heart he knew the immortal goddess.</s></p>

<s xml:id="sent2185764" n="1.421-1.422">Now the wooers turned to the dance and to gladsome song, and made them merry, and waited till evening should come;

<s xml:id="sent2185767" n="1.425-1.427"><milestone ed="p" n="425" unit="line"/>But Telemachus, where his chamber was built in the beautiful court, high, in a place of wide outlook, thither went to his bed, pondering many things in mind;

<s xml:id="sent2185769" n="1.434-1.435">She it was who bore for Telemachus the blazing torches; <milestone ed="p" n="435" unit="line"/> for she of all the handmaids loved him most, and had nursed him when he was a child.

<s xml:id="sent2185772" n="1.439-1.442">And she folded and smoothed the tunic <milestone ed="p" n="440" unit="line"/> and hung it on a peg beside the corded<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> bedstead, and then went forth from the chamber, drawing the door to by its silver handle, and driving the bolt home with the thong. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185773" n="1.443-1.444">So there, the night through, wrapped in a fleece of wool, he pondered in his mind upon the journey which Athena had shewn him.</s></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="book" n="2">
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:2.1-2.38">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2185774" n="2.1-2.5"><milestone ed="p" n="1" unit="line"/>Soon as early Dawn appeared, the rosy-fingered, up from his bed arose the dear son of Odysseus and put on his clothing. About his shoulder he slung his sharp sword, and beneath his shining feet bound his fair sandals, <milestone ed="p" n="5" unit="line"/> and went forth from his chamber like a god to look upon. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185775" n="2.6-2.7">Straightway he <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> the clear-voiced heralds to summon to the assembly the long-haired Achaeans. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185776" n="2.8">And the heralds made the summons, and the Achaeans assembled full quickly. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185777" n="2.9-2.11">Now when they were assembled and met together, <milestone ed="p" n="10" unit="line"/>Telemachus went his way to the place of assembly, holding in his hand a spear of bronze—not alone, for along with him two swift hounds followed; 
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185778" n="2.12">and wondrous was the grace that Athena shed upon him,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185779" n="2.13">and all the people marvelled at him as he came. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185780" n="2.14">But he sat down in his father's seat, and the elders gave place.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185781" n="2.15-2.16"><milestone ed="p" n="15" unit="line"/>Then among them the lord Aegyptius was the first to speak, a man bowed with age and wise with wisdom untold. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185782" n="2.17-2.19">Now he spoke, because his dear son had gone in the hollow ships to Ilius, famed for its horses, in the company of godlike Odysseus, even the warrior Antiphus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185783" n="2.19-2.20">But him the savage Cyclops had slain <milestone ed="p" n="20" unit="line"/> in his hollow cave, and made of him his latest meal. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185784" n="2.21-2.22">Three others there were; one, Eurynomus, consorted with the wooers, and two ever kept their father's farm. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185785" n="2.23">Yet, even so, he could not forget that other, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185786" n="2.24">mourning and sorrowing; and weeping for him he addressed the assembly, and spoke among them:
<milestone ed="p" n="25" unit="line"/>


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2185787" n="2.25"><mod n="Hearken:simpsub">Listen</mod> now to me, men of <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName>, to the word that I shall say. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185788" n="2.26-2.27">Never have we held assembly or session since the day when <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus departed in the hollow ships. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185789" n="2.28">And now who has called us together? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185790" n="2.28-2.29">On whom has such need come either of the young men or of those who are older?

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185791" n="2.30-2.31"><milestone ed="p" n="30" unit="line"/>Has he heard some tidings of the army's return,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> which he might tell us plainly, seeing that he has first learned of it himself? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185792" n="2.32">Or is there some other public matter on which he is to speak and address us? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185793" n="2.33">A good man he seems in my eyes, a blessed man. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185794" n="2.33-2.34">May Zeus fulfil <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod> him himself some good, even whatsoever he desires in his heart.

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2185795" n="2.35-2.37"><milestone ed="p" n="35" unit="line"/>So he spoke, and the dear son of Odysseus rejoiced at the word of omen; nor did he thereafter remain seated, but <corr n="was fain">wanted</corr> to speak. So he took his stand in the midst of the assembly,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185796" n="2.37-2.38">and the staff was placed in his hands by the herald Peisenor, wise in counsel.</s></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:2.39-2.83">
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2185797" n="2.39">Then he spoke, addressing first the old man:
<milestone ed="p" n="40" unit="line"/>


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2185798" n="2.40-2.41">Old man, not far off, as <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> soon learn <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod>, is that man who has called the host together—even I;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185799" n="2.41">for on me above all others has sorrow come. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185800" n="2.42-2.46">I have neither heard any tidings of the army's return, which I might tell you plainly, seeing that I had first learned of it myself, nor is there any other public matter on which I am to speak and address you. <sic>Nay</sic>, it is <corr n="mine own">my own</corr> need, <corr n="for that">for</corr> evil has fallen upon my house in two-fold wise. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185801" n="2.46-2.47"><milestone ed="p" n="45" unit="line"/>First, I have lost my noble sire who was once king among you here, and was gentle as a father;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185802" n="2.48-2.49">and now there is come an evil yet greater far, which will presently altogether destroy my house and ruin all my livelihood.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185803" n="2.50-2.54"><milestone ed="p" n="50" unit="line"/>My mother have wooers beset against her will, the sons of those men who are here the noblest. <milestone unit="para"/> They shrink from going to the house of her father, Icarius, that he may himself exact the bride-gifts for his daughter, and give her to whom he will, even to him who meets his favour,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185804" n="2.55-2.58"><milestone ed="p" n="55" unit="line"/> but thronging our house day after day they <mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod> our oxen and sheep and fat goats, and keep revel, and drink the sparkling wine recklessly;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185805" n="2.58">and havoc is made of all this wealth. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185806" n="2.58-2.59">For there is no man here, such as Odysseus was, to ward off ruin from the house.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185807" n="2.60"><milestone ed="p" n="60" unit="line"/>As for me, I am no-wise such as he to ward it off. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185808" n="2.60-2.61"><sic>Nay</sic> <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod>, even if I try I shall be found a weakling and one knowing <mod n="naught:simpsub">nothing</mod> of valor. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185809" n="2.62">Yet truly I would defend myself, if I had but the power;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185810" n="2.63-2.64">for now deeds past all enduring have been <sic>wrought</sic>, and past all that is seemly has my house been destroyed. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185811" n="2.64-2.66">Take shame upon yourselves, <milestone ed="p" n="65" unit="line"/> and have regard to your neighbors who dwell roundabout,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185812" n="2.66-2.67">and fear the wrath of the gods, lest <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> they turn against you in anger at your evil deeds.<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note>

<s xml:id="sent2185813" n="2.68-2.69">I pray you by Olympian Zeus, and by Themis who looses and gathers the assemblies of men,

<s xml:id="sent2185814" n="2.70-2.74"><milestone ed="p" n="70" unit="line"/> forbear, my friends,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">2</note> and leave me alone to pine in bitter grief—unless indeed my father, <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus, despitefully <sic>wrought</sic> the well-greaved Achaeans woe, in requital <sic>whereof</sic> <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> work me woe despitefully by urging these men on.

<s xml:id="sent2185815" n="2.74-2.75">For me it were better <milestone ed="p" n="75" unit="line"/> that <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> should yourselves eat up my treasures and my flocks. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185816" n="2.76">If <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> were to devour them, recompense would <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> be made some day; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185817" n="2.77-2.78">for just so long should we go up and down the city, pressing our suit and asking back our goods, until all was given back. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185818" n="2.79">But now past cure are the woes <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> put upon my heart.

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2185819" n="2.80-2.81"><milestone ed="p" n="80" unit="line"/>Thus he spoke in wrath, and dashed the staff down upon the ground, bursting into tears;

<s xml:id="sent2185820" n="2.81">and pity fell upon all the people. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185821" n="2.82-2.83">Then all the others kept silent, and no man had the heart to answer Telemachus with angry words.</s></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:2.84-2.128">

<s xml:id="sent2185822" n="2.84">Antinous alone answered him, and said:
<milestone ed="p" n="85" unit="line"/>

<q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2185823" n="2.85-2.86">Telemachus, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> braggart, unrestrained in daring, what a thing <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> said, putting us to shame,

<s xml:id="sent2185825" n="2.87-2.88"><sic>Nay</sic>, I tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, it is not the Achaean wooers who are <mod n="anywise:simpsub">in any way</mod> at fault, but <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> own mother, for she is crafty above all women.

<s xml:id="sent2185826" n="2.89-2.90">For it is now the third year and the fourth will soon pass,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note>

<s xml:id="sent2185827" n="2.91-2.92">To all she offers hopes, and has promises for each man, sending them messages,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2185829" n="2.94-2.95">And she devised in her heart this guileful thing also: she set up in her halls a great web, and fell to weaving— <milestone ed="p" n="95" unit="line"/> fine of thread was the web and very wide;</s>

<s xml:id="sent2185833" n="2.103">So she spoke, and our proud hearts consented.

<s xml:id="sent2185834" n="2.104-2.105">Then day by day she would weave at the great web, <milestone ed="p" n="105" unit="line"/> but by night would unravel it, when she had let place torches by her.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185836" n="2.107-2.109">but when the fourth year came as the seasons rolled on, even then one of her women who knew all told us, and we caught her unravelling the splendid web.

<s xml:id="sent2185837" n="2.110"><milestone ed="p" n="110" unit="line"/>So she finished it against her will, perforce. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185838" n="2.111-2.112">Therefore to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> the wooers make answer thus, that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='mayest'>may</mod> <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod> know it in <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> heart, and that all the Achaeans may know.

<s xml:id="sent2185839" n="2.113-2.114">Send away <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> mother, and command her to wed <mod n="whomsoever:simpsub">whoever</mod> her father <mod n="bids:simpsub">commands</mod>, and whoso is pleasing to her.

<s xml:id="sent2185840" n="2.115-2.120"><milestone ed="p" n="115" unit="line"/>But if she shall continue long time to vex the sons of the Achaeans, mindful in her heart of this, that Athena has endowed her above other women with knowledge of fair handiwork and an understanding heart, and wiles, such as we have never yet heard that any even of the women of old knew, of those who long ago were fair-tressed Achaean women— <milestone ed="p" n="120" unit="line"/>Tyro and Alcmene and Mycene of the fair crown—

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185841" n="2.121-2.122">of whom not one was like Penelope in shrewd device; 
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185842" n="2.122">yet this at least she devised not aright. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185843" n="2.123-2.125">For so long shall men devour <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> livelihood and <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> possessions, even as long as she shall keep the counsel which <milestone ed="p" n="125" unit="line"/> the gods now put in her heart.

<s xml:id="sent2185844" n="2.125-2.126">Great fame she brings on herself, but on <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> regret for <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> much substance.

<s xml:id="sent2185845" n="2.127-2.128">For us, we will go neither to our lands nor else <mod n="whither:simpsub">where</mod>, until she marries that one of the Achaeans whom she will.</s></p></q></p>

<s xml:id="sent2185846" n="2.129">Then wise Telemachus answered him, and said: <milestone ed="p" n="130" unit="line"/>

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2185847" n="2.130-2.131">Antinous, in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> may I thrust forth from the house against her will her that bore me and reared me;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185848" n="2.131-2.132">and, as for my father, he is in some other land, whether he be alive or dead. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185849" n="2.132-2.133">An evil thing it were for me to pay back a great price to Icarius, as I must, if of my own will I send my mother away. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185850" n="2.134-2.136">For from her father's hand shall I suffer evil, and heaven <milestone ed="p" n="135" unit="line"/> will send other ills besides, for my mother as she leaves the house will invoke the <sic>dread</sic> Avengers;

<s xml:id="sent2185853" n="2.138-2.140">And for you, if your own heart is <mod n="wroth:simpsub">angry</mod> here at, get you forth from my halls and prepare you other feasts, <milestone ed="p" n="140" unit="line"/> eating your own substance and changing from house to house. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185854" n="2.141-2.143">But if this seems in your eyes to be a better and more profitable thing, that one man's livelihood should be ruined without atonement, waste <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> it.

<s xml:id="sent2185855" n="2.143-2.144">But I will call upon the gods that are forever, if <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> Zeus may grant that deeds of requital may be <sic>wrought</sic>.

<s xml:id="sent2185857" n="2.146-2.147">So spoke Telemachus, and in answer Zeus, whose voice is borne afar,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> sent forth two eagles, flying from on high, from a mountain peak.

<s xml:id="sent2185859" n="2.150-2.152"><milestone ed="p" n="150" unit="line"/> but when they reached the middle of the many-voiced assembly, then they wheeled about, flapping their wings rapidly, and down on the heads of all they looked, and death was in their glare.

<s xml:id="sent2185863" n="2.157-2.158">Then among them spoke the old lord Halitherses, son of Mastor,

<s xml:id="sent2185865" n="2.160"><milestone ed="p" n="160" unit="line"/>He with good intent addressed their assembly, and spoke among them:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2185866" n="2.161"><mod n="Hearken:simpsub">Listen</mod> now to me, men of <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName>, to the word that I shall say;

<s xml:id="sent2185871" n="2.167-2.168">But long <mod n="ere:simpsub">before</mod> that let us take thought how we may make an end of this—

<s xml:id="sent2185874" n="2.170"><milestone ed="p" n="170" unit="line"/>Not as one untried do I prophesy, but with sure knowledge.

<s xml:id="sent2185875" n="2.171-2.173">For <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod> Odysseus I declare that all things are fulfilled even as I told him, when the Argives embarked for <placeName key="tgn,7002329">Ilios</placeName> and with them went Odysseus of many wiles.

<s xml:id="sent2185877" n="2.176">and <sic>lo</sic>, all this is now being brought to pass.</s></q></p>

<s xml:id="sent2185878" n="2.177">Then Eurymachus, son of Polybus, answered him, and said:

<s xml:id="sent2185891" n="2.198-2.202">For <mod n="ere:simpsub">before</mod> that, methinks, the sons of the Achaeans will not cease from their grievous wooing, since in any case we fear no man,— <milestone ed="p" n="200" unit="line"/> no, not Telemachus for all his many words,—nor do we <mod n="reck:simpsub">care</mod> of any soothsaying which <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod>, old man, <mod n='mayest'>may</mod> declare; it will fail of fulfillment, and <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> be hated the more.

<s xml:id="sent2185894" n="2.208">Then wise Telemachus answered him:

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185898" n="2.214-2.217">For I shall go to <placeName key="perseus,Sparta">Sparta</placeName> and to sandy <placeName key="perseus,Pylos">Pylos</placeName>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185899" n="2.218-2.219">If so be I shall hear that my father is alive and coming home, then <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod>, though I am <sic>sore</sic> afflicted, I could endure for yet a year. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2185900" n="2.220-2.223"><milestone ed="p" n="220" unit="line"/>But if I shall hear that he is dead and gone, then I will return to my dear native land and heap up a mound for him, and over it pay funeral rites, full many, as is due, and give my mother to a husband.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:2.224-2.266">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2185901" n="2.224-2.227">So saying he sat down, and among them rose <milestone ed="p" n="225" unit="line"/>Mentor, who was a comrade of noble Odysseus. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2185902" n="2.228">He with good intent addressed their assembly, and spoke among them:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2185903" n="2.229"><mod n="Hearken:simpsub">Listen</mod> now to me, men of <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName>, to the word that I shall say.

<s xml:id="sent2185904" n="2.230-2.232"><milestone ed="p" n="230" unit="line"/>Never henceforth let sceptred king with a ready heart be kind and gentle, nor let him heed righteousness in his heart, but let him ever be harsh and work unrighteousness,

<s xml:id="sent2185905" n="2.233-2.234">seeing that no one remembers divine Odysseus of the people whose lord he was; yet gentle was he as a father.

<s xml:id="sent2185906" n="2.235-2.236"><milestone ed="p" n="235" unit="line"/>But of a truth I begrudge not the proud wooers that they work deeds of violence in the evil contrivings of their minds,

<s xml:id="sent2185908" n="2.239-2.241"><sic>Nay</sic>, rather it is with the rest of the <mod n="folk:simpsub">people</mod> that I am <mod n="wroth:simpsub">angry</mod>, that <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> all <milestone ed="p" n="240" unit="line"/> sit thus in silence, and utter no word of rebuke to make the wooers cease, though <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> are many and they but few.

<s xml:id="sent2185909" n="2.242">Then Leocritus, son of Euenor, answered him:

<s xml:id="sent2186015" n="2.427-2.428">So the wind filled the belly of the sail, and the dark wave sang loudly about the stem of the ship as she went,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186016" n="2.429">and she sped over the wave accomplishing her way.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186017" n="2.430-2.433"><milestone ed="p" n="430" unit="line"/>Then, when they had made the tackling fast in the swift black ship, they set forth bowls brim full of wine, and poured libations to the immortal gods that are forever, and chiefest of all to the flashing-eyed daughter of Zeus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186018" n="2.434">So all night long and through the dawn the ship cleft her way.</s></p>

<s xml:id="sent2186019" n="3.1-3.3"><milestone ed="p" n="1" unit="line"/>And now the sun, leaving the beauteous mere, sprang up into the brazen heaven to give light to the immortals and to mortal men on the earth, the giver of grain;

<s xml:id="sent2186230" n="3.382-3.383">and to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> in return will I sacrifice a sleek<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> heifer, broad of brow, unbroken, which no man <mod n="hath:simpsub">has</mod> yet led beneath the yoke. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186231" n="3.384">Her will I sacrifice, and I will overlay her horns with gold.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2186232" n="3.385"><milestone ed="p" n="385" unit="line"/>So he spoke in prayer, and Pallas Athena heard him. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186233" n="3.386-3.387">Then the horseman, Nestor of <placeName key="perseus,Gerenia">Gerenia</placeName>, led them, his sons and the husbands of his daughters, to his beautiful palace. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186234" n="3.388-3.389">And when they reached the glorious palace of the king, they sat down in rows on the chairs and high seats;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186235" n="3.390-3.392"><milestone ed="p" n="390" unit="line"/> and on their coming the old man mixed for them a bowl of sweet wine, which now in the eleventh year the housewife opened, when she had loosed the string that held the lid. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186236" n="3.393-3.394">Thereof the old man <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> mix a bowl, and earnestly he prayed, as he poured libations, to Athena, the daughter of Zeus who bears the aegis.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186237" n="3.395-3.401"><milestone ed="p" n="395" unit="line"/>But when they had poured libations, and had drunk to their heart's content, they went, each to his home, to take their rest. <milestone unit="para"/> But the horseman, Nestor of <placeName key="perseus,Gerenia">Gerenia</placeName>, <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> Telemachus, the dear son of divine Odysseus, to sleep there on a corded bedstead under the echoing portico, <milestone ed="p" n="400" unit="line"/> and by him Peisistratus, of the good ashen spear, a leader of men, who among his sons was still unwed in the palace. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186238" n="3.402-3.403">But he himself slept in the inmost chamber of the lofty house, and beside him lay the lady his wife, who had strewn the couch.</s></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:3.404-3.446">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2186239" n="3.404-3.408">Soon as early Dawn appeared, the rosy-fingered, <milestone ed="p" n="405" unit="line"/> up from his bed rose the horseman, Nestor of <placeName key="perseus,Gerenia">Gerenia</placeName>, and went forth and sat down on the polished stones which were before his lofty doors, white and glistening as with oil.<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note>

<s xml:id="sent2186240" n="3.408-3.409">On these of old was <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to sit Neleus, the peer of the gods in counsel;

<s xml:id="sent2186241" n="3.410-3.412"><milestone ed="p" n="410" unit="line"/> but he <mod n="ere:simpsub">before</mod> this had been stricken by fate and had gone to the house of Hades, and now there sat upon them in his turn Nestor of <placeName key="perseus,Gerenia">Gerenia</placeName>, the warder of the Achaeans, holding a sceptre in his hands.

<s xml:id="sent2186244" n="3.417">and the horseman, Nestor of <placeName key="perseus,Gerenia">Gerenia</placeName>, was first to speak among them:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2186245" n="3.418-3.420">Quickly, my dear children, fulfil my desire, that first of all the gods I may propitiate Athena, <milestone ed="p" n="420" unit="line"/> who came to me in manifest presence to the rich feast of the god. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186246" n="3.421-3.422">Come now, let one go to the plain for a heifer, that she may come speedily, and that the neatherd may drive her;

<s xml:id="sent2186247" n="3.423-3.424">and let one go to the black ship of great-hearted Telemachus and bring all his comrades, and let him leave two men only;

<s xml:id="sent2186249" n="3.427-3.429">And do <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> others <mod n="abide:simpsub">remain</mod> here together; and <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> the handmaids within to make ready a feast throughout our glorious halls, to fetch seats, and logs to set on either side of the altar, and to bring clear water.

<s xml:id="sent2186250" n="3.430"><milestone ed="p" n="430" unit="line"/>So he spoke, and they all set busily to work. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186251" n="3.430-3.435">The heifer came from the plain and from the swift, shapely ship came the comrades of great-hearted Telemachus; the smith came, bearing in his hands his tools of bronze, the implements of his craft, anvil and hammer and well-made tongs, <milestone ed="p" n="435" unit="line"/> wherewith he <sic>wrought</sic> the gold;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186252" n="3.435-3.436">and Athena came to accept the sacrifice.

<s xml:id="sent2186253" n="3.436-3.437">Then the old man, Nestor, the driver of chariots, gave gold,

<s xml:id="sent2186254" n="3.437-3.438">and the smith prepared it, and overlaid therewith the horns of the heifer, that the goddess might rejoice when she beheld the offering.

<s xml:id="sent2186255" n="3.439">And Stratius and <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Echephron led the heifer by the horns,

<s xml:id="sent2186256" n="3.440-3.443"><milestone ed="p" n="440" unit="line"/> and Aretus came from the chamber, bringing them water for the hands in a basin embossed with flowers, and in the other hand he held barley grains in a basket; and Thrasymedes, steadfast in fight, stood by, holding in his hands a sharp axe, to fell the heifer;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186257" n="3.444">and Perseus held the bowl for the blood.

<s xml:id="sent2186258" n="3.444-3.446">Then the old man, Nestor, driver of chariots, <milestone ed="p" n="445" unit="line"/> began the opening rite of hand-washing and sprinkling with barley grains, and earnestly he prayed to Athena, cutting off as first offering the hair from the head, and casting it into the fire.</s></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:3.447-3.497">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2186259" n="3.447-3.449">Now when they had prayed, and had strewn the barley grains, straightway the son of Nestor, Thrasymedes, high of heart, came near and dealt the blow; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186260" n="3.449-3.450">and the axe cut through the sinews <milestone ed="p" n="450" unit="line"/> of the neck, and loosened the strength of the heifer.

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2186264" n="3.455-3.458"><milestone ed="p" n="455" unit="line"/>And when the black blood had flowed from her and the life had left the bones, at once they cut up the body and straightway cut out the thigh-pieces all in due order, and covered them with a double layer of fat, and laid raw flesh upon them.

</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186267" n="3.461-3.463">But when the thigh-pieces were wholly burned, and they had tasted the inner parts, they cut up the rest and spitted and roasted it, holding the pointed spits in their hands.

<s xml:id="sent2186268" n="3.464-3.465">Meanwhile the fair Polycaste, <milestone ed="p" n="465" unit="line"/> the youngest daughter of Nestor, son of Neleus, bathed Telemachus.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186270" n="3.469">and he went and sat down by Nestor, the shepherd of the people.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186271" n="3.470-3.471"><milestone ed="p" n="470" unit="line"/>Now when they had roasted the outer flesh and had drawn it off the spits, they sat down and feasted,</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186273" n="3.473-3.474">But when they had put from them the desire of food and drink, the horseman, Nestor of <placeName key="perseus,Gerenia">Gerenia</placeName>, was first to speak, saying:
<milestone ed="p" n="475" unit="line"/>


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2186274" n="3.475-3.476">My sons, up, yoke for Telemachus horses with beautiful mane beneath the <mod n="car:simpsub">chariot</mod>, that he may get forward on his journey.

<s xml:id="sent2186275" n="3.477-3.478">So he spoke, and they readily <mod n="hearkened:simpsub">listened</mod> and obeyed; and quickly they yoked beneath the <mod n="car:simpsub">chariot</mod> the swift horses. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186276" n="3.479-3.480">And the housewife placed in the <mod n="car:simpsub">chariot</mod> bread and wine <milestone ed="p" n="480" unit="line"/> and dainties, such as kings, fostered of Zeus, are <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to eat. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186277" n="3.481">Then Telemachus mounted the beautiful <mod n="car:simpsub">chariot</mod>,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186278" n="3.482-3.485">and Peisistratus, son of Nestor, a leader of men, mounted beside him, and took the reins in his hands. He touched the horses with the whip to start them, and nothing loath the pair sped on <milestone ed="p" n="485" unit="line"/> to the plain, and left the steep citadel of <placeName key="perseus,Pylos">Pylos</placeName>. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186279" n="3.486">So all day long they shook the yoke which they bore about their necks.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186280" n="3.487-3.489">Now the sun set and all the ways grew dark. And they came to Pherae, to the house of Diocles, son of Ortilochus, whom Alpheus begot.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186281" n="3.490"><milestone ed="p" n="490" unit="line"/>There they spent the night, and before them he set the entertainment due to strangers.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186282" n="3.491-3.492">So soon as early Dawn appeared, the rosy-fingered, they yoked the horses and mounted the inlaid <mod n="car:simpsub">chariot</mod>,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186283" n="3.493">and drove forth from the gateway and the echoing portico. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186284" n="3.494">Then Peisistratus touched the horses with the whip to start them, and nothing loath the pair sped onward.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186285" n="3.495-3.496"><milestone ed="p" n="495" unit="line"/>So they came to the wheat-bearing plain, and thereafter pressed on toward their journey's end, </s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186287" n="3.497">And the sun set and all the ways grew dark.</s></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:4.1-4.48">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2186288" n="4.1-4.2"><milestone ed="p" n="1" unit="line"/>And they came to the hollow land of <placeName key="tgn,7011065">Lacedaemon</placeName> with its many ravines, and drove to the palace of glorious Menelaus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186289" n="4.3-4.4">Him they found giving a marriage feast to his many <mod n="kinsfolk:simpsub">family</mod> for his noble son and daughter within his house.

<s xml:id="sent2186290" n="4.5"><milestone ed="p" n="5" unit="line"/>His daughter he was sending to the son of Achilles, breaker of the ranks of men,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186291" n="4.6-4.7">for in the land of <placeName key="perseus,Troy">Troy</placeName> he first had promised and pledged that he would give her, and now the gods were bringing their marriage to pass. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186292" n="4.8-4.9">Her then he was sending forth with horses and chariots to go her way to the glorious city of the Myrmidons, over whom her lord was king;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186293" n="4.10-4.12"><milestone ed="p" n="10" unit="line"/> but for his son he was bringing to his home from <placeName key="perseus,Sparta">Sparta</placeName> the daughter of Alector, even for the stalwart Megapenthes, who was his son well-beloved,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> born of a slave woman; 


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186294" n="4.12-4.14">for to Helen the gods <mod n="vouchsafed:simpsub">promised</mod> issue no more after that she had at the first borne her lovely child, Hermione, who had the beauty of golden Aphrodite.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186295" n="4.15-4.17"><milestone ed="p" n="15" unit="line"/>So they were feasting in the great high-roofed hall, the neighbors and <mod n="kinsfolk:simpsub">family</mod> of glorious Menelaus, and making merry; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186296" n="4.17-4.19">and among them a divine minstrel was singing to the lyre, and two tumblers whirled up and down through the midst of them, as he began his song.

<s xml:id="sent2186297" n="4.20-4.22"><milestone ed="p" n="20" unit="line"/>Then the two, the prince Telemachus and the glorious son of Nestor, halted at the gateway of the palace, they and their two horses. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186298" n="4.22-4.25">And the lord Eteoneus came forth and saw them, the busy squire of glorious Menelaus; and he went through the hall to bear the tidings to the shepherd of the people. <milestone ed="p" n="25" unit="line"/>So he came near and spoke to him winged words:


</s>
<q>



<s xml:id="sent2186299" n="4.26-4.27">Here are two strangers, Menelaus, fostered of Zeus, two men that are like the seed of great Zeus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186300" n="4.28-4.29">But tell me, shall we unyoke for them their swift horses, or send them on their way to some other host, who will give them entertainment?

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2186301" n="4.30"><milestone ed="p" n="30" unit="line"/>Then, stirred to <sic>sore</sic> displeasure, fair-haired Menelaus spoke to him: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2186302" n="4.31-4.32">Aforetime <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> was not <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to be a fool, Eteoneus, son of Boethous,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186303" n="4.32">but now like a child <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> talkest folly. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186304" n="4.33-4.35">Surely we two ate full often hospitable cheer of other men, <mod n="ere:simpsub">before</mod> we came <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod> in the hope that Zeus <milestone ed="p" n="35" unit="line"/> would hereafter grant us respite from sorrow. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186305" n="4.35-4.36"><sic>Nay</sic>, unyoke the strangers' horses, and lead the men forward into the house, that they may feast.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2186306" n="4.37-4.38">So he spoke, and the other hastened through the hall, and called to the other busy squires to follow along with him. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186307" n="4.39-4.43">They loosed the sweating horses from beneath the yoke <milestone ed="p" n="40" unit="line"/> and tied them at the stalls of the horses, and flung before them spelt, and mixed therewith white barley.
