</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186308" n="4.43-4.44">But at the sight they marvelled as they passed through the palace of the king, fostered of Zeus;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186309" n="4.45-4.46"><milestone ed="p" n="45" unit="line"/> for there was a gleam as of sun or moon over the high-roofed house of glorious Menelaus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186310" n="4.47-4.48">But when they had satisfied their eyes with gazing they went into the polished baths and bathed.</s></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:4.49-4.99">
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2186311" n="4.49-4.51">And when the maids had bathed them and anointed them with oil, <milestone ed="p" n="50" unit="line"/> and had cast about them fleecy cloaks and tunics, they sat down on chairs beside Menelaus, son of Atreus.

</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186314" n="4.55-4.56"><milestone ed="p" n="55" unit="line"/>And the grave housewife brought and set before them bread, and therewith dainties in abundance, giving freely of her store.

<s xml:id="sent2186315" n="4.57-4.58">And a carver lifted up and placed before them platters of all manner of meats, and set by them golden goblets.

<s xml:id="sent2186316" n="4.59">Then fair-haired Menelaus greeted the two and said:
<milestone ed="p" n="60" unit="line"/>

<s xml:id="sent2186317" n="4.60">Take of the food, and be glad, 

</s>


<s xml:id="sent2186318" n="4.60-4.62">and then when you have supped, we will ask you who among men you are; 

</s>


<s xml:id="sent2186319" n="4.62-4.64">for in you two the breed of your sires is not lost, but <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> are of the breed of men that are sceptred kings, fostered of Zeus; for base churls could not beget such sons as you.

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2186320" n="4.65-4.66"><milestone ed="p" n="65" unit="line"/>So saying he took in his hands roast meat and set it before them, even the fat ox-chine which they had set before himself as a mess of honor.

<s xml:id="sent2186322" n="4.68-4.70">But when they had put from them the desire of food and drink, <sic>lo</sic>, then Telemachus spoke to the son of Nestor, <milestone ed="p" n="70" unit="line"/> holding his head close to him, that the others might not hear:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2186323" n="4.71-4.73">Son of Nestor, dear to this heart of mine, mark the flashing of bronze throughout the echoing halls, and the flashing of gold, of electrum,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> of silver, and of ivory. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186324" n="4.74-4.75">Of such sort, methinks, is the court of Olympian Zeus within, <milestone ed="p" n="75" unit="line"/> such untold wealth is here;</s>

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2186326" n="4.75-4.76">Now as he spoke fair-haired Menelaus heard him, and he spoke and addressed them with winged words:

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186329" n="4.80-4.81"><milestone ed="p" n="80" unit="line"/> but of men another might vie with me in wealth or <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> might not. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186330" n="4.81-4.85">For of a truth after many woes and wide wanderings I brought my wealth home in my ships and came in the eighth year. Over <placeName key="tgn,1000112">Cyprus</placeName> and <placeName key="tgn,6004687">Phoenicia</placeName> I wandered, and <placeName key="tgn,7016833">Egypt</placeName>, and I came to the Ethiopians and the Sidonians and the Erembi, <milestone ed="p" n="85" unit="line"/> and to <placeName key="tgn,1000172">Libya</placeName>, where the lambs are horned from their birth.<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186331" n="4.86">For there the ewes bear their young <mod n="thrice:simpsub">three times</mod> within the full course of the year; 
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186332" n="4.87-4.89">there neither master nor shepherd has any lack of cheese or of meat or of sweet milk, but the flocks ever yield milk to the milking the year through.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186333" n="4.90-4.92"><milestone ed="p" n="90" unit="line"/>While I wandered in those lands gathering much livelihood, meanwhile another <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> my brother by stealth and at unawares, by the guile of his accursed wife. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186334" n="4.93">Thus, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='mayest'>may</mod> see, I have no joy in being lord of this wealth; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186335" n="4.94-4.96">and you may well have heard of this from your fathers, whosoever they <milestone ed="p" n="95" unit="line"/> may be, for full much did I suffer, and let fall into ruin a stately house and one stored with much goodly treasure. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186336" n="4.97-4.99">Would that I dwelt in my halls with but a third part of this wealth, and that those men were safe who then perished in the broad land of <placeName key="perseus,Troy">Troy</placeName> far from horse-pasturing <placeName key="perseus,Argos">Argos</placeName>.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:4.100-4.146"> <milestone ed="p" n="100" unit="line"/>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2186337" n="4.100-4.103">And yet, though I often sit in my halls weeping and sorrowing for them all—one moment indeed I ease my heart with weeping, and then again I cease, 
</s>

<s xml:id="sent2186447" n="4.316-4.317">Menelaus, son of Atreus, fostered of Zeus, leader of hosts, I came if <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='mightest'>might</mod> tell me some tidings of my father.

<s xml:id="sent2186455" n="4.335-4.340"><milestone ed="p" n="335" unit="line"/>Even as when in the thicket-lair of a mighty lion a hind has laid to sleep her new-born suckling fawns, and roams over the mountain slopes and grassy vales seeking pasture, and then the lion comes to his lair and upon the two<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> lets loose a cruel doom, <milestone ed="p" n="340" unit="line"/> so will Odysseus let loose a cruel doom upon these men.

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:4.512-4.553">

<p><q>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2186558" n="4.512-4.513">But <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> brother escaped, indeed, the fates and shunned them with his hollow ships,

<s xml:id="sent2186564" n="4.526-4.527">and he had been keeping guard for a year, lest Agamemnon should pass by him unseen, and be mindful of his furious might.

<s xml:id="sent2186568" n="4.532-4.533">Then he went with chariot and horses to summon Agamemnon, shepherd of the people, his mind pondering a dastardly deed.

<s xml:id="sent2186570" n="4.536-4.537">And not one of the comrades of the son of Atreus was left, of all that followed him, nor one of the men of Aegisthus, but they were all slain in the halls.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2186571" n="4.538-4.540">So he spoke, and my spirit was broken within me, and I wept, as I sat on the sands, nor had my heart <milestone ed="p" n="540" unit="line"/> any longer desire to live and to behold the light of the sun.

<s xml:id="sent2186572" n="4.541-4.542">But when I had had my fill of weeping and writhing, then the unerring old man of the sea said to me:</s></p>

<s xml:id="sent2186576" n="4.548-4.550">So he spoke, and my heart and spirit were again warmed with comfort in my breast despite my grief, <milestone ed="p" n="550" unit="line"/> and I spoke, and addressed him with winged words:</s></p>

<s xml:id="sent2186579" n="4.553">Fain would I hear, despite my grief.</s></q></p></q></p>

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2186780" n="5.50"><milestone ed="p" n="50" unit="line"/>On to <placeName key="tgn,7002729">Pieria</placeName> he stepped from the upper air, and he swooped down upon the sea,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186781" n="5.51-5.53">and then sped over the wave like a bird, the cormorant, which in quest of fish over the <sic>dread</sic> gulfs of the unresting sea wets its thick plumage in the brine. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186782" n="5.54">In such wise did Hermes ride upon the multitudinous waves.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186783" n="5.55-5.58"><milestone ed="p" n="55" unit="line"/>But when he had reached the island which lay afar, then forth from the violet sea he came to land, and went his way until he came to a great cave, <mod n="wherein:simpsub">in which</mod> dwelt the fair-tressed nymph; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186784" n="5.58">and he found her within. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186785" n="5.59-5.61">A great fire was burning on the hearth, and from afar over the isle there was a fragrance <milestone ed="p" n="60" unit="line"/> of cleft cedar and juniper, as they burned; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186786" n="5.61-5.62">but she within was singing with a sweet voice as she went to and fro before the loom, weaving with a golden shuttle. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186787" n="5.63-5.64">Round about the cave grew a luxuriant wood, alder and poplar and sweet-smelling cypress.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186788" n="5.65-5.67"><milestone ed="p" n="65" unit="line"/> Therein birds long of wing were <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to nest, owls and falcons and sea-crows with chattering tongues, who ply their business on the sea. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186789" n="5.68-5.69">And right there about the hollow cave ran trailing a garden vine, in pride of its prime, richly <sic>laden</sic> with clusters.

<s xml:id="sent2186790" n="5.70-5.71"><milestone ed="p" n="70" unit="line"/>And fountains four in a row were flowing with bright water hard by one another, turned one this way, one that. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186791" n="5.72-5.73">And round about soft meadows of violets and parsley were blooming. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186792" n="5.73-5.74">There even an immortal, who chanced to come, might gaze and marvel, and delight his soul;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186793" n="5.75"><milestone ed="p" n="75" unit="line"/> and there the messenger Argeiphontes stood and marvelled. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186794" n="5.76-5.77">But when he had marvelled in his heart at all things, straightway he went into the wide cave.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186795" n="5.77-5.78">Nor did Calypso, the beautiful goddess, fail to know him, when she saw him face to face; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186796" n="5.79-5.80">for not unknown are <milestone ed="p" n="80" unit="line"/> the immortal gods to one another, even though one dwells in a home far away. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186797" n="5.81-5.83">But the great-hearted Odysseus he found not within; for he sat weeping on the shore, as his <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> had been, racking his soul with tears and groans and griefs, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186798" n="5.84">and he would look over the unresting sea, shedding tears.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186799" n="5.85-5.86"><milestone ed="p" n="85" unit="line"/>And Calypso, the beautiful goddess, questioned Hermes, when she had made him sit on a bright shining chair:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2186803" n="5.89-5.90">my heart <mod n="bids:simpsub">commands</mod> me fulfil it, <milestone ed="p" n="90" unit="line"/> if fulfil it I can, and it is a thing that <mod n="hath:simpsub">has</mod> fulfillment.

<s xml:id="sent2186814" n="5.103-5.104">But it is in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> possible for any other god to evade or make void the will of Zeus, who bears the aegis.

<s xml:id="sent2186829" n="5.137-5.140">But since it is in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> possible for any other god to evade or make void the will of Zeus who bears the aegis, let him go his way, if Zeus thus orders and commands, <milestone ed="p" n="140" unit="line"/> over the unresting sea.

<s xml:id="sent2186852" n="5.180-5.181"><milestone ed="p" n="180" unit="line"/>So he spoke, but Calypso, the beautiful goddess, smiled, and stroked him with her hand, and spoke, and addressed him:

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2186877" n="5.228-5.232">As soon as early Dawn appeared, the rosy-fingered, straightway Odysseus put on a cloak and a tunic, <milestone ed="p" n="230" unit="line"/> and the nymph clothed herself in a long white robe, finely woven and beautiful, and about her waist she cast a fair girdle of gold, and on her head a veil above. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186878" n="5.233">Then she set herself to plan the sending of the great-hearted Odysseus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186879" n="5.234-5.235">She gave him a great axe, well fitted to his hands, <milestone ed="p" n="235" unit="line"/> an axe of bronze, sharpened on both sides; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186880" n="5.235-5.236">and in it was a beautiful handle of olive wood, securely fastened; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186881" n="5.237">and thereafter she gave him a polished adze. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186882" n="5.237-5.240">Then she led the way to the borders of the island where tall trees were standing, alder and poplar and fir, reaching to the skies, <milestone ed="p" n="240" unit="line"/> long dry and well-seasoned, which would float for him lightly. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186883" n="5.241-5.243">But when she had shewn him where the tall trees grew, Calypso, the beautiful goddess, returned homewards, but he fell to cutting timbers, 

</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186885" n="5.244-5.245">Twenty trees in all did he fell, and trimmed them with the axe; <milestone ed="p" n="245" unit="line"/> then he cunningly smoothed them all and made them straight to the line. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186886" n="5.246">Meanwhile Calypso, the beautiful goddess, brought him augers; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186887" n="5.247-5.248">and he bored all the pieces and fitted them to one another, and with pegs and morticings did he hammer it together. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186888" n="5.249-5.251">Wide as a man well-skilled in carpentry marks out the curve of the hull of a freight-ship, <milestone ed="p" n="250" unit="line"/> broad of beam, even so wide did Odysseus make his raft. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186889" n="5.252-5.253">And he set up the deck-beams, bolting them to the close-set ribs, and laboured on; 


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186890" n="5.253">and he finished the raft with long gunwales. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186891" n="5.254">In it he set a mast and a yard-arm, fitted to it,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186892" n="5.255"><milestone ed="p" n="255" unit="line"/> and furthermore made him a steering-oar, wherewith to steer. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186893" n="5.256-5.257">Then he fenced in the whole from stem to stern with willow withes to be a defence against the wave, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186894" n="5.257">and he strewed much brush thereon.<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186895" n="5.258-5.259">Meanwhile Calypso, the beautiful goddess, brought him cloth to make him a sail, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186896" n="5.259">and he fashioned that too with skill.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186897" n="5.260-5.261"><milestone ed="p" n="260" unit="line"/>And he made fast in the raft braces and halyards and sheets, and then with levers<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">2</note> forced it down into the bright sea.</s></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:5.262-5.312">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2186898" n="5.262">Now the fourth day came and all his work was done. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186899" n="5.263-5.264">And on the fifth the beautiful Calypso sent him on his way from the island after she had bathed him and clothed him in fragrant raiment.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186900" n="5.265-5.267"><milestone ed="p" n="265" unit="line"/>On the raft the goddess put a skin of dark wine, and another, a great one, of water, and provisions, too, he put in a wallet. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186901" n="5.267">Therein she put abundance of dainties to satisfy his heart, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186902" n="5.268">and she sent forth a gentle wind and warm. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186903" n="5.269">Gladly then did <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus spread his sail to the breeze;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186904" n="5.270-5.275"><milestone ed="p" n="270" unit="line"/> and he sat and guided his raft skilfully with the steering-oar, nor did sleep fall upon his eyelids, as he watched the Pleiads, and late-setting Bootes, and the Bear, which men also call the Wain, which ever circles where it is and watches Orion, <milestone ed="p" n="275" unit="line"/> and alone has no part in the baths of Ocean. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186905" n="5.276-5.277">For this star Calypso, the beautiful goddess, had bidden him to keep on the left hand as he sailed over the sea. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186906" n="5.278-5.280">For seventeen days then he sailed over the sea, and on the eighteenth appeared the shadowy mountains <milestone ed="p" n="280" unit="line"/> of the land of the Phaeacians, where it lay nearest to him; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186907" n="5.281">and it <mod n="shewed:simpsub">showed</mod> <corr n="like unto">like</corr> a shield in the misty deep.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186908" n="5.282-5.283">But the glorious Earth-shaker, as he came back from the Ethiopians,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> beheld him from afar, from the mountains of the Solymi: 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186909" n="5.283-5.284">for Odysseus was seen of him sailing over the sea;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186910" n="5.284-5.285">and he <mod n="waxed:simpsub">became</mod> the more <mod n="wroth:simpsub">angry</mod> in spirit, <milestone ed="p" n="285" unit="line"/> and shook his head, and thus he spoke to his own heart:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2186911" n="5.286-5.289">Out on it! Surely the gods have changed their purpose regarding Odysseus, while I was among the Ethiopians. And <sic>lo</sic>, he is near to the land of the Phaeacians, where it is his fate to escape from the great bonds of the woe which has come upon him.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186912" n="5.290"><milestone ed="p" n="290" unit="line"/>Aye, but even yet, methinks, I shall drive him to surfeit of evil.

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2186913" n="5.291-5.292">So saying, he gathered the clouds, and seizing his trident in his hands troubled the sea,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186914" n="5.292-5.294">and  he roused all blasts of all manner of winds, and hid with clouds land and sea alike; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186915" n="5.294">and night rushed down from heaven.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186916" n="5.295-5.296"><milestone ed="p" n="295" unit="line"/>Together the East Wind and the South Wind dashed, and the fierce-blowing West Wind and the <placeName key="tgn,2550011">North Wind</placeName>, born in the bright heaven, rolling before him a mighty wave. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186917" n="5.297-5.298">Then were the knees of Odysseus loosened and his heart melted, and deeply moved he spoke to his own mighty spirit:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2186918" n="5.299">Ah me, wretched that I am! What is to befall me at the last?

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186919" n="5.300-5.302"><milestone ed="p" n="300" unit="line"/>I fear me that <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> all that the goddess said was true, when she declared that on the sea, before ever I came to my native land, I should fill up my measure of woes; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186920" n="5.302">and <sic>lo</sic>, all this now is being brought to pass. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186921" n="5.303-5.305">In such wise does Zeus overcast the broad heaven with clouds, and has stirred up the sea, and the blasts <milestone ed="p" n="305" unit="line"/> of all manner of winds sweep upon me; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186922" n="5.305">now is my utter destruction sure. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186923" n="5.306-5.307"><mod n="Thrice:simpsub">Three times</mod> blessed those Danaans, aye, four times blessed, who of old perished in the wide land of <placeName key="tgn,7014164">Troy</placeName>, doing the pleasure of the sons of Atreus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186924" n="5.308-5.310">Even so would that I had died and met my fate on that day when the throngs <milestone ed="p" n="310" unit="line"/> of the Trojans hurled upon me bronze-tipped spears, fighting around the body of the dead son of Peleus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186925" n="5.311">Then should I have got funeral rites, and the Achaeans would have spread my fame, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186926" n="5.312">but now by a miserable death was it appointed me to be cut off.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:5.313-5.364">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2186927" n="5.313-5.314">Even as thus he spoke the great wave <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> him from on high, rushing upon him with terrible might, and around it whirled his raft.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186928" n="5.315-5.316"><milestone ed="p" n="315" unit="line"/>Far from the raft he fell, and let fall the steering-oar from his hand; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186929" n="5.316-5.318">but his mast was broken in the midst by the fierce blast of tumultuous winds that came upon it, and far in the sea sail and yardarm fell. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186930" n="5.319-5.320">As for him, long time did the wave hold him in the depths, nor could he <milestone ed="p" n="320" unit="line"/> rise at once from beneath the onrush of the mighty wave, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186931" n="5.321">for the garments which beautiful Calypso had given him weighed him down. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186932" n="5.322-5.323">At length, however, he came up, and spat forth from his mouth the bitter brine which flowed in streams from his head.

<s xml:id="sent2186933" n="5.324-5.326">Yet even so he did not forget his raft, in evil case though he was, <milestone ed="p" n="325" unit="line"/> but sprang after it <mod n="amid:simpsub">among</mod> the waves, and laid hold of it, and sat down in the midst of it, seeking to escape the doom of death; 

</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186935" n="5.328-5.330">As when in autumn the <placeName key="tgn,2550011">North Wind</placeName> bears the thistle-tufts over the plain, and close they cling to one another, <milestone ed="p" n="330" unit="line"/> so did the winds bear the raft this way and that over the sea. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186936" n="5.331-5.332">Now the South Wind would fling it to the <placeName key="tgn,2550011">North Wind</placeName> to be driven on, and now again the East Wind would yield it to the <placeName key="tgn,2081336">West Wind</placeName> to drive.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186937" n="5.333-5.335">But the daughter of <placeName key="tgn,2078692">Cadmus</placeName>, Ino of the fair ankles, saw him, even Leucothea, who of old was a mortal of human speech, <milestone ed="p" n="335" unit="line"/> but now in the deeps of the sea has won a share of honor from the gods. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186938" n="5.336-5.338">She was touched with pity for Odysseus, as he wandered and was in <sic>sore</sic> travail, and she rose up from the deep like a sea-mew on the wing, and sat on the stoutly-bound raft, and spoke, saying:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2186939" n="5.339-5.340">Unhappy man, how is it that Poseidon, the earth-shaker, <milestone ed="p" n="340" unit="line"/> has conceived such furious wrath against <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, that he is sowing for <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> the seeds of many evils? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186940" n="5.341">Yet <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> he shall not utterly destroy <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> for all his rage. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186941" n="5.342"><sic>Nay</sic>, do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> thus; and methinks <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> not lack understanding. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186942" n="5.343-5.345">Strip off these garments, and leave <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> raft to be driven by the winds, but do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> swim with <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> hands and so strive to reach <milestone ed="p" n="345" unit="line"/> the land of the Phaeacians, where it is <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> fate to escape.

<s xml:id="sent2186943" n="5.346-5.347">Come, take this veil, and stretch it beneath <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> breast. It is immortal;

<s xml:id="sent2186944" n="5.347">there is no fear that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> suffer <mod n="aught:simpsub">anything</mod> or perish. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186945" n="5.348-5.350">But when with <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> hands <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> laid hold of the land, loose it from <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, and cast it into the wine-dark sea <milestone ed="p" n="350" unit="line"/> far from the land, and <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod> turn away.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2186946" n="5.351-5.353">So saying, the goddess gave him the veil, and herself plunged again into the surging deep, like a sea-mew; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186947" n="5.353">and the dark wave hid her. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186948" n="5.354-5.355">Then the much-enduring, <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus pondered, <milestone ed="p" n="355" unit="line"/> and deeply moved he spoke to his own mighty spirit:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2186949" n="5.356-5.357">Woe is me! Let it not be that some one of the immortals is again weaving a snare for me, that she <mod n="bids:simpsub">commands</mod> me leave my raft. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186950" n="5.358-5.359"><sic>Nay</sic>, but <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> I will not yet obey, for afar off mine eyes beheld the land, where she said I was to escape.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186951" n="5.360"><milestone ed="p" n="360" unit="line"/>But this will I do, and meseems that this is best: 
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186952" n="5.361-5.362">as long as the timbers hold firm in their fastenings, so long will I remain here and endure to suffer affliction; 
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186953" n="5.363-5.364">but when the wave shall have shattered the raft to pieces, I will swim, seeing that there is <mod n="naught:simpsub">nothing</mod> better to devise.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:5.365-5.407">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2186954" n="5.365-5.367"><milestone ed="p" n="365" unit="line"/>While he pondered thus in mind and heart, Poseidon, the earth-shaker, made to rise up a great wave, <sic>dread</sic> and grievous, arching over from above, and drove it upon him. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186955" n="5.368-5.369">And as when a strong wind tosses a heap of straw that is dry, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186956" n="5.369">and some it scatters here, some there,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186957" n="5.370"><milestone ed="p" n="370" unit="line"/> even so the wave scattered the long timbers of the raft. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186958" n="5.370-5.372">But Odysseus bestrode one plank, as though he were riding a horse, and stripped off the garments which beautiful Calypso had given him. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186959" n="5.373-5.375">Then straightway he stretched the veil beneath his breast, and flung himself headlong into the sea with hands outstretched, <milestone ed="p" n="375" unit="line"/> ready to swim. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186960" n="5.375-5.376">And the lord, the earth-shaker, saw him, and he shook his head, and thus he spoke to his own heart:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2186961" n="5.377-5.378">So now, after <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> suffered many ills, go wandering over the deep, till <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> comest among the <mod n="folk:simpsub">people</mod> fostered of Zeus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186962" n="5.379">Yet even so, methinks, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> not make any mock at <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> suffering.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2186963" n="5.380-5.381"><milestone ed="p" n="380" unit="line"/>So saying, he lashed his fair-maned horses, and came to <placeName key="tgn,1041944">Aegae</placeName>, where is his glorious palace.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186964" n="5.382">But Athena, daughter of Zeus, took other counsel. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186965" n="5.383-5.384">She stayed the paths of the other winds, and <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> them all cease and be lulled to rest;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186966" n="5.385-5.387"><milestone ed="p" n="385" unit="line"/> but she roused the swift <placeName key="tgn,2550011">North Wind</placeName>, and broke the waves before him, to the end that Zeus-born Odysseus might come among the Phaeacians, lovers of the oar, escaping from death and the fates.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186967" n="5.388-5.389">Then for two nights and two days he was driven about over the swollen waves, and full often his heart forboded destruction.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186968" n="5.390-5.392"><milestone ed="p" n="390" unit="line"/>But when fair-tressed Dawn brought to its birth the third day, then the wind ceased and there was a windless calm, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186969" n="5.392-5.393">and he caught sight of the shore close at hand, casting a quick glance forward, as he was raised up by a great wave. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186970" n="5.394-5.399">And even as when most welcome to his children appears the life <milestone ed="p" n="395" unit="line"/> of a father who lies in sickness, bearing grievous pains, long while wasting away, and some cruel god assails him, but then to their joy the gods free him from his woe, so to Odysseus did the land and the wood seem welcome; and he swam on, eager to set foot on the land.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186971" n="5.400-5.401"><milestone ed="p" n="400" unit="line"/>But when he was as far away as a man's voice carries when he shouts, and heard the boom of the sea upon the reefs—

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186972" n="5.402-5.403">for the great wave thundered against the dry land, belching upon it in terrible fashion, and all things were wrapped in the foam of the sea; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186973" n="5.404">for there were neither harbors where ships might ride, nor road-steads,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186974" n="5.405"><milestone ed="p" n="405" unit="line"/> but projecting headlands, and reefs, and cliffs—

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186975" n="5.406-5.407">then the knees of Odysseus were loosened and his heart melted, and deeply moved he spoke to his own mighty spirit:</s></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:5.408-5.450">

<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2186976" n="5.408-5.410">Ah me, when Zeus has at length granted me to see the land beyond my hopes, and <sic>lo</sic>, I have prevailed to cleave my way and to cross this gulf, <milestone ed="p" n="410" unit="line"/> nowhere <mod n="doth:simpsub">does</mod> there appear a way to come forth from the grey sea. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186977" n="5.411-5.414">For without are sharp crags, and around them the wave roars foaming, and the rock runs up sheer, and the water is deep close in shore, so that in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> is it possible to plant both feet firmly and escape ruin.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186978" n="5.415-5.416"><milestone ed="p" n="415" unit="line"/>Haply were I to seek to land, a great wave may seize me and dash me against the jagged rock, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186979" n="5.416">and so shall my striving be in vain. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186980" n="5.417-5.422">But if I swim on yet further in hope to find shelving beaches<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> and harbors of the sea, I fear me lest the storm-wind may catch me up again, <milestone ed="p" n="420" unit="line"/> and bear me, groaning heavily, over the teeming deep; or lest some god may even send forth upon me some great monster <corr n="from out">out of</corr> the sea—and many such does glorious Amphitrite breed. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186981" n="5.423">For I know that the glorious Earth-shaker is filled with wrath against me.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2186982" n="5.424-5.425">While he pondered thus in mind and heart, <milestone ed="p" n="425" unit="line"/> a great wave bore him against the rugged shore. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186983" n="5.426-5.427">There would his skin have been stripped off and his bones broken, had not the goddess, flashing-eyed Athena, put a thought in his mind. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186984" n="5.428-5.429">On he rushed and seized the rock with both hands, and clung to it, groaning, until the great wave went by.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186985" n="5.430-5.431"><milestone ed="p" n="430" unit="line"/>Thus then did he escape this wave, but in its backward flow it once more rushed upon him and <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> him, and flung him far out in the sea. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186986" n="5.432-5.435">And just as, when a cuttlefish is dragged from its hole, many pebbles cling to its suckers, even so from his strong hands <milestone ed="p" n="435" unit="line"/> were bits of skin stripped off against the rocks; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186987" n="5.435">and the great wave covered him. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186988" n="5.436-5.437">Then <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> would hapless Odysseus have perished beyond his fate, had not flashing-eyed Athena given him prudence. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186989" n="5.438-5.440">Making his way forth from the surge where it belched upon the shore, he swam outside, looking ever toward the land in hope to find <milestone ed="p" n="440" unit="line"/> shelving beaches and harbors of the sea. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186990" n="5.441-5.444">But when, as he swam, he came to the mouth of a fair-flowing river, where seemed to him the best place, since it was smooth of stones, and besides there was shelter from the wind, he knew the river as he flowed forth, and prayed to him in his heart:
<milestone ed="p" n="445" unit="line"/>


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2186991" n="5.445">Hear me, O king, whosoever <corr n="thou art">you are</corr>. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186992" n="5.445-5.446">As to one greatly longed-for<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> do I come to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, seeking to escape <corr n="from out">out of</corr> the sea from the threats of Poseidon. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186993" n="5.447-5.449">Reverend even in the eyes of the immortal gods is that man who comes as a wanderer, even as I have now come to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> stream and to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> knees, after many toils.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186994" n="5.450"><milestone ed="p" n="450" unit="line"/><sic>Nay</sic>, pity me, O king, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186995" n="5.450">for I declare that I am <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> suppliant.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:5.451-5.493">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2186996" n="5.451-5.453">So he spoke, and the god straightway stayed his stream, and checked the waves, and made a calm before him, and brought him safely to the mouth of the river. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186997" n="5.453-5.454">And he let his two knees bend and his strong hands fall, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186998" n="5.454">for his spirit was crushed by the sea.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2186999" n="5.455-5.456"><milestone ed="p" n="455" unit="line"/>And all his flesh was swollen, and sea water flowed in streams up through his mouth and nostrils. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187000" n="5.456-5.457">So he lay breathless and speechless, with scarce strength to move; for terrible weariness had come upon him. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187001" n="5.458-5.459">But when he revived, and his spirit returned again into his breast, then he loosed from him the veil of the goddess and let it fall into the river that murmured seaward;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187002" n="5.460-5.462"><milestone ed="p" n="460" unit="line"/> and the great wave bore it back down the stream, and straightway Ino received it in her hands. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187003" n="5.462-5.463">But Odysseus, going back from the river, sank down in the reeds and kissed the earth, the giver of grain; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187004" n="5.464">and deeply moved he spoke to his own mighty spirit:
<milestone ed="p" n="465" unit="line"/>


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187005" n="5.465">Ah, woe is me! what is to befall me? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187006" n="5.465">What will happen to me at the last? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187007" n="5.466-5.468">If here in the river bed I keep watch throughout the weary night, I fear that together the bitter frost and the fresh dew may overcome me, when from feebleness I have breathed forth my spirit; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187008" n="5.469">and the breeze from the river blows cold in the early morning.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187009" n="5.470-5.473"><milestone ed="p" n="470" unit="line"/>But if I climb up the slope to the shady wood and lie down to rest in the thick brushwood, in the hope that the cold and weariness might leave me, and if sweet sleep comes over me, I fear me lest I become a prey and spoil to wild beasts.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2187010" n="5.474">Then, as he pondered, this thing seemed to him the better:

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187011" n="5.475"><milestone ed="p" n="475" unit="line"/> he went his way to the wood and 
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187012" n="5.475-5.476">he found it near the water in a clear space; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187013" n="5.476-5.477">and he crept beneath two bushes that grew from the same spot, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187014" n="5.477">one of thorn and one of olive. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187015" n="5.478-5.480">Through these the strength of the wet winds could never blow, nor the rays of the bright sun beat, nor could the rain pierce through them, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187016" n="5.480-5.481">so closely did they grow, intertwining one with the other. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187017" n="5.481-5.482">Beneath these Odysseus crept 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187018" n="5.482-5.483">and he straightway gathered with his hands a broad bed, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187019" n="5.483-5.485">for fallen leaves were there in plenty, enough to shelter two men or three <milestone ed="p" n="485" unit="line"/> in winter-time, however bitter the weather. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187020" n="5.486-5.487">And the much-enduring <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus saw it, and was glad, and he lay down in the midst, and heaped over him the fallen leaves. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187021" n="5.488-5.491">And as a man hides a brand beneath the dark embers in an outlying farm, a man who has no neighbors, <milestone ed="p" n="490" unit="line"/> and so saves a seed of fire, that he may not have to kindle it from some other source, so Odysseus covered himself with leaves. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187022" n="5.491-5.492">And Athena shed sleep upon his eyes, that it might enfold his lids and speedily free him from toilsome weariness.</s></p>

<s xml:id="sent2187125" n="6.178-6.179">Shew me the city, and give me some rag to throw about me, if <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hadst:simpsub">had</mod> any wrapping for the clothes when <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='camest'>came</mod> <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod>.

<s xml:id="sent2187126" n="6.180-6.182"><milestone ed="p" n="180" unit="line"/>And for <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod>, may the gods grant <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> all that <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> heart desires; a husband and a home may they grant <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, and oneness of heart—a goodly gift. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187127" n="6.182-6.184">For nothing is greater or better than this, when man and wife dwell in a home in one accord, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187128" n="6.184-6.185">a great grief to their foes <milestone ed="p" n="185" unit="line"/> and a joy to their friends; but they know it<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> best themselves.</s></q></p>

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187129" n="6.186">Then white-armed Nausicaa answered him:

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187130" n="6.187">Stranger, since <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='seemest'>seem</mod> to be neither an evil man nor a witless, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187131" n="6.188-6.189">and it is Zeus himself, the Olympian, that gives happy fortune to men, both to the good and the evil, to each man as he will;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187132" n="6.190"><milestone ed="p" n="190" unit="line"/> so to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, I <mod n="ween:simpsub">believe</mod>, he has given this lot, and <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> must in any case endure it. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187133" n="6.191-6.193">But now, since <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> come to our city and land, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> not lack clothing or <mod n="aught:simpsub">anything</mod> else of those things which befit a sore-tried suppliant when he <mod n='cometh'>comes</mod> in the way.

<s xml:id="sent2187134" n="6.194">The city will I <mod n="shew:simpsub">show</mod> <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, and will tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> the name of the people.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187135" n="6.195-6.197"><milestone ed="p" n="195" unit="line"/>The Phaeacians possess this city and land, and I am the daughter of great-hearted Alcinous, upon whom depend the might and power of the Phaeacians.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187136" n="6.198">She spoke, and called to her fair-tressed handmaids:

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187137" n="6.199">Stand, my maidens. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187138" n="6.199"><mod n="Whither:simpsub">Where</mod> do <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> flee at the sight of a man?

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187139" n="6.200"><milestone ed="p" n="200" unit="line"/><mod n="Ye:simpsub">You</mod> do not think, surely, that he is an enemy? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187140" n="6.201-6.203">That mortal man lives not, or exists<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> nor shall ever be born who shall come to the land of the Phaeacians as a foeman, 
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187141" n="6.203">for we are very dear to the immortals. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187142" n="6.204-6.205">Far off we dwell in the surging sea, <milestone ed="p" n="205" unit="line"/> the furthermost of men, and no other mortals have dealings with us. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187143" n="6.206-6.207"><sic>Nay</sic>, this is some hapless wanderer that has come <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod>. Him must we now tend;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187144" n="6.207-6.208">for from Zeus are all strangers and beggars, and a gift, though small, is welcome. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187145" n="6.209-6.210">Come, then, my maidens, give to the stranger food and drink, <milestone ed="p" n="210" unit="line"/> and bathe him in the river in a spot where there is shelter from the wind.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:6.211-6.250">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187146" n="6.211-6.213">So she spoke, and they halted and called to each other. Then they set Odysseus in a sheltered place, as Nausicaa, the daughter of great-hearted Alcinous, <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod>, and 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187147" n="6.214-6.216">beside him they put a cloak and a tunic for raiment, <milestone ed="p" n="215" unit="line"/> and gave him soft olive oil in the flask of gold, and <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> him bathe in the streams of the river. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187148" n="6.217">Then among the maidens spoke <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187149" n="6.218-6.220">Maidens, stand <sic>yonder</sic> apart, that by myself I may wash the brine from my shoulders, and <milestone ed="p" n="220" unit="line"/> anoint myself with olive oil

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187150" n="6.220">for of a truth it is long since oil came near my skin.

<s xml:id="sent2187151" n="6.221">But in your presence will I not bathe, 

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2187153" n="6.223">So he said, and they went apart and told the princess.

<s xml:id="sent2187154" n="6.224-6.226">But with water from the river <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus washed from his skin <milestone ed="p" n="225" unit="line"/> the brine which clothed his back and broad shoulders, and from his head he wiped the scurf of the unresting sea. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187155" n="6.227-6.231">But when he had washed his whole body and anointed himself with oil, and had put on him the raiment which the unwedded maid had given him, then Athena, the daughter of Zeus, made him <milestone ed="p" n="230" unit="line"/> taller to look upon and mightier, and from his head she made the locks to flow in curls <corr n="like unto">like</corr> the hyacinth flower. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187156" n="6.232-6.235">And as when a man overlays silver with gold, a cunning workman whom Hephaestus and Pallas Athena have taught all manner of craft, and full of grace is the work he produces, <milestone ed="p" n="235" unit="line"/> even so the goddess shed grace upon his head and shoulders. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187157" n="6.236-6.237">Then he went apart and sat down on the shore of the sea, gleaming with beauty and grace;

</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187159" n="6.238">She spoke to her fair-tressed handmaids, saying:

<s xml:id="sent2187160" n="6.239">Listen, white-armed maidens, that I may say somewhat.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187161" n="6.240-6.241"><milestone ed="p" n="240" unit="line"/>Not without the will of all the gods who hold <placeName key="tgn,7011019">Olympus</placeName> does this man come among the godlike Phaeacians. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187162" n="6.242-6.243">Before he seemed to me uncouth, but now he is like the gods, who hold broad heaven. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187163" n="6.244-6.245">Would that a man such as he might be called my husband, <milestone ed="p" n="245" unit="line"/> dwelling here, and that it might please him here to remain. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187164" n="6.246">But come, my maidens; give to the stranger food and drink.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2187165" n="6.247-6.248">So she spoke, and they readily <mod n="hearkened:simpsub">listened</mod> and obeyed, and set before Odysseus food and drink.

<s xml:id="sent2187166" n="6.249-6.250">Then <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> did the much-enduring <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus drink and eat, <milestone ed="p" n="250" unit="line"/> ravenously; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187167" n="6.250">for long had he been without taste of food.</s></p>

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187168" n="6.251">But the white-armed Nausicaa took other counsel.

<s xml:id="sent2187174" n="6.262-6.264">But when we are about to enter the city, around which runs a lofty wall,—a fair harbor lies on either side of the city and the entrance is narrow,

<s xml:id="sent2187177" n="6.266-6.267">There, too, is their place of assembly about the fair temple of Poseidon, fitted with huge<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> stones set deep in the earth.

<s xml:id="sent2187178" n="6.268-6.269">Here the men are busied with the tackle of their black ships, with cables and sails, and here they shape the thin oar-blades.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187179" n="6.270-6.272"><milestone ed="p" n="270" unit="line"/>For the Phaeacians care not for bow or quiver, but for masts and oars of ships, and for the shapely ships, rejoicing in which they cross over the grey sea. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187180" n="6.273-6.274">It is their ungentle speech that I shun, lest hereafter some man should taunt me, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187181" n="6.274">for indeed there are insolent <mod n="folk:simpsub">people</mod> in the land,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187182" n="6.275"><milestone ed="p" n="275" unit="line"/> and thus might some baser fellow say, shall he meet us:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187183" n="6.276-6.277">Who is this that follows Nausicaa, a comely man and tall, a stranger?

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187185" n="6.277">He will doubtless be a husband for her. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187186" n="6.278-6.279">Haply she has brought from his ship some wanderer of a <mod n="folk:simpsub">people</mod> that dwell afar—for none are near us—

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187187" n="6.280-6.281"><milestone ed="p" n="280" unit="line"/> or some god, long prayed-for, has come down from heaven in answer to her prayers, and she will have him as her husband all her days. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187188" n="6.282-6.283">Better so, even if she has herself gone forth and found a husband from another people; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187189" n="6.283-6.284">for of a truth she scorns the Phaeacians here in the land, where she has wooers many and noble!

</q>

<s xml:id="sent2187190" n="6.285"><milestone ed="p" n="285" unit="line"/>So will they say, and this would become a reproach to me.

<s xml:id="sent2187191" n="6.286-6.288"><sic>Yea</sic>, I would myself blame another maiden who should do such thing, and in despite of her dear father and mother, while yet they live, should consort with men before the day of open marriage.</s></q></p>

<p><q>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187209" n="6.319-6.320">and she drove with care that <milestone ed="p" n="320" unit="line"/> the maidens and Odysseus might follow on foot, and with judgment did she ply the lash.

<s xml:id="sent2187210" n="6.321-6.322">Then the sun set, and they came to the glorious grove, sacred to Athena. There Odysseus sat him down, 
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187211" n="6.323">and he straightway prayed to the daughter of great Zeus:

<s xml:id="sent2187213" n="6.325-6.326"><milestone ed="p" n="325" unit="line"/><mod n="Hearken:simpsub">Listen</mod> now to my prayer, since aforetime <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> not <mod n="hearken:simpsub">listen</mod> when I was <mod n="smitten:simpsub">struck</mod>, what time the glorious Earth-shaker <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> me.

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187219" n="7.1-7.2"><milestone ed="p" n="1" unit="line"/>So he prayed there, the much-enduring <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus, while the two strong mules bore the maiden to the city.

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2187231" n="7.24-7.25">For I am come <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod> a stranger sore-tried <milestone ed="p" n="25" unit="line"/> from afar, from a distant country;

<s xml:id="sent2187232" n="7.25-7.26"><mod n="wherefore:simpsub">for which reason</mod> I know no one of the people who possess this city and land.

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187234" n="7.28-7.29">Then <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod>, Sir stranger, I will <mod n="shew:simpsub">show</mod> <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> the palace as <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> me, for it lies hard by the house of my own noble father.

<s xml:id="sent2187235" n="7.30-7.31"><milestone ed="p" n="30" unit="line"/>Only go <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> quietly, and I will lead the way. But turn not <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> eyes upon any man nor question any,

<s xml:id="sent2187236" n="7.32-7.33">for the men here endure not stranger-folk, nor do they give kindly welcome to him who comes from another land.

<s xml:id="sent2187237" n="7.34-7.35">They, indeed, trusting in the speed of their swift ships, <milestone ed="p" n="35" unit="line"/> cross over the great gulf of the sea, for this the Earth-shaker has granted them; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187238" n="7.36">and their ships are swift as a bird on the wing or as a thought.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:7.37-7.77">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187239" n="7.37-7.38">So speaking, Pallas Athena led the way quickly,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187240" n="7.38">and he followed in the footsteps of the goddess.

<s xml:id="sent2187241" n="7.39-7.40">And as he went <milestone ed="p" n="40" unit="line"/> through the city in the midst of them, the Phaeacians, famed for their ships, took no heed of him,

<s xml:id="sent2187242" n="7.40-7.42">for fair-tressed Athena, the <sic>dread</sic> goddess, would not suffer it, but shed about him a wondrous mist, for her heart was kind toward him.

<s xml:id="sent2187243" n="7.43-7.45">And Odysseus marvelled at the harbors and the stately ships, at the meeting-places where the heroes themselves gathered, and the walls, long and <milestone ed="p" n="45" unit="line"/> high and crowned with palisades, a wonder to behold.

<s xml:id="sent2187244" n="7.46-7.47">But when they had come to the glorious palace of the king, the goddess, flashing-eyed Athena, was the first to speak, saying:

<s xml:id="sent2187245" n="7.48-7.49">Here, Sir stranger, is the house which <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> me <mod n="shew:simpsub">show</mod> to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>,

<s xml:id="sent2187249" n="7.53">The queen <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> approach first in the palace;

<s xml:id="sent2187250" n="7.54-7.55">Arete is the name by which she is called, <milestone ed="p" n="55" unit="line"/> and she is sprung from the same line as is the king Alcinous. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187251" n="7.56-7.59">Nausithous at the first was born from the earth-shaker Poseidon and Periboea, the comeliest of women, youngest daughter of great-hearted Eurymedon, who once was king over the insolent Giants.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187252" n="7.60"><milestone ed="p" n="60" unit="line"/>But he brought destruction on his <mod n="froward:simpsub">willful</mod> people, and was himself destroyed.

<s xml:id="sent2187255" n="7.64-7.66">Rhexenor, when as yet he had no son, Apollo of the silver bow <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> <milestone ed="p" n="65" unit="line"/> in his hall, a bridegroom though he was, and he left only one daughter, Arete.

<s xml:id="sent2187256" n="7.66-7.68">Her Alcinous made his wife, and honored her as no other woman on earth is honored, of all those who in these days direct their households in subjection to their husbands; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187257" n="7.69-7.72">so heartily is she honored, <milestone ed="p" n="70" unit="line"/> and has ever been, by her children and by Alcinous himself and by the people, who look upon her as upon a goddess, and greet her as she goes through the city. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187258" n="7.73">For she of herself is <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> lacking in good understanding, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187259" n="7.74">and for the women<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> to whom she has good will she makes an end of strife even among their husbands.

<s xml:id="sent2187260" n="7.75-7.77"><milestone ed="p" n="75" unit="line"/>If in her sight <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> win favour, then there is hope that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wilt:simpsub">will</mod> see <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> friends, and return to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> high-roofed house and <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod> <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> native land.</s></q></p>

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187261" n="7.78-7.81">So saying, flashing-eyed Athena departed over the unresting sea, and left lovely <placeName key="tgn,7010886">Scheria</placeName>. <milestone ed="p" n="80" unit="line"/> She came to Marathon and broad-wayed <placeName key="perseus,Athens">Athens</placeName>, and entered the well-built house of Erectheus;

<s xml:id="sent2187263" n="7.82-7.83">There he stood, and his heart pondered much before he reached the threshold of bronze;

<s xml:id="sent2187264" n="7.84-7.85">for there was a gleam as of sun or moon <milestone ed="p" n="85" unit="line"/> over the high-roofed house of great-hearted Alcinous.

<s xml:id="sent2187265" n="7.86-7.87">Of bronze were the walls that stretched this way and that from the threshold to the innermost chamber, and around was a cornice of cyanus.<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">2</note>

<s xml:id="sent2187266" n="7.88">Golden were the doors that shut in the well-built house,

<s xml:id="sent2187267" n="7.89-7.90">and doorposts of silver were set in a threshold of bronze. <milestone ed="p" n="90" unit="line"/> Of silver was the lintel above, and of gold the handle.

<s xml:id="sent2187268" n="7.91-7.94">On either side of the door there stood gold and silver dogs, which Hephaestus had fashioned with cunning skill to guard the palace of great-hearted Alcinous; immortal were they and ageless all their days.<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">3</note>

<s xml:id="sent2187269" n="7.95-7.97"><milestone ed="p" n="95" unit="line"/>Within, seats were fixed along the wall on either hand, from the threshold to the innermost chamber, and on them were thrown robes of soft fabric, cunningly woven, the handiwork of women.

<s xml:id="sent2187272" n="7.100-7.102"><milestone ed="p" n="100" unit="line"/>And golden youths stood on well-built pedestals, holding lighted torches in their hands to give light by night to the banqueters in the hall. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187273" n="7.103-7.106">And fifty slave-women he had in the house, of whom some grind the yellow grain on the millstone, <milestone ed="p" n="105" unit="line"/> and others weave webs, or, as they sit, twirl the yarn, <corr n="like unto">like</corr> the leaves<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> of a tall poplar tree;

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187275" n="7.108-7.110">For as the Phaeacian men are skilled above all others in speeding a swift ship upon the sea, so are the women <milestone ed="p" n="110" unit="line"/> cunning workers at the loom, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187276" n="7.110-7.111">for Athena has given to them above all others skill in fair handiwork, and an understanding heart.

<s xml:id="sent2187277" n="7.112-7.113">But without the courtyard, hard by the door, is a great orchard of four acres,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">3</note>

<s xml:id="sent2187279" n="7.114-7.116">Therein grow trees, tall and luxuriant, <milestone ed="p" n="115" unit="line"/> pears and pomegranates and apple-trees with their bright fruit, and sweet figs, and luxuriant olives. 

</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187281" n="7.118-7.119">and ever does the west wind, as it blows, quicken to life some fruits, and ripen others;

<s xml:id="sent2187285" n="7.127-7.128">There again, by the last row of the vines, grow trim garden beds of every sort, blooming the year through,

<s xml:id="sent2187287" n="7.132">Such were the glorious gifts of the gods in the palace of Alcinous.

<s xml:id="sent2187288" n="7.133">There the much-enduring <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus stood and gazed.

<s xml:id="sent2187289" n="7.134-7.135">But when he had marvelled in his heart at all things, <milestone ed="p" n="135" unit="line"/> he passed quickly over the threshold into the house.

<s xml:id="sent2187290" n="7.136-7.138">There he found the leaders and counsellors of the Phaeacians pouring libations from their cups to the keen-sighted Argeiphontes, to whom they were <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to pour the wine last of all, when they were minded to go to their rest.

<s xml:id="sent2187291" n="7.139-7.141">But the much-enduring <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus went through the hall, <milestone ed="p" n="140" unit="line"/> wrapped in the thick mist which Athena had shed about him, till he came to Arete and to Alcinous the king. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187292" n="7.142-7.143">About the knees of Arete Odysseus cast his hands, and straightway the wondrous mist melted from him, 

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2187295" n="7.145">But Odysseus made his prayer:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187296" n="7.146-7.148">Arete, daughter of godlike Rhexenor, to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> husband and to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> knees am I come after many toils,—aye and to these banqueters,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187298" n="7.151-7.152">But for me do <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> speed my sending, that I may come to my native land, and that quickly; for long time have I been suffering woes far from my friends.</s></q></p>

<s xml:id="sent2187304" n="7.162-7.165">Come, make the stranger to arise, and set him upon a silver-studded chair, and <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> the heralds mix wine, <milestone ed="p" n="165" unit="line"/> that we may pour libations also to Zeus, who hurls the thunderbolt; for he ever attends upon reverend suppliants.

<s xml:id="sent2187306" n="7.167-7.171">When the strong and mighty Alcinous heard this, he took by the hand Odysseus, the wise and crafty-minded, and raised him from the hearth, and set him upon a bright chair <milestone ed="p" n="170" unit="line"/> from which he <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> his son, the kindly<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> Laodamas, to rise; for he sat next to him, and was his best beloved.

<s xml:id="sent2187314" n="7.184-7.185">But when they had poured libations, and had drunk to their heart's content, <milestone ed="p" n="185" unit="line"/> Alcinous addressed the assembly, and spoke among them:

<s xml:id="sent2187315" n="7.186-7.187"><mod n="Hearken:simpsub">Listen</mod> to me, leaders and counsellors of the Phaeacians, that I may say what the heart in my breast <mod n="bids:simpsub">commands</mod> me.

<s xml:id="sent2187317" n="7.189-7.196">But in the morning we will call more of the elders together, <milestone ed="p" n="190" unit="line"/> and will entertain the stranger in our halls and offer goodly victims to the gods. <milestone unit="para"/> After that we will take thought also of his sending, that without toil or pain <sic>yon</sic> stranger may under our sending, come to his native land speedily and with rejoicing, though he come from never so far. <milestone ed="p" n="195" unit="line"/> Nor shall he meanwhile suffer any evil or harm, until he sets foot upon his own land;

<s xml:id="sent2187318" n="7.196-7.198">but thereafter he shall suffer whatever Fate and the <sic>dread</sic> Spinners spun with their thread for him at his birth, when his mother bore him.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:7.199-7.239">

<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2187319" n="7.199-7.200">But if he is one of the immortals come down from heaven, <milestone ed="p" n="200" unit="line"/> then is this some new thing which the gods are planning;

<s xml:id="sent2187344" n="7.244">There is an isle, Ogygia, which lies far off in the sea.

She took me to her home with kindly welcome, and gave me food, and said that she would make me immortal and ageless all my days; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187350" n="7.258">but she could never persuade the heart in my breast. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187351" n="7.259-7.260">There for seven years' space I remained continually, and ever <milestone ed="p" n="260" unit="line"/> with my tears would I wet the immortal raiment which Calypso gave me. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187352" n="7.261-7.263">But when the eight year came in circling course, then she roused me and <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> me go, either because of some message from Zeus, or because her own mind was turned. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187353" n="7.264-7.266">And she sent me on my way on a raft, stoutly bound, and gave me abundant store <milestone ed="p" n="265" unit="line"/> of bread and sweet wine, and clad me in immortal raiment, and sent forth a gentle wind and warm. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187354" n="7.267-7.270">So for seventeen days I sailed over the sea, and on the eighteenth appeared the shadowy mountains of your land; and my heart was glad, <milestone ed="p" n="270" unit="line"/> ill-starred that I was; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187355" n="7.270-7.274">for <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> I was yet to have fellowship with great woe, which Poseidon, the earth-shaker, sent upon me. For he stirred up the winds against me and stayed my course, and wondrously roused the sea, nor would the wave suffer me to be borne upon my raft, as I groaned ceaselessly.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187356" n="7.275"><milestone ed="p" n="275" unit="line"/>My raft indeed the storm shattered, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187357" n="7.275-7.277">but by swimming I clove my way through <sic>yon</sic> gulf of the sea, until the wind and the waves, as they bore me, brought me to your shores. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187358" n="7.278-7.279">There, had I sought to land, the waves would have hurled me upon the shore, and dashed me against the great crags and a cheerless place,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187359" n="7.280-7.282"><milestone ed="p" n="280" unit="line"/> but I gave way, and swam back until I came to a river, where seemed to me the best place, since it was smooth of rocks, and besides there was shelter from the wind. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187360" n="7.283-7.284">Forth then I staggered, and sank down, gasping for breath, and immortal night came on. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187361" n="7.284-7.286">Then I went forth from the heaven-fed river, and lay down to sleep in the bushes, gathering leaves about me.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187362" n="7.286">A god shed over me infinite sleep.</s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:7.287-7.316">

<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2187363" n="7.287-7.288">So there among the leaves I slept, my heart <sic>sore</sic> stricken, the whole night through, until the morning and until midday;

<s xml:id="sent2187367" n="7.292-7.294">and she in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> failed in good understanding, to do as <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> wouldst not <mod n="deem:simpsub">think</mod> that one of younger years would do on meeting <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>;

<s xml:id="sent2187373" n="7.302">Then Odysseus of many wiles answered him, and said:

<s xml:id="sent2187375" n="7.304-7.306">She did indeed <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> me follow with her maidens, <milestone ed="p" n="305" unit="line"/> but I would not for fear and shame, lest <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> heart should darken with wrath as <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> sawest it;

<s xml:id="sent2187376" n="7.307">for we are quick to anger, we tribes of men upon the earth.

<s xml:id="sent2187377" n="7.308">And again Alcinous answered him, and said:

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2187378" n="7.309-7.310">Stranger, not such is the heart in my breast, <milestone ed="p" n="310" unit="line"/> to be filled with wrath without a cause.

<s xml:id="sent2187379" n="7.310">Better is due measure in all things.

<s xml:id="sent2187380" n="7.311-7.314">I would, O father Zeus, and Athena and Apollo, that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod>, so goodly a man, and like-minded with me, wouldst have my daughter to wife, and be called my son, and <mod n="abide:simpsub">remain</mod> here;

<s xml:id="sent2187382" n="7.315-7.316">but against <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> will shall no one of the Phaeacians keep <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>;

<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2187396" n="7.342"><mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> bed is made.

<s xml:id="sent2187398" n="7.344-7.345">So there he slept, the much-enduring <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus, <milestone ed="p" n="345" unit="line"/> on the corded bedstead under the echoing portico. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187399" n="7.346-7.347">But Alcinous lay down in the inmost chamber of the lofty house, and beside him lay the lady his wife, who had strewn the couch.</s></p>

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187400" n="8.1-8.3"><milestone ed="p" n="1" unit="line"/>As soon as early Dawn appeared, the rosy-fingered, the strong and mighty Alcinous rose from his couch, and up rose also Zeus-born Odysseus, the sacker of cities. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187401" n="8.4-8.5">And the strong and mighty Alcinous led the way <milestone ed="p" n="5" unit="line"/> to the place of assembly of the Phaeacians, which was <mod n="builded:simpsub">built</mod> for them hard by their ships. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187402" n="8.6-8.7">Thither they came and sat down on the polished stones close by one another; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187403" n="8.7-8.10">and Pallas Athena went throughout the city, in the likeness of the herald of wise Alcinous, devising a return for great-hearted Odysseus. <milestone ed="p" n="10" unit="line"/> To each man's side she came, and spoke and said:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187404" n="8.11-8.14">Hither now, leaders and counsellors of the Phaeacians, come to the place of assembly, that you may learn of the stranger who has newly come to the palace of wise Alcinous after his wanderings over the sea, and in form is <corr n="like unto">like</corr> the immortals.

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2187405" n="8.15"><milestone ed="p" n="15" unit="line"/>So saying she roused the spirit and heart of each man, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187406" n="8.16-8.17">and speedily the place of assembly and the seats were filled with men that gathered. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187407" n="8.17-8.18">And many marvelled at the sight of the wise son of Laertes, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187408" n="8.18-8.23">for wondrous was the grace that Athena shed upon his head and shoulders; <milestone ed="p" n="20" unit="line"/> and she made him taller and sturdier to behold, that he might be welcomed by all the Phaeacians, and win awe and reverence, and might accomplish the many feats <mod n="wherein:simpsub">in which</mod> the Phaeacians made trial of Odysseus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187409" n="8.24-8.25">Now when they were assembled and met together, <milestone ed="p" n="25" unit="line"/> Alcinous addressed their assembly and spoke among them:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187410" n="8.26-8.27"><mod n="Hearken:simpsub">Listen</mod> to me, leaders and counsellors of the Phaeacians, that I may speak what the heart in my breast <mod n="bids:simpsub">commands</mod> me. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187411" n="8.28-8.29">This stranger—I know not who he is—has come to my house in his wanderings, whether from men of the east or of the west.

<s xml:id="sent2187412" n="8.30"><milestone ed="p" n="30" unit="line"/>He urges that he be sent on his way, and prays for assurance, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187413" n="8.31">and let us on our part, as of old we were <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod>, speed on his sending; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187414" n="8.32-8.33">for <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> no man soever who comes to my house, abides here long in sorrow for lack of sending.

<s xml:id="sent2187415" n="8.34-8.36"><sic>Nay</sic> come, let us draw a black ship down to the bright sea <milestone ed="p" n="35" unit="line"/> for her first voyage, and let men choose two and fifty youths <corr n="from out">out of</corr> the people, even those that have heretofore been the best. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187416" n="8.37-8.38">And when you have all duly lashed the oars to the thole-pins,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> go ashore,

<s xml:id="sent2187417" n="8.38-8.39">and then go your way to my house, and prepare a feast with speed;

<s xml:id="sent2187418" n="8.39">and I will provide bountifully for all.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187419" n="8.40"><milestone ed="p" n="40" unit="line"/>To the youths this is my command, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187420" n="8.40-8.43">but do you others, the sceptred kings, come to my fair palace, that we may entertain <sic>yon</sic> stranger in the halls; and let no man say me <sic>nay</sic>.

<s xml:id="sent2187421" n="8.43-8.44">And summon <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod> the divine minstrel, Demodocus;

<s xml:id="sent2187426" n="8.50-8.54"><milestone ed="p" n="50" unit="line"/>And when they had come down to the ship and to the sea, they drew the black ship down to the deep water, and placed the mast and sail in the black ship, and fitted the oars in the leathern thole-straps, all in due order, and spread the white sail.

<s xml:id="sent2187439" n="8.72-8.78">But when they had put from them the desire of food and drink, the Muse moved the minstrel to sing of the glorious deeds of warriors, from that lay the fame <sic>whereof</sic> had then reached broad heaven, <milestone ed="p" n="75" unit="line"/> even the quarrel of Odysseus and Achilles, son of Peleus, how once they strove with furious words at a rich feast of the gods, and Agamemnon, king of men, was glad at heart that the best of the Achaeans were quarrelling;

<s xml:id="sent2187440" n="8.79-8.81">for thus Phoebus Apollo, in giving his response, had told him that it should be, <milestone ed="p" n="80" unit="line"/> in sacred <placeName key="tgn,7010770">Pytho</placeName>, when he passed over the threshold of stone to enquire of the oracle.

<s xml:id="sent2187445" n="8.87-8.89"><sic>Yea</sic>, and as often as the divine minstrel ceased his singing, Odysseus would wipe away his tears and draw the cloak from off his head, and taking the two-handled cup would pour libations to the gods.

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:8.121-8.164">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187461" n="8.121">A course was marked out for them from the turning point,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187465" n="8.126">Then they made trial of toilsome wrestling, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187466" n="8.127">and here in turn Euryalus excelled all the princes. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187467" n="8.128">And in leaping Amphialus was best of all, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187468" n="8.129-8.130">and with the discus again far the best of all was Elatreus, <milestone ed="p" n="130" unit="line"/> and in boxing Laodamas, the good son of Alcinous. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187469" n="8.131-8.132">But when the hearts of all had taken pleasure in the contests, Laodamas, the son of Alcinous, spoke among them:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187470" n="8.133-8.134">Come, friends, let us ask <sic>yon</sic> stranger whether he knows and has learned any contests. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187471" n="8.134-8.136">In build, surely, he is no mean man, <milestone ed="p" n="135" unit="line"/> in thighs and calves, and in his two arms above, his stout neck, and his great might. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187472" n="8.136-8.137">In <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> does he lack <mod n="aught:simpsub">anything</mod> of the strength of youth, but he has been broken by many troubles. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187473" n="8.138-8.139">For to my mind there is <mod n="naught:simpsub">nothing</mod> worse than the sea to confound a man, be he never so strong.

<s xml:id="sent2187474" n="8.140"><milestone ed="p" n="140" unit="line"/>And Euryalus in turn answered him, and said:

<s xml:id="sent2187475" n="8.141">Laodamas, this word of <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> is right fitly spoken.

<s xml:id="sent2187477" n="8.143-8.144">Now when the good son of Alcinous heard this he came and took his stand in the midst and spoke to Odysseus: <milestone ed="p" n="145" unit="line"/>

<s xml:id="sent2187478" n="8.145-8.146">Come, Sir stranger, do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod>, too, make trial of the contests, if <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='knowest'>know</mod> any;

<s xml:id="sent2187479" n="8.146">and it must be that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='knowest'>know</mod> contests,

<s xml:id="sent2187481" n="8.149"><sic>Nay</sic>, come, make trial, and cast away care from <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> heart.

<s xml:id="sent2187482" n="8.150-8.151"><milestone ed="p" n="150" unit="line"/>Thy journey shall no more be long delayed, <sic>nay</sic>, even now <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> ship is launched and the crew is ready.

<s xml:id="sent2187483" n="8.152">Then Odysseus of many wiles answered him, and said:

<s xml:id="sent2187484" n="8.153">Laodamas, why do <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> mock me with this challenge? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187485" n="8.154-8.157">Sorrow is in my mind far more than contests, <milestone ed="p" n="155" unit="line"/> seeing that in time past I have suffered much and toiled much, and now I sit in the midst of your assembly, longing for my return home, and making my prayer to the king and to all the people.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2187486" n="8.158">Then again Euryalus made answer and taunted him to his face: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187487" n="8.159-8.164"><sic>Nay</sic> <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod>, stranger, for I do not liken <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> to a man that is skilled <milestone ed="p" n="160" unit="line"/> in contests, such as abound among men, but to one who, faring to and fro with his benched ship, is a captain of sailors who are merchantmen, one who is mindful of his freight, and has charge of a home-borne cargo, and the gains of his greed. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187488" n="8.164">Thou <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> not look like an athlete.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:8.165-8.198">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187489" n="8.165"><milestone ed="p" n="165" unit="line"/>Then with an angry glance from beneath his brows Odysseus of many wiles answered him: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187490" n="8.166">Stranger, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> not spoken well; 
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187491" n="8.166"><corr n="thou art">you are</corr> as one blind with folly. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187492" n="8.167-8.168">So true is it that the gods do not give gracious gifts to all alike, not form nor mind nor eloquence. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187493" n="8.169-8.171">For one man is inferior in comeliness, <milestone ed="p" n="170" unit="line"/> but the god sets a crown<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> of beauty upon his words, and men look upon him with delight, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187494" n="8.171-8.173">and he speaks on unfalteringly with sweet modesty, and is conspicuous among the gathered people, and as he goes through the city men gaze upon him as upon a god. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187495" n="8.174-8.177">Another again is in comeliness like the immortals, <milestone ed="p" n="175" unit="line"/> but no crown of grace is set about his words. So, in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> case, <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> comeliness is preeminent, nor could a god himself mend it, but in mind <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> stunted.

<s xml:id="sent2187496" n="8.178-8.179">Thou <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> stirred the spirit in my breast by speaking thus unmannerly.

<s xml:id="sent2187497" n="8.179-8.181">I am not unskilled in sports <milestone ed="p" n="180" unit="line"/> as <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <sic>pratest</sic>, <sic>nay</sic>, methinks I was among the first so long as I trusted in my youth and in my hands.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187499" n="8.182-8.183">for much have I endured in passing through wars of men and the grievous waves. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187500" n="8.184">But even so, though I have suffered much, I will make trial of the contests,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187501" n="8.185"><milestone ed="p" n="8.185" unit="line"/> for <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> word has stung me to the heart, and <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> provoked me with <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> speech.

</s>
