<s xml:id="sent2187502" n="8.186-8.188">He spoke, and, leaping up with his cloak about him as it was, seized a discus larger than the rest and thick, no little heavier than those with which the Phaeacians were <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to contend one with another. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187503" n="8.189-8.190">This with a whirl he sent from his stout hand, <milestone ed="p" n="190" unit="line"/> and the stone hummed as it flew; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187504" n="8.190-8.192">and down they crouched to the earth, the Phaeacians of the long oars, men famed for their ships, beneath the rush of the stone. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187505" n="8.192-8.193">Past the marks of all it flew, speeding lightly from his hand, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187506" n="8.193-8.194">and Athena, in the likeness of a man, set the mark, and she spoke and addressed him:
<milestone ed="p" n="195" unit="line"/>


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187507" n="8.195-8.197">Even a blind man, stranger, could distinguish this mark, groping for it with his hands, for it is in <mod n="nowise:simpsub">in no way</mod> confused with the throng of the others, but is far the first. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187508" n="8.197">Be <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> of good cheer for this bout at least:

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187509" n="8.198">no one of the Phaeacians will reach this, or cast beyond it.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:8.199-8.249">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187510" n="8.199-8.200">So she spoke, and the much-enduring <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus was glad, <milestone ed="p" n="200" unit="line"/> rejoicing that he saw a true friend in the lists. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187511" n="8.201">Then with a lighter heart he spoke among the Phaeacians:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187512" n="8.202">Reach this now, young men;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187513" n="8.202-8.203">and presently, methinks, I will send another after it, as far or even further. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187514" n="8.204-8.207">Of the rest, if any man's heart and spirit <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> him, <milestone ed="p" n="205" unit="line"/> let him come <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod> and make trial—for <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> have greatly angered me—be it in boxing or in wrestling, aye, or in running, I care not; let any one come of all the Phaeacians, save Laodamas alone. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187515" n="8.208">For he is my host, 
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187516" n="8.208">and who would quarrel with one that entertains him? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187517" n="8.209-8.211">Foolish is that man and worthless, <milestone ed="p" n="210" unit="line"/> who challenges to a contest the host who receives him in a strange land; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187518" n="8.211">he does but mar his own fortunes. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187519" n="8.212-8.213">But of all the rest I refuse none, and make light of none, but am fain to know them, and make trial of them man to man. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187520" n="8.214">For in all things I am no weakling, even in all the contests that are practised among men.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187521" n="8.215"><milestone ed="p" n="215" unit="line"/>Well do I know how to handle the polished bow, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187522" n="8.216-8.218">and ever would I be the first to shoot and <mod n="smite:simpsub">strike</mod> my man in the throng of the foe, even though many comrades stood by me and were shooting at the men. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187523" n="8.219-8.220">Only Philoctetes excelled me with the bow <milestone ed="p" n="220" unit="line"/> in the land of the Trojans, when we Achaeans shot. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187524" n="8.221-8.222">But of all others I declare that I am best by far, of all mortals that are now upon the earth and eat bread. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187525" n="8.223-8.225">Yet with men of former days I will not seek to vie, with Heracles or with Eurytus of <placeName key="perseus,Oechalia">Oechalia</placeName>, <milestone ed="p" n="225" unit="line"/> who strove even with the immortals in archery. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187526" n="8.226-8.227"><mod n="Wherefore:simpsub">For which reason</mod> great Eurytus died soon, nor did old age come upon him in his halls,

<s xml:id="sent2187527" n="8.227-8.228">for Apollo <mod n="waxed:simpsub">became</mod> <mod n="wroth:simpsub">angry</mod> and <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> him, because he had challenged him to a contest with the bow. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187528" n="8.229">And with the spear I throw farther than any other man can shoot with an arrow.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187529" n="8.230-8.231"><milestone ed="p" n="230" unit="line"/>In the foot race alone I fear that someone of the Phaeacians may out strip me, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187530" n="8.231-8.233">for cruelly have I been broken <mod n="amid:simpsub">among</mod> the many waves, since there was in my ship no lasting store of provisions; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187531" n="8.233">therefore my limbs are loosened.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2187532" n="8.234">So he spoke and they were all hushed in silence;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187533" n="8.235"><milestone ed="p" n="235" unit="line"/> but Alcinous alone answered him and said:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187534" n="8.236-8.240">Stranger, since not ungraciously <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> speak thus in our midst, but art minded to <mod n="shew:simpsub">show</mod> forth the prowess which waits upon <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, in anger that <sic>yonder</sic> man came up to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> in the lists and taunted <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> in a way in which no mortal would make light of <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> prowess, <milestone ed="p" n="240" unit="line"/> who knew in his heart how to speak fitly; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187535" n="8.241-8.245">come, now, <mod n="hearken:simpsub">listen</mod> to my words, that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='mayest'>may</mod> tell to another hero, when in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> halls <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> feasting with <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> wife and children, and <mod n='rememberest'>remember</mod> our skill, what feats <milestone ed="p" n="245" unit="line"/> Zeus has <mod n="vouchsafed:simpsub">promised</mod> to us from our fathers' days even until now. 


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187536" n="8.246-8.249">For we are not faultless boxers or wrestlers, but in the foot race we run swiftly, and we are the best seamen; and ever to us is the banquet dear, and the lyre, and the dance, and changes of raiment, and warm baths, and the couch.</s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:8.250-8.294"> <milestone ed="p" n="250" unit="line"/>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2187537" n="8.250-8.253">But come now, all <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> that are the best dancers of the Phaeacians, make sport, that the stranger may tell his friends on reaching home how far we surpass others in seamanship and in fleetness of foot, and in the dance and in song.

<s xml:id="sent2187538" n="8.254-8.255">And let one go straightway <milestone ed="p" n="255" unit="line"/> and fetch for Demodocus the clear-toned lyre which lies somewhere in our halls.

<s xml:id="sent2187539" n="8.256-8.257">So spoke Alcinous the godlike, and the herald rose to fetch the hollow lyre from the palace of the king. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187540" n="8.258-8.260">Then stood up masters of the lists, nine in all, men chosen <corr n="from out">out of</corr> the people, who in their gatherings were <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to order all things aright. <milestone ed="p" n="260" unit="line"/>They levelled a place for the dance, and marked out a fair wide ring,

<s xml:id="sent2187542" n="8.262">He then moved into the midst, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187543" n="8.262-8.264">and around him stood boys in the first bloom of youth, well skilled in the dance, and they <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> the goodly dancing floor with their feet.

<s xml:id="sent2187544" n="8.264-8.265">And Odysseus <milestone ed="p" n="265" unit="line"/> gazed at the twinklings of their feet and marvelled in spirit.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187545" n="8.266-8.270">But the minstrel struck the chords in prelude to his sweet lay and sang of the love of Ares and Aphrodite of the fair crown, how first they lay together in the house of Hephaestus secretly; and Ares gave her many gifts, and shamed the bed <milestone ed="p" n="270" unit="line"/> of the lord Hephaestus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187546" n="8.270-8.271">But straightway one came to him with tidings, even Helius, who had marked them as they lay together in love. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187547" n="8.272-8.275">And when Hephaestus heard the grievous tale, he went his way to his smithy, pondering evil in the deep of his heart, and set on the anvil block the great anvil and forged bonds <milestone ed="p" n="275" unit="line"/> which might not be broken or loosed, that the lovers<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> might bide fast where they were.

<s xml:id="sent2187548" n="8.276-8.278">But when he had fashioned the snare in his wrath against Ares, he went to his chamber where lay his bed, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187549" n="8.279-8.281">and everywhere round about the bed-posts he spread the bonds, and many too were hung from above, from the roof-beams, <milestone ed="p" n="280" unit="line"/> fine as spiders' webs, so that no one even of the blessed gods could see them, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187550" n="8.281">so exceeding craftily were they fashioned. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187551" n="8.282-8.284">But when he had spread all his snare about the couch, he made as though he would go to <placeName key="tgn,7011173">Lemnos</placeName>, that well-built citadel, which is in his eyes far the dearest of all lands.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187552" n="8.285-8.286"><milestone ed="p" n="285" unit="line"/>And no blind watch did Ares of the golden rein keep, when he saw Hephaestus, famed for his handicraft, departing, but he went his way to the house of famous Hephaestus, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187553" n="8.287-8.288">eager for the love of Cytherea of the fair crown. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187554" n="8.289-8.290">Now she had but newly come from the presence of her father, the mighty son of Cronos, <milestone ed="p" n="290" unit="line"/> and had sat her down. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187555" n="8.290-8.291">And Ares came into the house and clasped her hand and spoke and addressed her:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187556" n="8.292">Come, love, let us to bed and take our joy, couched together. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187557" n="8.293-8.294">For Hephaestus is no longer here in the land, but has now gone, I <mod n="ween:simpsub">believe</mod>, to <placeName key="tgn,7011173">Lemnos</placeName>, to visit the Sintians of savage speech.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:8.295-8.342">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187558" n="8.295"><milestone ed="p" n="295" unit="line"/>So he spoke, and a welcome thing it seemed to her to lie with him.

</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187562" n="8.300-8.301"><milestone ed="p" n="300" unit="line"/>And near to them came the famous god of the two strong arms,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> having turned back before he reached the land of <placeName key="tgn,7011173">Lemnos</placeName>; 

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2187564" n="8.303">So he went to his house with a heavy heart,

<s xml:id="sent2187566" n="8.305"><milestone ed="p" n="305" unit="line"/>And terribly he cried out and called to all the gods:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187567" n="8.306-8.311">Father Zeus, and <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> other blessed gods that are forever, come <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod> that <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> may see a laughable matter and a monstrous,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> even how Aphrodite, daughter of Zeus, scorns me <corr n="for that">for</corr> I am lame and loves destructive Ares <milestone ed="p" n="310" unit="line"/> because he is comely and strong of limb, whereas I was born misshapen. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187568" n="8.311-8.312">Yet for this is none other to blame but my two parents—would they had never begotten me! 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187569" n="8.313-8.314">But <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> shall see where these two have gone up into my bed and sleep together in love; and I am troubled at the sight.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187570" n="8.315-8.316"><milestone ed="p" n="315" unit="line"/>Yet, methinks, they will not wish to lie longer thus, no, not for a moment, how loving soever they are. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187571" n="8.316-8.317">Soon shall both lose their desire to sleep; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187572" n="8.317-8.320">but the snare and the bonds shall hold them until her father pays back to me all the gifts of wooing that I gave him for the sake of his shameless girl; <milestone ed="p" n="320" unit="line"/> for his daughter is fair but bridles not her passion.<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">2</note>

<s xml:id="sent2187573" n="8.321">So he spoke and the gods gathered to the house of the brazen floor.<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">3</note>

<s xml:id="sent2187574" n="8.322-8.323">Poseidon came, the earth-enfolder, and the helper Hermes came, and the lord Apollo, the archer god.<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">4</note>

<s xml:id="sent2187575" n="8.324">Now the goddesses <sic>abode</sic> for shame each in her own house,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187576" n="8.325"><milestone ed="p" n="325" unit="line"/> but the gods, the givers of good things, stood in the gateway; 

</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187578" n="8.328">And thus would one speak, with a glance at his neighbor:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187579" n="8.329">Ill deeds thrive not. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187580" n="8.329-8.332">The slow catches the swift; <milestone ed="p" n="330" unit="line"/> even as now Hephaestus, slow though he is, has out-stripped Ares for all that he is the swiftest of the gods who hold <placeName key="tgn,7011019">Olympus</placeName>. Lame though he is, he has caught him by craft, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187581" n="8.332"><mod n="wherefore:simpsub">for which reason</mod> Ares owes the fine of the adulterer.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2187582" n="8.333">Thus they spoke to one another.

<s xml:id="sent2187695" n="8.536-8.537">Hear me, leaders and counsellors of the Phaeacians, and let Demodocus now check his clear-toned lyre, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187696" n="8.538">for in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> to all alike does he give pleasure with this song. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187697" n="8.539-8.541">Ever since we began to sup and the divine minstrel was moved to sing, <milestone ed="p" n="540" unit="line"/> from that time <sic>yon</sic> stranger has never ceased from sorrowful lamentation; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187698" n="8.541">surely, methinks, grief has encompassed his heart. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187699" n="8.542-8.543"><sic>Nay</sic>, let the minstrel cease, that we may all make merry, hosts and guest alike, since it is better thus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187700" n="8.544-8.545"><sic>Lo</sic>, for the sake of the honored stranger all these things have been made ready, <milestone ed="p" n="545" unit="line"/> his sending and the gifts of friendship which we give him of our love. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187701" n="8.546-8.547">Dear as a brother is the stranger and the suppliant to a man whose wits have never so short a range. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187702" n="8.548-8.549">Therefore do not <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> longer hide with crafty thought whatever I shall ask <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187703" n="8.549">to speak out plainly is the better course.</s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:8.550-8.586">

<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2187704" n="8.550-8.551"><milestone ed="p" n="550" unit="line"/>Tell me the name by which they were <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to call <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> home, even <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> mother and <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> father and other <mod n="folk:simpsub">people</mod> besides, <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> townsmen and the dwellers round about. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187705" n="8.552-8.554">For there is no one of all mankind who is nameless, be he base man or noble, when once he has been born, but parents bestow names on all when they give them birth.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187706" n="8.555"><milestone ed="p" n="555" unit="line"/>And tell me <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> country,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187707" n="8.555-8.556"><mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> people, and <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> city, that our ships may convey <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> thither, discerning the course by their wits. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187708" n="8.557-8.558">For the Phaeacians have no pilots, nor steering-oars such as other ships have, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187709" n="8.559-8.562">For but their ships of themselves understand the thoughts and minds of men, <milestone ed="p" n="560" unit="line"/> and they know the cities and rich fields of all peoples, and most swiftly do they cross over the gulf of the sea, hidden in mist and cloud,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187710" n="8.562-8.563">nor ever have they fear of harm or ruin. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187711" n="8.564-8.566">Yet this story I once heard thus told by my father <milestone ed="p" n="565" unit="line"/> Nausithous, who was <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to say that Poseidon was <mod n="wroth:simpsub">angry</mod> with us because we give safe convoy to all men. 


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187712" n="8.567-8.569">He said that someday, as a well-built ship of the Phaeacians was returning from a convoy over the misty deep, Poseidon would <mod n="smite:simpsub">strike</mod> her and would fling a great mountain about our city.<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note>


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187713" n="8.570"><milestone ed="p" n="570" unit="line"/>So that old man spoke,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187714" n="8.570-8.571">and these things the god will <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> bring to pass, or will leave unfulfilled, as may be his good pleasure. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187715" n="8.572-8.576">But come, now, tell me this and declare it truly: <mod n="whither:simpsub">where</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> wandered and to what countries of men <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> come; tell me of the people and of their well-built cities, <milestone ed="p" n="575" unit="line"/> both of those who are cruel and wild and unjust, and of those who love strangers and fear the gods in their thoughts. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187716" n="8.577-8.578">And tell me why <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> weep and wail in spirit as <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='hearest'>hear</mod> the doom of the Argive Danaans and of <placeName key="tgn,7002329">Ilios</placeName>. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187717" n="8.579-8.580">This the gods <sic>wrought</sic>, and spun the skein of ruin <milestone ed="p" n="580" unit="line"/> for men, that there might be a song for those yet to be born. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187718" n="8.581-8.583">Did some kinsman of <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> fall before <placeName key="tgn,7002329">Ilios</placeName>, some good, true man, <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> daughter's husband or <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> wife's father, such as are nearest to one after one's own kin and blood? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187719" n="8.584-8.585">Or was it <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> some comrade dear to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> heart, <milestone ed="p" n="585" unit="line"/> some good, true man? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187720" n="8.585-8.586">For no whit worse than a brother is a comrade who has an understanding heart.</s></q></p>
</div>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="book" n="9">
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:9.1-9.46">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187721" n="9.1"><milestone ed="p" n="1" unit="line"/>Then Odysseus, of many wiles, answered him, and said: 

</s>
<q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2187722" n="9.2-9.4">Lord Alcinous, renowned above all men, <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> this is a good thing, to listen to a minstrel such as this man is, <corr n="like unto">like</corr> the gods in voice.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187723" n="9.5-9.10"><milestone ed="p" n="5" unit="line"/>For myself I declare that there is no greater fulfillment of delight than when joy possesses a whole people, and banqueters in the halls listen to a minstrel as they sit in order due, and by them tables are <sic>laden</sic> with bread and meat, and the cup-bearer draws wine from the bowl <milestone ed="p" n="10" unit="line"/> and bears it round and pours it into the cups. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187724" n="9.11">This seems to my mind the fairest thing there is. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187725" n="9.12-9.13">But <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> heart is turned to ask of my grievous woes, that I may weep and groan the more. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187726" n="9.14">What, then, shall I tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> first, what last?

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187727" n="9.15"><milestone ed="p" n="15" unit="line"/> for woes full many have the heavenly gods given me. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187728" n="9.16-9.18">First now will I tell my name, that <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod>, too, may know it, and that I hereafter, when I have escaped from the pitiless day of doom, may be your host, though I dwell in a home that is afar. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187729" n="9.19-9.20">I am Odysseus, son of Laertes, who <milestone ed="p" n="20" unit="line"/> am known among men for all manner of wiles,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> and my fame reaches <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod> heaven. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187730" n="9.21">But I dwell in clear-seen <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName>,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187731" n="9.21-9.22"><mod n="wherein:simpsub">in which</mod> is a mountain, Neriton, covered with waving forests, conspicuous from afar;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187732" n="9.22-9.24">and round it lie many isles hard by one another, Dulichium, and Same, and wooded <placeName key="tgn,7011374">Zacynthus</placeName>.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187733" n="9.25-9.27"><milestone ed="p" n="25" unit="line"/>

<placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName> itself lies close in to the mainland<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> the furthest toward the gloom,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">2</note> but the others lie apart toward the Dawn and the sun—a rugged isle, but a good nurse of young men;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187734" n="9.27-9.28">and for myself no other thing can I see sweeter than one's own land. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187735" n="9.29-9.30">Of a truth Calypso, the beautiful goddess, sought to keep me by her <milestone ed="p" n="30" unit="line"/> in her hollow caves, yearning that I should be her husband; 


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187736" n="9.31-9.32">and in like manner Circe would fain have held me back in her halls, the guileful lady of Aeaea, yearning that I should be her husband; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187737" n="9.33">but they could never persuade the heart within my breast. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187738" n="9.34-9.36">So true is it that <mod n="naught:simpsub">nothing</mod> is sweeter than a man's own land and his parents, <milestone ed="p" n="35" unit="line"/> even though it be in a rich house that he dwells afar in a foreign land away from his parents. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187739" n="9.37-9.38">But come, let me tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> also of my woeful home-coming, which Zeus laid upon me as I came from <placeName key="perseus,Troy">Troy</placeName>.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187740" n="9.39-9.40">From <placeName key="tgn,7002329">Ilios</placeName> the wind bore me and brought me to the Cicones, <milestone ed="p" n="40" unit="line"/> to Ismarus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187741" n="9.40">There I sacked the city and <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> the men; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187742" n="9.41-9.42">and from the city we took their wives and great store of treasure, and divided them among us, that so far as lay in me no man might go defrauded of an equal share. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187743" n="9.43-9.44">Then <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> I gave command that we should flee with swift foot, but the others in their great folly did not <mod n="hearken:simpsub">listen</mod>.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187744" n="9.45-9.46"><milestone ed="p" n="45" unit="line"/>But there much wine was drunk, and many sheep they <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> by the shore, and sleek <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod> of shambling gait.</s></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:9.47-9.81">
<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2187745" n="9.47-9.50">Meanwhile the Cicones went and called to other Cicones who were their neighbors, at once more numerous and braver than they—men that dwelt inland and were skilled <milestone ed="p" n="50" unit="line"/> at fighting with their foes from chariots, and, if need were, on foot. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187746" n="9.51-9.52">So they came in the morning, as thick as leaves or flowers spring up in their season; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187747" n="9.52-9.53">and then it was that an evil fate from Zeus beset us luckless men, that we might suffer woes full many. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187748" n="9.54-9.55`">They set their battle in array and fought by the swift ships, <milestone ed="p" n="55" unit="line"/> and each side hurled at the other with bronze-tipped spears. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187749" n="9.56-9.57">Now as long as it was morn and the sacred day was waxing, so long we held our ground and beat them off, though they were more than we. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187750" n="9.58-9.59">But when the sun turned to the time for the unyoking of oxen, then the Cicones prevailed and routed the Achaeans,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187751" n="9.60-9.61"><milestone ed="p" n="60" unit="line"/> and six of my well-greaved comrades perished from each ship; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187752" n="9.61">but the rest of us escaped death and fate.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187753" n="9.62-9.63">Thence we sailed on, grieved at heart, glad to have escaped from death, though we had lost our dear comrades; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187754" n="9.64-9.66">nor did I let my curved ships pass on <milestone ed="p" n="65" unit="line"/> till we had called <mod n="thrice:simpsub">three times</mod> on each of those hapless comrades of ours who died on the plain, cut down by the Cicones. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187755" n="9.67-9.69">But against our ships Zeus, the cloud-gatherer, roused the North Wind with a wondrous tempest, and hid with clouds the land and the sea alike,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187756" n="9.69">and night rushed down from heaven.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187757" n="9.70-9.71"><milestone ed="p" n="70" unit="line"/>Then the ships were driven headlong, and their sails were torn to shreds by the violence of the wind. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187758" n="9.72-9.73">So we lowered the sails and stowed them aboard, in fear of death, and rowed the ships hurriedly toward the land. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187759" n="9.74-9.75">There for two nights and two days continuously <milestone ed="p" n="75" unit="line"/> we lay, eating our hearts for weariness and sorrow. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187760" n="9.76-9.78">But when now fair-tressed Dawn brought to its birth the third day, we set up the masts and hoisted the white sails, and took our seats, and the wind and the helmsmen steered the ships. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187761" n="9.79">And now all unscathed should I have reached my native land,


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187762" n="9.80-9.81"><milestone ed="p" n="80" unit="line"/> but the wave and the current and the North Wind beat me back as I was rounding Malea, and drove me from my course past <placeName key="tgn,7010869">Cythera</placeName>.</s></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:9.82-9.115">

<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2187763" n="9.82-9.83">Thence for nine days' space I was borne by direful winds over the teeming deep; 


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187764" n="9.83-9.84">but on the tenth we set foot on the land of the Lotus-eaters, who eat a flowery food.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187765" n="9.85-9.86"><milestone ed="p" n="85" unit="line"/>There we went on shore and drew water, and straightway my comrades took their meal by the swift ships. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187766" n="9.87-9.90">But when we had tasted food and drink, I sent forth some of my comrades to go and learn who the men were, who here ate bread upon the earth; <milestone ed="p" n="90" unit="line"/> two men I chose, sending with them a third as a herald. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187767" n="9.91">So they went straightway and mingled with the Lotus-eaters,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187768" n="9.92-9.93">and the Lotus-eaters did not plan death for my comrades, but gave them of the lotus to taste. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187769" n="9.94-9.97">And whosoever of them ate of the honey-sweet fruit of the lotus, <milestone ed="p" n="95" unit="line"/> had no longer any wish to bring back word or to return, but there they were fain to <mod n="abide:simpsub">remain</mod> among the Lotus-eaters, feeding on the lotus, and forgetful of their homeward way. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187770" n="9.98-9.99">These men, therefore, I brought back perforce to the ships, weeping, and dragged them beneath the benches and bound them fast in the hollow ships;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187771" n="9.100-9.102"><milestone ed="p" n="100" unit="line"/> and I <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> the rest of my trusty comrades to embark with speed on the swift ships, lest <mod n="perchance:simpsub">perchance</mod> anyone should eat of the lotus and forget his homeward way. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187772" n="9.103-9.104">So they went on board straightway and sat down upon the benches, and sitting well in order <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> the grey sea with their oars.</s></p>
<milestone ed="p" n="105" unit="line"/>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187773" n="9.105">Thence we sailed on, grieved at heart,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187774" n="9.106-9.111">and we came to the land of the Cyclopes, an overweening and lawless <mod n="folk:simpsub">people</mod>, who, trusting in the immortal gods, plant nothing with their hands nor plough; but all these things spring up for them without sowing or ploughing, <milestone ed="p" n="110" unit="line"/> wheat, and barley, and vines, which bear the rich clusters of wine, and the rain of Zeus gives them increase. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187775" n="9.112-9.115">Neither assemblies for council have they, nor appointed laws, but they dwell on the peaks of lofty mountains in hollow caves, and each one is lawgiver <milestone ed="p" n="115" unit="line"/> to his children and his wives, and they <mod n="reck:simpsub">care</mod> nothing one of another.</s></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:9.116-9.160">

<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2187776" n="9.116-9.118">Now there is a level<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> isle that stretches aslant outside the harbor, neither close to the shore of the land of the Cyclopes, nor yet far off, a wooded isle. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187777" n="9.118-9.119">Therein live wild goats innumerable, for the tread of men scares them not away,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187778" n="9.119-9.121"><milestone ed="p" n="120" unit="line"/> nor are hunters <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to come thither, men who endure toils in the woodland as they course over the peaks of the mountains. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187779" n="9.122-9.124">Neither with flocks is it held, nor with ploughed lands, but unsown and untilled all the days it knows <mod n="naught:simpsub">nothing</mod> of men, but feeds the bleating goats.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187780" n="9.125-9.129"><milestone ed="p" n="125" unit="line"/>For the Cyclopes have at hand no ships with vermilion cheeks,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">2</note> nor are there ship-wrights in their land who might build them well-benched ships, which should perform all their wants, passing to the cities of other <mod n="folk:simpsub">people</mod>, as men often cross the sea in ships to visit one another—

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187781" n="9.130"><milestone ed="p" n="130" unit="line"/> craftsmen, who would have made of this isle also a fair settlement. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187782" n="9.131">For the isle is <mod n="nowise:simpsub">in no way</mod> poor, but would bear all things in season. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187783" n="9.132-9.133">In it are meadows by the shores of the grey sea, well-watered meadows and soft,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187784" n="9.133">where vines would never fail,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187785" n="9.134">and in it level ploughland,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187786" n="9.134-9.135">whence <milestone ed="p" n="135" unit="line"/> they might reap from season to season harvests exceeding deep, so rich is the soil beneath;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187787" n="9.136-9.139">and in it, too, is a harbor giving safe anchorage, where there is no need of moorings, either to throw out anchor-stones or to make fast stern cables, but one may beach one's ship and wait until the sailors' minds <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> them put out, and the breezes blow fair.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187788" n="9.140-9.141"><milestone ed="p" n="140" unit="line"/>Now at the head of the harbor a spring of bright water flows forth from beneath a cave,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187789" n="9.141">and round about it poplars grow. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187790" n="9.142-9.143">Thither we sailed in, and some god guided us through the murky night; for there was no light to see, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187791" n="9.144-9.145">but a mist lay deep about the ships and the moon <milestone ed="p" n="145" unit="line"/> showed no light from heaven, but was shut in by clouds. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187792" n="9.146-9.148">Then no man's eyes beheld that island, nor did we see the long waves rolling on the beach, until we ran our well-benched ships on shore. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187793" n="9.149-9.150">And when we had beached the ships we lowered all the sails <milestone ed="p" n="150" unit="line"/> and ourselves went forth on the shore of the sea,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187794" n="9.151">and there we fell asleep and waited for the bright Dawn.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187795" n="9.152-9.153">As soon as early Dawn appeared, the rosy-fingered, we roamed throughout the isle marvelling at it;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187796" n="9.154-9.155">and the nymphs, the daughters of Zeus who bears the aegis, roused <milestone ed="p" n="155" unit="line"/> the mountain goats, that my comrades might have <sic>whereof</sic> to make their meal. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187797" n="9.156-9.158">Straightway we took from the ships our curved bows and long javelins, and arrayed in three bands we fell to <mod n="smiting:simpsub">striking</mod>;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187798" n="9.158">and the god soon gave us game to satisfy our hearts. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187799" n="9.159-9.160">The ships that followed me were twelve, and to each <milestone ed="p" n="160" unit="line"/> nine goats fell by lot, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187800" n="9.160">but for me alone they chose out ten.</s></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:9.161-9.192">

<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2187801" n="9.161-9.162">So then all day long till set of sun we sat feasting on abundant flesh and sweet wine. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187802" n="9.163-9.164">For not yet was the red wine spent <corr n="from out">out of</corr> our ships, but some was still left;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187803" n="9.164-9.165">for abundant store <milestone ed="p" n="165" unit="line"/> had we drawn in jars for each crew</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187804" n="9.165">when we took the sacred citadel of the Cicones. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187805" n="9.166-9.167">And we looked across to the land of the Cyclopes, who dwelt close at hand, and marked the smoke, and the voice of men, and of the sheep, and of the goats. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187806" n="9.168-9.169">But when the sun set and darkness came on, then we lay down to rest on the shore of the sea.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187807" n="9.170-9.171"><milestone ed="p" n="170" unit="line"/>And as soon as early Dawn appeared, the rosy-fingered, I called my men together and spoke among them all:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2187808" n="9.172">Remain here now, all the rest of you, my trusty comrades, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187809" n="9.173-9.176">but I with my own ship and my own company will go and make trial of <sic>yonder</sic> men, to learn who they are, <milestone ed="p" n="175" unit="line"/> whether they are cruel, and wild, and unjust, or whether they love strangers and fear the gods in their thoughts.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187810" n="9.177-9.178">So saying, I went on board the ship and <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> my comrades themselves to embark, and to loose the stern cables. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187811" n="9.179-9.180">So they went on board straightway and sat down upon the benches, <milestone ed="p" n="180" unit="line"/> and sitting well in order <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> the grey sea with their oars. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187812" n="9.181-9.183">But when we had reached the place, which lay close at hand, there on the land's edge hard by the sea we saw a high cave, roofed over with laurels,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187813" n="9.183-9.184">and there many flocks, sheep and goats alike, were <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to sleep. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187814" n="9.184-9.186">Round about it <milestone ed="p" n="185" unit="line"/> a high court was built with stones set deep in the earth, and with tall pines and high-crested oaks. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187815" n="9.187-9.188">There a monstrous man was <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to sleep, who shepherded his flocks alone and afar,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187816" n="9.188-9.189">and mingled not with others, but lived apart, with his heart set on lawlessness.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187817" n="9.190-9.192"><milestone ed="p" n="190" unit="line"/>For he was fashioned a wondrous monster, and was not like a man that lives by bread, but like a wooded peak of lofty mountains, which stands out to view alone, apart from the rest.</s></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:9.193-9.230">

<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2187818" n="9.193-9.196">Then I <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> the rest of my trusty comrades to remain there by the ship and to guard the ship, <milestone ed="p" n="195" unit="line"/> but I chose twelve of the best of my comrades and went my way. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187819" n="9.196-9.200">With me I had a goat-skin of the dark, sweet wine, which Maro, son of Euanthes, had given me, the priest of Apollo, the god who used to watch over Ismarus. <milestone unit="para"/> And he had given it me because we had protected him with his child and wife <milestone ed="p" n="200" unit="line"/> out of reverence;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187820" n="9.200-9.201">for he dwelt in a wooded grove of Phoebus Apollo. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187821" n="9.201">And he gave me splendid gifts:</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187822" n="9.202-9.205">of well-wrought gold he gave me seven talents, and he gave me a mixing-bowl all of silver; and besides these, wine, wherewith he filled twelve jars in all, <milestone ed="p" n="205" unit="line"/> wine sweet and unmixed, a drink divine. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187823" n="9.205-9.207">Not one of his slaves nor of the maids in his halls knew <sic>thereof</sic>, but himself and his dear wife, and one house-dame only. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187824" n="9.208-9.211">And as often as they drank that honey-sweet red wine he would fill one cup and pour it into twenty measures of water, <milestone ed="p" n="210" unit="line"/> and a smell would rise from the mixing-bowl marvellously sweet;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187825" n="9.211">then <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> would one not choose to hold back. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187826" n="9.212-9.213">With this wine I filled and took with me a great skin, and also provision in a scrip;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187827" n="9.213-9.215">for my proud spirit had a foreboding that presently a man would come to me clothed in great might, <milestone ed="p" n="215" unit="line"/> a savage man that knew <mod n="naught:simpsub">nothing</mod> of justice or of law.<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note></s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187828" n="9.216-9.217">Speedily we came to the cave, nor did we find him within, but he was pasturing his fat flocks in the fields. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187829" n="9.218">So we entered the cave and gazed in wonder at all things there. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187830" n="9.219-9.220">The crates were <sic>laden</sic> with cheeses, and the pens were crowded <milestone ed="p" n="220" unit="line"/> with lambs and kids. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187831" n="9.220-9.222">Each kind was penned separately: by themselves the firstlings, by themselves the later lambs, and by themselves again the newly weaned. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187832" n="9.222-9.223">And with whey were swimming all the well-wrought vessels, the milk-pails and the bowls into which he milked. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187833" n="9.224-9.227">Then my comrades spoke and besought me first of all <milestone ed="p" n="225" unit="line"/> to take of the cheeses and depart, and thereafter speedily to drive to the swift ship the kids and lambs <corr n="from out">out of</corr> the pens, and to sail over the salt water. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187834" n="9.228-9.229">But I did not listen to them—verily it would have been better far—to the end that I might see the man himself, and whether he would give me gifts of entertainment.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187835" n="9.230"><milestone ed="p" n="230" unit="line"/>Yet, as it fell, his appearing was not to prove a joy to my comrades.</s></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:9.231-9.280">

<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2187836" n="9.231-9.233">Then we kindled a fire and offered sacrifice, and ourselves, too, took of the cheeses and ate, and thus we sat in the cave and waited for him until he came back, herding his flocks. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187837" n="9.233-9.235">He bore a mighty weight of dry wood to serve him at supper time, <milestone ed="p" n="235" unit="line"/> and flung it down with a crash inside the cave,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187838" n="9.236">but we, seized with terror, shrank back into a recess of the cave. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187839" n="9.237-9.239">But he drove his fat flocks into the wide cavern—all those that he milked; but the males—the rams and the goats—he left without in the deep court.<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note>


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187840" n="9.240-9.241"><milestone ed="p" n="240" unit="line"/>Then he lifted on high and set in place the great door-stone, a mighty rock; 


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187841" n="9.241-9.242">two and twenty stout four-wheeled wagons could not lift it from the ground,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187842" n="9.243">such a towering mass of rock he set in the doorway. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187843" n="9.244-9.245">Thereafter he sat down and milked the ewes and bleating goats <milestone ed="p" n="245" unit="line"/> all in turn, and beneath each dam he placed her young. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187844" n="9.246-9.249">Then presently he curdled half the white milk, and gathered it in wicker baskets and laid it away, and the other half he set in vessels that he might have it to take and drink, and that it might serve him for supper.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187845" n="9.250-9.251"><milestone ed="p" n="250" unit="line"/>But when he had busily performed his tasks, then he rekindled the fire, and caught sight of us, and asked:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2187846" n="9.252">Strangers, who are <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod>? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187847" n="9.252">Whence do <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> sail over the watery ways? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187848" n="9.253-9.255">Is it on some business, or do <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> wander at random over the sea, even as pirates, who wander, <milestone ed="p" n="255" unit="line"/> hazarding their lives and bringing evil to men of other lands?</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187849" n="9.256-9.257">So he spoke, and in our breasts our spirit was broken for terror of his deep voice and monstrous self;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187850" n="9.258">yet even so I made answer and spoke to him, saying:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187851" n="9.259-9.262">We, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> must know, are from <placeName key="perseus,Troy">Troy</placeName>, Achaeans, driven wandering <milestone ed="p" n="260" unit="line"/> by all manner of winds over the great gulf of the sea. Seeking our home, we have come by another way, by other paths; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187852" n="9.262">so, I <mod n="ween:simpsub">believe</mod>, Zeus was pleased to devise. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187853" n="9.263-9.264">And we declare that we are the men of Agamemnon, son of Atreus, whose fame is now mightiest under heaven,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187854" n="9.265-9.266"><milestone ed="p" n="265" unit="line"/> so great a city did he sack, and <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> many people;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187855" n="9.266-9.268">but we on our part, thus visiting <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, have come as suppliants to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> knees, in the hope that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wilt:simpsub">will</mod> give us entertainment, or in other wise make some present, as is the due of strangers. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187856" n="9.269"><sic>Nay</sic>, mightiest one, reverence the gods;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187857" n="9.269-9.271">we are <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> suppliants; <milestone ed="p" n="270" unit="line"/> and Zeus is the avenger of suppliants and strangers—Zeus, the strangers' god—who ever attends upon reverend strangers.</s></q></p>


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187858" n="9.272">So I spoke, and he straightway made answer with pitiless heart: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187859" n="9.273-9.274">A fool <corr n="art thou">are you</corr>, stranger, or art come from afar, seeing that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='biddest'>command</mod> me either to fear or to shun the gods.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187860" n="9.275-9.276"><milestone ed="p" n="275" unit="line"/>For the Cyclopes <mod n="reck:simpsub">care</mod> not of Zeus, who bears the aegis, nor of the blessed gods, since <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> we are better far than they. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187861" n="9.277-9.278">Nor would I, to shun the wrath of Zeus, spare either <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> or <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> comrades, unless my own heart should <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> me. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187862" n="9.279-9.280">But tell me where <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> moor <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> well-wrought ship on <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> coming. <milestone ed="p" n="280" unit="line"/>Was it <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> at a remote part of the land, or close by? I fain would know.</s></q></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:9.281-9.317">

<p><q><p>



<s xml:id="sent2187864" n="9.281-9.282">So he spoke, tempting me, but he trapped me not because of my great cunning; and I made answer again in crafty words:


</s>
<q>



<s xml:id="sent2187865" n="9.283-9.285">My ship Poseidon, the earth-shaker, dashed to pieces, casting her upon the rocks at the border of your land; <milestone ed="p" n="285" unit="line"/> for he brought her close to the headland,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187866" n="9.285">and the wind drove her in from the sea. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187867" n="9.286">But I, with these men here, escaped utter destruction.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187868" n="9.287-9.290">So I spoke, but from his pitiless heart he made no answer, but sprang up and put forth his hands upon my comrades. Two of them at once he seized and  to the earth like puppies, <milestone ed="p" n="290" unit="line"/> dashed. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187869" n="9.290">And the brain flowed forth upon the ground and wetted the earth. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187870" n="9.291">Then he cut them limb from limb and made ready his supper,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187871" n="9.292-9.293">and ate them as a mountain-nurtured lion, leaving naught—ate the entrails, and the flesh, and the marrowy bones. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187872" n="9.294-9.295">And we with wailing held up our hands to Zeus, <milestone ed="p" n="295" unit="line"/> beholding his cruel deeds; and helplessness possessed our souls. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187873" n="9.296-9.298">But when the Cyclops had filled his huge maw by eating human flesh and thereafter drinking pure milk, he lay down within the cave, stretched out among the sheep. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187874" n="9.299-9.302">And I formed a plan in my great heart <milestone ed="p" n="300" unit="line"/> to steal near him, and draw my sharp sword from beside my thigh and <mod n="smite:simpsub">strike</mod> him in the breast, where the midriff holds the liver, feeling for the place with my hand. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187875" n="9.302">But a second thought checked me,


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187876" n="9.303">for right there should we, too, have perished in utter ruin. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187877" n="9.304-9.305">For we should not have been able <milestone ed="p" n="305" unit="line"/> to thrust back with our hands from the high door the mighty stone which he had set there. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187878" n="9.306">So then, with wailing, we waited for the bright Dawn.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187879" n="9.307-9.309">As soon as early Dawn appeared, the rosy-fingered, he rekindled the fire and milked his goodly flocks all in turn, and beneath each dam placed her young.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187880" n="9.310-9.311"><milestone ed="p" n="310" unit="line"/>Then, when he had busily performed his tasks, again he seized two men at once and made ready his meal. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187881" n="9.312-9.313">And when he had made his meal he drove his fat flocks forth from the cave, easily moving away the great door-stone;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187882" n="9.313-9.314">and then he put it in place again, as one might set the lid upon a quiver.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187883" n="9.315-9.316"><milestone ed="p" n="315" unit="line"/>Then with loud whistling the Cyclops turned his fat flocks toward the mountain,


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187884" n="9.316-9.317">and I was left there, devising evil in the deep of my heart, if in any way I might take vengeance on him, and Athena grant me glory.</s></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:9.318-9.359">

<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2187885" n="9.318">Now this seemed to my mind the best plan. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187886" n="9.319-9.320">There lay beside a sheep-pen a great club of the Cyclops, <milestone ed="p" n="320" unit="line"/> a staff of green olive-wood,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187887" n="9.320-9.321">which he had cut to carry with him when dry;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187888" n="9.321-9.323">and as we looked at it we thought it as large as is the mast of a black ship of twenty oars, a merchantman, broad of beam, which crosses over the great gulf;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187889" n="9.324">so huge it was in length and in breadth to look upon.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187890" n="9.325-9.326"><milestone ed="p" n="325" unit="line"/>To this I came, and cut off therefrom about a fathom's length and handed it to my comrades, bidding them dress it down;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187891" n="9.327">and they made it smooth, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187892" n="9.327-9.328">and I, standing by, sharpened it at the point, and then straightway took it and hardened it in the blazing fire. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187893" n="9.329-9.330">Then I laid it carefully away, hiding it beneath the dung, <milestone ed="p" n="330" unit="line"/> which lay in great heaps throughout the cave. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187894" n="9.331-9.333">And I <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> my comrades cast lots among them, which of them should have the hardihood with me to lift the stake and grind it into his eye when sweet sleep should come upon him. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187895" n="9.334-9.335">And the lot fell upon those whom I myself would fain have chosen; <milestone ed="p" n="335" unit="line"/> four they were, and I was numbered with them as the fifth. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187896" n="9.336">At even then he came, herding his flocks of goodly fleece,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187897" n="9.337-9.339">and straightway drove into the wide cave his fat flocks one and all, and left not one without in the deep court, either from some foreboding or because a god so <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> him.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187898" n="9.340-9.342"><milestone ed="p" n="340" unit="line"/>Then he lifted on high and set in place the great door-stone, and sitting down he milked the ewes and bleating goats all in turn, and beneath each dam he placed her young. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187899" n="9.343-9.344">But when he had busily performed his tasks, again he seized two men at once and made ready his supper.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187900" n="9.345-9.346"><milestone ed="p" n="345" unit="line"/>Then I drew near and spoke to the Cyclops, holding in my hands an ivy<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> bowl of the dark wine:
</s></p>


<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2187901" n="9.347-9.349">Cyclops, take and drink wine after <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> meal of human flesh, that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='mayest'>may</mod> know what manner of drink this is which our ship contained. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187902" n="9.349-9.350">It was to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> that I was bringing it as a drink offering, in the hope that, touched with pity, <milestone ed="p" n="350" unit="line"/> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='mightest'>might</mod> send me on my way home;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187903" n="9.350">but <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='ragest'>rage</mod> in a way that is past all bearing. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187904" n="9.351-9.352">Cruel man, how shall any one of all the multitudes of men ever come to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> again hereafter, seeing that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> <sic>wrought</sic> lawlessness?</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187905" n="9.353">So I spoke, and he took the cup and drained it,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187906" n="9.353-9.354">and was wondrously pleased as he drank the sweet draught, and asked me for it again a second time:</s></p> <milestone ed="p" n="355" unit="line"/>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2187907" n="9.355-9.356">Give it me again with a ready heart, and tell me <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> name straightway, that I may give <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> a stranger's gift whereat <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='mayest'>may</mod> be glad. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187908" n="9.357-9.358">For among the Cyclopes the earth, the giver of grain, bears the rich clusters of wine, and the rain of Zeus gives them increase; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187909" n="9.359">but this is a streamlet of ambrosia and nectar.</s></q></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:9.360-9.408">





<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2187911" n="9.360"><milestone ed="p" n="360" unit="line"/>So he spoke, and again I handed him the flaming wine. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187912" n="9.361"><mod n="Thrice:simpsub">Three times</mod> I brought and gave it him, and <mod n="thrice:simpsub">three times</mod> he drained it in his folly. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187913" n="9.362-9.363">But when the wine had stolen about the wits of the Cyclops, then I spoke to him with gentle words:</s></p>

<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2187914" n="9.364-9.365">Cyclops, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='askest'>ask</mod> me of my glorious name, and I <milestone ed="p" n="365" unit="line"/> will tell it <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187915" n="9.365">and do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> give me a stranger's gift, even as <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> promise. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187916" n="9.366">Noman is my name, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187917" n="9.366-9.367">Noman do they call me—my mother and my father, and all my comrades as well.</s></q></p>


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187918" n="9.368">So I spoke, and he straightway answered me with pitiless heart: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187919" n="9.369-9.370">Noman will I eat last among his comrades, <milestone ed="p" n="370" unit="line"/> and the others before him;
</s>


<s xml:id="sent2187920" n="9.370">this shall be <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> gift.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187921" n="9.371-9.373">He spoke, and reeling fell upon his back, and lay there with his thick neck bent aslant, and sleep, that conquers all, laid hold on him. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187922" n="9.373-9.374">And from his gullet came forth wine and bits of human flesh,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187923" n="9.374">and he vomited in his drunken sleep.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187924" n="9.375-9.376"><milestone ed="p" n="375" unit="line"/>Then <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> I thrust in the stake under the deep ashes until it should grow hot,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187925" n="9.376-9.377">and heartened all my comrades with cheering words, that I might see no man flinch through fear. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187926" n="9.378-9.381">But when presently that stake of olive-wood was about to catch fire, green though it was, and began to glow terribly, <milestone ed="p" n="380" unit="line"/> then <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> I drew <mod n="nigh:simpsub">near</mod>, bringing the stake from the fire, and my comrades stood round me

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187927" n="9.381">and a god breathed into us great courage. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187928" n="9.382-9.383">They took the stake of olive-wood, sharp at the point, and thrust it into his eye,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187929" n="9.383-9.386">while I, throwing my weight upon it from above, whirled it round, as when a man bores a ship's timber <milestone ed="p" n="385" unit="line"/> with a drill, while those below keep it spinning with the thong, which they lay hold of by either end, and the drill runs around unceasingly. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187930" n="9.387-9.388">Even so we took the fiery-pointed stake and whirled it around in his eye, and the blood flowed around the heated thing. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187931" n="9.389-9.390">And his eyelids wholly and his brows round about did the flame singe <milestone ed="p" n="390" unit="line"/> as the eyeball burned, and its roots crackled in the fire. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187932" n="9.391-9.393">And as when a smith dips a great axe or an adze in cold water <mod n="amid:simpsub">among</mod> loud hissing to temper it—

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187933" n="9.393-9.394">for therefrom comes the strength of iron— even so did his eye hiss round the stake of olive-wood.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187934" n="9.395-9.396"><milestone ed="p" n="395" unit="line"/>Terribly then did he cry aloud, and the rock rang around; and we, seized with terror, shrank back, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187935" n="9.396-9.397">while he wrenched from his eye the stake, all befouled with blood,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187936" n="9.398-9.400">and flung it from him, wildly waving his arms. Then he called aloud to the Cyclopes, who <milestone ed="p" n="400" unit="line"/> dwelt round about him in caves among the windy heights, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187937" n="9.401-9.402">and they heard his cry and came thronging from every side, and standing around the cave asked him what ailed him:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2187938" n="9.403-9.404">What so <sic>sore</sic> distress is <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod>, Polyphemus, that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> criest out thus through the immortal night, and <mod n='makest'>make</mod> us sleepless?

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187939" n="9.405"><milestone ed="p" n="405" unit="line"/>Can it be that some mortal man is driving off <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> flocks against <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> will,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187940" n="9.406">or slaying <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod> by guile or by might?</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187941" n="9.407">Then <corr n="from out">out of</corr> the cave the mighty Polyphemus answered them: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187942" n="9.408">My friends, it is Noman that is slaying me by guile and not by force.</s>
</q></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:9.409-9.460">

<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2187944" n="9.409">And they made answer and addressed him with winged words:

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187945" n="9.410-9.412"><milestone ed="p" n="410" unit="line"/> If, then, no man does violence to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> loneliness, sickness which comes from great Zeus <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='mayest'>may</mod> in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> escape. <sic>Nay</sic>, do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> pray to our father, the lord Poseidon.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187946" n="9.413-9.414">So they spoke and went their way; and my heart laughed within me that my name and cunning device had so beguiled.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187947" n="9.415-9.418"><milestone ed="p" n="415" unit="line"/>But the Cyclops, groaning and travailing in anguish, groped with his hands and took away the stone from the door, and himself sat in the doorway with arms outstretched in the hope of catching anyone who sought to go forth with the sheep—

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187948" n="9.419">so witless, <sic>forsooth</sic>, he thought in his heart to find me.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187949" n="9.420-9.422"><milestone ed="p" n="420" unit="line"/>But I took counsel how all might be the very best, if I might <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> find some way of escape from death for my comrades and for myself. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187950" n="9.422-9.423">And I wove all manner of wiles and counsel, as a man will in a matter of life and death;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187951" n="9.423">for great was the evil that was <mod n="nigh:simpsub">near</mod> us. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187952" n="9.424">And this seemed to my mind the best plan.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187953" n="9.425-9.426"><milestone ed="p" n="425" unit="line"/>Rams there were, well-fed and thick of fleece, fine beasts and large, with wool dark as the violet. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187954" n="9.427-9.429">These I silently bound together with twisted withes on which the Cyclops, that monster with his heart set on lawlessness, was <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to sleep. Three at a time I took. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187955" n="9.429-9.430">The one in the middle in each case bore a man, <milestone ed="p" n="430" unit="line"/> and the other two went, one on either side, saving my comrades. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187956" n="9.431">Thus every three sheep bore a man. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187957" n="9.431-9.434">But as for me—there was a ram, far the best of all the flock; him I grasped by the back, and curled beneath his shaggy belly, lay there face upwards,


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187958" n="9.434-9.435"><milestone ed="p" n="435" unit="line"/> clinging fast with my hands to his wondrous fleece with steadfast heart. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187959" n="9.436">So then, with wailing, we waited for the bright dawn.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187960" n="9.437-9.439">As soon as early Dawn appeared, the rosy-fingered, then the males of the flock hastened forth to pasture and the females bleated unmilked about the pens,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187961" n="9.440"><milestone ed="p" n="440" unit="line"/> for their udders were bursting. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187962" n="9.440-9.442">And their master, distressed with grievous pains, felt along the backs of all the sheep as they stood up before him, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187963" n="9.442-9.443">but in his folly he marked not this, that my men were bound beneath the breasts of his fleecy sheep. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187964" n="9.444-9.445">Last of all the flock the ram went forth, <milestone ed="p" n="445" unit="line"/> burdened with the weight of his fleece and my cunning self. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187965" n="9.446">And mighty Polyphemus, as he felt along his back, spoke to him, saying:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2187966" n="9.447-9.448">Good ram, why pray is it that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='goest'>go</mod> forth thus through the cave the last of the flock? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187967" n="9.448-9.452">Thou <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> not heretofore been <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to lag behind the sheep, but <mod n="wast:simpsub">were</mod> ever far the first to feed on the tender bloom of the grass, <milestone ed="p" n="450" unit="line"/> moving with long strides, and ever the first <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> reach the streams of the river, and the first <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> long to return to the fold at evening. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187968" n="9.452">But now <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> last of all. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187969" n="9.452-9.455">Surely <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> sorrowing for the eye of <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> master, which an evil man blinded along with his miserable fellows, when he had overpowered my wits with wine, <milestone ed="p" n="455" unit="line"/> even Noman, who, I tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, has not yet escaped destruction. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187970" n="9.456-9.457">If only <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> couldst feel as I do, and couldst get <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> power of speech to tell me where he skulks away from my wrath,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187971" n="9.458-9.460">then should his brains be dashed on the ground here and there throughout the cave, when I had <mod n="smitten:simpsub">struck</mod> him, and my heart <milestone ed="p" n="460" unit="line"/> should be lightened of the woes which good-for-naught Noman has brought me.</s></q></p></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:9.461-9.499">

<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2187973" n="9.461">So saying, he sent the ram forth from him. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187974" n="9.462-9.463">And when we had gone a little way from the cave and the court, I first loosed myself from under the ram and set my comrades free. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187975" n="9.464-9.466">Speedily then we drove off those long-shanked sheep, rich with fat, <milestone ed="p" n="465" unit="line"/> turning full often to look about until we came to the ship. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187976" n="9.466-9.467">And welcome to our dear comrades was the sight of us who had escaped death, but for the others they wept and wailed;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187977" n="9.468-9.470">yet I would not suffer them to weep, but with a frown forbade each man. Rather I <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> them <milestone ed="p" n="470" unit="line"/> to fling on board with speed the many sheep of goodly fleece, and sail over the salt water. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187978" n="9.471-9.472">So they went on board straightway and sat down upon the benches, and sitting well in order <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> the grey sea with their oars. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187979" n="9.473-9.474">But when I was as far away as a man's voice carries when he shouts, then I spoke to the Cyclops with mocking words:



</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187980" n="9.475-9.476"><milestone ed="p" n="475" unit="line"/>Cyclops, that man, it seems, was no weakling, whose comrades <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wast:simpsub">were</mod> minded to devour by brutal strength in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> hollow cave.

<s xml:id="sent2187981" n="9.477-9.479">Full surely were <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> evil deeds to fall on <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> own head, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> cruel wretch, who <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> not shrink from eating <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> guests in <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> own house. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187982" n="9.479">Therefore has Zeus taken vengeance on <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, and the other gods.</s></q></p>



<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187983" n="9.480-9.484"><milestone ed="p" n="480" unit="line"/>So I spoke, and he <mod n="waxed:simpsub">became</mod> the more <mod n="wroth:simpsub">angry</mod> at heart, and broke off the peak of a high mountain and hurled it at us, and cast it in front of the dark-prowed ship.<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187984" n="9.485-9.486">And the sea surged beneath the stone as it fell, <milestone ed="p" n="485" unit="line"/> and the backward flow, like a flood from the deep, bore the ship swiftly landwards and drove it upon the shore. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187985" n="9.487-9.490">But I seized a long pole in my hands and shoved the ship off and along the shore, <milestone ed="p" n="490" unit="line"/> and with a nod of my head I roused my comrades, and <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> them fall to their oars that we might escape out of our evil plight. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187986" n="9.490">And they bent to their oars and rowed. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187987" n="9.491-9.492">But when, as we fared over the sea, we were twice as far distant, then was I fain to call to the Cyclops,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187988" n="9.492-9.493">though round about me my comrades, one after another, sought to check me with gentle words:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2187989" n="9.494">Reckless one, why <mod n="wilt:simpsub">will</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> provoke to wrath a savage man,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187990" n="9.495-9.496"><milestone ed="p" n="495" unit="line"/> who but now hurled his missile into the deep and drove our ship back to the land, and <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> we thought that we had perished there? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187991" n="9.497-9.499">And had he heard one of us uttering a sound or speaking, he would have hurled a jagged rock and crushed our heads and the timbers of our ship,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187992" n="9.499">so mightily does he throw.</s></q></p></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:9.500-9.535">





<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2187994" n="9.500-9.501"><milestone ed="p" n="500" unit="line"/>So they spoke, but they could not persuade my great-hearted spirit; and I answered him again with angry heart:</s></p>

<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2187995" n="9.502-9.505">Cyclops, if any one of mortal men shall ask <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> about the shameful blinding of <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> eye, say that Odysseus, the sacker of cities, blinded it, <milestone ed="p" n="505" unit="line"/> even the son of Laertes, whose home is in <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName>.</s></q></p>


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2187996" n="9.506">So I spoke, and he groaned and said in answer: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2187997" n="9.507"><sic>Lo</sic> now, <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> a prophecy uttered long ago is come upon me. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187998" n="9.508-9.510">There lived here a soothsayer, a good man and tall, Telemus, son of Eurymus, who excelled all men in soothsaying, <milestone ed="p" n="510" unit="line"/> and grew old as a seer among the Cyclopes. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2187999" n="9.511-9.512">He told me that all these things should be brought to pass in days to come, that by the hands of Odysseus I should lose my sight. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188000" n="9.513-9.514">But I ever looked for some tall and comely man to come <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod>, clothed in great might,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188001" n="9.515-9.516"><milestone ed="p" n="515" unit="line"/> but now one that is puny, a man of <mod n="naught:simpsub">nothing</mod> and a weakling, has blinded me of my eye when he had overpowered me with wine. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188002" n="9.517-9.518">Yet come <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod>, Odysseus, that I may set before <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> gifts of entertainment, and may speed <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> sending hence, that the glorious Earth-shaker may grant it <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188003" n="9.519">For I am his son, and he declares himself my father;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188004" n="9.520-9.521"><milestone ed="p" n="520" unit="line"/> and he himself will heal me, if it be his good pleasure, but none other either of the blessed gods or of mortal men.</s></q></p>


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188005" n="9.522">So he spoke, and I answered him and said: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188006" n="9.523-9.525">Would that I were able to rob <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> of soul and life, and to send <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> to the house of Hades, <milestone ed="p" n="525" unit="line"/> as surely as not even the Earth-shaker shall heal <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> eye.</s></q></p>


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188007" n="9.526">So I spoke,</s>


<s xml:id="sent2188008" n="9.526-9.527">and he then prayed to the lord Poseidon, stretching out both his hands to the starry heaven: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188009" n="9.528-9.531">Hear me, Poseidon, earth-enfolder, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> dark-haired god, if indeed I am <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> son and <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='declarest'>declare</mod> <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod> my father; <milestone ed="p" n="530" unit="line"/> grant that Odysseus, the sacker of cities, may never reach his home, even the son of Laertes, whose home is in <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName>; 

</s>


<s xml:id="sent2188010" n="9.532-9.535">but if it is his fate to see his friends and to reach his well-built house and his native land, late may he come and in evil case, after losing all his comrades, <milestone ed="p" n="535" unit="line"/> in a ship that is another's; and may he find woes in his house.</s></q></p></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:9.536-9.566">

<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188011" n="9.536">So he spoke in prayer, and the dark-haired god heard him. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188012" n="9.537-9.540">But the Cyclops lifted on high again a far greater stone, and swung and hurled it, putting into the throw measureless strength. He cast it <milestone ed="p" n="540" unit="line"/> a little behind the dark-prowed ship, and barely missed the end of the steering-oar. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188013" n="9.541">And the sea surged beneath the stone as it fell,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188014" n="9.542">and the wave bore the ship onward and drove it to the shore.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188015" n="9.543-9.547">Now when we had come to the island, where our other well-benched ships lay all together, and round about them our comrades, <milestone ed="p" n="545" unit="line"/> ever expecting us, sat weeping, then, on coming thither, we beached our ship on the sands, and ourselves went forth upon the shore of the sea. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188016" n="9.548-9.549">Then we took <corr n="from out">out of</corr> the hollow ship the flocks of the Cyclops, and divided them, that so far as in me lay no man might go defrauded of an equal share.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188017" n="9.550-9.551"><milestone ed="p" n="550" unit="line"/>But the ram my well-greaved comrades gave to me alone, when the flocks were divided, as a gift apart; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188018" n="9.551-9.553">and on the shore I sacrificed him to Zeus, son of Cronos, god of the dark clouds, who is lord of all, and burned the thigh-pieces. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188019" n="9.553-9.555"><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod> he heeded not my sacrifice, but was planning how all <milestone ed="p" n="555" unit="line"/> my well-benched ships might perish and my trusty comrades.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188020" n="9.556-9.557">So, then, all day long till set of sun we sat feasting on abundant flesh and sweet wine;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188021" n="9.558-9.559">but when the sun set and darkness came on, then we lay down to rest on the shore of the sea.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188022" n="9.560-9.562"><milestone ed="p" n="560" unit="line"/>And as soon as early Dawn appeared, the rosy-fingered, I roused my comrades, and <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> them themselves to embark and to loose the stern cables. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188023" n="9.563-9.564">So they went on board straightway and sat down upon the benches, and sitting well in order <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> the grey sea with their oars.</s></p>
<milestone ed="p" n="565" unit="line"/>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188024" n="9.565-9.566">Thence we sailed on, grieved at heart, glad to have escaped death, though we had lost our dear comrades.</s></p></q></p>
