<div type="textpart" subtype="book" n="10">
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:10.1-10.45">
<p><q>



<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188025" n="10.1"><milestone ed="p" n="1" unit="line"/>Then to the Aeolian isle we came,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188026" n="10.1-10.3">where dwelt Aeolus, son of Hippotas, dear to the immortal gods, in a floating island,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188027" n="10.3-10.4">and all around it is a wall of unbreakable bronze, and the cliff runs up sheer.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188028" n="10.5-10.6"><milestone ed="p" n="5" unit="line"/>Twelve children of his, too, there are in the halls, six daughters and six sturdy sons,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188029" n="10.7">and he gave his daughters to his sons to wife. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188030" n="10.8-10.11">These, then, feast continually by their dear father and good mother, and before them lies boundless good cheer. <milestone ed="p" n="10" unit="line"/>And the house, filled with the savour of feasting, resounds all about even in the outer court by day,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188031" n="10.11-10.12">and by night again they sleep beside their chaste wives on blankets and on corded bedsteads. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188032" n="10.13">To their city, then, and fair palace did we come,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188033" n="10.14-10.15">and for a full month he made me welcome and questioned me about each thing, <milestone ed="p" n="15" unit="line"/> about <placeName key="tgn,7002329">Ilios</placeName>, and the ships of the Argives, and the return of the Achaeans. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188034" n="10.16">And I told him all the tale in due order. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188035" n="10.17-10.18">But when I, on my part, asked him that I might depart and <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> him send me on my way, he, too, denied me nothing, but furthered my sending. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188036" n="10.19-10.20">He gave me a wallet, made of the hide of an ox nine years old,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">2</note> which he flayed, <milestone ed="p" n="20" unit="line"/> and therein he bound the paths of the blustering winds; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188037" n="10.21-10.22">for the son of Cronos had made him keeper of the winds, both to still and to rouse whatever one he will. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188038" n="10.23-10.24">And in my hollow ship he bound it fast with a bright cord of silver, that not a breath might escape, were it never so slight.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188039" n="10.25-10.26"><milestone ed="p" n="25" unit="line"/>But for my furtherance he sent forth the breath of the West Wind to blow, that it might bear on their way both ships and men. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188040" n="10.26-10.27">Yet this he was not to bring to pass,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188041" n="10.27">for we were lost through our own folly.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188042" n="10.28-10.30">For nine days we sailed, night and day alike, and now on the tenth our native land came in sight, <milestone ed="p" n="30" unit="line"/> and <sic>lo</sic>, we were so near that we saw men tending the beacon fires.<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188043" n="10.31-10.33">Then upon me came sweet sleep in my weariness, for I had ever kept in hand the sheet of the ship, and had yielded it to none other of my comrades, that we might the sooner come to our native land. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188044" n="10.34-10.36">But my comrades meanwhile began to speak one to another, <milestone ed="p" n="35" unit="line"/> and said that I was bringing home for myself gold and silver as gifts from Aeolus, the great-hearted son of Hippotas. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188045" n="10.37">And thus would one speak, with a glance at his neighbor:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188046" n="10.38-10.39">Out on it, how beloved and honored this man is by all men, to whose city and land soever he comes!

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188047" n="10.40-10.42"><milestone ed="p" n="40" unit="line"/>Much goodly treasure is he carrying with him from the land of <placeName key="tgn,7002329">Troy</placeName> <corr n="from out">out of</corr> the spoil, while we, who have accomplished the same journey as he, are returning, bearing with us empty hands. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188048" n="10.43-10.44">And now Aeolus has given him these gifts, granting them freely of his love. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188049" n="10.44-10.45"><sic>Nay</sic>, come, let us quickly see what is here, <milestone ed="p" n="45" unit="line"/> what store of gold and silver is in the wallet.</s></q></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:10.46-10.86">


<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188051" n="10.46">So they spoke, and the evil counsel of my comrades prevailed. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188052" n="10.47">They loosed the wallet, and all the winds leapt forth,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188053" n="10.48-10.49">and swiftly the storm-wind seized them and bore them weeping out to sea away from their native land;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188054" n="10.49-10.52">but as for me, <milestone ed="p" n="50" unit="line"/>I awoke, and pondered in my goodly heart whether I should fling myself from the ship and perish in the sea, or endure in silence and still remain among the living. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188055" n="10.53-10.54">However, I endured and <sic>abode</sic>, and covering my head lay down in the ship. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188056" n="10.54-10.55">But the ships were borne by an evil blast of wind <milestone ed="p" n="55" unit="line"/> back to the Aeolian isle; and my comrades groaned.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188057" n="10.56-10.57">There we went ashore and drew water, and straightway my comrades took their meal by the swift ships. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188058" n="10.58-10.60">But when we had tasted of food and drink, I took with me a herald and one companion <milestone ed="p" n="60" unit="line"/> and went to the glorious palace of Aeolus,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188059" n="10.60-10.61">and I found him feasting beside his wife and his children. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188060" n="10.62-10.63">So we entered the house and sat down by the doorposts on the threshold,></s>


<s xml:id="sent2188061" n="10.63">and they were amazed at heart, and questioned us:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188062" n="10.64">How <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> come <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod>, Odysseus? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188063" n="10.64">What cruel god assailed <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>?

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188064" n="10.65-10.66"><milestone ed="p" n="65" unit="line"/>Surely we sent <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> forth with kindly care, that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='mightest'>might</mod> reach <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> native land and <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> home, and whatever place <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='wouldest'>would</mod>.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188065" n="10.67">So said they, but I with a sorrowing heart spoke among them and said: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188066" n="10.68-10.69">Bane did my evil comrades work me, and therewith sleep accursed;</s>


<s xml:id="sent2188067" n="10.69">but bring <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> healing, my friends,</s>


<s xml:id="sent2188068" n="10.69">for with you is the power.</s></q></p>



<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188069" n="10.70-10.71"><milestone ed="p" n="70" unit="line"/>So I spoke and addressed them with gentle words, but they were silent. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188070" n="10.71">Then their father answered and said:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188071" n="10.72">Begone from our island with speed, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> vilest of all that live. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188072" n="10.73-10.74">In <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> may I help or send upon his way that man who is hated of the blessed gods.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188073" n="10.75"><milestone ed="p" n="75" unit="line"/>Begone, for <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> comest <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod> as one hated of the immortals.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188074" n="10.76">So saying, he sent me forth from the house, groaning heavily. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188075" n="10.77">Thence we sailed on, grieved at heart. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188076" n="10.78-10.79">And worn was the spirit of the men by the grievous rowing, because of our own folly, for no longer appeared any breeze to bear us on our way.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188077" n="10.80-10.83"><milestone ed="p" n="80" unit="line"/>So for six days we sailed, night and day alike, and on the seventh we came to the lofty citadel of Lamus, even to Telepylus of the Laestrygonians, where herdsman calls to herdsman as he drives in his flock, and the other answers as he drives his forth. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188078" n="10.84-10.85">There a man who never slept could have earned a double wage, <milestone ed="p" n="85" unit="line"/> one by herding cattle, and one by pasturing white sheep;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188079" n="10.86">for the out goings of the night and of the day are close together.<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note>
</s></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:10.87-10.132">
<p><q>


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188080" n="10.87-10.91">When we had come thither into the goodly harbor, about which on both sides a sheer cliff runs continuously, and projecting headlands opposite to one another <milestone ed="p" n="90" unit="line"/> stretch out at the mouth, and the entrance is narrow, then all the rest steered their curved ships in,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188081" n="10.92-10.93">and the ships were moored within the hollow harbor close together;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188082" n="10.93-10.94">for therein no wave ever swelled, great or small, but all about was a bright calm.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188083" n="10.95-10.96"><milestone ed="p" n="95" unit="line"/>But I alone moored my black ship outside, there on the border of the land, making the cables fast to the rock. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188084" n="10.97">Then I climbed to a rugged height, a point of outlook, and there took my stand;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188085" n="10.98-10.99">from thence no works of oxen or of men appeared; smoke alone we saw springing up from the land.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188086" n="10.100-10.102"><milestone ed="p" n="100" unit="line"/>So then I sent forth some of my comrades to go and learn who the men were, who here ate bread upon the earth—two men I chose, and sent with them a third as a herald. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188087" n="10.103-10.106">Now when they had gone ashore, they went along a smooth road by which wagons were <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to bring wood down to the city from the high mountains. <milestone ed="p" n="105" unit="line"/>And before the city they met a maiden drawing water, the goodly<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> daughter of Laestrygonian Antiphates, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188088" n="10.107-10.108">who had come down to the fair-flowing spring Artacia,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188089" n="10.108">So from whence they were <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to bear water to the town. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188090" n="10.109-10.110">So they came up to her and spoke to her, <milestone ed="p" n="110" unit="line"/> and asked her who was king of this <mod n="folk:simpsub">people</mod>, and who they were of whom he was lord. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188091" n="10.111">And she showed them forth with the high-roofed house of her father. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188092" n="10.112-10.113">Now when they had entered the glorious house, they found there his wife, huge as the peak of a mountain, and they were aghast at her. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188093" n="10.114-10.115">At once she called from the place of assembly the glorious Antiphates, <milestone ed="p" n="115" unit="line"/> her husband, and he devised for them woeful destruction. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188094" n="10.116">Straightway he seized one of my comrades and made ready his meal,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188095" n="10.117">but the other two sprang up and came in flight to the ships. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188096" n="10.118">Then he raised a cry throughout the city,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188097" n="10.118-10.120">and as they heard it the mighty Laestrygonians came thronging from all sides, <milestone ed="p" n="120" unit="line"/> a host past counting, not like men but like the Giants. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188098" n="10.121-10.122">They hurled at us from the cliffs with rocks huge as a man could lift,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188099" n="10.122-10.123">and at once there rose throughout the ships a dreadful din, alike from men that were dying and from ships that were being crushed. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188100" n="10.124">And spearing them like fishes they bore them home, a <mod n="loathly:simpsub">disgusting</mod> meal.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188101" n="10.125-10.127"><milestone ed="p" n="125" unit="line"/>Now while they were slaying those within the deep harbor, I meanwhile drew my sharp sword from beside my thigh, and cut therewith the cables of my dark-prowed ship;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188102" n="10.128-10.129">and quickly calling to my comrades <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> them fall to their oars, that we might escape <corr n="from out">out of</corr> our evil plight.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188103" n="10.130"><milestone ed="p" n="130" unit="line"/>And they all tossed the sea with their oar-blades in fear of death,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188104" n="10.131-10.132">and joyfully seaward, away from the beetling cliffs, my ship sped on;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188105" n="10.132">but all those other ships were lost together there.</s></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:10.133-10.177">


<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188106" n="10.133-10.134">Thence we sailed on, grieved at heart, glad to have escaped death, though we had lost our dear comrades;

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2188107" n="10.135"><milestone ed="p" n="135" unit="line"/> and we came to the isle of Aeaea, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188108" n="10.135-10.137">where dwelt fair-tressed Circe, a <sic>dread</sic> goddess of human speech, own sister to Aeetes of <sic>baneful</sic> mind; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188109" n="10.138-10.139">and both are sprung from Helius, who gives light to mortals, and from <placeName key="tgn,7000231">Perse</placeName>, their mother, whom Oceanus begot.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188110" n="10.140-10.141"><milestone ed="p" n="140" unit="line"/>Here we put in to shore with our ship in silence, into a harbor where ships may lie, and some god guided us. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188111" n="10.142-10.143">Then we disembarked, and lay there for two days and two nights, eating our hearts for weariness and sorrow. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188112" n="10.144-10.147">But when fair-tressed Dawn brought to its birth the third day, <milestone ed="p" n="145" unit="line"/> then I took my spear and my sharp sword, and quickly went up from the ship to a place of wide prospect, in the hope that I might see the works of men, and hear their voice. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188113" n="10.148-10.150">So I climbed to a rugged height, a place of outlook, and there took my stand, and I saw smoke rising from the broad-wayed earth <milestone ed="p" n="150" unit="line"/> in the halls of Circe, through the thick brush and the wood. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188114" n="10.151-10.152">And I debated in mind and heart, whether I should go and make search, when I had seen the flaming smoke. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188115" n="10.153-10.155">And as I pondered, this seemed to me to be the better way, to go first to the swift ship and the shore of the sea, <milestone ed="p" n="155" unit="line"/> and give my comrades their meal, and send them forth to make search. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188116" n="10.156-10.159">But when, as I went, I was near to the curved ship, then some god took pity on me in my loneliness, and sent a great, high-horned stag into my very path. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188117" n="10.159-10.160">He was coming down to the river from his pasture in the wood <milestone ed="p" n="160" unit="line"/> to drink, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188118" n="10.160">for the might of the sun oppressed him; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188119" n="10.161-10.162">and as he came out I struck him on the spine in the middle of the back,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188120" n="10.162-10.163">and the bronze spear passed right through him, and down he fell in the dust with a moan, and his spirit flew from him. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188121" n="10.164-10.165">Then I planted my foot upon him, <milestone ed="p" n="165" unit="line"/> and drew the bronze spear forth from the wound,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188122" n="10.165-10.166">and left it there to lie on the ground. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188123" n="10.166-10.171">But for myself, I plucked twigs and osiers, and weaving a rope as it were a fathom in length, well twisted from end to end, I bound together the feet of the monstrous beast, and went my way to the black ship, bearing him across my back and <milestone ed="p" n="170" unit="line"/> leaning on my spear, since in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> could I hold him on my shoulder with one hand,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188124" n="10.171">for he was a very mighty beast. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188125" n="10.172-10.173">Down I flung him before the ship, and heartened my comrades with gentle words, coming up to each man in turn:</s></p>

<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188126" n="10.174-10.175">Friends, not yet shall we go down <milestone ed="p" n="175" unit="line"/> to the house of Hades, despite our sorrows, before the day of fate comes upon us. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188127" n="10.176-10.177"><sic>Nay</sic>, come, while there is yet food and drink in our swift ship, let us <sic>bethink</sic> us of food, that we pine not with hunger.</s></q></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:10.178-10.207">


<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188129" n="10.178-10.180">So I spoke, and they quickly <mod n="hearkened:simpsub">listened</mod> to my words. From their faces they drew their cloaks,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note>
<milestone ed="p" n="180" unit="line"/> and marvelled at the stag on the shore of the unresting sea,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188130" n="10.180">for he was a very mighty beast. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188131" n="10.181-10.182">But when they had satisfied their eyes with gazing, they washed their hands, and made ready a glorious feast. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188132" n="10.183-10.184">So then all day long till set of sun we sat feasting on abundant flesh and sweet wine.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188133" n="10.185-10.186"><milestone ed="p" n="185" unit="line"/>But when the sun set and darkness came on, then we lay down to rest on the shore of the sea. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188134" n="10.187-10.188">And as soon as early Dawn appeared, the rosy-fingered, I called my men together, and spoke among them all:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188135" n="10.189"><mod n="Hearken:simpsub">Listen</mod> to my words, comrades, for all your evil plight.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188136" n="10.190-10.192"><milestone ed="p" n="190" unit="line"/>My friends, we know not where the darkness is or where the dawn, neither where the sun, who give light to mortals, goes beneath the earth, nor where he rises; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188137" n="10.192-10.193">but let us straightway take thought if any device be still left us. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188138" n="10.193">As for me I think not that there is. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188139" n="10.194-10.195">For I climbed to a rugged point of outlook, and beheld <milestone ed="p" n="195" unit="line"/> the island, about which is set as a crown the boundless deep. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188140" n="10.196">The isle itself lies low,


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188141" n="10.196-10.197">and in the midst of it my eyes saw smoke through the thick brush and the wood.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188142" n="10.198-10.200">So I spoke, and their spirit was broken within them, as they remembered the deeds of the Laestrygonian, Antiphates, <milestone ed="p" n="200" unit="line"/> and the violence of the great-hearted Cyclops, the man-eater. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188143" n="10.201">And they wailed aloud, and shed big tears. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188144" n="10.202">But no good came of their mourning.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188145" n="10.203-10.204">Then I told off in two bands all my well-greaved comrades, and appointed a leader for each band.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188146" n="10.205"><milestone ed="p" n="205" unit="line"/>Of the one I took command, and of the other godlike Eurylochus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188147" n="10.206">Quickly then we shook lots in a brazen helmet, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188148" n="10.207">and out leapt the lot of great-hearted Eurylochus.</s></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:10.208-10.260">

<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188149" n="10.208-10.209">So he set out, and with him went two-and-twenty comrades, all weeping; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188150" n="10.209">and they left us behind, lamenting.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188151" n="10.210-10.211"><milestone ed="p" n="210" unit="line"/>Within the forest glades they found the house of Circe, built of polished stone in a place of wide outlook,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188152" n="10.212-10.213">and round about it were mountain wolves and lions, whom Circe herself had bewitched; for she gave them evil drugs. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188153" n="10.214-10.215">Yet these beasts did not rush upon my men, <milestone ed="p" n="215" unit="line"/> but pranced about them fawningly, wagging their long tails. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188154" n="10.216-10.219">And as when hounds fawn around their master as he comes from a feast, for he ever brings them bits to soothe their temper, so about them fawned the stout-clawed wolves and lions;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188155" n="10.219">but they were seized with fear, as they saw the <sic>dread</sic> monsters.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188156" n="10.220-10.223"><milestone ed="p" n="220" unit="line"/>So they stood in the gateway of the fair-tressed goddess, and within they heard Circe singing with sweet voice, as she went to and fro before a great imperishable web, such as is the handiwork of goddesses, finely-woven and beautiful, and glorious. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188157" n="10.224-10.225">Then among them spoke Polites, a leader of men, <milestone ed="p" n="225" unit="line"/> dearest to me of my comrades, and trustiest:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188158" n="10.226-10.228">Friends, within someone goes to and fro before a great web, singing sweetly, so that all the floor echoes; some goddess it is, or some woman. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188159" n="10.228">Come, let us quickly call to her.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188160" n="10.229">So he spoke, and they cried aloud, and called to her.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188161" n="10.230-10.231"><milestone ed="p" n="230" unit="line"/>And she straightway came forth and opened the bright doors, and <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> them in;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188162" n="10.231">and all went with her in their folly. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188163" n="10.232">Only Eurylochus remained behind, for he suspected that there was a snare. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188164" n="10.233-10.235">She brought them in and made them sit on chairs and seats, and made for them a potion of cheese and barley meal and yellow honey <milestone ed="p" n="235" unit="line"/> with Pramnian wine; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188165" n="10.235-10.236">but in the food she mixed <sic>baneful</sic> drugs, that they might utterly forget their native land. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188166" n="10.237-10.238">Now when she had given them the potion, and they had drunk it off, then she presently <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> them with her wand, and penned them in the sties. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188167" n="10.239-10.240">And they had the heads, and voice, and bristles, <milestone ed="p" n="240" unit="line"/> and shape of swine, but their minds remained unchanged even as before. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188168" n="10.241-10.243">So they were penned there weeping, and before them Circe flung mast and acorns, and the fruit of the cornel tree, to eat, such things as wallowing swine are <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to feed upon.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188170" n="10.246-10.247">Not a word could he utter, for all his desire, so stricken to the heart was he with great distress,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2188172" n="10.249-10.250">But when we questioned him in amazement, <milestone ed="p" n="250" unit="line"/> then he told the fate of the others, his comrades.</s></p>

<s xml:id="sent2188239" n="10.346-10.347">But when she had sworn, and made an end of the oath, then I went up to the beautiful bed of Circe.</s></p>

<s xml:id="sent2188240" n="10.348-10.349">But her handmaids meanwhile were busied in the halls, four maidens who are her serving-women in the house.

<s xml:id="sent2188241" n="10.350-10.351"><milestone ed="p" n="350" unit="line"/>Children are they of the springs and groves, and of the sacred rivers that flow forth to the sea,

<s xml:id="sent2188247" n="10.360-10.363"><milestone ed="p" n="360" unit="line"/>But when the water boiled in the bright bronze, she set me in a bath, and bathed me with water <corr n="from out">out of</corr> the great cauldron, mixing it to my liking, and pouring it over my head and shoulders, till she took from my limbs soul-consuming weariness.

<s xml:id="sent2188275" n="10.408-10.409">and there I found my trusty comrades by the swift ship, wailing piteously, shedding big tears.

<s xml:id="sent2188276" n="10.410-10.412"><milestone ed="p" n="410" unit="line"/>And as when calves in a farmstead sport about the droves of cows returning to the yard, when they have had their fill of grazing—all together they frisk before them,</s>

</s>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:10.428-10.474">


<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188289" n="10.428">So I spoke, and they quickly <mod n="hearkened:simpsub">listened</mod> to my words. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188290" n="10.429">Eurylochus alone sought to hold back all my comrades,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188291" n="10.430"><milestone ed="p" n="430" unit="line"/> and he spoke, and addressed them with winged words:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188292" n="10.431">Ah, wretched men, <mod n="whither:simpsub">where</mod> are we going? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188293" n="10.431">Why are you so enamoured of these woes,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188294" n="10.432-10.436">as to go down to the house of Circe, who will change us all to swine, or wolves, or lions, that so we may guard her great house perforce? <milestone ed="p" n="435" unit="line"/>Even so did the Cyclops, when our comrades went to his fold, and with them went this reckless Odysseus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188295" n="10.437">For it was through this man's folly that they too perished.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188296" n="10.438-10.441">So he spoke, and I pondered in heart, whether to draw my long sword from beside my stout thigh, <milestone ed="p" n="440" unit="line"/> and therewith strike off his head, and bring it to the ground, near kinsman of mine by marriage though he was;</s>


<s xml:id="sent2188297" n="10.441-10.442">but my comrades one after another sought to check me with gentle words:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188298" n="10.443-10.444">O <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> sprung from Zeus, as for this man, we will leave him, if <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> so <mod n='biddest'>command</mod>, to <mod n="abide:simpsub">remain</mod> here by the ship, and to guard the ship,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188299" n="10.445"><milestone ed="p" n="445" unit="line"/> but as for us, do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> lead us to the sacred house of Circe.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188300" n="10.446">So saying, they went up from the ship and the sea. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188301" n="10.447-10.448">Nor was Eurylochus left beside the hollow ship, but he went with us,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188302" n="10.448">for he feared my <sic>dread</sic> reproof.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188303" n="10.449-10.451">Meanwhile in her halls Circe <milestone ed="p" n="450" unit="line"/> bathed the rest of my comrades with kindly care, and anointed them richly with oil, and cast about them fleecy cloaks and tunics;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188304" n="10.452">and we found them all feasting bountifully in the halls. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188305" n="10.453-10.454">But when they saw and recognized one another, face to face, they wept and wailed, and the house rang around.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188306" n="10.455"><milestone ed="p" n="455" unit="line"/>Then the beautiful goddess drew near me, and said:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188307" n="10.456">No longer now do <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> rouse this plenteous lamenting. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188308" n="10.456-10.458">Of myself I know both all the woes you have suffered on the teeming deep, and all the wrong that cruel men have done you on the land.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188309" n="10.460-10.463"><milestone ed="p" n="460" unit="line"/><sic>Nay</sic>, come, eat food and drink wine, until you once more get spirit in your breasts such as when at the first you left your native land of rugged <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName>;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188310" n="10.463-10.465">but now <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> are withered and spiritless, ever thinking of your weary wanderings, nor are your <milestone ed="p" n="465" unit="line"/> hearts ever joyful, for <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> have suffered much.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188311" n="10.466">So she spoke, and our proud hearts consented. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188312" n="10.467-10.468">So there day after day for a full year we <sic>abode</sic>, feasting on abundant flesh and sweet wine. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188313" n="10.469-10.471">But when a year was gone and the seasons turned, <milestone ed="p" n="470" unit="line"/> as the months waned and the long days were brought in their course, then my trusty comrades called me forth, and said:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188314" n="10.472-10.474">Strange man, <sic>bethink</sic> <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> now at last of <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> native land, if it is fated for <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> to be saved, and to reach <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> high-roofed house and <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> native land.</s></q></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:10.475-10.502">
<p><q>



<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188316" n="10.475"><milestone ed="p" n="475" unit="line"/>So they spoke, and my proud heart consented. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188317" n="10.476-10.477">So then all day long till set of sun we sat feasting on abundant flesh and sweet wine. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188318" n="10.478-10.479">But when the sun set and darkness came on, they lay down to sleep throughout the shadowy halls,

</s>


<s xml:id="sent2188319" n="10.480-10.481"><milestone ed="p" n="480" unit="line"/> but I went up to the beautiful bed of Circe, and besought her by her knees; and the goddess heard my voice,</s>


<s xml:id="sent2188320" n="10.482">and I spoke, and addressed her with winged words:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188321" n="10.483-10.484">Circe, fulfil for me the promise which <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='gavest'>gave</mod> to send me home; </s>


<s xml:id="sent2188322" n="10.484-10.486">for my spirit is now eager to be gone, <milestone ed="p" n="485" unit="line"/>and the spirit of my comrades, who make my heart to pine, as they sit about me mourning, whensoever <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> art not at hand.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188323" n="10.487">So I spoke, and the beautiful goddess straightway made answer: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188324" n="10.488-10.489">Son of Laertes, sprung from Zeus, Odysseus of many devices, <mod n="abide:simpsub">remain</mod> <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> now no longer in my house against your will;

</s>


<s xml:id="sent2188325" n="10.490-10.493"><milestone ed="p" n="490" unit="line"/> but you must first complete another journey, and come to the house of Hades and <sic>dread</sic> Persephone, to seek soothsaying of the spirit of Theban Teiresias, the blind seer, whose mind abides steadfast. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188326" n="10.494-10.495">To him even in death Persephone has granted reason, <milestone ed="p" n="495" unit="line"/> that he alone should have understanding; but the others flit about as shadows.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188327" n="10.496">So she spoke, and my spirit was broken within me,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188328" n="10.497-10.498">and I wept as I sat on the bed, nor had my heart any longer desire to live and behold the light of the sun. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188329" n="10.499-10.500">But when I had my fill of weeping and writhing, <milestone ed="p" n="500" unit="line"/> then I made answer, and addressed her, saying:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188330" n="10.501">O Circe, who will guide us on this journey? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188331" n="10.502">To Hades no man ever yet went in a black ship.</s></q></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:10.503-10.545">


<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188333" n="10.503">So I spoke, and the beautiful goddess straightway made answer: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188334" n="10.504-10.507">Son of Laertes, sprung from Zeus, Odysseus of many devices, <milestone ed="p" n="505" unit="line"/> let there be in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> mind no concern for a pilot to guide <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> ship,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> but set up <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> mast, and spread the white sail, and sit <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> down;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188335" n="10.507">But and the breath of the North Wind will bear her onward. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188336" n="10.508-10.512">But when in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> ship <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> now crossed the stream of Oceanus, where is a level shore and the groves of Persephone— <milestone ed="p" n="510" unit="line"/> tall poplars, and willows that shed their fruit—there do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> beach <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> ship by the deep eddying Oceanus, but go <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod> to the dank house of Hades. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188337" n="10.513-10.515">There into <placeName key="tgn,1120946">Acheron</placeName> flow Periphlegethon and Cocytus, which is a branch of the water of the Styx; <milestone ed="p" n="515" unit="line"/> and there is a rock, and the meeting place of the two roaring rivers. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188338" n="10.516-10.520">Thither, prince, do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> draw <mod n="nigh:simpsub">near</mod>, as I <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, and dig a pit of a cubit's length this way and that, and around it pour a libation to all the dead, first with milk and honey, thereafter with sweet wine, <milestone ed="p" n="520" unit="line"/> and in the third place with water,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188339" n="10.520">and sprinkle thereon white barley meal. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188340" n="10.521-10.525">And do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> earnestly entreat the powerless heads of the dead, vowing that when <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> comest to <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wilt:simpsub">will</mod> sacrifice in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> halls a barren heifer, the best <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod>, and <mod n="wilt:simpsub">will</mod> fill the altar with rich gifts; and that to Teiresias alone <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wilt:simpsub">will</mod> sacrifice separately a ram, <milestone ed="p" n="525" unit="line"/> wholly black, the goodliest of <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> flock. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188341" n="10.526-10.529">But when with prayers <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> made supplication to the glorious tribes of the dead, then sacrifice a ram and a black ewe, turning their heads toward Erebus but <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod> turning backward, and setting <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> face towards the streams of the river. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188342" n="10.529-10.530">Then many <milestone ed="p" n="530" unit="line"/> ghosts of men that are dead will come forth. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188343" n="10.531-10.534">But do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> thereafter call to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> comrades, and <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> them flay and burn the sheep that lie there, slain by the pitiless bronze, and <corr n="make prayer">pray</corr> to the gods, to mighty Hades and to <sic>dread</sic> Persephone.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188344" n="10.535-10.537"><milestone ed="p" n="535" unit="line"/>And do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod> draw <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> sharp sword from beside <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> thigh, and sit there, not suffering the powerless heads of the dead to draw near to the blood, till <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> enquired of Teiresias. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188345" n="10.538-10.540">Then the seer will presently come to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, leader of men, and he will tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> way and the measures of <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> path, <milestone ed="p" n="540" unit="line"/> and of <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> return, how <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='mayest'>may</mod> go over the teeming deep.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188346" n="10.541">So she spoke, and straightway came golden-throned Dawn. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188347" n="10.542">Round about me then she cast a cloak and tunic as raiment,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188348" n="10.543-10.545">and the nymph clothed herself in a long white robe, finely-woven and beautiful, and about her waist she cast <milestone ed="p" n="545" unit="line"/> a fair girdle of gold, and upon her head she put a veil. </s></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:10.546-10.574">

<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188349" n="10.546-10.547">But I went through the halls, and roused my men with gentle words, coming up to each man in turn.</s></p>

<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188350" n="10.548-10.549">No longer now sleep <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod>, and drowse in sweet slumber, but let us go;</s>


<s xml:id="sent2188351" n="10.549"><sic>lo</sic>! queenly Circe has told me all.</s></q></p>



<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188352" n="10.550"><milestone ed="p" n="550" unit="line"/>So I spoke, and their proud hearts consented. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188353" n="10.551">But not even from thence could I lead my men unscathed. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188354" n="10.552-10.553">There was one, Elpenor, the youngest of all, not over valiant in war nor sound of understanding,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188355" n="10.554-10.555">who had laid him down apart from his comrades in the sacred house of Circe, <milestone ed="p" n="555" unit="line"/> seeking the cool air, for he was heavy with wine. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188356" n="10.556-10.559">He heard the noise and the bustle of his comrades as they moved about, and suddenly sprang up, and forgot to go to the long ladder that he might come down again, but fell headlong from the roof,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188357" n="10.559-10.560">and his neck <milestone ed="p" n="560" unit="line"/> was broken away from the spine, and his spirit went down to the house of Hades.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188358" n="10.561">But as my men were going on their way I spoke among them, saying: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188359" n="10.562-10.563"><mod n="Ye:simpsub">You</mod> think, <sic>forsooth</sic>, that <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> are going to your dear native land;
</s>


<s xml:id="sent2188360" n="10.563-10.565">but Circe has pointed out for us another journey, even to the house of Hades and <sic>dread</sic> Persephone, <milestone ed="p" n="565" unit="line"/> to consult the spirit of Theban Teiresias.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188361" n="10.566-10.567">So I spoke, and their spirit was broken within them, and sitting down right where they were, they wept and tore their hair. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188362" n="10.568">But no good came of their lamenting.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188363" n="10.569-10.573">But when we were on our way to the swift ship and the shore of the sea, <milestone ed="p" n="570" unit="line"/> sorrowing and shedding big tears, meanwhile Circe had gone forth and made fast beside the black ship a ram and a black ewe, for easily had she passed us by. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188364" n="10.573-10.574">Who with his eyes could behold a god against his will, whether going to or fro?</s></p></q></p>
</div>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="book" n="11">
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:11.1-11.50">
<p><q>



<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188365" n="11.1-11.5"><milestone ed="p" n="1" unit="line"/>But when we had come down to the ship and to the sea, first of all we drew the ship down to the bright sea, and set the mast and sail in the black ship, and took the sheep and put them aboard, <milestone ed="p" n="5" unit="line"/> and ourselves embarked, sorrowing, and shedding big tears. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188366" n="11.6-11.8">And for our aid in the wake of our dark-prowed ship a fair wind that filled the sail, a goodly comrade, was sent by fair-tressed Circe, <sic>dread</sic> goddess of human speech. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188367" n="11.9-11.10">So when we had made fast all the tackling throughout the ship, <milestone ed="p" n="10" unit="line"/> we sat down,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188368" n="11.10">and the wind and the helms man made straight her course. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188369" n="11.11">All the day long her sail was stretched as she sped over the sea;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188370" n="11.12">and the sun set and all the ways grew dark.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188371" n="11.13">She came to deep-flowing Oceanus, that bounds the Earth,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note></s>



<s xml:id="sent2188372" n="11.14-11.15">where is the land and city of the Cimmerians, <milestone ed="p" n="15" unit="line"/> wrapped in mist and cloud. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188373" n="11.15-11.19">Never does the bright sun look down on them with his rays either when he mounts the starry heaven or when he turns again to earth from heaven, but <sic>baneful</sic> night is spread over wretched mortals.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188374" n="11.20-11.21"><milestone ed="p" n="20" unit="line"/>Thither we came and beached our ship, and took out the sheep,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188375" n="11.21-11.22">and ourselves went beside the stream of Oceanus until we came to the place of which Circe had told us.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188376" n="11.23-11.24">Here Perimedes and Eurylochus held the victims,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188377" n="11.24-11.28">while I drew my sharp sword from beside my thigh, <milestone ed="p" n="25" unit="line"/> and dug a pit of a cubit's length this way and that, and around it poured a libation to all the dead, first with milk and honey, thereafter with sweet wine, and in the third place with water, 
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188378" n="11.28">and I sprinkled thereon white barley meal. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188379" n="11.29-11.33">And I earnestly entreated the powerless heads of the dead, <milestone ed="p" n="30" unit="line"/> vowing that when I came to <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName> I would sacrifice in my halls a barren heifer, the best I had, and pile the altar with goodly gifts, and to Teiresias alone would sacrifice separately a ram, wholly black, the goodliest of my flocks. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188380" n="11.34-11.36">But when with vows and prayers <milestone ed="p" n="35" unit="line"/>I had made supplication to the tribes of the dead, I took the sheep and cut their throats over the pit, and the dark blood ran forth. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188381" n="11.36-11.37">Then there gathered <corr n="from out">out of</corr> of Erebus the spirits of those that are dead, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2188382" n="11.38-11.41">brides, and unwedded youths, and toil-worn old men, and tender maidens with hearts yet new to sorrow, <milestone ed="p" n="40" unit="line"/> and many, too, that had been wounded with bronze-tipped spears, men slain in fight, wearing their blood-stained armour. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188383" n="11.42-11.43">These came thronging in crowds about the pit from every side, with a wondrous cry;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188384" n="11.43">and pale fear seized me. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188385" n="11.44-11.47">Then I called to my comrades and <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> them flay and burn <milestone ed="p" n="45" unit="line"/> the sheep that lay there slain with the pitiless bronze, and to <corr n="make prayer">pray</corr> to the gods, to mighty Hades and <sic>dread</sic> Persephone. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188386" n="11.48-11.50">And I myself drew my sharp sword from beside my thigh and sat there, and would not suffer the powerless heads of the dead <milestone ed="p" n="50" unit="line"/> to draw near to the blood until I had enquired of Teiresias.
</s></p></q></p>

</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:11.51-11.96">


<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188387" n="11.51">The first to come was the spirit of my comrade Elpenor. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188388" n="11.52">Not yet had he been buried beneath the broad-wayed earth,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188389" n="11.53-11.54">for we had left his corpse behind us in the hall of Circe, unwept and unburied, since another task was then urging us on.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188390" n="11.55-11.56"><milestone ed="p" n="55" unit="line"/>When I saw him I wept, and my heart had compassion on him; and I spoke and addressed him with winged words:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188391" n="11.57">Elpenor, how <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> come beneath the murky darkness? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188392" n="11.58">Thou coming on foot <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> out-stripped me in my black ship.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188393" n="11.59">So I spoke, and with a groan he answered me and said:




</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188394" n="11.60-11.61"><milestone ed="p" n="60" unit="line"/>Son of Laertes, sprung from Zeus, Odysseus of many devices, an evil doom of some god was my undoing, and measureless wine. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188395" n="11.62-11.64">When I had lain down to sleep in the house of Circe I did not think to go to the long ladder that I might come down again, but fell headlong from the roof,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188396" n="11.64-11.65">and my neck <milestone ed="p" n="65" unit="line"/> was broken away from the spine and my spirit went down to the house of Hades. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188397" n="11.66-11.68">Now I beseech <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> by those whom we left behind, who are not present with us, by <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> wife and <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> father who reared <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> when a babe, and by Telemachus whom <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> leave an only son in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> halls;</s>

<s xml:id="sent2188401" n="11.77-11.78">Fulfil this my prayer, and fix upon the mound my oar wherewith I rowed in life when I was among my comrades.</s></q></p>

<s xml:id="sent2188404" n="11.81-11.83">Thus we two sat and held sad converse one with the other, I on one side holding my sword over the blood, while on the other side the phantom of my comrade spoke at large.</s></p>

<s xml:id="sent2188405" n="11.84-11.86">Then there came up the spirit of my dead mother, <milestone ed="p" n="85" unit="line"/>Anticleia, the daughter of great-hearted Autolycus, whom I had left alive when I departed for sacred <placeName key="tgn,7002329">Ilios</placeName>.

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:11.225-11.270"> <milestone ed="p" n="225" unit="line"/>

<s xml:id="sent2188481" n="11.225-11.227">Thus we two talked with one another; and the women came, for august Persephone sent them forth, even all those that had been the wives and the daughters of chieftains.

<s xml:id="sent2188484" n="11.231-11.232">I drew my long sword from beside my stout thigh, and would not suffer them to drink of the dark blood all at one time.

<s xml:id="sent2188487" n="11.235-11.237"><milestone ed="p" n="235" unit="line"/>Then <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> the first that I saw was high-born Tyro, who said that she was the daughter of noble Salmoneus, and declared herself to be the wife of Cretheus, son of Aeolus.

<s xml:id="sent2188492" n="11.246-11.247">But when the god had ended his work of love, he clasped her hand, and spoke, and addressed her:</s></p>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188494" n="11.248-11.250">and as the year goes on its course <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> bear glorious children, for not weak are the embraces <milestone ed="p" n="250" unit="line"/> of a god.
