<s xml:id="sent2188495" n="11.250">These do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> tend and rear. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188496" n="11.251">But now go to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> house, and hold <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> peace, and tell no man;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188497" n="11.252">but know that I am Poseidon, the shaker of the earth.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188498" n="11.253">So saying, he plunged beneath the surging sea. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188499" n="11.254-11.256">But she conceived and bore Pelias and Neleus, <milestone ed="p" n="255" unit="line"/> who both became strong servants of great Zeus; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188500" n="11.256-11.257">and Pelias dwelt in spacious Iolcus, and was rich in flocks, and the other dwelt in sandy <placeName key="perseus,Pylos">Pylos</placeName>. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188501" n="11.258-11.259">But her other children she, the queenly among women, bore to Cretheus, even Aeson, and Pheres, and Amythaon, who fought from chariots.<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note></s></p>



<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188502" n="11.260-11.265"><milestone ed="p" n="260" unit="line"/>And after her I saw Antiope, daughter of Asopus, who boasted that she had slept even in the arms of Zeus, and she bore two sons, Amphion and Zethus, who first established the seat of seven-gated Thebe, and fenced it in with walls, for they could not <milestone ed="p" n="265" unit="line"/> dwell in spacious Thebe unfenced, how mighty soever they were.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188503" n="11.266-11.268">And after her I saw Alcmene, wife of Amphitryon, who lay in the arms of great Zeus, and bore Heracles, staunch in fight, the lion-hearted. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188504" n="11.269-11.270">And <placeName key="perseus,Megara">Megara</placeName> I saw, daughter of Creon, high-of-heart, <milestone ed="p" n="270" unit="line"/> whom the son of Amphitryon, ever stubborn in might, had to wife.</s></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:11.271-11.320">


<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188505" n="11.271-11.273">And I saw the mother of Oedipodes, fair Epicaste, who <sic>wrought</sic> a monstrous deed in ignorance of mind, in that she wedded her own son, 


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188506" n="11.273-11.274">and he, when he had slain his own father, wedded her,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188507" n="11.274">and straightway the gods made these things known among men.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188508" n="11.275-11.276"><milestone ed="p" n="275" unit="line"/><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod> he <sic>abode</sic> as lord of the Cadmeans in lovely Thebe, suffering woes through the <sic>baneful</sic> counsels of the gods, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188509" n="11.277-11.279">but she went down to the house of Hades, the strong warder. She made fast a noose on high from a lofty beam, overpowered by her sorrow, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188510" n="11.279-11.280">but for him she left behind woes <milestone ed="p" n="280" unit="line"/> full many, even all that the Avengers of a mother bring to pass.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188511" n="11.281-11.284">And I saw beauteous Chloris, whom once Neleus wedded because of her beauty, when he had brought countless gifts of wooing. Youngest daughter was she of Amphion, son of Iasus, who once ruled mightily in <placeName key="tgn,7011034">Orchomenus</placeName> of the Minyae.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188512" n="11.285-11.286"><milestone ed="p" n="285" unit="line"/>And she was queen of <placeName key="perseus,Pylos">Pylos</placeName>, and bore to her husband glorious children, Nestor, and Chromius, and lordly Periclymenus, 


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188513" n="11.287-11.288">and besides these she bore noble <placeName key="tgn,1045925">Pero</placeName>, a wonder to men. Her all that dwelt about sought in marriage,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188514" n="11.288-11.291">but Neleus would give her to no man, save to him who <milestone ed="p" n="290" unit="line"/> should drive from <placeName key="perseus,Phylace">Phylace</placeName> the <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod> of mighty Iphicles, sleek and broad of brow; and hard they were to drive. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188515" n="11.291-11.292">These the blameless seer alone undertook to drive off;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188516" n="11.292-11.293">but a grievous fate of the gods ensnared him, even hard bonds and the herdsmen of the field.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188517" n="11.294-11.297"><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod> when at length the months and the days were being brought to fulfillment, <milestone ed="p" n="295" unit="line"/> as the year rolled round, and the seasons came on, then <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> mighty Iphicles released him, when he had told all the oracles;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188518" n="11.297">and the will of Zeus was fulfilled.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188519" n="11.298-11.301">And I saw <placeName key="tgn,1026553">Lede</placeName>, the wife of Tyndareus, who bore to Tyndareus two sons, stout of heart, <milestone ed="p" n="300" unit="line"/>Castor the tamer of horses, and the boxer Polydeuces. These two the earth, the giver of life, covers, <mod n="albeit:simpsub">although</mod> alive,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188520" n="11.302-11.304">and even in the world below they have honor from Zeus. day they live in turn, and one day they are dead;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188521" n="11.304">and they have won honor <corr n="like unto">like</corr> that of the gods.</s></p>



<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188522" n="11.305-11.310"><milestone ed="p" n="305" unit="line"/>And after her I saw Iphimedeia, wife of Aloeus, who declared that she had lain with Poseidon. She bore two sons, but short of life were they, godlike Otus, and far-famed Ephialtes—men whom the earth, the giver of grain, reared as the tallest, <milestone ed="p" n="310" unit="line"/> and far the comeliest, after the famous Orion. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188523" n="11.311-11.312">For at nine years they were nine cubits in breadth and in height nine fathoms. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188524" n="11.313-11.314"><sic>Yea</sic>, and they threatened to raise the din of furious war against the immortals in <placeName key="tgn,7011019">Olympus</placeName>.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188525" n="11.315-11.316"><milestone ed="p" n="315" unit="line"/>They were fain to pile Ossa on <placeName key="tgn,7011019">Olympus</placeName>, and Pelion, with its waving forests, on Ossa, that so heaven might be scaled. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188526" n="11.317">And this they would have accomplished, if they had reached the measure of manhood;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188527" n="11.318-11.320">but the son of Zeus, whom fair-haired Leto bore, <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> them both before <milestone ed="p" n="320" unit="line"/> the down blossomed beneath their temples and covered their chins with a full growth of beard.</s></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:11.321-11.360">


<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188528" n="11.321-11.324">And Phaedra and Procris I saw, and fair Ariadne, the daughter of Minos of <sic>baneful</sic> mind, whom once Theseus <corr n="was fain">wanted</corr> to bear from <placeName key="tgn,7012056">Crete</placeName> to the hill of sacred <placeName key="perseus,Athens">Athens</placeName>; but he had no joy of her,

</s>


<s xml:id="sent2188529" n="11.324-11.325">for <mod n="ere:simpsub">before</mod> that Artemis <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> her <milestone ed="p" n="325" unit="line"/> in sea-girt Dia because of the witness of Dionysus.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188530" n="11.326-11.327">And Maera and Clymene I saw, and hateful Eriphyle, who took precious gold as the price of the life of her own lord. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188531" n="11.328-11.329">But I cannot tell or name all the wives and daughters of heroes that I saw; <milestone ed="p" n="330" unit="line"/>
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188532" n="11.330"><mod n="ere:simpsub">before</mod> that immortal night would wane. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188533" n="11.330-11.332"><sic>Nay</sic>, it is now time to sleep, either when I have gone to the swift ship and the crew, or here. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188534" n="11.332">My sending shall rest with the gods, and with you.</s></p></q></p>


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188535" n="11.333-11.334">So he spoke, and they were all hushed in silence, and were held spell-bound throughout the shadowy halls.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188536" n="11.335"><milestone ed="p" n="335" unit="line"/>Then among them white-armed Arete was the first to speak:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188537" n="11.336-11.337">Phaeacians, how seems this man to you for comeliness and stature, and for the balanced spirit within him? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188538" n="11.338">And moreover he is my guest, though each of you has a share in this honor. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188539" n="11.339-11.340"><mod n="Wherefore:simpsub">For which reason</mod> be not in haste to send him away, nor <milestone ed="p" n="340" unit="line"/> stint your gifts to one in such need;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188540" n="11.340-11.341">for many are the treasures which lie stored in your halls by the favour of the gods.</s></q></p>


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188541" n="11.342-11.343">Then among them spoke also the old lord Echeneus, who was an elder among the Phaeacians: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188542" n="11.344-11.345">Friends, <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> not wide of the mark or of our own thought <milestone ed="p" n="345" unit="line"/> are the words of our wise queen. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188543" n="11.345"><sic>Nay</sic>, do you give heed to them. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188544" n="11.346">Yet it is on Alcinous here that deed and word depend.</s></q></p>


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188545" n="11.347">Then again Alcinous answered him and said: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188546" n="11.348-11.349">This word of hers shall <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> hold, as surely as I live and am lord over the Phaeacians, lovers of the oar.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188547" n="11.350-11.352"><milestone ed="p" n="350" unit="line"/>But let our guest, for all his great longing to return, nevertheless endure to remain until tomorrow, till I shall make all our gift complete. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188548" n="11.352-11.353">His sending shall rest with the men, with all, but most of all with me;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188549" n="11.353">for mine is the control in the land.</s></q></p>


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188550" n="11.354">Then Odysseus of many wiles answered him and said:




</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188551" n="11.355-11.359"><milestone ed="p" n="355" unit="line"/>Lord Alcinous, renowned above all men, if you should <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> me <mod n="abide:simpsub">remain</mod> here even for a year, and should further my sending, and give glorious gifts, even that would I choose; and it would be better far to come with a fuller hand to my dear native land.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188552" n="11.360-11.361"><milestone ed="p" n="360" unit="line"/>Aye, and I should win more respect and love from all men who should see me when I had returned to <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName>.</s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:11.361-11.403">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188553" n="11.362">Then again Alcinous made answer and said:

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188554" n="11.363-11.366">Odysseus, in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> as we look on <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> do we <mod n="deem:simpsub">think</mod> this of <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, that <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> a cheat and a dissembler, such as are many <milestone ed="p" n="365" unit="line"/> whom the dark earth breeds scattered far and wide, men that fashion lies out of what no man can even see. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188555" n="11.367">But upon <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> is grace of words, and within <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> is a heart of wisdom,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188556" n="11.368-11.369">and <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> tale <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> told with skill, as <mod n="doth:simpsub">does</mod> a minstrel, even the grievous woes of all the Argives and of <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> own self.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188557" n="11.370-11.372"><milestone ed="p" n="370" unit="line"/>But come, tell me this, and declare it truly, whether <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> sawest any of <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> godlike comrades, who went to <placeName key="tgn,7002329">Ilios</placeName> together with <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, and there met their fate. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188558" n="11.373">The night is before us, long, aye, wondrous long, and it is not yet the time for sleep in the hall. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188559" n="11.373-11.374">Tell on, I pray <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, the tale of these wondrous deeds.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188560" n="11.375-11.376"><milestone ed="p" n="375" unit="line"/><mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod> I could <mod n="abide:simpsub">remain</mod> until bright dawn, so <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='wouldest'>would</mod> be willing to tell in the hall of these woes of <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod>.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2188561" n="11.377">Then Odysseus of many wiles answered him and said:
</s>
<q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188562" n="11.378-11.379">Lord Alcinous, renowned above all men, there is a time for many words and there is a time also for sleep.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188563" n="11.380-11.384"><milestone ed="p" n="380" unit="line"/>But if <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> fain still to listen, I would not begrudge to tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> of other things more pitiful still than these, even the woes of my comrades, who perished afterward, who escaped from the <sic>dread</sic> battle-cry of the Trojans, but perished on their return through the will of an evil woman.</s></p>
<milestone ed="p" n="385" unit="line"/>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188564" n="11.385-11.388">When then holy Persephone had scattered this way and that the spirits of the women, there came up the spirit of Agamemnon, son of Atreus, sorrowing;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188565" n="11.388-11.389">and round about him others were gathered, spirits of all those who were slain with him in the house of Aegisthus, and met their fate.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188566" n="11.390"><milestone ed="p" n="390" unit="line"/>He knew me straightway, when he had drunk the dark blood,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188567" n="11.391-11.392">and he wept aloud, and shed big tears, and stretched forth his hands toward me eager to reach me. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188568" n="11.393-11.394">But no longer had he <mod n="aught:simpsub">anything</mod> of strength or might remaining such as of old was in his supple limbs.</s></p>
<milestone ed="p" n="395" unit="line"/>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188569" n="11.395-11.396">When I saw him I wept, and my heart had compassion on him, and I spoke, and addressed him with winged words:</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188570" n="11.397-11.398">‘Most glorious son of Atreus, king of men, Agamemnon, what fate of grievous death overcame <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188571" n="11.399-11.400">Did Poseidon <mod n="smite:simpsub">strike</mod> <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> on board <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> ships, <milestone ed="p" n="400" unit="line"/> when he had roused a furious blast of cruel winds? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188572" n="11.401-11.403">Or did foemen work <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> harm on the land, while <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wast:simpsub">were</mod> cutting off their cattle and fair flocks of sheep, or <mod n="wast:simpsub">were</mod> fighting to win their city and their women?</s></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:11.404-11.439">


<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188573" n="11.404">So I spoke, and he straightway made answer and said:




</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188574" n="11.405-11.411"><milestone ed="p" n="405" unit="line"/>Son of Laertes, sprung from Zeus, Odysseus of many devices, neither did Poseidon <mod n="smite:simpsub">strike</mod> me on board my ships, when he had roused a furious blast of cruel winds, nor did foemen work me harm on the land, but Aegisthus <sic>wrought</sic> for me death and fate, <milestone ed="p" n="410" unit="line"/> and <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> me with the aid of my accursed wife, when he had bidden me to his house and made me a feast, even as one slays an ox at the stall. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188575" n="11.412">So I died by a most pitiful death,</s>


<s xml:id="sent2188576" n="11.412-11.415">and round about me the rest of my comrades were slain unceasingly like white-tusked swine, which are slaughtered in the house of a rich man of great might <milestone ed="p" n="415" unit="line"/> at a marriage feast, or a joint meal, or a rich drinking-bout. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188577" n="11.416-11.417">Ere now <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> been present at the slaying of many men, killed in single combat or in the press of the fight,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188578" n="11.418-11.420">but in heart <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> wouldst have felt most pity <mod n="hadst:simpsub">had</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> seen that sight, how about the mixing bowl and the <sic>laden</sic> tables <milestone ed="p" n="420" unit="line"/> we lay in the hall, and the floor all swam with blood. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188579" n="11.421-11.424">But the most piteous cry that I heard was that of the daughter of Priam, Cassandra, whom guileful Clytemnestra <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> by my side.<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> And I sought to raise my hands and <mod n="smite:simpsub">strike</mod> down the murderess, dying though I was, pierced through with the sword. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188580" n="11.424-11.426">But she, the shameless one, <milestone ed="p" n="425" unit="line"/> turned her back upon me, and even though I was going to the house of Hades deigned neither to draw down my eyelids with her fingers nor to close my mouth. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188581" n="11.427-11.428">So true is it that there is nothing more <sic>dread</sic> or more shameless than a woman who puts into her heart such deeds,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188582" n="11.429-11.430">even as she too devised a monstrous thing, <milestone ed="p" n="430" unit="line"/> contriving death for her wedded husband. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188583" n="11.430-11.432"><mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod> I thought that I should come home welcome to my children and to my slaves;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188584" n="11.432-11.434">but she, with her heart set on utter wickedness, has shed shame on herself and on women yet to be, even upon her that <mod n='doeth'>does</mod> uprightly.</s></q></p>



<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188585" n="11.435"><milestone ed="p" n="435" unit="line"/>So he spoke, and I made answer and said: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188586" n="11.436-11.438">Ah, <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> has Zeus, whose voice is borne afar, visited wondrous hatred on the race of Atreus from the first because of the counsels of women. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188587" n="11.438-11.439">For Helen's sake many of us perished, and against <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> Clytemnestra spread a snare whilst <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wast:simpsub">were</mod> afar.</s></q></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:11.440-11.485">
<p><q>




<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188589" n="11.440"><milestone ed="p" n="440" unit="line"/>So I spoke, and he straightway made answer and said: </s>


<s xml:id="sent2188590" n="11.441">‘Wherefore in <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> own case be <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> never gentle even to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> wife. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188591" n="11.442-11.443">Declare not to her all the thoughts of <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> heart, but tell her somewhat, and let somewhat also be hidden. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188592" n="11.444">Yet not upon <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, Odysseus, shall death come from <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> wife,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188593" n="11.445-11.446"><milestone ed="p" n="445" unit="line"/> for very prudent and of an understanding heart is the daughter of Icarius, wise Penelope. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188594" n="11.447-11.448"><mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod> we left her a bride newly wed, when we went to the war,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188595" n="11.448-11.450">and a boy was at her breast, a babe, who now, I <mod n="ween:simpsub">believe</mod>, sits in the ranks of men, <milestone ed="p" n="450" unit="line"/> happy

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188596" n="11.450-11.451">in that his dear father will behold him when he comes, and he will greet his father as is meet. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188597" n="11.452-11.453">But my wife did not let me <sic>sate</sic> my eyes even with sight of my own son. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188598" n="11.453"><sic>Nay</sic>, <mod n="ere:simpsub">before</mod> that she <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> even me, her husband. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188599" n="11.454">And another thing will I tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, and do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> lay it to heart:

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188600" n="11.455-11.456"><milestone ed="p" n="455" unit="line"/> in secret and not openly do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> bring <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> ship to the shore of <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> dear native land;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188601" n="11.456">for no longer is there faith in women. 
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188602" n="11.457-11.460">But, come, tell me this, and declare it truly, whether <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> hear of my son as yet alive in <placeName key="tgn,7011034">Orchomenus</placeName> it may be, or in sandy <placeName key="perseus,Pylos">Pylos</placeName>, <milestone ed="p" n="460" unit="line"/> or yet with Menelaus in wide <placeName key="perseus,Sparta">Sparta</placeName>;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188603" n="11.461">for not yet has <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Orestes perished on the earth.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188604" n="11.462">So he spoke, and I made answer and said: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188605" n="11.463">Son of Atreus, <mod n="wherefore:simpsub">for which reason</mod> <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> question me of this? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188606" n="11.463-11.464">I know not at all whether he be alive or dead,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188607" n="11.464">and it is an ill thing to speak words vain as wind.</s></q></p>



<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188608" n="11.465-11.466"><milestone ed="p" n="465-11.466" unit="line"/>Thus we two stood and held sad converse with one another, sorrowing and shedding big tears; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188609" n="11.467-11.470">and there came up the spirit of Achilles, son of Peleus, and those of Patroclus and of peerless Antilochus and of Aias, who in comeliness and form was the goodliest <milestone ed="p" n="470" unit="line"/> of all the Danaans after the peerless son of Peleus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188610" n="11.471-11.472">And the spirit of the swift-footed son of Aeacus recognized me, and weeping, spoke to me winged words:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188611" n="11.473-11.474">Son of Laertes, sprung from Zeus, Odysseus of many devices, rash man, what deed yet greater than this <mod n="wilt:simpsub">will</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> devise in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> heart?

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188612" n="11.475-11.476"><milestone ed="p" n="475" unit="line"/>How <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> dare to come down to Hades, where dwell the unheeding dead, the phantoms of men outworn.</s></q></p><note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188613" n="11.477">So he spoke, and I made answer and said: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188614" n="11.478-11.480">Achilles, son of Peleus, far the mightiest of the Achaeans, I came through need of Teiresias,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> if <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> <milestone ed="p" n="480" unit="line"/> he would tell me some plan whereby I might reach rugged <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName>. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188615" n="11.481-11.482">For not yet have I come near to the land of <placeName key="tgn,7002733">Achaea</placeName>, nor have I as yet set foot on my own country, but am ever suffering woes;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188616" n="11.482-11.483">whereas than <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod>, Achilles, no man aforetime was more blessed nor shall ever be hereafter. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188617" n="11.484-11.486">For of old, when <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wast:simpsub">were</mod> alive, we Argives honored <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> even as the gods, <milestone ed="p" n="485" unit="line"/> and now that <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> here, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='rulest'>rule</mod> mightily among the dead. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188618" n="11.486"><mod n="Wherefore:simpsub">For which reason</mod> grieve not at all that <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> dead, Achilles.</s></q></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:11.486-11.537">


<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188620" n="11.487">So I spoke, and he straightway made answer and said: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188621" n="11.488"><sic>Nay</sic>, seek not to speak soothingly to me of death, glorious Odysseus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188622" n="11.489-11.491">I should choose, so I might live on earth,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">2</note> to serve as the hireling of another, <milestone ed="p" n="490" unit="line"/> of some portionless man whose livelihood was but small, rather than to be lord over all the dead that have perished. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188623" n="11.492-11.493">But come, tell me tidings of my son, that lordly youth, whether or not he followed to the war to be a leader. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188624" n="11.494-11.497">And tell me of noble Peleus, if <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> heard <mod n="aught:simpsub">anything</mod>, <milestone ed="p" n="495" unit="line"/> whether he still has honor among the host of the Myrmidons, or whether men do him dishonor throughout <placeName key="tgn,1000074">Hellas</placeName> and <placeName key="perseus,Phthia">Phthia</placeName>, because old age binds him hand and foot. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188625" n="11.498-11.500">For I am not there to bear him aid beneath the rays of the sun in such strength as once was mine in wide <placeName key="perseus,Troy">Troy</placeName>, <milestone ed="p" n="500" unit="line"/> when I <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> the best of the host in defence of the Argives. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188626" n="11.501">If but in such strength I could come, were it but for an hour, to my father's house,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188627" n="11.502-11.503">I would give many a one of those who do him violence and keep him from his honor, cause to rue my strength and my invincible hands.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188628" n="11.504">So he spoke, and I made answer and said:




</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188629" n="11.505-11.507"><milestone ed="p" n="505" unit="line"/><mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod> of noble Peleus have I heard <mod n="naught:simpsub">nothing</mod>, but as touching <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> dear son, Neoptolemus, I will tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> all the truth, as <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='biddest'>command</mod> me. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188630" n="11.508-11.509">I it was, myself, who brought him from Scyros in my shapely, hollow ship to join the host of the well-greaved Archaeans.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188631" n="11.510-11.511"><milestone ed="p" n="510" unit="line"/>And <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod>, as often as we took counsel around the city of <placeName key="perseus,Troy">Troy</placeName>, he was ever the first to speak, and made no miss of words;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188632" n="11.512">godlike Nestor and I alone surpassed him. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188633" n="11.513-11.516">But as often as we fought with the bronze on the Trojan plain, he would never remain behind in the throng or press of men, <milestone ed="p" n="515" unit="line"/> but would ever run forth far to the front, yielding to none in his might; and many men he <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> in <sic>dread</sic> combat. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188634" n="11.517-11.521">All of them I could not tell or name, all the host that he <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> in defence of the Argives; but what a warrior was that son of Telephus whom he <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> with the sword, <milestone ed="p" n="520" unit="line"/> the prince Eurypylus! Aye, and many of his comrades, the Ceteians, were slain about him, because of gifts a woman craved.<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188635" n="11.522">He <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> was the comeliest man I saw, next to <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Memnon. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188636" n="11.523-11.527">And again, when we, the best of the Argives, were about to go down into the horse which Epeus made, and the command of all was laid upon me, <milestone ed="p" n="525" unit="line"/> both to open and to close the door of our stout-built ambush, then the other leaders and counsellors of the Danaans would wipe away tears from their eyes, and each man's limbs shook beneath him,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188637" n="11.528-11.530">but never did my eyes see his fair face grow pale at all, nor see him <milestone ed="p" n="530" unit="line"/> wiping tears from his cheeks;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188638" n="11.530-11.532">but he earnestly besought me to let him go forth from the horse, and kept handling his sword-hilt and his spear heavy with bronze, and was eager to work harm to the Trojans. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188639" n="11.533-11.537">But after we had sacked the lofty city of Priam, he went on board his ship with his share of the spoil and a goodly prize— <milestone ed="p" n="535" unit="line"/> all unscathed he was, neither <mod n="smitten:simpsub">struck</mod> with the sharp spear nor wounded in close fight, as often befalls in war;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188640" n="11.537">for Ares rages confusedly.</s></q></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:11.538-11.566">


<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188642" n="11.538-11.540">So I spoke, and the spirit of the son of Aeacus departed with long strides over the field of asphodel, <milestone ed="p" n="540" unit="line"/> joyful in that I said that his son was preeminent.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188643" n="11.541-11.542">And other spirits of those dead and gone stood sorrowing, and each asked of those dear to him. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188644" n="11.543-11.546">Alone of them all the spirit of Aias, son of Telamon, stood apart, still full of wrath for the victory <milestone ed="p" n="545" unit="line"/> that I had won over him in the contest by the ships for the arms of Achilles,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188645" n="11.546">whose honored mother had set them for a prize;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188646" n="11.547">and the judges were the sons of the Trojans and Pallas Athena. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188647" n="11.548">I would that I had never won in the contest for such a prize,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188648" n="11.549-11.551">over so noble a head did the earth close because of those arms, <milestone ed="p" n="550" unit="line"/> even over Aias, who in comeliness and in deeds of war was above all the other Achaeans, next to the peerless son of Peleus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188649" n="11.552">To him I spoke with soothing words:</s></p>

<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188650" n="11.553-11.555">Aias, son of peerless Telamon, <mod n="wast:simpsub">were</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> then not even in death to forget <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> wrath against me because of <milestone ed="p" n="555" unit="line"/> those accursed arms? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188651" n="11.555-11.556">Surely the gods set them to be a bane to the Argives: such a tower of strength was lost to them in <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188652" n="11.556-11.558">and for <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> in death we Achaeans sorrow unceasingly, even as for the life of Achilles, son of Peleus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188653" n="11.558-11.560">Yet no other is to blame but Zeus, <milestone ed="p" n="560" unit="line"/> who bore terrible hatred against the host of Danaan spearmen, and brought on <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> doom. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188654" n="11.561-11.562"><sic>Nay</sic>, come <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod>, prince, that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='mayest'>may</mod> hear my word and my speech;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188655" n="11.562">and subdue <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> wrath and <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> proud spirit.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188656" n="11.563-11.564">So I spoke, but he answered me not a word, but went his way to Erebus to join the other spirits of those dead and gone.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188657" n="11.565"><milestone ed="p" n="565" unit="line"/>Then would he nevertheless have spoken to me for all his wrath, or I to him,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188658" n="11.566-11.567">but the heart in my breast <corr n="was fain">wanted</corr> to see the spirits of those others that are dead.</s></p></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:11.567-11.600">


<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188659" n="11.568-11.571">There then I saw Minos, the glorious son of Zeus, golden sceptre in hand, giving judgment to the dead <milestone ed="p" n="570" unit="line"/> from his seat, while they sat and stood about the king through the wide-gated house of Hades, and asked of him judgment.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188660" n="11.572-11.575">And after him I marked huge Orion driving together over the field of asphodel wild beasts which he himself had slain on the lonely hills, <milestone ed="p" n="575" unit="line"/> and in his hands he held a club all of bronze, ever unbroken.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188661" n="11.576-11.577">And I saw Tityos, son of glorious Gaea, lying on the ground. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188662" n="11.577-11.579">Over nine roods<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> he stretched, and two vultures sat, one on either side, and tore his liver, plunging their beaks into his bowels, nor could he beat them off with his hands.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188663" n="11.580-11.581"><milestone ed="p" n="580" unit="line"/>For he had offered violence to Leto, the glorious wife of Zeus, as she went toward <placeName key="tgn,7010770">Pytho</placeName> through Panopeus with its lovely lawns.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188664" n="11.582-11.583">Aye, and I saw Tantalus in violent torment, standing in a pool,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188665" n="11.583">and the water came <mod n="nigh:simpsub">near</mod> <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod> his chin. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188666" n="11.584">He seemed as one athirst, but could not take and drink;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188667" n="11.585-11.587"><milestone ed="p" n="585" unit="line"/> for as often as that old man stooped down, eager to drink, so often would the water be swallowed up and vanish away, and at his feet the black earth would appear, for some god made all dry. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188668" n="11.588-11.590">And trees, high and leafy, let stream their fruits above his head, pears, and pomegranates, and apple trees with their bright fruit, <milestone ed="p" n="590" unit="line"/> and sweet figs, and luxuriant olives. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188669" n="11.591-11.592">But as often as that old man would reach out toward these, to clutch them with his hands, the wind would toss them to the shadowy clouds.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188670" n="11.593-11.594">Aye, and I saw Sisyphus in violent torment, seeking to raise a monstrous stone with both his hands.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188671" n="11.595-11.596"><milestone ed="p" n="595" unit="line"/><mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod> he would brace himself with hands and feet, and thrust the stone toward the crest of a hill,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188672" n="11.596-11.597">but as often as he was about to heave it over the top, the weight would turn it back,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188673" n="11.598">and then down again to the plain would come rolling the ruthless stone. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188674" n="11.599-11.600">But he would strain again and thrust it back, and the sweat <milestone ed="p" n="600" unit="line"/> flowed down from his limbs, and dust rose up from his head.</s></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:11.601-11.640">


<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188675" n="11.601-11.602">And after him I marked the mighty Heracles—his phantom;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188676" n="11.602-11.604">for he himself among the immortal gods takes his joy in the feast, and has to wife Hebe, of the fair ankles, daughter of great Zeus and of Here, of the golden sandals.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188677" n="11.605-11.606"><milestone ed="p" n="605" unit="line"/>About him rose a clamor from the dead, as of birds flying everywhere in terror;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188678" n="11.606-11.608">and he like dark night, with his bow bare and with arrow on the string, glared about him terribly, like one in act to shoot. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188679" n="11.609-11.612">Awful was the belt about his breast, <milestone ed="p" n="610" unit="line"/> a baldric of gold, <mod n="whereon:simpsub">on which</mod> wondrous things were fashioned, bears and wild boars, and lions with flashing eyes, and conflicts, and battles, and murders, and slayings of men. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188680" n="11.613-11.614">May he never have designed,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> or hereafter design such another, even he who stored up in his craft the device of that belt.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188681" n="11.615-11.616"><milestone ed="p" n="615" unit="line"/>He in turn knew me when his eyes beheld me, and weeping spoke to me winged words:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188682" n="11.617-11.619">Son of Laertes, sprung from Zeus, Odysseus of many devices, ah, wretched man, <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod>, too, drag out an evil lot such as I once bore beneath the rays of the sun?

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188683" n="11.620-11.621"><milestone ed="p" n="620" unit="line"/>I was the son of Zeus, son of Cronos, but I had woe beyond measure; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2188684" n="11.621-11.622">for to a man far worse than I was I made subject, and he laid on me hard labours. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188685" n="11.623"><sic>Yea</sic>, he once sent me <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod> to fetch the hound of Hades,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188686" n="11.623-11.624">for he could devise for me no other task mightier than this.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188687" n="11.625"><milestone ed="p" n="625" unit="line"/>The hound I carried off and led forth from the house of Hades; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188688" n="11.626">and Hermes was my guide, and flashing-eyed Athena.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188689" n="11.627-11.629">So saying, he went his way again into the house of Hades, but I <sic>abode</sic> there steadfastly, in the hope that some other <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> might still come forth of the warrior heroes who died in the days of old.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188690" n="11.630-11.631"><milestone ed="p" n="630" unit="line"/>And I should have seen yet others of the men of former time, whom I <corr n="was fain">wanted</corr> to behold, even Theseus and Peirithous, glorious children of the gods, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188691" n="11.632-11.633">but <mod n="ere:simpsub">before</mod> that the myriad tribes of the dead came thronging up with a wondrous cry,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188692" n="11.633-11.635">and pale fear seized me, lest <milestone ed="p" n="635" unit="line"/> august Persephone might send forth upon me <corr n="from out">out of</corr> the house of Hades the head of the Gorgon, that awful monster.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188693" n="11.636-11.637">Straightway then I went to the ship and <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> my comrades themselves to embark, and to loose the stern cables. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188694" n="11.638">So they went on board quickly and sat down upon the benches. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188695" n="11.639-11.640">And the ship was borne down the stream Oceanus by the swelling flood, <milestone ed="p" n="640" unit="line"/> first with our rowing, and afterwards the wind was fair.</s></p></q></p>
