<div type="textpart" subtype="book" n="12">
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:12.1-12.35"> <milestone ed="p" n="1" unit="line"/>

<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188696" n="12.1-12.6">Now after our ship had left the stream of the river Oceanus and had come to the wave of the broad sea, and the Aeaean isle, where is the dwelling of early Dawn and her dancing-lawns, and the risings of the sun, <milestone ed="p" n="5" unit="line"/> there on our coming we beached our ship on the sands, and ourselves went forth upon the shore of the sea,

</s>


<s xml:id="sent2188697" n="12.7">and there we fell asleep, and waited for the bright Dawn.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188698" n="12.8-12.10">As soon as early Dawn appeared, the rosy-fingered, then I sent forth my comrades to the house of Circe <milestone ed="p" n="10" unit="line"/> to fetch the body of the dead Elpenor. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188699" n="12.11-12.12">Straightway then we cut billets of wood and gave him burial where the headland runs furthest out to sea, sorrowing and shedding big tears. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188700" n="12.13-12.15">But when the dead man was burned, and the armour of the dead, we heaped up a mound and dragged on to it a pillar, <milestone ed="p" n="15" unit="line"/> and on the top of the mound we planted his shapely oar.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188701" n="12.16">We then were busied with these several tasks,


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188702" n="12.16-12.18"><mod n="howbeit:simpsub">however</mod> Circe was not unaware of our coming forth from the house of Hades, but speedily she arrayed herself and came,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188703" n="12.18-12.19">and her handmaids brought with her bread and meat in abundance and flaming red wine.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188704" n="12.20"><milestone ed="p" n="20" unit="line"/>And the beautiful goddess stood in our midst, and spoke among us, saying:</s></p>

<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188705" n="12.21-12.22">Rash men, who have gone down alive to the house of Hades to meet death twice, while other men die but once. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188706" n="12.23-12.24"><sic>Nay</sic>, come, eat food and drink wine here this whole day through;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188707" n="12.24-12.25">but at the coming of Dawn <milestone ed="p" n="25" unit="line"/> <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> shall set sail,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188708" n="12.25-12.27">and I will point out the way and declare to you each thing, in order that <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> may not suffer pain and woes through wretched ill-contriving either by sea or on land.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188709" n="12.28">So she spoke, and our proud hearts consented. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188710" n="12.29-12.30">So then all day long till set of sun <milestone ed="p" n="30" unit="line"/> we sat feasting on abundant flesh and sweet wine. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188711" n="12.31-12.34">But when the sun set and darkness came on, they lay down to rest beside the stern cables of the ship; but Circe took me by the hand, and leading me apart from my dear comrades, made me to sit, and herself lay down close at hand and asked me all the tale.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188712" n="12.35"><milestone ed="p" n="35" unit="line"/>And I told her all in due order.</s></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:12.36-12.72">

<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188713" n="12.36">Then queenly Circe spoke to me and said:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188714" n="12.37-12.38">All these things have thus found an end; but do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hearken:simpsub">listen</mod> as I shall tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, and a god shall himself bring it to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> mind. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188715" n="12.39-12.40">To the Sirens first <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> come, who <milestone ed="p" n="40" unit="line"/> beguile all men whosoever comes to them. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188716" n="12.41-12.46">Whoso in ignorance draws near to them and hears the Sirens' voice, he nevermore returns, that his wife and little children may stand at his side rejoicing, but the Sirens beguile him with their clear-toned song, <milestone ed="p" n="45" unit="line"/> as they sit in a meadow, and about them is a great heap of bones of mouldering men, and round the bones the skin is shrivelling. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188717" n="12.47-12.49">But do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> row past them, and anoint the ears of <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> comrades with sweet wax, which <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> kneaded, lest any of the rest may hear. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188718" n="12.49-12.52">But if <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> a will to listen, <milestone ed="p" n="50" unit="line"/> let them bind <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> in the swift ship hand and foot upright in the step of the mast, and let the ropes be made fast at the ends to the mast itself, that with delight <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='mayest'>may</mod> listen to the voice of the two Sirens. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188719" n="12.53-12.54">And if <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> implore and <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> comrades to loose <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, then let them bind <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> with yet more bonds.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188720" n="12.55-12.58"><milestone ed="p" n="55" unit="line"/>But when <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> comrades shall have rowed past these, thereafter I shall not fully say on which side <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> course is to lie, but do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod> ponder it in mind,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188721" n="12.58">and I will tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> of both ways. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188722" n="12.59-12.60">For on the one hand are beetling crags, and against them <milestone ed="p" n="60" unit="line"/> roars the great wave of dark-eyed Amphitrite; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2188723" n="12.61">the Planctae<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> do the blessed gods call these. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188724" n="12.62-12.64">Thereby not even winged things may pass, no, not the timorous doves that bear ambrosia to father Zeus, but the smooth rock ever snatches away one even of these,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188725" n="12.65"><milestone ed="p" n="65" unit="line"/> and the father sends in another to make up the tale. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188726" n="12.66-12.68">And thereby has no ship of men ever yet escaped that has come thither, but the planks of ships and bodies of men are whirled confusedly by the waves of the sea and the blasts of <sic>baneful</sic> fire. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188727" n="12.69-12.70">One seafaring ship alone has passed thereby, <milestone ed="p" n="70" unit="line"/> that <placeName key="tgn,1094163">Argo</placeName> famed of all, on her voyage from Aeetes,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188728" n="12.71-12.72">and even her the wave would speedily have dashed there against the great crags, had not Here sent her through, <corr n="for that">for</corr> Jason was dear to her.</s></q></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:12.73-12.110">
<p><q>

<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188729" n="12.73-12.75">Now on the other path are two cliffs, one of which reaches with its sharp peak to the broad heaven, and a dark cloud surrounds it.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188730" n="12.75-12.77"><milestone ed="p" n="75" unit="line"/>This never melts away, nor does clear sky ever surround that peak in summer or in harvest time. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188731" n="12.77-12.78">No mortal man could scale it or set foot upon the top, not though he had twenty hands and feet;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188732" n="12.79">for the rock is smooth, as if it were polished.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188733" n="12.80-12.82"><milestone ed="p" n="80" unit="line"/>And in the midst of the cliff is a dim cave, turned to the West, toward Erebus, even where you shall steer your hollow ship, glorious Odysseus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188734" n="12.83-12.84">Not even a man of might could shoot an arrow from the hollow ship so as to reach into that vaulted cave.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188735" n="12.85"><milestone ed="p" n="85" unit="line"/>Therein dwells Scylla, yelping terribly. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188736" n="12.86-12.87">Her voice is indeed but as the voice of a new-born whelp, but she herself is an evil monster,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188737" n="12.87-12.88">nor would anyone be glad at sight of her, no, not though it were a god that met her. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188738" n="12.89-12.92"><mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod> she has twelve feet, all misshapen,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note>
<milestone ed="p" n="90" unit="line"/> and six necks, exceeding long, and on each one an awful head, and therein three rows of teeth, thick and close, and full of black death. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188739" n="12.93-12.97">Up to her middle she is hidden in the hollow cave, but she holds her head out beyond the <sic>dread</sic> chasm, <milestone ed="p" n="95" unit="line"/> and fishes there, eagerly searching around the rock for dolphins and sea-dogs and whatever greater beast she may <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> catch, such creatures as deep-moaning Amphitrite rears in multitudes past counting. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188740" n="12.98-12.99">By her no sailors yet may boast that they have fled unscathed in their ship, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2188741" n="12.99-12.100">for with each head she carries off <milestone ed="p" n="100" unit="line"/> a man, snatching him from the dark-prowed ship.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188742" n="12.101">But the other cliff, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wilt:simpsub">will</mod> note, Odysseus, is lower—</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188743" n="12.102">they are close to each other;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188744" n="12.102"><mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> couldst even shoot an arrow across—</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188745" n="12.103">and on it is a great fig tree with rich foliage,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188746" n="12.104">but beneath this divine Charybdis sucks down the black water.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188747" n="12.105-12.106"><milestone ed="p" n="105" unit="line"/><mod n="Thrice:simpsub">Three times</mod> a day she belches it forth, and <mod n="thrice:simpsub">three times</mod> she sucks it down terribly. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188748" n="12.106">Mayest <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> not be there when she sucks it down,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188749" n="12.107">for no one could save <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> from ruin, no, not the Earth-shaker. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188750" n="12.108-12.110"><sic>Nay</sic>, draw very close to Scylla's cliff, and drive <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> ship past quickly; for it is better far <milestone ed="p" n="110" unit="line"/> to mourn six comrades in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> ship than all together.</s></p></q></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:12.111-12.152">


<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188752" n="12.111">So she spoke, but I made answer and said: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188753" n="12.112-12.114">Come, I pray <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, goddess, tell me this thing truly, if in any wise I might escape from fell Charybids, and ward off that other, when she works harm to my comrades.</s></q></p>



<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188754" n="12.115"><milestone ed="p" n="115" unit="line"/>So I spoke, and the beautiful goddess answered and said:
</s>
<q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188755" n="12.116-12.117">Rash man, <sic>lo</sic>, now again <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> heart is set on the deeds of war and on toil. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188756" n="12.117">Wilt <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> not yield even to the immortal gods? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188757" n="12.118-12.119">She is not mortal, but an immortal bane, <sic>dread</sic>, and dire, and fierce, <milestone ed="p" n="120" unit="line"/> and not to be fought with;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188758" n="12.119-12.120">there is no defence;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188759" n="12.120">to flee from her is bravest. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188760" n="12.121-12.123">For if <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> tarriest to arm <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod> by the cliff, I fear lest she may again dart forth and attack <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> with as many heads and seize as many men as before. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188761" n="12.124-12.125"><sic>Nay</sic>, row past with all <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> might, and call upon Crataiis, <milestone ed="p" n="125" unit="line"/> the mother of Scylla, who bore her for a bane to mortals. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188762" n="12.126">Then will she keep her from darting forth again.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188763" n="12.127">And <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wilt:simpsub">will</mod> come to the isle Thrinacia. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188764" n="12.127-12.130">There in great numbers feed the <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod> of Helios and his goodly flocks, seven herds of <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod> and as many fair flocks of sheep, <milestone ed="p" n="130" unit="line"/> and fifty in each. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188765" n="12.130-12.131">These bear no young, nor do they ever die,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188766" n="12.131-12.133">and goddesses are their shepherds, fair-tressed nymphs, Phaethusa and Lampetie, whom beautiful Neaera bore to Helios Hyperion. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188767" n="12.134-12.136">These their honored mother, when she had borne and reared them, <milestone ed="p" n="135" unit="line"/> sent to the isle Thrinacia to dwell afar, and keep the flocks of their father and his sleek <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod>. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188768" n="12.137-12.138">If <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='leavest'>leave</mod> these unharmed and heedest <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> homeward way, <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> may yet reach <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName>, though in evil plight. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188769" n="12.139-12.140">But if <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> harmest them, then I foretell ruin <milestone ed="p" n="140" unit="line"/> for <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> ship and for <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> comrades, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2188770" n="12.140-12.141">and even if <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod> escape, late <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> come home and in evil case, after losing all <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> comrades.</s></p></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188771" n="12.142">So she spoke, and presently came golden-throned Dawn. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188772" n="12.143">Then the beautiful goddess departed up the island,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188773" n="12.144-12.145">but I went to the ship and roused my comrades <milestone ed="p" n="145" unit="line"/> themselves to embark and to loose the stern cables. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188774" n="12.146">So they went on board straightway and sat down upon the benches,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188775" n="12.147">and sitting well in order <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> the grey sea with their oars. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188776" n="12.148-12.150">And for our aid in the wake of our dark-prowed ship a fair wind that filled the sail, a goodly comrade, was sent <milestone ed="p" n="150" unit="line"/> by fair-tressed Circe, <sic>dread</sic> goddess of human speech. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188777" n="12.151-12.152">So when we had straightway made fast all the tackling throughout the ship we sat down,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188778" n="12.152">but the wind and the helmsman guided the ship.</s></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:12.153-12.191">


<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188779" n="12.153">Then <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> I spoke among my comrades, grieved at heart: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188780" n="12.154-12.155">Friends, since it is not right that one or two alone should know <milestone ed="p" n="155" unit="line"/> the oracles that Circe, the beautiful goddess, told me,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188781" n="12.156-12.157">therefore will I tell them, in order that knowing them we may either die or, shunning death and fate, escape. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188782" n="12.158-12.159">First she <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> us avoid the voice of the wondrous Sirens, and their flowery meadow.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188783" n="12.160"><milestone ed="p" n="160" unit="line"/>Me alone she <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> to listen to their voice;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188784" n="12.160-12.162">but do <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> bind me with grievous bonds, that I may <mod n="abide:simpsub">remain</mod> fast where I am, upright in the step of the mast, and let the ropes be made fast at the ends to the mast itself;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188785" n="12.163-12.164">and if I implore and <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> you to loose me, then do <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> tie me fast with yet more bonds.</s></q></p>
<milestone ed="p" n="165" unit="line"/>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188786" n="12.165">Thus I rehearsed all these things and told them to my comrades. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188787" n="12.166-12.167">Meanwhile the well-built ship speedily came to the isle of the two Sirens,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188788" n="12.167">for a fair and gentle wind bore her on. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188789" n="12.168-12.169">Then presently the wind ceased and there was a windless calm, and a god lulled the waves to sleep.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188790" n="12.170-12.172"><milestone ed="p" n="170" unit="line"/>But my comrades rose up and furled the sail and stowed it in the hollow ship, and thereafter sat at the oars and made the water white with their polished oars of fir. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188791" n="12.173-12.174">But I with my sharp sword cut into small bits a great round cake of wax, and kneaded it with my strong hands,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188792" n="12.175-12.176"><milestone ed="p" n="175" unit="line"/> and soon the wax grew warm, forced by the strong pressure and the rays of the lord Helios Hyperion.<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188793" n="12.177">Then I anointed with this the ears of all my comrades in turn; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2188794" n="12.178-12.179">and they bound me in the ship hand and foot, upright in the step of the mast, and made the ropes fast at the ends to the mast itself; <milestone ed="p" n="180" unit="line"/>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188795" n="12.180">and themselves sitting down <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> the grey sea with their oars. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188796" n="12.181-12.183">But when we were as far distant as a man can make himself heard when he shouts, driving swiftly on our way, the Sirens failed not to note the swift ship as it drew near, and they raised their clear-toned song:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188797" n="12.184-12.185">Come <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod>, as <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> farest, renowned Odysseus, great glory of the Achaeans; <milestone ed="p" n="185" unit="line"/> stay <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> ship that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='mayest'>may</mod> listen to the voice of us two. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188798" n="12.186-12.188">For never yet has any man rowed past this isle in his black ship until he has heard the sweet voice from our lips. <sic>Nay</sic>, he has joy of it, and goes his way a wiser man. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188799" n="12.189-12.191">For we know all the toils that in wide <placeName key="tgn,7014164">Troy</placeName>
<milestone ed="p" n="190" unit="line"/> the Argives and Trojans endured through the will of the gods, and we know all things that come to pass upon the fruitful earth.</s></q></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:12.192-12.233">


<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188801" n="12.192">So they spoke, sending forth their beautiful voice,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188802" n="12.192-12.194">and my heart <corr n="was fain">wanted</corr> to listen, and I <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> my comrades loose me, nodding to them with my brows;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188803" n="12.194">but they fell to their oars and rowed on.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188804" n="12.195-12.196"><milestone ed="p" n="195" unit="line"/>And presently Perimedes and Eurylochus arose and bound me with yet more bonds and drew them tighter. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188805" n="12.197-12.200">But when they had rowed past the Sirens, and we could no more hear their voice or their song, then straightway my trusty comrades took away the <milestone ed="p" n="200" unit="line"/> wax with which I had anointed their ears and loosed me from my bonds.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188806" n="12.201-12.202">But when we had left the island, I presently saw smoke and a great billow, and heard a booming. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188807" n="12.203-12.204">Then from the hands of my men in their terror the oars flew, and splashed one and all in the swirl,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188808" n="12.204-12.205">and <milestone ed="p" n="205" unit="line"/> the ship stood still where it was, when they no longer plied with their hands the tapering oars. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188809" n="12.206-12.207">But I went through the ship and cheered my men with gentle words, coming up to each man in turn:

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188810" n="12.208">‘Friends, hitherto we have been in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> ignorant of sorrow;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188811" n="12.209-12.210">surely this evil that besets us now is no greater than when the Cyclops
<milestone ed="p" n="210" unit="line"/> penned us in his hollow cave by brutal strength;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188812" n="12.211-12.212">yet even thence we made our escape through my valor and counsel and wit; these dangers, too, methinks we shall some day remember. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188813" n="12.213">But now come, as I <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod>, let us all obey. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188814" n="12.214-12.216">Do you keep your seats on the benches <milestone ed="p" n="215" unit="line"/> and <mod n="smite:simpsub">strike</mod> with your oars the deep surf of the sea, in the hope that Zeus may grant us to escape and avoid this death. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188815" n="12.217">And to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, steersman, I give this command,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188816" n="12.217-12.218">and do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> lay it to heart, since <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> wieldest the steering oar of the hollow ship. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188817" n="12.219-12.221">From this smoke and surf keep <milestone ed="p" n="220" unit="line"/> the ship well away and hug the cliff, lest, <mod n="ere:simpsub">before</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> know it, the ship swerve off to the other side and <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> cast us into destruction.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188818" n="12.222">So I spoke, and they quickly <mod n="hearkened:simpsub">listened</mod> to my words. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188819" n="12.223-12.225">But of Scylla I went not on to speak, a cureless bane, lest <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> my comrades, seized with fear, should cease <milestone ed="p" n="225" unit="line"/> from rowing and huddle together in the hold. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188820" n="12.226-12.227">Then <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> I forgot the hard command of Circe, whereas she <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> me in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> to arm myself;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188821" n="12.228-12.230">but when I had put on my glorious armour and grasped in my hand two long spears, I went to the fore-deck of the ship,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188822" n="12.230-12.231"><milestone ed="p" n="230" unit="line"/> whence I <mod n="deemed:simpsub">thought</mod> that Scylla of the rock would first be seen, who was to bring ruin upon my comrades. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188823" n="12.232-12.233">But nowhere could I descry her, and my eyes grew weary as I gazed everywhere toward the misty rock.</s></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:12.234-12.276">


<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188824" n="12.234">We then sailed on up the narrow strait with wailing.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188825" n="12.235-12.236"><milestone ed="p" n="235" unit="line"/>For on one side lay Scylla and on the other divine Charybdis terribly sucked down the salt water of the sea. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188826" n="12.237-12.239"><mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod> whenever she belched it forth, like a cauldron on a great fire she would seethe and bubble in utter turmoil, and high over head the spray would fall on the tops of both the cliffs.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188827" n="12.240-12.243"><milestone ed="p" n="240" unit="line"/>But as often as she sucked down the salt water of the sea, within she could all be seen in utter turmoil, and round about the rock roared terribly, while beneath the earth appeared black with sand; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2188828" n="12.243">and pale fear seized my men. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188829" n="12.244">So we looked toward her and feared destruction;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188830" n="12.245-12.246"><milestone ed="p" n="245" unit="line"/> but meanwhile Scylla seized <corr n="from out">out of</corr> the hollow ship six of my comrades who were the best in strength and in might. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188831" n="12.247-12.249">Turning my eyes to the swift ship and to the company of my men,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> even then I noted above me their feet and hands as they were raised aloft. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188832" n="12.249-12.250">To me they cried aloud, calling upon me <milestone ed="p" n="250" unit="line"/> by name <corr n="for that">for</corr> last time in anguish of heart. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188833" n="12.251-12.255">And as a fisher on a jutting rock, when he casts in his baits as a snare to the little fishes, with his long pole lets down into the sea the horn of an ox of the steading,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">2</note> and then as he catches a fish flings it writhing ashore, <milestone ed="p" n="255" unit="line"/> even so were they drawn writhing up towards the cliffs. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188834" n="12.256-12.257">Then at her doors she devoured them shrieking and stretching out their hands toward me in their awful death-struggle. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188835" n="12.258-12.259">Most piteous did mine eyes behold that thing of all that I bore while I explored the paths of the sea.</s></p>



<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188836" n="12.260-12.262"><milestone ed="p" n="260" unit="line"/>Now when we had escaped the rocks, and <sic>dread</sic> Charybdis and Scylla, presently then we came to the goodly island of the god,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188837" n="12.262-12.263">where were the fair <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod>, broad of brow, and the many goodly flocks of Helios Hyperion. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188838" n="12.264-12.266">Then while I was still out at sea in my black ship, <milestone ed="p" n="265" unit="line"/>I heard the lowing of the cattle that were being stalled and the bleating of the sheep,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188839" n="12.266-12.269">and upon my mind fell the words of the blind seer, Theban Teiresias, and of Aeaean Circe, who very straitly charged me to shun the island of Helios, who gives joy to mortals.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188840" n="12.270"><milestone ed="p" n="270" unit="line"/>Then <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> I spoke among my comrades, grieved at heart:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188841" n="12.271-12.274">Hear my words, comrades, for all your evil plight, that I may tell you the oracles of Teiresias and of Aeaean Circe, who very straitly charged me to shun the island of Helios, who gives joy to mortals;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188842" n="12.275"><milestone ed="p" n="275" unit="line"/> for there, she said, was our most terrible bane. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188843" n="12.276"><sic>Nay</sic>, row the black ship out past the island.</s></q></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:12.277-12.326">


<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188845" n="12.277">So I spoke, but their spirit was broken within them,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188846" n="12.278">and straightway Eurylochus answered me with hateful words:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188847" n="12.279">Hardy <corr n="art thou">are you</corr>, Odysseus;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188848" n="12.279-12.280"><mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> strength beyond that of other men and <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> limbs never <milestone ed="p" n="280" unit="line"/> grow weary. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188849" n="12.280-12.285"><mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod> <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> wholly <sic>wrought</sic> of iron, seeing that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='sufferest'>suffer</mod> not <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> comrades, worn out with toil and drowsiness, to set foot on shore, where on this sea-girt isle we might once more make ready a savoury supper; but <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='biddest'>command</mod> us even as we are to wander on through the swift night, <milestone ed="p" n="285" unit="line"/> driven away from the island over the misty deep. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188850" n="12.286-12.287">It is from the night that fierce winds are born, wreckers of ships. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188851" n="12.287-12.290">How could one escape utter destruction, if <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> there should suddenly come a blast of the South Wind or the blustering <placeName key="tgn,2081336">West Wind</placeName>, which oftenest <milestone ed="p" n="290" unit="line"/> wreck ships in despite of the sovereign gods? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188852" n="12.291-12.293"><sic>Nay</sic>, <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> for this time let us yield to black night and make ready our supper, remaining by the swift ship, and in the morning we will go aboard, and put out into the broad sea.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188853" n="12.294">So spoke Eurylochus, and the rest of my comrades gave assent.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188854" n="12.295-12.296"><milestone ed="p" n="295" unit="line"/>Then <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> I knew that some god was assuredly devising ill, and I spoke and addressed him with winged words:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188855" n="12.297">Eurylochus, <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> constrain me, who stand alone. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188856" n="12.298">But come now, do <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> all swear to me a mighty oath, to the end that,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188857" n="12.299-12.301">if we <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> find a herd of <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod> or a great flock of sheep, <milestone ed="p" n="300" unit="line"/> no man may <mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod> either cow or sheep in the blind folly of his mind; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2188858" n="12.301-12.302">but be content to eat the food which immortal Circe gave.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188859" n="12.303">So I spoke; and they straightway swore that they would not, even as I <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> them. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188860" n="12.304-12.307">But when they had sworn and made an end of the oath, <milestone ed="p" n="305" unit="line"/> we moored our well-built ship in the hollow harbor near a spring of sweet water, and my comrades went forth from the ship and skilfully made ready their supper. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188861" n="12.308-12.310">But when they had put from them the desire of food and drink, then they fell to weeping, as they remembered their dear comrades <milestone ed="p" n="310" unit="line"/> whom Scylla had snatched <corr n="from out">out of</corr> the hollow ship and devoured;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188862" n="12.311">and sweet sleep came upon them as they wept. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188863" n="12.312-12.315">But when it was the third watch of the night, and the stars had turned their course, Zeus, the cloud-gatherer, roused against us a fierce wind with a wondrous tempest, and hid with clouds <milestone ed="p" n="315" unit="line"/> the land and sea alike,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188864" n="12.315">and night rushed down from heaven. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188865" n="12.316-12.317">And as soon as early Dawn appeared, the rosy-fingered, we dragged our ship, and made her fast in a hollow cave,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188866" n="12.318">where were the fair dancing-floors and seats of the nymphs. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188867" n="12.319">Then I called my men together and spoke among them:



</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188868" n="12.320-12.321"><milestone ed="p" n="320" unit="line"/>‘Friends, in our swift ship is meat and drink; let us therefore keep our hands from those <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod> lest we come to harm,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188869" n="12.322-12.323">for these are the cows and goodly sheep of a <sic>dread</sic> god, even of Helios, who oversees all things and overhears all things.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188870" n="12.324">So I spoke, and their proud hearts consented.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188871" n="12.325-12.326"><milestone ed="p" n="325" unit="line"/>Then for a full month the South Wind blew unceasingly, nor did any other wind arise except the East and the South.</s></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:12.327-12.363">


<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188872" n="12.327-12.328">Now so long as my men had grain and red wine they kept their hands from the <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod>, for they were eager to save their lives.<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188873" n="12.329-12.332">But when all the stores had been consumed <corr n="from out">out of</corr> the ship, <milestone ed="p" n="330" unit="line"/> and now they must needs roam about in search of game, fishes, and fowl, and whatever might come to their hands—fishing with bent hooks, for hunger pinched their bellies—</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188874" n="12.333-12.334">then I went apart up the island that I might pray to the gods in the hope that one of them might show me a way to go.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188875" n="12.335-12.337"><milestone ed="p" n="335" unit="line"/>And when, as I went through the island, I had got away from my comrades, I washed my hands in a place where there was shelter from the wind, and prayed to all the gods that hold <placeName key="tgn,2109778">Olympus</placeName>;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188876" n="12.338">but they shed sweet sleep upon my eyelids. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188877" n="12.339">And meanwhile Eurylochus began to give evil counsel to my comrades:





</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188878" n="12.340"><milestone ed="p" n="340" unit="line"/>Hear my words, comrades, for all your evil plight. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188879" n="12.341-12.342">All forms of death are hateful to wretched mortals, but to die of hunger, and so meet one's doom, is the most pitiful. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188880" n="12.343-12.344"><sic>Nay</sic>, come, let us drive off the best of the <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod> of Helios and offer sacrifice to the immortals who hold broad heaven.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188881" n="12.345-12.347"><milestone ed="p" n="345" unit="line"/>And if we ever reach <placeName key="tgn,7013803">Ithaca</placeName>, our native land, we will straightway build a rich temple to Helios Hyperion and put therein many goodly offerings. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188882" n="12.348-12.351">And if <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> he be <mod n="wroth:simpsub">angry</mod> at all because of his straight-horned <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod>, and be minded to destroy our ship, and the other gods consent, <milestone ed="p" n="350" unit="line"/> rather would I lose my life once for all with a gulp at the wave, than pine slowly away in a desert isle.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188883" n="12.352">So spoke Eurylochus, and the rest of my comrades gave assent. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188884" n="12.353-12.355">Straightway they drove off the best of the <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod> of Helios from near at hand, for not far from the dark-prowed ship <milestone ed="p" n="355" unit="line"/> were grazing the fair, sleek <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod>, broad of brow. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188885" n="12.356-12.357">Around these, then, they stood and made prayer to the gods, plucking the tender leaves from off a high-crested oak;<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> </s>



<s xml:id="sent2188886" n="12.358">for they had no white barley on board the well-benched ship. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188887" n="12.359-12.361">Now when they had prayed and had cut the throats of the <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod> and flayed them, <milestone ed="p" n="360" unit="line"/> they cut out the thigh-pieces and covered them with a double layer of fat and laid raw flesh upon them. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188888" n="12.362-12.363">They had no wine to pour over the blazing sacrifice, but they made libations with water, and roasted all the entrails over the fire. </s></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:12.364-12.396">

<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188889" n="12.364-12.365">Now when the thighs were wholly burned and they had tasted the inner parts, <milestone ed="p" n="365" unit="line"/> they cut up the rest and spitted it. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188890" n="12.366-12.367">Then it was that sweet sleep fled from my eyelids, and I went my way to the swift ship and the shore of the sea. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188891" n="12.368-12.369">But when, as I went, I drew near to the curved ship, then <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> the hot savour of the fat was wafted about me,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188892" n="12.370"><milestone ed="p" n="370" unit="line"/> and I groaned and cried aloud to the immortal gods:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188893" n="12.371-12.372">Father Zeus and <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> other blessed gods that are for ever, <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> it was for my ruin that <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> lulled me in pitiless sleep, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188894" n="12.373">while my comrades remaining behind have contrived a monstrous deed.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188895" n="12.374-12.375">Swiftly then to Helios Hyperion came <milestone ed="p" n="375" unit="line"/>Lampetie of the long robes, bearing tidings that we had slain his <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod>;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188896" n="12.376">and straightway he spoke among the immortals, <mod n="wroth:simpsub">angry</mod> at heart:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2188897" n="12.377-12.381">Father Zeus and <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> other blessed gods that are for ever, take vengeance now on the comrades of Odysseus, son of Laertes, who have insolently slain my <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod>, in which I <milestone ed="p" n="380" unit="line"/> ever took delight, when I went toward the starry heaven and when I turned back again to earth from heaven. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188898" n="12.382-12.383">If they do not pay me fit atonement for the <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod> I will go down to Hades and shine among the dead.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188899" n="12.384">Then Zeus, the cloud-gatherer, answered him and said:




</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188900" n="12.385-12.386"><milestone ed="p" n="385" unit="line"/>Helios, do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> shine on among the immortals and among mortal men upon the earth, the giver of grain. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188901" n="12.387-12.388">As for these men I will soon <mod n="smite:simpsub">strike</mod> their swift ship with my bright thunder-bolt, and shatter it to pieces in the midst of the wine-dark sea.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188902" n="12.389">This I heard from fair-haired Calypso,


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188903" n="12.390"><milestone ed="p" n="390" unit="line"/> and she said that she herself had heard it from the messenger Hermes.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188904" n="12.391-12.393">But when I had come down to the ship and to the sea I upbraided my men, coming up to each in turn, but we could find no remedy—the <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod> were already dead. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188905" n="12.394">For my men, then, the gods straightway <mod n="shewed:simpsub">showed</mod> forth portents.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188906" n="12.395-12.396"><milestone ed="p" n="395" unit="line"/>The hides crawled, the flesh, both roast and raw, bellowed upon the spits, and there was a lowing as of <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod>.</s></p></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:12.397-12.425">


<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188907" n="12.397-12.398">For six days, then, my trusty comrades feasted on the best of the <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod> of Helios which they had driven off. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188908" n="12.399-12.402">But when Zeus, the son of Cronos, brought upon us the seventh day, <milestone ed="p" n="400" unit="line"/> then the wind ceased to blow tempestuously, and we straightway went on board, and put out into the broad sea when we had set up the mast and hoisted the white sail.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188909" n="12.403-12.406">But when we had left that island and no other land appeared, but only sky and sea, <milestone ed="p" n="405" unit="line"/> then <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> the son of Cronos set a black cloud above the hollow ship, and the sea grew dark beneath it. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188910" n="12.407">She ran on for no long time,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188911" n="12.407-12.410">for straightway came the shrieking <placeName key="tgn,2081336">West Wind</placeName>, blowing with a furious tempest, and the blast of the wind snapped both the fore-stays of the mast,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188912" n="12.410-12.411"><milestone ed="p" n="410" unit="line"/> so that the mast fell backward and all its tackling was strewn in the bilge. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188913" n="12.411-12.413">On the stern of the ship the mast struck the head of the pilot and crushed all the bones of his skull together,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188914" n="12.413-12.414">and like a diver he fell from the deck and his proud spirit left his bones.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188915" n="12.415"><milestone ed="p" n="415" unit="line"/>Therewith Zeus thundered and hurled his bolt upon the ship,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188916" n="12.416-12.417">and she quivered from stem to stern, <mod n="smitten:simpsub">struck</mod> by the bolt of Zeus, and was filled with sulphurous smoke, and my comrades fell <corr n="from out">out of</corr> the ship. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188917" n="12.418-12.419">Like sea-crows they were borne on the waves about the black ship, and the god took from them their returning.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188918" n="12.420-12.422"><milestone ed="p" n="420" unit="line"/>But I kept pacing up and down the ship till the surge tore the sides from the keel, and the wave bore her on dismantled and snapped the mast off at the keel;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188919" n="12.422-12.423">but over the mast had been flung the back-stay fashioned of ox-hide;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188920" n="12.424-12.425">with this I lashed the two together, both keel and mast, <milestone ed="p" n="425" unit="line"/> and sitting on these was borne by the direful winds.</s></p></q></p>             
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:12.426-12.453">


<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2188921" n="12.426-12.428">Then <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> the <placeName key="tgn,2081336">West Wind</placeName> ceased to blow tempestuously, and swiftly the South Wind came, bringing sorrow to my heart, that I might traverse again the way to <sic>baneful</sic> <placeName key="tgn,2233588">Charybdis</placeName>. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188922" n="12.429-12.430">All night long was I borne, and at the rising of the sun <milestone ed="p" n="430" unit="line"/>I came to the cliff of Scylla and to <sic>dread</sic> <placeName key="tgn,2233588">Charybdis</placeName>. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188923" n="12.431">She <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> sucked down the salt water of the sea,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188924" n="12.432-12.433">but I, springing up to the tall fig-tree, laid hold of it, and clung to it like a bat. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188925" n="12.433-12.434">Yet I could in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> plant my feet firmly or climb upon the tree,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188926" n="12.435-12.436"><milestone ed="p" n="435" unit="line"/> for its roots spread far below and its branches hung out of reach above, long and great, and overshadowed <placeName key="tgn,2233588">Charybdis</placeName>. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188927" n="12.437-12.438">There I clung steadfastly until she should vomit forth mast and keel again,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188928" n="12.438-12.439">and to my joy they came at length. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188929" n="12.439-12.441">At the hour when a man rises from the assembly for his supper, <milestone ed="p" n="440" unit="line"/> one that decides the many quarrels of young men that seek judgment, even at that hour those spars appeared <corr n="from out">out of</corr> <placeName key="tgn,2233588">Charybdis</placeName>. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188930" n="12.442-12.444">And I let go hands and feet from above and plunged down into the waters out beyond the long spars, and sitting on these I rowed onward with my hands.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188931" n="12.445-12.446"><milestone ed="p" n="445" unit="line"/>But as for Scylla, the father of gods and men did not suffer her again to catch sight of me,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188932" n="12.446">else should I never have escaped utter destruction.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188933" n="12.447-12.450">Thence for nine days was I borne, and on the tenth night the gods brought me to Ogygia, where the fair-tressed Calypso dwells, <sic>dread</sic> goddess of human speech, <milestone ed="p" n="450" unit="line"/> who gave me welcome and tendance. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188934" n="12.450">But why should I tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> this tale? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188935" n="12.451-12.452">For it was but yesterday that I told it in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> hall to <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod> and to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> noble wife. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188936" n="12.452-12.453">It is an irksome thing, meseems, to tell again a plain-told tale.</s></p></q></p>
</div>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="book" n="13">
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:13.1-13.46">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188937" n="13.1-13.2"><milestone ed="p" n="1" unit="line"/>So he spoke, and they were all hushed in silence, and were spellbound throughout the shadowy halls. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188938" n="13.3">And Alcinous again answered him, and said:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188939" n="13.4-13.6">Odysseus, since <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> come to my <milestone ed="p" n="5" unit="line"/> high-roofed house with floor of brass, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> not, methinks, be driven back, and return with baffled purpose, even though <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> suffered much. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188940" n="13.7-13.9">And to each man of you that in my halls are ever <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to drink the flaming wine of the elders, and to listen to the minstrel, I speak, and give this charge.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188941" n="13.10-13.12"><milestone ed="p" n="10" unit="line"/>Raiment for the stranger lies already stored in the polished chest, with gold curiously <sic>wrought</sic> and all the other gifts which the counsellors of the Phaeacians brought <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod>. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188942" n="13.13-13.14">But, come now, let us give him a great tripod and a cauldron, each man of us,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188943" n="13.14-13.15">and we in turn will gather the cost from among the people, <milestone ed="p" n="15" unit="line"/> and repay ourselves. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188944" n="13.15">It were hard for one man to give freely, without requital.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2188945" n="13.16">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> Alcinous, and his word was pleasing to them. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188946" n="13.17-13.19">They then went, each man to his house, to take their rest; but as soon as early Dawn appeared, the rosy-fingered, they hastened to the ship and brought the bronze, that gives strength to men.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188947" n="13.20-13.22"><milestone ed="p" n="20" unit="line"/>And the strong and mighty Alcinous went himself throughout the ship, and carefully stowed the gifts beneath the benches, that they might not hinder any of the crew at their rowing, when they busily plied the oars. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188948" n="13.23">Then they went to the house of Alcinous, and prepared a feast.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188949" n="13.24-13.25">And for them the strong and mighty Alcinous sacrificed a bull <milestone ed="p" n="25" unit="line"/> to Zeus, son of Cronos, god of the dark clouds, who is lord of all. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188950" n="13.26-13.27">Then, when they had burned the thigh-pieces, they feasted a glorious feast, and made merry,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188951" n="13.27-13.28">and among them the divine minstrel Demodocus, held in honor by the people, sang to the lyre. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188952" n="13.28-13.30">But Odysseus would ever turn his head toward the blazing sun, <milestone ed="p" n="30" unit="line"/> eager to see it set, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188953" n="13.30">for <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> he was eager to return home. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188954" n="13.31-13.32">And as a man longs for supper, for whom all day long a yoke of wine-dark oxen has drawn the jointed plough through fallow land,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188955" n="13.33-13.34">and gladly for him does the light of the sun sink, that he may busy him with his supper, and his knees grow weary as he goes;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188956" n="13.35"><milestone ed="p" n="35" unit="line"/> even so gladly for Odysseus did the light of the sun sink. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188957" n="13.36-13.37">Straightway then he spoke among the Phaeacians, lovers of the oar, and to Alcinous above all he declared his word, and said:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188958" n="13.38-13.39">Lord Alcinous, renowned above all men, pour libations now, and send <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> me on my way in peace; and yourselves too—Farewell!

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188959" n="13.40-13.42"><milestone ed="p" n="40" unit="line"/>For now all that my heart desired has been brought to pass: a convoy, and gifts of friendship. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188960" n="13.42-13.43">May the gods of heaven bless them to me, and on my return may I find in my home my peerless wife with those I love unscathed;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188961" n="13.44-13.45">and may you again, remaining here, make glad <milestone ed="p" n="45" unit="line"/> your wedded wives and children;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188962" n="13.45-13.46">and may the gods grant you prosperity of every sort, and may no evil come upon your people.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:13.47-13.92">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188963" n="13.47-13.48">So he spoke, and they all praised his words, and <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> send the stranger on his way, since he had spoken fittingly. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188964" n="13.49">Then the mighty Alcinous spoke to the herald, saying:




</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188965" n="13.50-13.52"><milestone ed="p" n="50" unit="line"/>Pontonous, mix the bowl, and serve out wine to all in the hall, in order that, when we have made prayer to father Zeus, we may send forth the stranger to his own native land.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2188966" n="13.53-13.54">So he spoke, and Pontonous mixed the honey hearted wine and served out to all, coming up to each in turn;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188967" n="13.54-13.56">and they  <milestone ed="p" n="55" unit="line"/> poured libations  to the blessed gods, who hold broad heaven, from where they sat.

<s xml:id="sent2188968" n="13.56-13.58">But <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus arose, and placed in the hand of Arete the two-handled cup, and spoke, and addressed her with winged words:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2188969" n="13.59-13.60">Fare <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> well, O queen, throughout all the years, till old age <milestone ed="p" n="60" unit="line"/> and death come, which are the lot of mortals. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188970" n="13.61">As for me, I go my way,</s>


<s xml:id="sent2188971" n="13.61-13.62">but do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> in this house have joy of <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> children and <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> people and Alcinous the king.

<s xml:id="sent2188972" n="13.63-13.65">So the <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> and passed over the threshold. And with him the mighty Alcinous sent forth a herald <milestone ed="p" n="65" unit="line"/> to lead him to the swift ship and the shore of the sea. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188973" n="13.66-13.68">And Arete sent with him slave women, one bearing a newly washed cloak and a tunic, and another again she <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> follow to bear the strong chest,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188974" n="13.69">and yet another bore bread and red wine.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188975" n="13.70-13.72"><milestone ed="p" n="70" unit="line"/>But when they had come down to the ship and to the sea, straightway the lordly youths that were his escort took these things, and stowed them in the hollow ship, even all the food and drink. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188976" n="13.73-13.75">Then for Odysseus they spread a rug and a linen sheet on the deck of the hollow ship <milestone ed="p" n="75" unit="line"/> at the stern, that he might sleep soundly;</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188978" n="13.76-13.77">Then they sat down on the benches, each in order, and loosed the hawser from the pierced stone. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188979" n="13.78-13.80">And as soon as they leaned back, and tossed the brine with their oarblades, sweet sleep fell upon his eyelids, <milestone ed="p" n="80" unit="line"/> an unawakening sleep, most sweet, and most like to death. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188980" n="13.81-13.85">And as on a plain four yoked stallions spring forward all together beneath the strokes of the lash, and leaping on high swiftly accomplish their way, even so the stern of that ship leapt on high, and in her wake <milestone ed="p" n="85" unit="line"/> the dark wave of the loud-sounding sea foamed mightily,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188981" n="13.86">and she sped safely and surely on her way;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188982" n="13.86-13.87">not even the circling hawk, the swiftest of winged things, could have kept pace with her. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188983" n="13.88-13.89">Thus she sped on swiftly and clove the waves of the sea, bearing a man the peer of the gods in counsel,


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188984" n="13.90-13.92"><milestone ed="p" n="90" unit="line"/> one who in time past had suffered many griefs at heart in passing through wars of men and the grievous waves; but now he slept in peace, forgetful of all that he had suffered.</s></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:13.93-13.138">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2188985" n="13.93-13.95">Now when that brightest of stars rose which ever comes to herald the light of early Dawn, <milestone ed="p" n="95" unit="line"/> even then the seafaring ship drew near to the island.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188986" n="13.96-13.97">There is in the land of <placeName key="tgn,7013803">Ithaca</placeName> a certain harbor of Phorcys, the old man of the sea,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188987" n="13.97-13.100">and at its mouth two projecting headlands sheer to seaward, but sloping down on the side toward the harbor. These keep back the great waves raised by heavy winds <milestone ed="p" n="100" unit="line"/> without, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2188988" n="13.100-13.101">but within the benched ships lie unmoored when they have reached the point of anchorage. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188989" n="13.102-13.104">At the head of the harbor is a long-leafed olive tree, and near it a pleasant, shadowy cave sacred to the nymphs that are called Naiads.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188990" n="13.105-13.106"><milestone ed="p" n="105" unit="line"/>Therein are mixing bowls and jars of stone,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2188992" n="13.107-13.108">And in the cave are long looms of stone, at which the nymphs weave webs of purple dye, a wonder to behold;

<s xml:id="sent2188993" n="13.109">and therein are also ever-flowing springs. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188994" n="13.109-13.111">Two doors there are to the cave, <milestone ed="p" n="110" unit="line"/> one toward the <placeName key="tgn,2550011">North Wind</placeName>, by which men go down, but that toward the South Wind is sacred,

<s xml:id="sent2188995" n="13.111-13.112">nor do men enter thereby; it is the way of the immortals.

<s xml:id="sent2188996" n="13.113">Here they rowed in, knowing the place of old;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188997" n="13.113-13.115">and the ship ran full half her length on the shore <milestone ed="p" n="115" unit="line"/> in her swift course,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188998" n="13.115">at such pace was she driven by the arms of the rowers. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2188999" n="13.116-13.121">Then they stepped forth from the benched ship upon the land, and first they lifted Odysseus out of the hollow ship, with the linen sheet and bright rug as they were, and laid him down on the sand, still overpowered by sleep. <milestone ed="p" n="120" unit="line"/>And they lifted out the goods which the lordly Phaeacians had given him, as he set out for home, through the favour of great-hearted Athena. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189000" n="13.122-13.124">These they set all together by the trunk of the olive tree, out of the path, lest <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> some wayfarer, before Odysseus awoke, might come upon them and spoil them.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189001" n="13.125"><milestone ed="p" n="125" unit="line"/>Then they themselves returned home again. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189002" n="13.125-13.127">But the Shaker of the Earth did not forget the threats wherewith at the first he had threatened godlike Odysseus, and he thus enquired of the purpose of Zeus:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189003" n="13.128-13.130">Father Zeus, no longer shall I, even I, be held in honor among the immortal gods, seeing that mortals honor me not a whit— <milestone ed="p" n="130" unit="line"/> even the Phaeacians, who, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='knowest'>know</mod>, are of my own lineage. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189004" n="13.131-13.132">For I but now declared that Odysseus should suffer many woes <mod n="ere:simpsub">before</mod> he reached his home,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189005" n="13.132-13.133">though I did not wholly rob him of his return when once <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hadst:simpsub">had</mod> promised it and confirmed it with <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> nod; </s>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:13.139-13.183">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189007" n="13.139">Then Zeus, the cloud-gatherer, answered him, and said: <milestone ed="p" n="140" unit="line"/>


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189008" n="13.140">Ah me, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> shaker of the earth, wide of sway, what a thing <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> said!</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189009" n="13.141">The gods do <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> no dishonor;

<s xml:id="sent2189011" n="13.143-13.144">But as for men, if any one, yielding to his might and strength, fails to do <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> honor in <mod n="aught:simpsub">anything</mod>,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2189013" n="13.145"><milestone ed="p" n="145" unit="line"/>Do as <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wilt:simpsub">will</mod>, and as is <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> good pleasure.

</q>

<s xml:id="sent2189018" n="13.153">Then Zeus, the cloud-gatherer, answered him and said: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189019" n="13.154-13.158">Lazy one, hear what seems best in my sight. <milestone ed="p" n="155" unit="line"/>When all the people are looking forth from the city upon her as she speeds on her way, then do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> turn her to stone hard by the land—a stone in the shape of a swift ship, that all men may marvel; and do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> fling a great mountain about their city.

<s xml:id="sent2189020" n="13.159-13.160">Now when Poseidon, the earth-shaker, heard this <milestone ed="p" n="160" unit="line"/> he went his way to <placeName key="tgn,7010886">Scheria</placeName>, where the Phaeacians dwell,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2189025" n="13.165-13.166"><milestone ed="p" n="165" unit="line"/>But they spoke winged words to one another, the Phaeacians of the long oars, men famed for their ships.

<s xml:id="sent2189028" n="13.169"><sic>Lo</sic>, she was in plain sight.

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:13.184-13.216">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189039" n="13.184">So he spoke, and they were seized with fear and made ready the bulls.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189040" n="13.185-13.187"><milestone ed="p" n="185" unit="line"/>Thus they were praying to the lord Poseidon, the leaders and counsellors of the land of the Phaeacians, as they stood about the altar,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189041" n="13.187-13.189">but Odysseus awoke out of his sleep in his native land. Yet he knew it not after his long absence,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189042" n="13.189-13.193">for about him the goddess had shed a mist, <milestone ed="p" n="190" unit="line"/> even Pallas Athena, daughter of Zeus, that she might render him unknown, and tell him all things, so that his wife might not know him, nor his townsfolk, nor his friends, until the wooers had paid the full price of all their transgressions. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189043" n="13.194-13.196">Therefore all things seemed strange to their lord, <milestone ed="p" n="195" unit="line"/> the long paths, the bays offering safe anchorage, the sheer cliffs, and the luxuriant trees. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189044" n="13.197">So he sprang up and stood and looked upon his native land, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189045" n="13.198-13.199">and then he groaned and <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> both of his thighs with the flat of his hands, and mournfully spoke, and said:

<s xml:id="sent2189046" n="13.200"><milestone ed="p" n="200" unit="line"/>Woe is me, to the land of what mortals am I now come? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189047" n="13.201-13.202">Are they cruel, and wild, and unjust, or do they love strangers and fear the gods in their thoughts? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189048" n="13.203"><mod n="Whither:simpsub">Where</mod> shall I bear all this wealth, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2189049" n="13.203-13.204">or <mod n="whither:simpsub">where</mod> shall I myself go wandering on? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189050" n="13.204-13.205">Would that I had remained there among the Phaeacians, <milestone ed="p" n="205" unit="line"/>
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189051" n="13.205-13.206">and had then come to some other of the mighty kings, who would have entertained me and sent me on my homeward way. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189052" n="13.207-13.208">But now I know not where to bestow this wealth; yet here will I not leave it, lest <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> it become the spoil of others to my cost.

<s xml:id="sent2189147" n="13.397">But come, I will make <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> unknown to all mortals.

<s xml:id="sent2189148" n="13.398-13.403">I will shrivel the fair skin on <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> supple limbs, and destroy the flaxen hair from off <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> head, and clothe <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> in a ragged garment, <milestone ed="p" n="400" unit="line"/> such that one would shudder to see a man clad therein. <s xml:id="sent2189149" n="13.404-13.406">And for <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod>, do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> go first of all to the swineherd <milestone ed="p" n="405" unit="line"/> who keeps <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> swine, and <sic>withal</sic> has a kindly heart towards <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, and loves <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> son and constant Penelope.

<s xml:id="sent2189150" n="13.407">Thou <mod n="wilt:simpsub">will</mod> find him abiding by the swine,

<s xml:id="sent2189151" n="13.407-13.410">and they are feeding by the rock of Corax and the spring Arethusa, eating acorns to their heart's content and <milestone ed="p" n="410" unit="line"/> drinking the black water, things which cause the rich flesh of swine to wax fat.

<s xml:id="sent2189152" n="13.411-13.413">There do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> stay, and sitting by his side question him of all things, while I go to <placeName key="perseus,Sparta">Sparta</placeName>, the land of fair women, to summon thence Telemachus, <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> dear son, Odysseus,

<s xml:id="sent2189153" n="13.414-13.415">who went to spacious <placeName key="tgn,7011065">Lacedaemon</placeName> to the house of Menelaus, <milestone ed="p" n="415" unit="line"/> to seek tidings of <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, if <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wast:simpsub">were</mod> still anywhere alive.</s></q></p>

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189154" n="13.416">Then Odysseus of many wiles answered her: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189156" n="13.418-13.419"><sic>Nay</sic>, was it <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> that he too might suffer woes, wandering over the unresting sea,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189157" n="13.419">and that others might devour his substance?

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2189158" n="13.420"><milestone ed="p" n="420" unit="line"/>Then the goddess, flashing-eyed Athena, answered him: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189159" n="13.421"><sic>Nay</sic> <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod>, not for him be <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> heart overmuch troubled.

<s xml:id="sent2189160" n="13.422-13.423">It was I that guided him, that he might win good report by going thither, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189161" n="13.423-13.424">and he has no toil, but sits in peace in the palace of the son of Atreus, and good cheer past telling is before him.

<s xml:id="sent2189162" n="13.425-13.426"><milestone ed="p" n="425" unit="line"/>Truly young men in a black ship lie in wait for him, eager to <mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod> him before he comes to his native land, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189163" n="13.427-13.428">but methinks this shall not be. Ere that shall the earth cover many a one of the wooers that devour <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> substance.

<s xml:id="sent2189164" n="13.429">So saying, Athena touched him with her wand.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189165" n="13.430-13.433"><milestone ed="p" n="430" unit="line"/>She withered the fair flesh on his supple limbs, and destroyed the flaxen hair from off his head, and about all his limbs she put the skin of an aged old man. And she dimmed his two eyes that were before so beautiful,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189166" n="13.434-13.435">and clothed him in other raiment, <milestone ed="p" n="435" unit="line"/> a vile ragged cloak and a tunic, tattered garments and foul, begrimed with filthy smoke. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189167" n="13.436-13.437">And about him she cast the great skin of a swift hind, stripped of the hair,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189168" n="13.437-13.438">and she gave him a staff, and a miserable wallet, full of holes,</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189170" n="13.439">So when the two had thus taken counsel together, they parted;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189171" n="13.439-13.440">and thereupon the goddess <milestone ed="p" n="440" unit="line"/> went to goodly <placeName key="tgn,7011065">Lacedaemon</placeName> to fetch the son of Odysseus.</s></p>

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189172" n="14.1-14.4"><milestone ed="p" n="1" unit="line"/>But Odysseus went forth from the harbor by the rough path up over the woodland and through the heights to the place where Athena had <mod n="shewed:simpsub">showed</mod> him that he should find the goodly swineherd, who cared for his substance above all the slaves that <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus had gotten.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189173" n="14.5-14.7"><milestone ed="p" n="5" unit="line"/>He found him sitting in the fore-hall of his house, where his court was built high in a place of wide outlook, a great and goodly court with an open space around it. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189174" n="14.7-14.10">This the swineherd had himself built for the swine of his master, that was gone, without the knowledge of his mistress and the old man Laertes. <milestone ed="p" n="10" unit="line"/>With huge stones had he built it, and set on it a coping of thorn. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189175" n="14.11-14.12">Without he had driven stakes the whole length, this way and that, huge stakes, set close together, which he had made by splitting an oak to the black core;<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note>
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189176" n="14.13-14.14">and within the court he had made twelve sties close by one another, as beds for the swine,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2189178" n="14.16-14.17">but the boars slept without. These were far fewer in numbers, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189179" n="14.17-14.19">for on them the godlike wooers feasted, and lessened them, for the swineherd ever sent in the best of all the fatted hogs,

<s xml:id="sent2189180" n="14.20"><milestone ed="p" n="20" unit="line"/> which numbered three hundred and sixty. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189181" n="14.21-14.22">By these ever slept four dogs, savage as wild beasts, which the swineherd had reared, a leader of men. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189182" n="14.23-14.24">But he himself was fitting boots about his feet, cutting an ox-hide of good color,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189183" n="14.24-14.26">while the others <milestone ed="p" n="25" unit="line"/> had gone, three of them, one here one there, with the droves of swine; 
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189184" n="14.26-14.28">and the fourth he had sent to the city to drive perforce a boar to the insolent wooers, that they might <mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod> it and satisfy their souls with meat.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189185" n="14.29">Suddenly then the baying hounds caught sight of Odysseus,

<s xml:id="sent2189186" n="14.30"><milestone ed="p" n="30" unit="line"/> and rushed upon him with loud barking,</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189188" n="14.32">Then even in his own farmstead would he have suffered cruel hurt, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189189" n="14.33-14.34">but the swineherd with swift steps followed after them, and hastened through the gateway, and the hide fell from his hand.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189190" n="14.35-14.36"><milestone ed="p" n="35" unit="line"/>He called aloud to the dogs, and drove them this way and that with a shower of stones,

</s>


<s xml:id="sent2189191" n="14.36">and spoke to his master, and said:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189192" n="14.37-14.38">Old man, <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> the dogs were like to have torn <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> to pieces all of a sudden, and on me <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='wouldest'>would</mod> have shed reproach. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189193" n="14.39">Aye, and the gods have given me other griefs and sorrow.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189194" n="14.40-14.42"><milestone ed="p" n="40" unit="line"/>It is for a godlike master that I mourn and grieve, as I <mod n="abide:simpsub">remain</mod> here, and rear fat swine for other men to eat, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189195" n="14.42-14.44">while he <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> in want of food wanders over the land and city of men of strange speech, if indeed he still lives and sees the light of the sun.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189196" n="14.45-14.47"><milestone ed="p" n="45" unit="line"/>But come with me, let us go to the hut, old man, that when <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> satisfied <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> heart with food and wine, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> too <mod n='mayest'>may</mod> tell whence <corr n="thou art">you are</corr>, and all the woes <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> endured.</s></q></p>

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189197" n="14.48-14.51">So saying, the goodly swineherd led him to the hut, and brought him in, and made him sit, strowing beneath thick brushwood, <milestone ed="p" n="50" unit="line"/> and thereon spreading the skin of a shaggy wild goat, large and hairy, on which he was himself <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to sleep. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189198" n="14.51-14.52">And Odysseus was glad that he gave him such welcome, and spoke, and addressed him:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189199" n="14.53-14.54">Stranger, may Zeus and the other immortal gods grant <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> what most <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='desirest'>desire</mod>, since <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> with a ready heart <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> given me welcome.

<s xml:id="sent2189200" n="14.55"><milestone ed="p" n="55" unit="line"/>To him then, swineherd Eumaeus, <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> make answer, and say: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189201" n="14.56-14.57"><sic>Nay</sic>, stranger, it were not right for me, even though one meaner than <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> were to come, to slight a stranger:</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189202" n="14.57-14.58">for from Zeus are all strangers and beggars,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189203" n="14.58-14.59">and a gift, though small, is welcome from such as we; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2189204" n="14.59-14.61">since this is the lot of slaves, <milestone ed="p" n="60" unit="line"/> ever in fear when over them as lords their masters hold sway—young masters such as ours. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189205" n="14.61-14.66">For <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> the gods have stayed the return of him who would have loved me with all kindness, and would have given me possessions of my own, a house and a bit of land, and a wife, sought of many wooers, even such things as a kindly master gives to his thrall <milestone ed="p" n="65" unit="line"/> who has toiled much for him, and whose labour the god makes to prosper, even as this work of mine prospers, to which I give heed. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189206" n="14.67">Therefore would my master have richly rewarded me, if he had grown old here at home: 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189207" n="14.68-14.69">but he perished—as I would all the kindred of Helen had perished in utter ruin, since she loosened the knees of many warriors.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189208" n="14.70-14.71"><milestone ed="p" n="70" unit="line"/>For he too went forth to win recompense for Agamemnon to <placeName key="tgn,7002329">Ilios</placeName>, famed for its horses, that he might fight with the Trojans.</s></q></p>

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189209" n="14.72-14.73">So saying, he quickly bound up his tunic with his belt, and went to the sties, where the tribes of swine were penned.

<s xml:id="sent2189210" n="14.74-14.75">Choosing two from thence, he brought them in and <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> them both, <milestone ed="p" n="75" unit="line"/> and singed, and cut them up, and spitted them.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189213" n="14.78-14.79">Then in a bowl of ivy wood he mixed honey-sweet wine, and himself sat down over against Odysseus, and <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> him to his food, and said:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189214" n="14.80-14.81"><milestone ed="p" n="80" unit="line"/>Eat now, stranger, such food as slaves have to offer, meat of young pigs;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189215" n="14.81-14.82">the fatted hogs the wooers eat, who <mod n="reck:simpsub">care</mod> not in their hearts of the wrath of the gods, nor have any pity.

<s xml:id="sent2189216" n="14.83-14.84"><mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod> the blessed gods love not reckless deeds, but they honor justice and the righteous deeds of men.

<s xml:id="sent2189217" n="14.85-14.88"><milestone ed="p" n="85" unit="line"/>Even cruel foemen that set foot on the land of others, and Zeus gives them booty, and they fill their ships and depart for home—even on the hearts of these falls great fear of the wrath of the gods. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189218" n="14.89-14.92">But these men here, look you, know somewhat, and have heard some voice of a god <milestone ed="p" n="90" unit="line"/> regarding my master's pitiful death, seeing that they will not woo righteously, nor go back to their own, but at their ease they waste our substance in insolent wise, and there is no sparing. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189219" n="14.93-14.94">For every day and night that comes from Zeus they sacrifice not one victim nor two alone,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189220" n="14.95"><milestone ed="p" n="95" unit="line"/> and they draw forth wine, and waste it in insolent wise. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189221" n="14.96"><mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod> his substance was great past telling, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189222" n="14.96-14.98">so much has no lord either on the dark mainland or in <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName> itself;</s>

<s xml:id="sent2189230" n="14.109-14.110">So he spoke, but Odysseus eagerly<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> ate flesh and drank wine, <milestone ed="p" n="110" unit="line"/> greedily, in silence, and was sowing the seeds of evil for the wooers.
