<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189233" n="14.115-14.116">Friend, who was it who bought <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> with his wealth, a man so very rich and mighty, as <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> tellest?

<s xml:id="sent2189238" n="14.121">Then the swineherd, a leader of men, answered him: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189239" n="14.122-14.125">Old man, no wanderer that came and brought tidings of him could persuade his wife and his dear son; <sic>nay</sic>, at random, when they have need of entertainment, do vagabonds <milestone ed="p" n="125" unit="line"/> lie, and are not minded to speak the truth. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189240" n="14.126-14.127">Whosoever in his wanderings comes to the land of <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName>, goes to my mistress and tells a deceitful tale.

<s xml:id="sent2189241" n="14.128-14.130">And she, receiving him kindly, gives him entertainment, and questions him of all things, and the tears fall from her eyelids, while she weeps, <milestone ed="p" n="130" unit="line"/> as is the way of a woman, when her husband dies afar.

<s xml:id="sent2189244" n="14.133-14.134">But as for him, <mod n="ere:simpsub">before</mod> now dogs and swift birds are like to have torn the flesh from his bones, and his spirit has left him;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189247" n="14.138-14.141">For never again shall I find a master so kind, how far soever I go, <milestone ed="p" n="140" unit="line"/> not though I come again to the house of my father and mother, where at the first I was born, and they reared me themselves. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189248" n="14.142-14.143">Yet it is not for them that I henceforth mourn so much, eager though I am to behold them with my eyes and to be in my native land; 

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2189250" n="14.145-14.146"><milestone ed="p" n="145" unit="line"/>His name, stranger, absent though he is, I speak with awe, </s>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:14.148-14.190">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189253" n="14.148">Then the much-enduring, <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus answered him: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189254" n="14.149-14.150">Friend, since <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> utterly make denial, and <mod n='declarest'>declare</mod> <milestone ed="p" n="150" unit="line"/> that he will never come again, and <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> heart is ever unbelieving, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189255" n="14.151-14.152">therefore will I tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, not at random but with an oath, that Odysseus shall return. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189256" n="14.152-14.153">And let me have a reward for bearing good tidings, as soon as he shall come, and reach his home; 


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189257" n="14.154">clothe me in a cloak and tunic, goodly raiment.

<s xml:id="sent2189281" n="14.191-14.192">Then Odysseus of many wiles answered him, and said: Then <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> I will frankly tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> all.</s>

<s xml:id="sent2189369" n="14.361-14.362">Ah, wretched stranger, <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> stirred my heart deeply in telling all the tale of <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> sufferings and <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> wanderings. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189370" n="14.363-14.364">But in this, methinks, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> not spoken aright, nor <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> persuade me with <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> tale about Odysseus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189371" n="14.364-14.365">Why <mod n="shouldst:simpsub">should</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod>, who art in such plight <milestone ed="p" n="365" unit="line"/> lie to no purpose? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189372" n="14.365-14.368"><sic>Nay</sic>, of myself I know well regarding the return of my master, that he was utterly hated of all the gods, in that they did not <mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod> him among the Trojans, or in the arms of his friends, when he had wound up the skein of war. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189373" n="14.369-14.371">Then would the whole host of the Achaeans have made him a tomb, <milestone ed="p" n="370" unit="line"/> and for his son too he would have won great glory in days to come. But as it is the spirits of the storm have swept him away, and left no tidings. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189374" n="14.372">I, for my part, dwell aloof with the swine,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189375" n="14.372-14.374">nor do I go to the city, unless <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> wise Penelope <mod n="bids:simpsub">commands</mod> me thither, when tidings come to her from anywhere.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189376" n="14.375-14.377"><milestone ed="p" n="375" unit="line"/>Then men sit around him that comes, and question him closely, both those that grieve for their lord, that has long been gone, and those who rejoice, as they devour his substance without atonement. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189377" n="14.378-14.381">But I care not to ask or enquire, since the time when an Aetolian beguiled me with his story, <milestone ed="p" n="380" unit="line"/> one that had killed a man, and after wandering over the wide earth came to my house,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189378" n="14.381">and I gave him kindly welcome. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189379" n="14.382-14.383">He said that he had seen Odysseus among the Cretans at the house of Idomeneus, mending his ships which storms had shattered. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189380" n="14.384-14.385">And he said that he would come either by summer or by harvest-time, <milestone ed="p" n="385" unit="line"/> bringing much treasure along with his godlike comrades. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189381" n="14.386-14.387">Thou too, old man of many sorrows, since a god has brought <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> to me, seek not to win my favour by lies, nor in any wise to cajole me. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189382" n="14.388-14.389">It is not for this that I shall <mod n="shew:simpsub">show</mod> <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> respect or kindness, but from fear of Zeus, the stranger's god, and from pity for <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod>.

</s></q>


<s xml:id="sent2189383" n="14.390-14.392"><milestone ed="p" n="390" unit="line"/>Then Odysseus of many wiles answered him, and said: <mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> bosom a heart that is slow to believe, seeing that in such wise, even with an oath, I won <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> not, neither persuade <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>. 

</s>

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189384" n="14.393">But come now, let us make a covenant,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189385" n="14.393-14.394">and the gods who hold <placeName key="tgn,7011019">Olympus</placeName> shall be witnesses for us both in time to come.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189386" n="14.395-14.397"><milestone ed="p" n="395" unit="line"/>If <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> master returns to this house, clothe me in a cloak and tunic, as raiment, and send me on my way to Dulichium, where I desire to be. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189387" n="14.398-14.400">But if <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> master does not come as I say, set the slaves upon me, and fling me down from a great cliff, <milestone ed="p" n="400" unit="line"/> that another beggar may beware of deceiving.</s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:14.401-14.445">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189388" n="14.401">And the goodly swineherd answered him, and said: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189389" n="14.402-14.405">Aye, stranger, so should I indeed win fair fame and prosperity among men both now and hereafter, if I, who brought <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> to my hut and gave <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> entertainment, <milestone ed="p" n="405" unit="line"/> should then <mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod> <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, and take away <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> dear life. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189390" n="14.406">With a ready heart thereafter should I pray to Zeus, son of Cronos. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189391" n="14.407">But it is now time for supper,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189392" n="14.407-14.408">and may my comrades soon be here, that we may make ready a savoury supper in the hut.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2189393" n="14.409-14.410">Thus they spoke to one another, <milestone ed="p" n="410" unit="line"/> and the swine and the swineherds drew near. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189394" n="14.411-14.413">The sows they shut up to sleep in their wonted sties, and a wondrous noise arose from them, as they were penned. Then the goodly swineherd called to his comrades saying: 


</s>

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189395" n="14.414-14.415">Bring forth the best of the boars, that I may slaughter him for the stranger <milestone ed="p" n="415" unit="line"/> who comes from afar,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189396" n="14.415-14.416">and we too shall have some profit therefrom, who have long borne toil and suffering for the sake of the white-tusked swine,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189397" n="14.417">while others devour our labour without atonement.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2189398" n="14.418-14.419">So saying, he split wood with the pitiless bronze, and the others brought in a fatted boar of five years old,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189399" n="14.420"><milestone ed="p" n="420" unit="line"/> and set him by the hearth. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189400" n="14.420-14.421">Nor did the swineherd forget the immortals,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189401" n="14.421">for he had an understanding heart,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189402" n="14.422-14.424">but as a first offering he cast into the fire bristles from the head of the white-tusked boar, and made prayer to all the gods that wise Odysseus might return to his own house.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189403" n="14.425"><milestone ed="p" n="425" unit="line"/>Then he raised himself up, and <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> the boar with a billet of oak, which he had left when splitting the wood,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189404" n="14.426">and the boar's life left him. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189405" n="14.426">And the others cut the boar's throat, and singed him,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189406" n="14.427">and quickly cut him up,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189407" n="14.427-14.432">and the swineherd took as first offerings bits of raw flesh from all the limbs, and laid them in the rich fat. These he cast into the fire, when he had sprinkled them with barley meal, <milestone ed="p" n="430" unit="line"/> but the rest they cut up and spitted, and roasted it carefully, and drew it all off the spits, and cast it in a heap on platters. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189408" n="14.432-14.433">Then the swineherd stood up to carve,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189409" n="14.433">for well did his heart know what was fair,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189410" n="14.434">and he cut up the mess and divided it into seven portions.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189411" n="14.435-14.436"><milestone ed="p" n="435" unit="line"/>One with a prayer he set aside for the nymphs and for Hermes, son of <placeName key="tgn,1049816">Maia</placeName>, and the rest he distributed to each. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189412" n="14.437-14.438">And Odysseus he honored with the long <mod n="chine:simpsub">back-meat</mod> of the white-tusked boar, and made glad the heart of his master;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189413" n="14.439">and Odysseus of many wiles spoke to him, and said:



</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189414" n="14.440-14.441"><milestone ed="p" n="440" unit="line"/> Eumaeus, <mod n='mayest'>may</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> be as dear to father Zeus as <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> to me, since <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> honourest me with a good portion, <mod n="albeit:simpsub">although</mod> I am in such plight.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2189415" n="14.442">To him then, swineherd Eumaeus, <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> make answer, and say: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189416" n="14.443-14.444">Eat, unhappy stranger, and have joy of such fare as is here. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189417" n="14.444-14.445">It is the god that will give one thing and withhold another, <milestone ed="p" n="445" unit="line"/> even as seems good to his heart;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189418" n="14.445">for he can do all things.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:14.446-14.493">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189419" n="14.446-14.448">He spoke, and sacrificed the firstling pieces to the gods that are for ever, and, when he had made libations of the flaming wine, he placed the cup in the hands of Odysseus, the sacker of cities,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189420" n="14.448">and took his seat by his own portion. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189421" n="14.449-14.451">And bread was served to them by Mesaulius, whom the swineherd <milestone ed="p" n="450" unit="line"/> had gotten by himself alone, while his master was gone, without the knowledge of his mistress or the old Laertes, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189422" n="14.452">buying him of the Taphians with his own goods. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189423" n="14.453">So they put forth their hands to the good cheer lying ready before them. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189424" n="14.454-14.456">But when they had put from them the desire of food and drink, <milestone ed="p" n="455" unit="line"/>Mesaulius took away the food, and they were fain to go to their rest, sated with bread and meat.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189425" n="14.457-14.458">Now the night came on, foul and without a moon, and Zeus rained the whole night through, and the West Wind, ever the rainy wind, blew strong. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189426" n="14.459-14.461">Then Odysseus spoke among them, making trial of the swineherd, <milestone ed="p" n="460" unit="line"/> to see whether he would strip off his own cloak and give it him, or <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> some other of his comrades to do so, since he cared for him so greatly:</s></p>

<p><q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2189427" n="14.462-14.463">Hear me now, Eumaeus and all the rest of you, his men, with a wish in my heart will I tell a tale;</s>


<s xml:id="sent2189428" n="14.463-14.466">for the wine <mod n="bids:simpsub">commands</mod> me, befooling wine, which sets one, even though he be right wise, to singing <milestone ed="p" n="465" unit="line"/> and laughing softly, and makes him stand up and dance, aye, and brings forth a word which were better unspoken. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189429" n="14.467">Still, since I have once spoken out, I will hide nothing. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189430" n="14.468-14.469">Would that I were young and my strength firm as when we made ready our ambush, and led it beneath the walls of <placeName key="tgn,7002329">Troy</placeName>.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189431" n="14.470-14.471"><milestone ed="p" n="470" unit="line"/>The leaders were Odysseus and Menelaus, son of Atreus, and with them I was third in command;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189432" n="14.471">for so had they ordered it themselves. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189433" n="14.472-14.475">Now when we had come to the city and the steep wall, round about the town in the thick brushwood among the needs and swamp-land <milestone ed="p" n="475" unit="line"/> we lay, crouching beneath our arms,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189434" n="14.475-14.476">and night came on, foul, when the North Wind had fallen, and frosty,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189435" n="14.476-14.477">and snow came down on us from above, covering us like rime, bitter cold, and ice formed upon our shields. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189436" n="14.478-14.479">Now all the rest had cloaks and tunics, and slept in peace, with their shields covering their shoulders,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189437" n="14.480-14.482"><milestone ed="p" n="480" unit="line"/> but I, when I set out, had left my cloak behind with my comrades in my folly, for I did not think that even so I should be cold, and had come with my shield alone and my bright kilt. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189438" n="14.483-14.485">But when it was the third watch of the night, and the stars had turned their course, then I spoke to Odysseus, who was near me, <milestone ed="p" n="485" unit="line"/> nudging him with my elbow;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189439" n="14.485">and he straightway <corr n="gave ear">listened</corr>:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2189440" n="14.486-14.488">Son of Laertes, sprung from Zeus, Odysseus of many devices, <sic>lo</sic> now, no longer shall I be among the living. <sic>Nay</sic>, the cold is killing me,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189441" n="14.488">for I have no cloak. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189442" n="14.488-14.489">Some god beguiled me to wear my tunic only,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189443" n="14.489">and now there is no more escape.</s></q></p>



<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189444" n="14.490-14.491"><milestone ed="p" n="490" unit="line"/>So I spoke, and he then devised this plan in his heart, such a man was he both to plan and to fight;</s>


<s xml:id="sent2189445" n="14.492">and speaking in a low voice he said to me: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189446" n="14.493">Be silent now, lest another of the Achaeans hear <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>.</s></q></p></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:14.494-14.533">
<p><q>


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189447" n="14.494">With this he raised his head upon his elbow, and spoke, saying: <milestone ed="p" n="495" unit="line"/>


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189448" n="14.495">Hear me, friends; 
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189449" n="14.495">a dream from the gods came to me in my sleep. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189450" n="14.496"><sic>Lo</sic>, we have come very far from the ships,


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189451" n="14.496-14.498">and I would that there were one to bear word to Agamemnon, son of Atreus, shepherd of the host, in the hope that he might <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> more men to come from the ships.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189452" n="14.499-14.501">So he spoke, and Thoas, son of Andraemon, sprang up <milestone ed="p" n="500" unit="line"/> quickly, and from him flung his purple cloak, and set out to run to the ships. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189453" n="14.501-14.502">Then in his garment I gladly lay, and golden-throned Dawn appeared. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189454" n="14.503">Would that I were young as then, and my strength as firm;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189455" n="14.504-14.505">then would one of the swineherds in the farmstead give me a cloak <milestone ed="p" n="505" unit="line"/> both from kindness and from respect for a brave warrior. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189456" n="14.506">But as it is they scorn me, since I have foul raiment about me.</s></p></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189457" n="14.507">To him then, swineherd Eumaeus, <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> make answer, and say: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189458" n="14.508-14.509">Old man, the tale <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> told is a good one, nor <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> thus far spoken <mod n="aught:simpsub">anything</mod> amiss or unprofitably.

<s xml:id="sent2189459" n="14.510-14.512"><milestone ed="p" n="510" unit="line"/><mod n="Wherefore:simpsub">For which reason</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> lack neither clothing nor <mod n="aught:simpsub">anything</mod> else that a sore-tried suppliant should receive, when he meets one—for this night at least;</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189461" n="14.513-14.514">For not many cloaks are here or changes of tunics to put on, but each man has one alone.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189462" n="14.515-14.517"><milestone ed="p" n="515" unit="line"/>But when the dear son of Odysseus comes, he will himself give <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> a cloak and a tunic as raiment, and will send <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> whithersoever <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> heart and spirit <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> go.

<s xml:id="sent2189463" n="14.518-14.519">So saying, he sprang up and placed a bed for Odysseus near the fire, and cast upon it skins of sheep and goats.

<s xml:id="sent2189464" n="14.520"><milestone ed="p" n="520" unit="line"/>There Odysseus lay down,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189465" n="14.520-14.522">and the swineherd threw over him a great thick cloak, which he kept at hand for a change of clothing whenever a terrible storm should arise.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189466" n="14.523-14.524">So there Odysseus slept, and beside him slept the young men. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189467" n="14.524-14.526">But the swineherd <milestone ed="p" n="525" unit="line"/> liked not a bed in that place, that he should lay him down away from the boars; so he made ready to go outside. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189468" n="14.526-14.527">And Odysseus was glad that he took such care of his master's substance while he was afar. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189469" n="14.528-14.531">First Eumaeus flung his sharp sword over his strong shoulders, and then put about him a cloak, very thick, to keep off the wind; <milestone ed="p" n="530" unit="line"/> and he picked up the fleece of a large, well-fatted goat, took a sharp javelin to ward off dogs and men,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189470" n="14.532-14.533">and went forth to lie down to sleep where the white-tusked boars slept beneath a hollow rock, in a place sheltered from the North Wind.</s></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="book" n="15">
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:15.1-15.47">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189471" n="15.1-15.3"><milestone ed="p" n="1" unit="line"/>But Pallas Athena went to spacious <placeName key="tgn,7011065">Lacedaemon</placeName> to remind the glorious son of great-hearted Odysseus of his return, and to hasten his coming. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189472" n="15.4-15.6">She found Telemachus and the noble son of Nestor <milestone ed="p" n="5" unit="line"/> lying in the fore-hall of the palace of glorious Menelaus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189473" n="15.7-15.8">Now Nestor's son was overcome with soft sleep, but sweet sleep did not hold Telemachus, but all through the immortal night anxious thoughts for his father kept him wakeful. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189474" n="15.9">And flashing-eyed Athena stood near him, and said:





</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189475" n="15.10-15.12"><milestone ed="p" n="10" unit="line"/>Telemachus, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> not well to wander longer far from <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> home, leaving behind <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> wealth and men in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> house so insolent,</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189477" n="15.14-15.15"><sic>Nay</sic>, rouse with all speed Menelaus, good at the war-cry, <milestone ed="p" n="15" unit="line"/> to send <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> on <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> way, that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='mayest'>may</mod> find <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> noble mother still in her home. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189478" n="15.16-15.17">For now her father and her brothers <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> her wed Eurymachus,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189479" n="15.17-15.18">for he surpasses all the wooers in his presents, and has increased his gifts of wooing. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189480" n="15.19">Beware lest she carry forth from <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> halls some treasure against <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> will.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189481" n="15.20"><milestone ed="p" n="20" unit="line"/>For <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='knowest'>know</mod> what sort of a spirit there is in a woman's breast; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2189482" n="15.21-15.23">she <corr n="is fain">wants</corr> to increase the house of the man who weds her, but of her former children and of the lord of her youth she takes no thought, when once he is dead, and asks no longer concerning them. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189483" n="15.24-15.26"><sic>Nay</sic>, go, and <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod> put all <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> possessions in the charge of whatsoever one <milestone ed="p" n="25" unit="line"/> of the handmaids seems to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> the best, until the gods shall show <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> a noble bride.

<s xml:id="sent2189508" n="15.69-15.71"><sic>Nay</sic>, I should blame another, <milestone ed="p" n="70" unit="line"/> who, as host, loves overmuch or hates overmuch;</s>

<s xml:id="sent2189512" n="15.75-15.77"><milestone ed="p" n="75" unit="line"/>But stay, till I bring fair gifts and put them on <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> <mod n="car:simpsub">chariot</mod>, and <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> own eyes behold them, and till I <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> the women make ready a meal in the halls of the abundant store that is within.

<s xml:id="sent2189600" n="15.215-15.216"><milestone ed="p" n="215" unit="line"/>So saying, he drove his horses with beautiful mane back to the city of the Pylians, and speedily reached the palace. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189601" n="15.217">And Telemachus called to his men, and gave command to them, saying:


</s>

<s xml:id="sent2189603" n="15.220-15.221"><milestone ed="p" n="220" unit="line"/>So he spoke, and they readily <mod n="hearkened:simpsub">listened</mod> and obeyed; and at once they went on board, and sat down upon the benches.</s></p>

<s xml:id="sent2189606" n="15.225-15.227">By lineage he was sprung from Melampus, who of old dwelt in <placeName key="perseus,Pylos">Pylos</placeName>, mother of flocks, a rich man and one that had a very wealthy house among the Pylians,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2189608" n="15.231-15.234">Now Melampus meanwhile lay bound with bitter bonds in the halls of Phylacus, suffering grievous pains because of the daughter of Neleus, and the terrible blindness of heart which the goddess, the Erinys, who brings houses to ruin,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">2</note> had laid upon him.

<s xml:id="sent2189616" n="15.250-15.251"><milestone ed="p" n="250" unit="line"/>Now Cleitus golden-throned Dawn snatched away by reason of his beauty, that he might dwell with the immortals;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189617" n="15.252-15.253">but of Polypheides, high of heart, Apollo made a seer, far the best of mortals, after that Amphiaraus was dead.

<s xml:id="sent2189650" n="15.301-15.302">But the two, Odysseus and the goodly swineherd, were supping in the hut,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2189652" n="15.303-15.306">But when they had put from them the desire of food and drink, Odysseus spoke among them, making trial of the swineherd to see <milestone ed="p" n="305" unit="line"/> whether he would still entertain him with kindly care and <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> him remain there at the farmstead, or send him forth to the city:

<s xml:id="sent2189661" n="15.325"><milestone ed="p" n="325" unit="line"/>Then deeply moved <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> speak to him, swineherd Eumaeus:

<s xml:id="sent2189693" n="15.390-15.392"><milestone ed="p" n="390" unit="line"/>Stranger, since <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> ask and question me of this, <mod n="hearken:simpsub">listen</mod> now in silence, and take <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> joy, and drink <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> wine, as <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='sittest'>sit</mod> here.

<s xml:id="sent2189698" n="15.395-15.396"><milestone ed="p" n="395" unit="line"/>As for the rest, if any man's heart and spirit <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> him, let him go forth and sleep,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189700" n="15.398-15.400">But we two will drink and feast in the hut, and will take delight each in the other's grievous woes, <milestone ed="p" n="400" unit="line"/> as we recall them to mind. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189701" n="15.400-15.401">For in after time a man finds joy even in woes, whosoever has suffered much, and wandered much. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189702" n="15.402">But this will I tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, of which <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> ask and enquire.</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189703" n="15.403-15.406">There is an isle called <placeName key="tgn,1000140">Syria</placeName>, if <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> heard <sic>thereof</sic>, above Ortygia, where are the turning-places of the sun. <milestone ed="p" n="405" unit="line"/>It is not so very thickly settled, but it is a good land, rich in herds, rich in flocks, full of wine, abounding in wheat. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189704" n="15.407-15.408">Famine never comes into the land, nor does any hateful sickness besides fall on wretched mortals;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189705" n="15.409-15.411">but when the tribes of men grow old throughout the city, <milestone ed="p" n="410" unit="line"/>Apollo, of the silver bow, comes with Artemis, and assails them with his gentle shafts, and slays them. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189706" n="15.412">In that isle are two cities, and all the land is divided between them,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189707" n="15.413-15.414">and over both ruled as king my father, Ctesius, son of Ormenus, a man like to the immortals.</s></p></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:15.415-15.453">
<p><q>



<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189708" n="15.415-15.416"><milestone ed="p" n="415" unit="line"/>Thither came Phoenicians, men famed for their ships, greedy knaves, bringing countless trinkets in their black ship. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189709" n="15.417-15.418">Now there was in my father's house a Phoenician woman, comely and tall, and skilled in glorious handiwork. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189710" n="15.419">Her the wily Phoenicians beguiled.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189711" n="15.420-15.422"><milestone ed="p" n="420" unit="line"/>First, as she was washing clothes, one of them lay with her in love by the hollow ship; for this beguiles the minds of women, even though one be upright. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189712" n="15.423">Then he asked her who she was, and whence she came,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189713" n="15.424">and she straightway <mod n="shewed:simpsub">showed</mod> him the high-roofed home of my father, and said:</s></p>




<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2189714" n="15.425-15.426"><milestone ed="p" n="425" unit="line"/>Out of <placeName key="tgn,7002861">Sidon</placeName>, rich in bronze, I declare that I come, and I am the daughter of Arybas, to whom wealth flowed in streams. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189715" n="15.427-15.429">But Taphian pirates seized me, as I was coming from the fields, and brought me <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod>, and sold me to the house of <sic>yonder</sic> man,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189716" n="15.429">and he paid for me a goodly price.</s></q></p>



<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189717" n="15.430"><milestone ed="p" n="430" unit="line"/>Then the man who had lain with her in secret answered her:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189718" n="15.431-15.433"><mod n='Wouldest'>Would</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> then return again with us to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> home, that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='mayest'>may</mod> see the high-roofed house of <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> father and mother, and see them too? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189719" n="15.433">For of a truth they yet live, and are accounted rich.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189720" n="15.434">Then the woman answered him, and said: <milestone ed="p" n="435" unit="line"/>


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189721" n="15.435-15.436">This may well be, if you sailors will pledge yourselves by an oath, that you will bring me safely home.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189722" n="15.437">So she spoke, and they all gave an oath <sic>thereto</sic>, as she <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> them. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189723" n="15.438-15.439">But when they had sworn and made an end of the oath, the woman again spoke among them, and made answer:</s></p> <milestone ed="p" n="440" unit="line"/>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2189724" n="15.440-15.442">Be silent now, and let no one of your company speak to me, if he meets me in the street or <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> at the well,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189725" n="15.442-15.444">lest some one go to the palace and tell the old king, and he wax suspicious and bind me with grievous bonds, and devise death for you.

<s xml:id="sent2189726" n="15.445"><milestone ed="p" n="445" unit="line"/><sic>Nay</sic>, keep my words in mind, and speed the barter of your wares. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189727" n="15.446-15.447">But, when your ship is <sic>laden</sic> with goods, let a message come quickly to me at the palace;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189728" n="15.448">for I will also bring whatever gold comes under my hand. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189729" n="15.449">Aye, and I would gladly give another thing for my passage.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189730" n="15.450-15.451"><milestone ed="p" n="450" unit="line"/>There is a child of my noble<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> master, whose nurse I am in the palace, such a cunning child, who ever runs abroad with me. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189731" n="15.452-15.453">Him would I bring on board, and he would fetch you a vast price, wherever you might take him for sale among men of strange speech.</s></q></p></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:15.454-15.492">

<s xml:id="sent2189732" n="15.454-15.456">So saying, she departed to the fair palace. <milestone ed="p" n="455" unit="line"/>And they remained there in our land a full year, and got by trade much substance in their hollow ship.

<s xml:id="sent2189733" n="15.457-15.458">But when their hollow ship was <sic>laden</sic> for their return, then they sent a messenger to bear tidings to the woman.

<s xml:id="sent2189734" n="15.459-15.460">There came a man, well versed in guile, to my father's house <milestone ed="p" n="460" unit="line"/> with a necklace of gold, and with amber beads was it strung between.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189746" n="15.477-15.479">but when Zeus, son of Cronos, brought upon us the seventh day, then Artemis, the archer, <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> the woman, and she fell with a thud into the hold, as a sea bird plunges.

<s xml:id="sent2189750" n="15.484">Thus it was that my eyes beheld this land.

<s xml:id="sent2189751" n="15.485"><milestone ed="p" n="485" unit="line"/>To him then Zeus-born Odysseus made answer, and said:

<s xml:id="sent2189757" n="15.495-15.497">But the comrades of Telemachus, drawing near the shore, furled the sail, and took down the mast quickly, and rowed the ship to her anchorage with their oars.

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2189768" n="15.512">Then wise Telemachus answered him:

<s xml:id="sent2189769" n="15.513-15.514">Were things otherwise, I should <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> go even to our house, </s>

<s xml:id="sent2189775" n="15.523-15.524">Nevertheless Olympian Zeus, who dwells in the sky, knows this, whether or not before marriage he will fulfil for them the evil day.</s></q></p>

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189780" n="15.533-15.534">Than yours is no other house in the land of <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName> more kingly; <sic>nay</sic>, <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> are ever supreme.

<s xml:id="sent2189794" n="15.555-15.557"><milestone ed="p" n="555" unit="line"/>But his feet bore him swiftly on, as he strode forward, until he reached the farmstead where were his countless swine, among whom slept the worthy swineherd with a heart loyal to his masters.</s></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="book" n="16">

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189795" n="16.1-16.3"><milestone ed="p" n="1" unit="line"/>Meanwhile the two in the hut, Odysseus and the goodly swineherd, had kindled a fire, and were making ready their breakfast at dawn, and had sent forth the herdsmen with the droves of swine;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189796" n="16.4-16.5">but around Telemachus the baying hounds fawned, <milestone ed="p" n="5" unit="line"/> and barked not as he drew near.

<s xml:id="sent2189797" n="16.5-16.6">And <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus noted the fawning of the hounds, and the sound of footsteps fell upon his ears;</s>

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189799" n="16.8-16.10">Eumaeus, surely some comrade of <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> will be coming, or at least some one <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='knowest'>know</mod>, for the hounds do not bark, <milestone ed="p" n="10" unit="line"/> but fawn about him,</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189808" n="16.23-16.24">I thought I should never see <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> more after <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hadst:simpsub">had</mod> gone in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> ship to <placeName key="perseus,Pylos">Pylos</placeName>.

<s xml:id="sent2189810" n="16.27-16.28">For <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> not often visit the farm and the herdsmen, but <mod n='abidest'>abide</mod> in the town; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189811" n="16.28-16.29">so, I <mod n="ween:simpsub">believe</mod>, has it seemed good to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> heart, to look upon the destructive throng of the wooers.

<s xml:id="sent2189812" n="16.30"><milestone ed="p" n="30" unit="line"/>Then wise Telemachus answered him:

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189814" n="16.31-16.35">It is for <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> sake that I am come <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod>, to see <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> with my eyes, and to hear <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> tell whether my mother still abides in the halls, or whether by now some other man has wedded her, and the couch of Odysseus <milestone ed="p" n="35" unit="line"/> lies <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> in want of bedding, covered with foul spider-webs.

<s xml:id="sent2189818" n="16.40"><milestone ed="p" n="40" unit="line"/>So saying, he took from him the spear of bronze,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2189820" n="16.42">As he drew near, his father, Odysseus, rose from his seat and gave him place,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2189824" n="16.45">There is a man here who will set us one.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:16.46-16.89">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189825" n="16.46">So he spoke, and Odysseus went back and sat down again,

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2189832" n="16.55-16.56"><milestone ed="p" n="55" unit="line"/>But when they had put from them the desire of food and drink, Telemachus spoke to the goodly swineherd, and said:

<s xml:id="sent2189833" n="16.57">Father, from whence did this stranger come to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>?

<s xml:id="sent2189837" n="16.60"><milestone ed="p" n="60" unit="line"/>To him then, swineherd Eumaeus, <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> make answer, and say:

<s xml:id="sent2189839" n="16.62-16.64">From broad <placeName key="tgn,7012056">Crete</placeName> he declares that he has birth, and he says that he has wandered roaming through many cities of mortals;</s>

<s xml:id="sent2189848" n="16.73-16.77">And as for my mother, the heart in her breast wavers this way and that, whether to <mod n="abide:simpsub">remain</mod> here with me and keep the house, <milestone ed="p" n="75" unit="line"/> respecting the bed of her husband and the voice of the people, or to go now with him whosoever is best of the Achaeans that woo her in the halls, and offers the most gifts of wooing.

<s xml:id="sent2189849" n="16.78-16.81">But <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod>, as regards this stranger, now that he has come to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> house, I will clothe him in a cloak and tunic, fair raiment, <milestone ed="p" n="80" unit="line"/> and will give him a two-edged sword, and sandals for his feet, and send him whithersoever his heart and spirit <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> him go.

<s xml:id="sent2189855" n="16.88-16.89">And to achieve <mod n="aught:simpsub">anything</mod> is hard for one man among many, how mighty soever he be, for <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> they are far stronger.</s></q></p>

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189856" n="16.90"><milestone ed="p" n="90" unit="line"/>Then the much-enduring, <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus answered him:

<s xml:id="sent2189859" n="16.99-16.100">Would that with my present temper I were as young as <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod>, <milestone ed="p" n="100" unit="line"/> either the son of blameless Odysseus, or Odysseus himself,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note>

<s xml:id="sent2189861" n="16.105-16.111"><milestone ed="p" n="105" unit="line"/>But if they should overwhelm me by their numbers, alone as I was, far rather would I die, slain in my own halls, than behold continually these shameful deeds, strangers mishandled, and men dragging the handmaidens in shameful fashion through the fair halls, <milestone ed="p" n="110" unit="line"/> and wine drawn to waste, and men devouring my bread all heedlessly, without limit, with no end to the business.

<s xml:id="sent2189862" n="16.112">And wise Telemachus answered him:

<s xml:id="sent2189864" n="16.114-16.116">Neither do the people at large bear me any grudge or hatred, <milestone ed="p" n="115" unit="line"/> nor have I cause to blame brothers, in whose fighting a man trusts, even if a great strife arise.

<s xml:id="sent2189865" n="16.117">For in <corr n="this wise">this way</corr> has the son of Cronos made our house to run in but a single line.

<s xml:id="sent2189866" n="16.118-16.119">As his only son did Arceisius beget Laertes, as his only son again did his father beget Odysseus,</s>

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189911" n="16.186">Then the much-enduring, <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus answered him:

<s xml:id="sent2189937" n="16.229-16.231">And they brought me as I slept in a swift ship over the sea, <milestone ed="p" n="230" unit="line"/> and set me down in <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName>, and gave me glorious gifts, stores of bronze and gold and woven raiment.

<s xml:id="sent2189940" n="16.235-16.236"><milestone ed="p" n="235" unit="line"/>Come now, count me the wooers, and tell their tale, that I may know how many they are and what manner of men,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189941" n="16.237-16.239">and that I may ponder in my noble heart and decide whether we two shall be able to maintain our cause against them alone without others, or whether we shall also seek out others.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2189942" n="16.240"><milestone ed="p" n="240" unit="line"/>Then wise Telemachus answered him: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189943" n="16.241-16.242">Father, of a truth I have ever heard of <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> great fame, that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wast:simpsub">were</mod> a warrior in strength of hand and in wise counsel,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189944" n="16.243">but this <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='sayest'>say</mod> is too great;</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189946" n="16.243-16.244">It could not be that two men should fight against many men and mighty.

<s xml:id="sent2189947" n="16.245-16.246"><milestone ed="p" n="245" unit="line"/>For of the wooers there are not ten alone, or twice ten, but full many more. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189948" n="16.246">Here as we are <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> straightway learn their number. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189949" n="16.247-16.248">From Dulichium there are two and fifty chosen youths, and six serving men attend them;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189950" n="16.249-16.253">from Same came four and twenty men; <milestone ed="p" n="250" unit="line"/> from <placeName key="tgn,7011374">Zacynthus</placeName> there are twenty youths of the Achaeans; and from <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName> itself twelve men, all of them the noblest, and with them is Medon, the herald, and the divine minstrel, and two squires skilled in carving meats. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189951" n="16.254-16.255">If we shall meet all these within the halls, <milestone ed="p" n="255" unit="line"/> bitter, I fear, and with bane will be <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> coming to avenge violence.

<s xml:id="sent2189952" n="16.256-16.257"><sic>Nay</sic>, do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> consider, if <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> canst <sic>bethink</sic> <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> of any helper—one that would aid us two with a ready heart.

<s xml:id="sent2189953" n="16.258">Then the much-enduring, <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus answered him:

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189954" n="16.259">Well, then, I will tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, and do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> give heed and <mod n="hearken:simpsub">listen</mod> to my words,

</s>


<s xml:id="sent2189955" n="16.260-16.261"><milestone ed="p" n="260" unit="line"/> and consider whether for us two Athena, with father Zeus, will be enough, or whether I shall <sic>bethink</sic> me of some other helper.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2189956" n="16.262">Then wise Telemachus answered him:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189957" n="16.263-16.264">Good, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='mayest'>may</mod> be sure, are these two helpers whom <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> mention, though high in the clouds do they <mod n="abide:simpsub">remain</mod>,</s>


<s xml:id="sent2189958" n="16.264-16.265">and they <milestone ed="p" n="265" unit="line"/> rule over all men alike and the immortal gods.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:16.266-16.307">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189959" n="16.266">Then the much-enduring, <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus answered:
</s>
<q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2189960" n="16.267-16.269">Not long <corr n="of a surety">surely</corr> will those two hold aloof from the mighty fray, when between the wooers and us in my halls the might of Ares is put to the test.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189961" n="16.270-16.271"><milestone ed="p" n="270" unit="line"/>But for the present, do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> go at daybreak to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> house and join the company of the haughty wooers. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189962" n="16.272-16.273">As for me, the swineherd will lead me later on to the city in the likeness of a woeful and aged beggar. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189963" n="16.274-16.277">And if they shall put despite on me in the house, <milestone ed="p" n="275" unit="line"/> let the heart in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> breast endure while I am evil entreated, even if they drag me by the feet through the house to the door, or hurl at me and <mod n="smite:simpsub">strike</mod> me;</s>

<s xml:id="sent2189965" n="16.278-16.279">Thou <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> indeed <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> them cease their folly, seeking to dissuade them with gentle words;

<s xml:id="sent2189966" n="16.279-16.280">yet in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> <milestone ed="p" n="280" unit="line"/> will they <mod n="hearken:simpsub">listen</mod> to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2189968" n="16.281">And another thing will I tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, and do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> lay it to heart.

<s xml:id="sent2189969" n="16.282-16.286">When Athena, rich in counsel, shall put it in my mind, I will nod to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> with my head; and do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> thereupon, when <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> notest it, take all the weapons of war that lie in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> halls, <milestone ed="p" n="285" unit="line"/> and lay them away one and all in the secret place of the lofty store-room.

<s xml:id="sent2189970" n="16.286-16.287">And as for the wooers, when they miss the arms and question <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> beguile them with gentle words, saying:</s></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189971" n="16.288-16.290">Out of the smoke have I laid them,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> since they are no longer like those which of old Odysseus left behind him when he went forth to <placeName key="perseus,Troy">Troy</placeName>, <milestone ed="p" n="290" unit="line"/> but are all befouled so far as the breath of the fire has reached them. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189972" n="16.291-16.294">And furthermore this greater fear has the son of Cronos put in my heart, lest <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod>, when heated with wine, you may set a quarrel afoot among you and wound one another, and so bring shame on your feast and on your wooing. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189973" n="16.294">For of itself does the iron draw a man to it.</s></p>
<milestone ed="p" n="295" unit="line"/>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189974" n="16.295-16.297">But for us two alone do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> leave behind two swords and two spears, and two ox-hide shields for us to grasp, that we may rush upon them and seize them;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189975" n="16.297-16.298">while as for the wooers, Pallas Athena and Zeus, the counsellor, will beguile them. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189976" n="16.299">And another thing will I tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, and do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> lay it to heart.

<s xml:id="sent2189977" n="16.300-16.304"><milestone ed="p" n="300" unit="line"/>If in truth <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> my son and of our blood, then let no one hear that Odysseus is at home; neither let Laertes know it, nor the swineherd, nor any of the household, nor Penelope herself; but by ourselves <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> and I will learn the temper of the women.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189978" n="16.305-16.307"><milestone ed="p" n="305" unit="line"/>Aye, and we will likewise make trial of many a one of the serving men, and see where any of them honours us two and fears us at heart, and who recks not of us and scorns <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, a man so goodly.</s></p></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:16.308-16.350">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189979" n="16.308-16.310">Then his glorious son answered him, and said: Father, my spirit, methinks, <milestone ed="p" n="310" unit="line"/> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> come to know hereafter,</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189980" n="16.310">for no slackness of will possesses me. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189981" n="16.311-16.312">But I think not that this plan will be a gain to us both, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2189982" n="16.312">and so I <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> take thought. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189983" n="16.313-16.314">Long time <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> vainly go about, making trial of each man as <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> visitest the farms,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2189985" n="16.316-16.317">Yet <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod>, as for the women, I do <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> learn who among them dishonor <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, and who are guiltless. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189986" n="16.318-16.320">But of the men in the farmsteads I would not that we should make trial, but that we should deal therewith hereafter, <milestone ed="p" n="320" unit="line"/> if in very truth <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='knowest'>know</mod> some sign from Zeus who bears the aegis.</s></q></p>


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189987" n="16.321-16.323">Thus they spoke to one another, but meanwhile into <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName> put the well-built ship that brought Telemachus and all his comrades from <placeName key="perseus,Pylos">Pylos</placeName>;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189988" n="16.324-16.327">and they, when they had come into the deep harbor, <milestone ed="p" n="325" unit="line"/> drew the black ship up on the shore, while proud squires bore forth their armour and straightway carried the beauteous gifts to the house of Clytius. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189989" n="16.328-16.334">But they sent a herald forth to the house of Odysseus to bear word to wise Penelope <milestone ed="p" n="330" unit="line"/> that Telemachus was at the farm, and had bidden the ship to sail on to the city, lest the noble queen might grow anxious and let round tears fall. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2189990" n="16.335-16.336"><milestone ed="p" n="335" unit="line"/>And when they reached the palace of the godlike king, the herald spoke out in the midst of the handmaids, and said: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2189991" n="16.337">Even now, queen, <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> son has come back from <placeName key="perseus,Pylos">Pylos</placeName>.</s></q></p>


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189992" n="16.338-16.339">But the swineherd came close to Penelope and told her all that her dear son had bidden him say.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189993" n="16.340-16.341"><milestone ed="p" n="340" unit="line"/>And when he had fully told all that had been commanded him, he went his way to the swine and left the courtyard and the hall.</s></p>


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189994" n="16.342-16.344">But the wooers were dismayed and downcast in spirit, and forth they went from the hall past the great wall of the court, and there before the gates they sat down.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189995" n="16.345"><milestone ed="p" n="345" unit="line"/>Then among them Eurymachus, son of Polybus, was the first to speak:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2189996" n="16.346-16.347">My friends, <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> a great deed has been insolently brought to pass by Telemachus, even this journey,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189997" n="16.347">and we <mod n="deemed:simpsub">thought</mod> that he would never see it accomplished. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2189998" n="16.348-16.350">But come, let us launch a black ship, the best we have, and let us get together seamen as rowers that they may straightway <milestone ed="p" n="350" unit="line"/> bear tidings to those others speedily to return home.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:16.351-16.392">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2189999" n="16.351-16.353">Not yet was the word fully uttered when Amphinomus, turning in his place, saw a ship in the deep harbor and men furling the sail, and with oars in their hands.

<s xml:id="sent2190000" n="16.354">Then, breaking into a merry laugh, he spoke among his comrades:
<milestone ed="p" n="355" unit="line"/>

<s xml:id="sent2190001" n="16.355">Let us not be sending a message any more,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190002" n="16.355">for here they are at home. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190003" n="16.356-16.357">Either some god told them of this, or they themselves caught sight of the ship of Telemachus as she sailed by, but could not catch her.

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2190004" n="16.358-16.360">So he spoke, and they rose up and went to the shore of the sea. Swiftly the men drew up the black ship on the shore, <milestone ed="p" n="360" unit="line"/> and proud squires bore forth their armour.

<s xml:id="sent2190005" n="16.361-16.362">Themselves meanwhile went all together to the place of assembly, and none other would they suffer to sit with them, either of the young men or the old.

<s xml:id="sent2190006" n="16.363">Then among them spoke Antinous, son of Eupeithes:

<s xml:id="sent2190007" n="16.364"><sic>Lo</sic>, now, see how the gods have delivered this man from destruction.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190008" n="16.365-16.366"><milestone ed="p" n="365" unit="line"/>Day by day watchmen sat upon the windy heights, watch ever following watch,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190009" n="16.366-16.370">and at set of sun we never spent a night upon the shore, but sailing over the deep in our swift ship we waited for the bright Dawn, lying in wait for Telemachus, that we might take him and <mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod> <milestone ed="p" n="370" unit="line"/> the man himself;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190010" n="16.370-16.372"><mod n="howbeit:simpsub">however</mod> meanwhile some god has brought him home. But, on our part, let us here devise for him a woeful death, even for Telemachus, and let him not escape <corr n="from out">out of</corr> our hands,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190011" n="16.372-16.373">for I <mod n="deem:simpsub">think</mod> that while he lives this work of ours will not prosper. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190012" n="16.374-16.375">For he is himself shrewd in counsel and in wisdom, <milestone ed="p" n="375" unit="line"/> and the people <mod n="nowise:simpsub">in no way</mod> show us favour any more. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190013" n="16.376-16.379"><sic>Nay</sic>, come, before he gathers the Achaeans to the place of assembly—for methinks he will in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> be slow to act, but will be full of wrath, and rising up will declare among them all how that we contrived against him utter destruction, but did not catch him;

<s xml:id="sent2190014" n="16.380"><milestone ed="p" n="380" unit="line"/> and they will not praise us when they hear of our evil deeds. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190015" n="16.381-16.382">Beware, then, lest they work us some harm and drive us out from our country, and we come to the land of strangers. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190016" n="16.383-16.384"><sic>Nay</sic>, let us act first, and seize him in the field far from the city, or on the road;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190017" n="16.384-16.386">and his substance let us ourselves keep, and his wealth, <milestone ed="p" n="385" unit="line"/> dividing them fairly among us; though the house we would give to his mother to possess, and to him who weds her. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190018" n="16.387-16.391"><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod> if this plan does not please you, but you choose rather that he should live and keep all the wealth of his fathers, let us not continue to devour his store of pleasant things <milestone ed="p" n="390" unit="line"/> as we gather together here, but let each man from his own hall woo her with his gifts and seek to win her;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190019" n="16.391-16.392">and she then would wed him who offers most, and who comes as her fated lord.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:16.393-16.433">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2190020" n="16.393">So he spoke, and they were all hushed in silence.

<s xml:id="sent2190024" n="16.400-16.401"><milestone ed="p" n="400" unit="line"/>Friends, I surely would not choose to kill Telemachus;

<s xml:id="sent2190028" n="16.405"><milestone ed="p" n="405" unit="line"/> but if the gods turn us from the act, I <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> you desist.

<s xml:id="sent2190030" n="16.407-16.408">So they arose straightway and went to the house of Odysseus, and entering in, sat down on the polished seats.

<s xml:id="sent2190031" n="16.409-16.410">Then the wise Penelope took other counsel, <milestone ed="p" n="410" unit="line"/> to show herself to the wooers, overweening in their insolence.

<s xml:id="sent2190035" n="16.414-16.417">But when the fair lady reached the wooers, <milestone ed="p" n="415" unit="line"/> she stood by the doorpost of the well-built hall, holding before her face her shining veil; and she rebuked Antinous, and spoke, and addressed him:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190036" n="16.418-16.420">Antinous, full of insolence, deviser of evil! and yet it is <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod>, men say, that <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> excel among all of <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> years in the land of <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName>

<s xml:id="sent2190038" n="16.421-16.423">Madman! why <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> devise death and fate for Telemachus, and <mod n='carest'>care</mod> not for suppliants, for whom Zeus is witness.</s>

<s xml:id="sent2190040" n="16.424-16.425">Dost <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> not know of the time when <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> father came to this house a fugitive <milestone ed="p" n="425" unit="line"/> in terror of the people?

<s xml:id="sent2190041" n="16.425-16.427">For of a truth they were greatly <mod n="wroth:simpsub">angry</mod> with him because he had joined Taphian pirates and harried the Thesprotians,</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190043" n="16.428-16.429">Him, then, they were minded to <mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod>, and take from him his life by violence, and utterly to devour his great and pleasant livelihood;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190044" n="16.430"><milestone ed="p" n="430" unit="line"/> but Odysseus held them back, and stayed them despite their eagerness. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190045" n="16.431-16.432">His house it is that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> consumest now without atonement, and wooest his wife, and <mod n='seekest'>seek</mod> to <mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod> his son, and on me <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='bringest'>bring</mod> great distress.

<s xml:id="sent2190046" n="16.433"><sic>Nay</sic>, forbear, I charge <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, and <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> the rest forbear.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:16.434-16.481">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2190047" n="16.434">Then Eurymachus, son of Polybus, answered her:




</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190048" n="16.435-16.436"><milestone ed="p" n="435" unit="line"/>Daughter of Icarius, wise Penelope, be of good cheer,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190049" n="16.436">and let not things distress <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> heart. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190050" n="16.437-16.439">That man lives not, nor shall live, nor shall ever be born, who shall lay hands upon <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> son Telemachus while I live and behold the light upon the earth.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190051" n="16.440"><milestone ed="p" n="440" unit="line"/>For thus will I speak out to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, and <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> it shall be brought to pass. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190052" n="16.441-16.444">Quickly shall that man's black blood flow forth about my spear; for of a truth me, too, did Odysseus the sacker of cities often set upon his knees, and put roast meat in my hands, and hold to my lips red wine.

<s xml:id="sent2190053" n="16.445-16.447"><milestone ed="p" n="445" unit="line"/>Therefore Telemachus is far the dearest of all men to me, and I <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> him have no fear of death, at least from the wooers;</s>


<s xml:id="sent2190054" n="16.447">but from the gods can no man avoid it.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2190055" n="16.448">Thus he spoke to cheer her, but against that son he was himself plotting death. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190056" n="16.449-16.451">So she went up to her bright upper chamber <milestone ed="p" n="450" unit="line"/> and then bewailed Odysseus, her dear husband, until flashing-eyed Athena cast sweet sleep upon her eyelids.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190057" n="16.452-16.453">But at evening the goodly swineherd came back to Odysseus and his son,


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190058" n="16.453-16.454">and they were busily making ready their supper, and had slain a boar of a year old. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190059" n="16.454-16.459">Then Athena <milestone ed="p" n="455" unit="line"/> came close to Odysseus, son of Laertes, and <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> him with her wand, and again made him an old man; and mean raiment she put about his body, lest the swineherd might look upon him and know him, and might go to bear tidings to constant Penelope, and not hold the secret fast in his heart.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190060" n="16.460"><milestone ed="p" n="460" unit="line"/>Now Telemachus spoke first to the swineherd, and said: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190061" n="16.461">Thou <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> come, <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Eumaeus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190062" n="16.461">What news is there in the city? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190063" n="16.462-16.463">Have the proud wooers by this time come home from their ambush, or are they still watching for me where they were, to take me on my homeward way?

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2190064" n="16.464">To him, then, swineherd Eumaeus, <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> make answer and say:




</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190065" n="16.465-16.466"><milestone ed="p" n="465" unit="line"/>I was not minded to go about the city, asking and enquiring of this;</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190067" n="16.468-16.469">But there joined me a swift messenger from <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> companions, a herald, who was the first to tell the news to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> mother.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190068" n="16.470"><milestone ed="p" n="470" unit="line"/>And this further thing I know,</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190070" n="16.471-16.473">I was now above the city, as I went on my way, where the hill of Hermes is, when I saw a swift ship putting into our harbor,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190071" n="16.473-16.474">and there were many men in her, and she was <sic>laden</sic> with shields and double-pointed spears.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190072" n="16.475"><milestone ed="p" n="475" unit="line"/>And I thought it was they, but I have no knowledge.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2190073" n="16.476-16.477">So he spoke, and the strong and mighty Telemachus smiled and with his eyes he glanced at his father, but shunned the swineherd's eye.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190074" n="16.478-16.479">And when they had ceased from their labour and had made ready the meal, they fell to feasting, nor did their hearts lack <mod n="aught:simpsub">anything</mod> of the equal feast.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190075" n="16.480-16.481"><milestone ed="p" n="480" unit="line"/>But when they had put from them the desire of food and drink, they bethought them of rest, and took the gift of sleep.</s></p>

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2190076" n="17.1-17.5"><milestone ed="p" n="1" unit="line"/>As soon as early Dawn appeared, the rosy-fingered, Telemachus, the dear son of divine Odysseus, bound beneath his feet his fair sandals and took his mighty spear, that fitted his grasp, <milestone ed="p" n="5" unit="line"/> hasting to the city; and he spoke to his swineherd, saying:

<s xml:id="sent2190077" n="17.6-17.7">Father, I <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> am going to the city, that my mother may see me,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190078" n="17.7-17.9">for, methinks, she will not cease from woeful wailing and tearful lamentation until she sees my very self. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190079" n="17.9">But to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> I give this charge.

<s xml:id="sent2190082" n="17.12-17.13">For my part, I can in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> burden myself with all men, seeing that I have grief at heart.

<s xml:id="sent2190083" n="17.14-17.15">But if the stranger is <sic>sore</sic> angered at this, <milestone ed="p" n="15" unit="line"/> it will be the worse for him.

<s xml:id="sent2190085" n="17.16">Then Odysseus of many wiles answered him, and said:

<s xml:id="sent2190089" n="17.20-17.21"><milestone ed="p" n="20" unit="line"/>For I am no more of an age to remain at the farmstead, so as to obey in all things the command of an overseer.

<s xml:id="sent2190090" n="17.22"><sic>Nay</sic>, go <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> way;

<s xml:id="sent2190091" n="17.22-17.23">this man that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='biddest'>command</mod> will lead me as soon as I have warmed myself at the fire, and the sun has grown hot. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190092" n="17.24">For miserably poor are these garments which I wear,

<s xml:id="sent2190093" n="17.24-17.25">and I fear lest <milestone ed="p" n="25" unit="line"/> the morning frost may overcome me;</s>

<s xml:id="sent2190095" n="17.26-17.27">So he spoke, and Telemachus passed out through the farmstead with rapid strides, and was sowing the seeds of evil for the wooers.

<s xml:id="sent2190096" n="17.28-17.30">But when he came to the stately house he set his spear in place, leaning it against a tall pillar, <milestone ed="p" n="30" unit="line"/> and himself went in and crossed the threshold of stone.

<s xml:id="sent2190099" n="17.36-17.40">Then forth from her chamber came wise Penelope, <corr n="like unto">like</corr> Artemis or golden Aphrodite, and bursting into tears she flung her arms about her dear son, and kissed his head and both his beautiful eyes; <milestone ed="p" n="40" unit="line"/> and with wailing she spoke to him winged words:

<s xml:id="sent2190105" n="17.48-17.51"><sic>Nay</sic>, bathe <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod>, and take clean raiment for <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> body, and then, going to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> upper chamber with <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> handmaids, <milestone ed="p" n="50" unit="line"/> vow to all the gods that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wilt:simpsub">will</mod> offer hecatombs that bring fulfillment, in the hope that Zeus may some day bring deeds of requital to pass.

<s xml:id="sent2190106" n="17.52-17.53">But I will go to the place of assembly that I may <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> to our house a stranger who followed me from Pylos on my way <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod>.

<s xml:id="sent2190109" n="17.58-17.60">Then she bathed and took clean raiment for her body, and vowed to all the gods that she would offer hecatombs <milestone ed="p" n="60" unit="line"/> that bring fulfillment, in the hope that Zeus would some day bring deeds of requital to pass.

<s xml:id="sent2190110" n="17.61-17.62">But Telemachus thereafter went forth through the hall with his spear in his hand,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2190114" n="17.65-17.66"><milestone ed="p" n="65" unit="line"/>Round about him the proud wooers thronged, speaking him fair, but pondering evil in the deep of their hearts.

<s xml:id="sent2190115" n="17.67-17.70"><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod> he avoided the great throng of these men, but where Mentor sat, and Antiphus, and Halitherses, who were friends of his father's house of old, <milestone ed="p" n="70" unit="line"/> there he went and sat down,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2190143" n="17.120-17.121"><milestone ed="p" n="120" unit="line"/>And straightway Menelaus, good at the war-cry, asked me in quest of what I had come to goodly <placeName key="tgn,7011065">Lacedaemon</placeName>;

<s xml:id="sent2190147" n="17.126-17.131">Even as when in the thicket-lair of a mighty lion a hind has laid to sleep her new-born suckling fawns, and roams over the mountain slopes and grassy vales seeking pasture, and then the lion comes to his lair <milestone ed="p" n="130" unit="line"/> and upon the two lets loose a cruel doom, so will Odysseus let loose a cruel doom upon these men. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190148" n="17.132-17.136">I would, O father Zeus, and Athena, and Apollo, that in such strength, as when once in fair-stablished <placeName key="tgn,7002672">Lesbos</placeName> he rose up and wrestled a match with Philomeleides <milestone ed="p" n="135" unit="line"/> and threw him mightily, and all the Achaeans rejoiced, even in such strength Odysseus might come among the wooers; </s>

<s xml:id="sent2190150" n="17.138-17.141">But in this matter of which <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> ask and entreat me, <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> I will not swerve aside to speak of other things, nor will I deceive <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>; <milestone ed="p" n="140" unit="line"/> but of all that the unerring old man of the sea told me, not one thing will I hide from <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> or conceal.

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2190156" n="17.150"><milestone ed="p" n="150" unit="line"/>So he spoke, and stirred the heart in her breast.

<s xml:id="sent2190158" n="17.152-17.153">Honored wife of Odysseus, son of Laertes, he truly has no clear understanding; but do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hearken:simpsub">listen</mod> to my words,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2190160" n="17.155-17.159"><milestone ed="p" n="155" unit="line"/>Be my witness Zeus above all gods, and this hospitable board and the hearth of noble Odysseus to which I am come, that <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> Odysseus is even now in his native land, resting or moving, learning of these evil deeds, and he is sowing the seeds of evil for all the wooers.

<s xml:id="sent2190161" n="17.160-17.161"><milestone ed="p" n="160" unit="line"/>So plain a bird of omen did I mark as I sat on the benched ship, and I declared it to Telemachus.</s></q></p>

<s xml:id="sent2190162" n="17.162">Then wise Penelope answered him:

<s xml:id="sent2190163" n="17.163">Ah, stranger, I would that this word of <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> might be fulfilled.

<s xml:id="sent2190164" n="17.164-17.165">Then <mod n='shouldest'>should</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> straightway know of kindness and many a gift <milestone ed="p" n="165" unit="line"/> from me, so that one who met <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> would call the blessed.</s></q></p>

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2190165" n="17.166-17.169">Thus they spoke to one another. And the wooers meanwhile in front of the palace of Odysseus were making merry, throwing the discus and the javelin in a levelled place, as their <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> was, in insolence of heart.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190166" n="17.170-17.172"><milestone ed="p" n="170" unit="line"/>But when it was the hour for dinner, and the flocks came in from all sides from the fields, and the men led them who were <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to lead, then Medon,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190167" n="17.172-17.173">who of all the heralds was most to their liking and was ever present at their feasts, spoke to them, saying:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190168" n="17.174-17.175">Youths, now that you have all made glad your hearts with sport, <milestone ed="p" n="175" unit="line"/> come to the house that we may make ready a feast;</s>


<s xml:id="sent2190169" n="17.176">for it is no bad thing to take one's dinner in season.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2190170" n="17.177">So he spoke, and they rose up and went, and <mod n="hearkened:simpsub">listened</mod> to his word. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190171" n="17.178-17.182">And when they had come to the stately house they laid their cloaks on the chairs and high seats, <milestone ed="p" n="180" unit="line"/> and men fell to slaying great sheep and fat goats, aye, and fatted and swine, and a heifer of the herd, and so made ready the meal. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190172" n="17.182-17.183">But Odysseus and the goodly swineherd were making haste to go from the field to the city; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2190173" n="17.184">and the swineherd, a leader of men, spoke first, and said:





</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190174" n="17.185-17.187"><milestone ed="p" n="185" unit="line"/>Stranger, since <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> eager to go the city today, as my master bade—though for myself I would rather have <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> left here to keep the farmstead;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190175" n="17.188-17.189">but I reverence and fear him, lest hereafter he chide me, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190176" n="17.189-17.190">and hard are the rebukes of masters— <milestone ed="p" n="190" unit="line"/> come now, let us go. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190177" n="17.190-17.191">The day is far spent, and soon <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wilt:simpsub">will</mod> find it colder toward evening.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2190178" n="17.192">Then Odysseus of many wiles answered him, and said: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190179" n="17.193">I see, I give heed;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190180" n="17.193">this <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='biddest'>command</mod> one with understanding. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190181" n="17.194">Come, let us go, and be <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> my guide all the way.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190182" n="17.195-17.196"><milestone ed="p" n="195" unit="line"/>But give me a staff to lean upon, if <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> one cut anywhere, for <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> said that the way was treacherous.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2190183" n="17.197-17.198">He spoke, and flung about his shoulders his miserable wallet, full of holes,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190184" n="17.198">slung by a twisted cord, 
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190185" n="17.199">and Eumaeus gave him a staff to his liking.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190186" n="17.200-17.201"><milestone ed="p" n="200" unit="line"/>So they two set forth, and the dogs and the herdsmen stayed behind to guard the farmstead;


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190187" n="17.201-17.203">but the swineherd led his master to the city in the likeness of a woeful and aged beggar, leaning on a staff; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2190188" n="17.203">and miserable was the raiment that he wore about his body.</s></p>

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2190189" n="17.204-17.207">But when, as they went along the rugged path, <milestone ed="p" n="205" unit="line"/> they were near the city, and had come to a well-wrought, fair-flowing fountain, <mod n="wherefrom:simpsub">from which</mod> the townsfolk drew water—this Ithacus had made, and Neritus, and Polyctor, </s>

<s xml:id="sent2190191" n="17.210-17.211">and on the top was built an altar to the nymphs where all passers-by made offerings—

,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190192" n="17.212-17.214">there Melantheus, son of Dolius, met them as he was driving his she-goats, the best that were in all the herds, to make a feast for the wooers;,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2190194" n="17.215-17.216"><milestone ed="p" n="215" unit="line"/>As he saw them, he spoke and addressed them, and reviled them in terrible and unseemly words,

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190196" n="17.217-17.218"><sic>Lo</sic>, now, in very truth the vile leads the vile. As ever, the god is bringing like and like together. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190197" n="17.219-17.220"><mod n="Whither:simpsub">Where</mod>, pray, <corr n="art thou">are you</corr> leading this filthy wretch,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> miserable swineherd, <milestone ed="p" n="220" unit="line"/> this nuisance of a beggar to mar our feasts? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190198" n="17.221-17.222">He is a man to stand and rub his shoulders on many doorposts, begging for scraps, not for swords or cauldrons.<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">2</note>
