<s xml:id="sent2190199" n="17.223-17.225">If <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='wouldest'>would</mod> give me this fellow to keep my farmstead, to sweep out the pens and to carry young shoots to the kids, <milestone ed="p" n="225" unit="line"/> then by drinking whey he might get himself a sturdy thigh. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190200" n="17.226-17.228">But since he has learned only deeds of evil, he will not care to busy himself with work, but is minded rather to go skulking through the land, that by begging he may feed his insatiate belly. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190201" n="17.229">But I will speak out to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, and this word shall <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> be brought to pass.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190202" n="17.230-17.232"><milestone ed="p" n="230" unit="line"/>If he comes to the palace of divine Odysseus, many a footstool, hurled about his head by the hands of those that are men, shall be broken on his ribs<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> as he is pelted through the house.

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2190203" n="17.233-17.234">So he spoke, and as he passed he kicked Odysseus on the hip in his folly,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190204" n="17.234-17.235">yet he did not drive him from the path, <milestone ed="p" n="235" unit="line"/> but he stood steadfast. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190205" n="17.235-17.237">And Odysseus pondered whether he should leap upon him and take his life with his staff, or seize him round about,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">2</note> and lift him up, and dash his head upon the ground.

<s xml:id="sent2190206" n="17.238">Yet he endured, and stayed him from his purpose. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190207" n="17.238-17.239">And the swineherd looked the man in the face, and rebuked him, and lifted up his hands, and prayed aloud:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190208" n="17.240-17.243"><milestone ed="p" n="240" unit="line"/>Nymphs of the fountain, daughters of Zeus, if ever Odysseus burned upon your altars pieces of the thighs of lambs or kids, wrapped in rich fat, fulfil for me this prayer; grant that he, my master, may come back, and that some god may guide him. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190209" n="17.244-17.246">Then would he scatter all the proud airs <milestone ed="p" n="245" unit="line"/> which now <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> puttest on in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> insolence,ever roaming about the city, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190210" n="17.246">while evil herdsmen destroy the flock.</s></q></p>

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2190211" n="17.247">Then Melanthius, the goatherd, answered him: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190212" n="17.248-17.250"><sic>Lo</sic> now, how the cur talks, his mind full of mischief. Him will I some day <milestone ed="p" n="250" unit="line"/> take on a black, benched ship far from <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName>, that he may bring me in much wealth.

<s xml:id="sent2190213" n="17.251-17.253">Would that Apollo, of the silver bow, might <mod n="smite:simpsub">strike</mod> Telemachus to-day in the halls, or that he might be slain by the wooers, as surely as for Odysseus in a far land the day of return has been lost.

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2190214" n="17.254-17.255">So saying, he left them there, as they walked slowly on, <milestone ed="p" n="255" unit="line"/> but himself strode forward and right swiftly came to the palace of the king.

<s xml:id="sent2190217" n="17.258-17.260">Then by him those that served set a portion of meat, and the grave housewife brought and set before him bread, <milestone ed="p" n="260" unit="line"/> for him to eat. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190218" n="17.260-17.262">And Odysseus and the goodly swineherd halted as they drew <mod n="nigh:simpsub">near</mod>, and about them rang the sound of the hollow lyre,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2190220" n="17.263">Then Odysseus clasped the swineherd by the hand, and said:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190221" n="17.264-17.265">Eumaeus, surely this is the beautiful house of Odysseus. <milestone ed="p" n="265" unit="line"/>Easily might it be known, though seen among many. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190222" n="17.266-17.268">There is building upon building, and the court is built with wall and coping, and the double gates are well-fenced;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190223" n="17.268">no man may scorn it. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190224" n="17.269-17.271">And I mark that in the house itself many <milestone ed="p" n="270" unit="line"/> men are feasting: for the savour of meat arises from it, and therewith resounds the voice of the lyre, which the gods have made the companion of the feast.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2190225" n="17.272">To him then, swineherd Eumaeus, <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> make answer, and say:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190226" n="17.273">Easily <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> marked it, for in all things <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> ready of wit. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190227" n="17.274">But come, let us take thought how these things shall be.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190228" n="17.275-17.276"><milestone ed="p" n="275" unit="line"/>Either do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> go first into the stately palace, and enter the company of the wooers, and I will remain behind here,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2190230" n="17.278-17.279">But do not <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> linger long, lest some man see <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> without and pelt <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> or <mod n="smite:simpsub">strike</mod> <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>.

<s xml:id="sent2190232" n="17.280"><milestone ed="p" n="280" unit="line"/>Then the much-enduring, <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus answered him:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190233" n="17.281">I see, I give heed: </s>



<s xml:id="sent2190234" n="17.281">this <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='biddest'>command</mod> one with understanding. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190235" n="17.282">But go <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> before, and I will remain behind here;

<s xml:id="sent2190237" n="17.284-17.285">Staunch is my heart, for much evil have I suffered <milestone ed="p" n="285" unit="line"/> <mod n="amid:simpsub">among</mod> the waves and in war;</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190239" n="17.286-17.289">But a ravening belly may no man hide, an accursed plague that brings many evils upon men. Because of it are the benched ships also made ready, that bear evil to foemen over the unresting sea.</s></q></p>

<s xml:id="sent2190241" n="17.291-17.294">And a hound that lay there raised his head and pricked up his ears, <placeName key="perseus,Argos">Argos</placeName>, the hound of Odysseus, of the steadfast heart, whom of old he had himself bred, but had no joy of him, for <mod n="ere:simpsub">before</mod> that he went to sacred <placeName key="tgn,7002329">Ilios</placeName>.

<s xml:id="sent2190243" n="17.296-17.299">but now he lay neglected, his master gone, in the deep dung of mules and cattle, which lay in heaps before the doors, till the slaves of Odysseus should take it away to dung his wide lands.

<s xml:id="sent2190244" n="17.300"><milestone ed="p" n="300" unit="line"/>There lay the hound <placeName key="perseus,Argos">Argos</placeName>, full of vermin; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190245" n="17.301-17.304">yet even now, when he marked Odysseus standing near, he wagged his tail and dropped both his ears, but nearer to his master he had no longer strength to move.

<s xml:id="sent2190246" n="17.304-17.305">Then Odysseus looked aside and wiped away a tear, <milestone ed="p" n="305" unit="line"/> easily hiding from Eumaeus what he did; and straightway he questioned him, and said:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190247" n="17.306">Eumaeus, <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> it is strange that this hound lies here in the dung.

<s xml:id="sent2190248" n="17.307-17.310">He is fine of form, but I do not clearly know whether he has speed of foot to match this beauty or whether he is merely as table-dogs <milestone ed="p" n="310" unit="line"/> are,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190249" n="17.310">which their masters keep for show.

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2190250" n="17.311">To him then, swineherd Eumaeus, <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> make answer and say: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190251" n="17.312">Aye, <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> this is the hound of a man that has died in a far land. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190252" n="17.313-17.315">If he were but in form and in action such as he was when Odysseus left him and went to <placeName key="perseus,Troy">Troy</placeName>, <milestone ed="p" n="315" unit="line"/> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='wouldest'>would</mod> soon be amazed at seeing his speed and his strength.

<s xml:id="sent2190253" n="17.316-17.317">No creature that he started in the depths of the thick wood could escape him,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190254" n="17.317">and in tracking too he was keen of scent. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190255" n="17.318-17.319">But now he is in evil plight, and his master has perished far from his native land, and the heedless women give him no care.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190256" n="17.320-17.321"><milestone ed="p" n="320" unit="line"/>Slaves, when their masters lose their power, are no longer minded thereafter to do honest service: 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190257" n="17.322-17.323">for Zeus, whose voice is borne afar, takes away half his worth from a man, when the day of slavery comes upon him.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2190258" n="17.324-17.325">So saying, he entered the stately house <milestone ed="p" n="325" unit="line"/> and went straight to the hall to join the company of the lordly wooers. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190259" n="17.326-17.327">But as for <placeName key="perseus,Argos">Argos</placeName>, the fate of black death seized him straightway when he had seen Odysseus in the twentieth year.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190260" n="17.328-17.330">Now as the swineherd came through the hall godlike Telemachus was far the first to see him, and quickly <milestone ed="p" n="330" unit="line"/> with a nod he called him and to his side. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190261" n="17.330-17.332">And Eumaeus looked about him and took a stool that lay near, on which the carver was <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to sit when carving for the wooers the many joints of meat, as they feasted in the hall. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190262" n="17.333-17.334">This he took and placed at the table of Telemachus, over against him, and there sat down himself. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190263" n="17.334-17.335">And a herald <milestone ed="p" n="335" unit="line"/> took a portion of meat and set it before him, and bread <corr n="from out">out of</corr> the basket.</s></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:17.336-17.379">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2190264" n="17.336-17.338">Night after him Odysseus entered the palace in the likeness of a woeful and aged beggar, leaning on a staff,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190265" n="17.338">and miserable was the raiment that he wore about his body. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190266" n="17.339-17.341">He sat down upon the ashen threshold within the doorway, <milestone ed="p" n="340" unit="line"/> leaning against a post of cypress wood, which of old a carpenter had skilfully planed, and made straight to the line. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190267" n="17.342-17.344">Then Telemachus called the swineherd to him, and, taking a whole loaf <corr n="from out">out of</corr> the beautiful basket, and all the meat his hands could hold in their grasp, spoke to him saying:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190268" n="17.345-17.346"><milestone ed="p" n="345" unit="line"/>Take, and give this mess to <sic>yon</sic> stranger, and <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> him go about himself and beg of the wooers one and all. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190269" n="17.347">Shame is no good comrade for a man that is in need.

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2190270" n="17.348-17.349">So he spoke, and the swineherd went, when he had heard this saying, and coming up to Odysseus spoke to him winged words:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190271" n="17.350-17.351"><milestone ed="p" n="350" unit="line"/>Stranger, Telemachus gives <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> these, and <mod n="bids:simpsub">commands</mod> <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> go about and beg of the wooers one and all. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190272" n="17.352">Shame, he says, is no good thing in a beggar man.

<s xml:id="sent2190273" n="17.353">Then Odysseus of many wiles answered him, and said, 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190274" n="17.354-17.355">King Zeus, grant, I pray <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, that Telemachus may be blest among men, <milestone ed="p" n="355" unit="line"/> and may have all that his heart desires.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2190275" n="17.356-17.358">He spoke, and took the mess in both his hands and set it down there before his feet on his miserable wallet. Then he ate so long as the minstrel sang in the halls. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190276" n="17.359">But when he had dined and the divine minstrel was ceasing to sing,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190277" n="17.360"><milestone ed="p" n="360" unit="line"/> the wooers broke into uproar throughout the halls;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190278" n="17.360-17.363">but Athena drew close to the side of Odysseus, son of Laertes, and roused him to go among the wooers and gather bits of bread, and learn which of them were righteous and which lawless. 

</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190280" n="17.365-17.366"><milestone ed="p" n="365" unit="line"/>So he set out to beg of every man, beginning on the right, stretching out his hand on every side, as though he had been long a beggar. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190281" n="17.367-17.368">And they pitied him and gave, and marvelled at him, asking one another who he was and whence he came.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190282" n="17.369">Then among them spoke Melanthius, the goatherd:




</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190283" n="17.370-17.371"><milestone ed="p" n="370" unit="line"/>Hear me, wooers of the glorious queen, regarding this stranger,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2190406" n="17.553-17.554">Sir stranger, wise Penelope calls for <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, the mother of Telemachus,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2190411" n="17.560"><milestone ed="p" n="560" unit="line"/>Then the much-enduring <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus answered him:

<s xml:id="sent2190429" n="17.583-17.584">And for <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod>, too, it is far more seemly, O queen, to speak to the stranger alone, and to hear his words.

<s xml:id="sent2190445" n="17.602-17.605">So he spoke, and the swineherd sat down again on the polished chair. But when he had satisfied his heart with meat and drink, he went his way to the swine, and left the courts and the hall <milestone ed="p" n="605" unit="line"/> full of banqueters.

<s xml:id="sent2190448" n="18.1-18.3"><milestone ed="p" n="1" unit="line"/>Now there came up a public beggar who was <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to beg through the town of <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName>, and was known for his greedy belly, eating and drinking without end.

<s xml:id="sent2190454" n="18.10"><milestone ed="p" n="10" unit="line"/>Give way, old man, from the doorway, lest soon <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> be even dragged out by the foot.

<s xml:id="sent2190455" n="18.11-18.12">Dost <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> not see that all men are winking at me, and bidding me drag <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>?

<s xml:id="sent2190462" n="18.20-18.22"><milestone ed="p" n="20" unit="line"/>But with <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> fists do not provoke me overmuch, lest <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> anger me, and, old man though I am, I befoul <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> breast and lips with blood.

<s xml:id="sent2190470" n="18.32-18.33">Thus on the polished threshold before the lofty doors they stirred one another's rage right heartily.

<s xml:id="sent2190471" n="18.34-18.35">And the strong and mighty Antinous heard the two, <milestone ed="p" n="35" unit="line"/> and, breaking into a merry laugh, he spoke among the wooers:

<s xml:id="sent2190526" n="18.124">Then Odysseus of many wiles answered him, and said:




</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190527" n="18.125"><milestone ed="p" n="125" unit="line"/>Amphinomus, <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='seemest'>seem</mod> to me to be a man of prudence;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190528" n="18.126-18.127">and such a man, too, was <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> father, for I have heard of his fair fame, that Nisus of Dulichium was a brave man and a wealthy. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190529" n="18.128">From him, they say, <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> sprung, and <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='seemest'>seem</mod> a man soft of speech. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190530" n="18.129"><mod n="Wherefore:simpsub">For which reason</mod> I will tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, and do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> give heed and <mod n="hearken:simpsub">listen</mod>.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190531" n="18.130-18.131"><milestone ed="p" n="130" unit="line"/>Nothing feebler does earth nurture than man, of all things that on earth are breathing and moving. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190532" n="18.132-18.133">For he thinks that he will never suffer evil in time to come, so long as the gods give him prosperity and his knees are quick;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190533" n="18.134-18.135">but when again the blessed gods decree him sorrow, <milestone ed="p" n="135" unit="line"/> this too he bears in <sic>sore</sic> despite with steadfast heart;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190534" n="18.136-18.137">for the spirit of men upon the earth is even such as the day which the father of gods and men brings upon them. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190535" n="18.138-18.140">For I, too, was once like to be prosperous among men, but many deeds of wantonness I <sic>wrought</sic>, yielding to my might and my strength, <milestone ed="p" n="140" unit="line"/> and trusting in my father and my brethren. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190536" n="18.141-18.142"><mod n="Wherefore:simpsub">For which reason</mod> let no man soever be lawless at any time, but let him keep in silence whatever gifts the gods give. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190537" n="18.143-18.146">Aye, for I see the wooers devising wantonness, wasting the wealth and dishonoring the wife <milestone ed="p" n="145" unit="line"/> of a man who, I tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, will not long be away from his friends and his native land;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190538" n="18.146"><sic>nay</sic>, he is very near. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190539" n="18.146-18.148">But may some god lead <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> forth hence to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> home, and <mod n='mayest'>may</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> not meet him when he comes home to his dear native land. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190540" n="18.149-18.150">For not without bloodshed, methinks, <milestone ed="p" n="150" unit="line"/> will the wooers and he part one from the other when once he comes beneath his roof.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2190541" n="18.151-18.152">So he spoke, and pouring a libation, drank of the honey-sweet wine, and then gave back the cup into the hands of the marshaller of the people. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190542" n="18.153-18.154">But Amphinomus went through the hall with a heavy heart, bowing his head;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190543" n="18.154">for his spirit boded bane.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190544" n="18.155"><milestone ed="p" n="155" unit="line"/>Yet even so he did not escape his fate, 
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190545" n="18.155-18.156">but him, too, did Athena set in bonds so that he might be slain outright at the hands of Telemachus and by his spear. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190546" n="18.157">So he sat down again on the chair from which he had risen.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190547" n="18.158-18.162">Then the goddess, flashing-eyed Athena, put it in the heart of the daughter of Icarius, wise Penelope, <milestone ed="p" n="160" unit="line"/> to show herself to the wooers, that she might set their hearts a-flutter and win greater honor from her husband and her son than heretofore. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190548" n="18.163">Then she laughed a meaningless laugh and spoke, and addressed the nurse:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190549" n="18.164-18.165">Eurynome, my heart longs, though it has never longed before, <milestone ed="p" n="165" unit="line"/> to show myself to the wooers, hateful though they are. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190550" n="18.166-18.168">Also I would say a word to my son that will be for his profit, namely, that he should not consort ever with the overweening wooers, who speak him fair but have evil plans thereafter.</s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:18.169-18.205">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2190551" n="18.169">Then the housewife, Eurynome, spoke to her and said: <milestone ed="p" n="170" unit="line"/>


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190552" n="18.170">Aye, <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod>, child, all this <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> spoken aright. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190553" n="18.171-18.172">Go, then, reveal <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> word to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> son and hide it not; but first wash <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> body and anoint <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> face, and go not as <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> with both cheeks stained with tears. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190554" n="18.173-18.174">Go, for it is ill to grieve ever without ceasing.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190555" n="18.175-18.176"><milestone ed="p" n="175" unit="line"/>For now, behold, <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> son is of such an age, and it has been <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> dearest prayer to the immortals to see him a bearded man.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2190556" n="18.177">Then wise Penelope answered her again: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190557" n="18.178-18.179">Eurynome, beguile me not thus in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> love to wash my body and anoint me with oil.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190558" n="18.180-18.181"><milestone ed="p" n="180" unit="line"/>All beauty of mine have the gods, that hold <placeName key="tgn,7011019">Olympus</placeName>, destroyed since the day when my lord departed in the hollow ships. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190559" n="18.182-18.183">But <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> Autonoe and Hippodameia come to me, that they may stand by my side in the hall. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190560" n="18.184">Alone I will not go among men,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190561" n="18.184">for I am ashamed.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2190562" n="18.185-18.186"><milestone ed="p" n="185" unit="line"/>So she spoke, and the old woman went forth through the chamber to bear tidings to the women, and <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> them come.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190563" n="18.187">Then again the goddess, flashing-eyed Athena, took other counsel. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190564" n="18.188-18.190">On the daughter of Icarius she shed sweet sleep, and she leaned back and slept <milestone ed="p" n="190" unit="line"/> there on her couch, and all her joints were relaxed. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190565" n="18.190-18.191">And meanwhile the fair goddess was giving her immortal gifts, that the Achaeans might marvel at her. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190566" n="18.192-18.194">With balm<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> she first made fair her beautiful face, with balm ambrosial, such as that wherewith Cytherea, of the fair crown, anoints herself when she goes into the lovely dance of the Graces;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190567" n="18.195-18.196"><milestone ed="p" n="195" unit="line"/> and she made her taller, too, and statelier to behold, and made her whiter than new-sawn ivory. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190568" n="18.197-18.199">Now when she had done this the fair goddess departed, and the white-armed handmaids came forth from the chamber and drew near with sound of talking. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190569" n="18.199-18.200">Then sweet sleep released Penelope, <milestone ed="p" n="200" unit="line"/> and she rubbed her cheeks with her hands, and said:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190570" n="18.201">Ah, in my utter wretchedness soft slumber enfolded me. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190571" n="18.202-18.205">Would that pure Artemis would even now give so soft a death, that I might no more waste my life away with sorrow at heart, longing for <milestone ed="p" n="205" unit="line"/> the manifold excellence of my dear husband, <corr n="for that">for</corr> he was pre-eminent among the Achaeans.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:18.206-18.249">


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2190574" n="18.208-18.210">Now when the fair lady reached the wooers she stood by the doorpost of the well-built hall, <milestone ed="p" n="210" unit="line"/> holding before her face her shining veil;

</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190576" n="18.212-18.213">Straightway then the knees of the wooers were loosened and their hearts enchanted with love, and they all prayed, each that he might lie by her side. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190577" n="18.214">But she spoke to Telemachus, her dear son:





</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190578" n="18.215"><milestone ed="p" n="215" unit="line"/>Telemachus, <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> mind and <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> thoughts are no longer steadfast as heretofore. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190579" n="18.216">When <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wast:simpsub">were</mod> but a child <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wast:simpsub">were</mod> <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to revolve in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> mind thoughts more cunning;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190580" n="18.217-18.220">but now that <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> grown and <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> reached the bounds of manhood, and <mod n='wouldest'>would</mod> be called a rich man's son by one who looked only to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> stature and <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> comeliness, being himself a stranger from afar, <milestone ed="p" n="220" unit="line"/> <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> mind and <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> thoughts are no longer right as before. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190581" n="18.221-18.222">What a thing is this that has been done in these halls, that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> suffered <sic>yon</sic> stranger to be so maltreated!</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190582" n="18.223-18.224">How now, if the stranger, while sitting thus in our house, should come to some harm through grievous mishandling?

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190583" n="18.225"><milestone ed="p" n="225" unit="line"/>On <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, then, would fall shame and disgrace among men.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2190584" n="18.226">Then wise Telemachus answered her: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190585" n="18.227">My mother, in this matter I take it not ill that <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> filled with anger. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190586" n="18.228-18.229">Yet of myself I know in my heart and understand each thing, the good and the evil, </s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190588" n="18.230"><milestone ed="p" n="230" unit="line"/>But I am not able to plan all things wisely, 


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190589" n="18.231-18.232">for these men here thwart my will, keeping by me, one on this side and one on that, with evil purpose, and I have none to help me. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190590" n="18.233-18.234"><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod>, I can tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, this battle between the stranger and Irus fell not out according to the mind of the wooers, but the stranger proved the better man.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190591" n="18.235-18.242"><milestone ed="p" n="235" unit="line"/>I would, O father Zeus, and Athena, and Apollo, that even now the wooers were thus subdued in our halls, and were hanging their heads, some in the court and some within the hall, and that each man's limbs were loosened, even as Irus now sits <sic>yonder</sic> by the gate of the court, <milestone ed="p" n="240" unit="line"/> hanging his head like a drunken man, and cannot stand erect upon his feet, or go home to whatsoever place he is <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to go, because his limbs are loosened.

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2190592" n="18.243">Thus they spoke to one another. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190593" n="18.244">But Eurymachus addressed Penelope, and said:





</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190594" n="18.245-18.249"><milestone ed="p" n="245" unit="line"/>Daughter of Icarius, wise Penelope, if all the Achaeans throughout Iasian Argos could see <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, even more wooers would be feasting in your halls from to-morrow on, for <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='excellest'>excell</mod> all women in comeliness and stature, and in the wise heart within <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:18.250-18.289">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2190595" n="18.250"><milestone ed="p" n="250" unit="line"/>Then wise Penelope answered him:
</s>
<q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2190596" n="18.251-18.253">Eurymachus, all excellence of mine, both of beauty and of form, the immortals destroyed on the day when the Argives embarked for <placeName key="tgn,7002329">Ilios</placeName>, and with them went my husband Odysseus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190597" n="18.254-18.255">If he might but come and watch over this life of mine, <milestone ed="p" n="255" unit="line"/> greater would be my fame and fairer.

<s xml:id="sent2190598" n="18.256">But now I am in sorrow,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190599" n="18.256">so many woes has some god brought upon me. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190600" n="18.257-18.258"><mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod>, when he went forth and left his native land, he clasped my right hand by the wrist, and said:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2190601" n="18.259-18.260">Wife, I <mod n="deem:simpsub">think</mod> not that the well-greaved Achaeans <milestone ed="p" n="260" unit="line"/> will all return from <placeName key="perseus,Troy">Troy</placeName> safe and unscathed, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190602" n="18.261-18.264">for the Trojans, men say, are men of war, hurlers of the spear, and drawers of the bow, and drivers of swift horses, such as most quickly decide the great strife of equal war.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190603" n="18.265-18.266"><milestone ed="p" n="265" unit="line"/>Therefore I know not whether the god will bring me back, or whether I shall be cut off there in the land of <placeName key="perseus,Troy">Troy</placeName>: so have <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> charge of all things here. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190604" n="18.266">Be mindful of my father 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190605" n="18.267-18.268">and my mother in the halls even as <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> now, or yet more, while I am far away. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190606" n="18.269-18.270">But when <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> see my son a bearded man, <milestone ed="p" n="270" unit="line"/> wed whom <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wilt:simpsub">will</mod>, and leave <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> house.</s></q></p>

<s xml:id="sent2190607" n="18.271">So he spoke,</s>


<s xml:id="sent2190608" n="18.271">and now all this is being brought to pass. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190609" n="18.272-18.273">The night shall come when a hateful marriage shall fall to the lot of me accursed, whose happiness Zeus has taken away. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190610" n="18.274">But herein has bitter grief come upon my heart and soul,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190611" n="18.275"><milestone ed="p" n="275" unit="line"/> for such as yours was never the way of wooers heretofore. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190612" n="18.276-18.279">They who are fain to woo a lady of worth and the daughter of a rich man and vie with one another, these bring of themselves cattle and goodly flocks, a banquet for the friends of the bride, and give to her glorious gifts;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190613" n="18.280"><milestone ed="p" n="280" unit="line"/> but they do not devour the livelihood of another without atonement.</s></p></q></p>


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2190614" n="18.281-18.283">So she spoke, and the much-enduring, <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus was glad, because she drew from them gifts, and beguiled their souls with gentle words, but her mind was set on other things.</s></p>


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2190615" n="18.284-18.287">Then Antinous, son of Eupeithes, spoke to her again, and said: <milestone ed="p" n="285" unit="line"/> Daughter of Icarius, wise Penelope, as for gifts, if any man of the Achaeans is minded to bring them <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod>, do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> take them;</s>
<q>>

<s xml:id="sent2190616" n="18.287">for it is not well to refuse a gift. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190617" n="18.288-18.289">But for us, we will go neither to our lands nor elsewhither, until <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> weddest him whosoever is best of the Achaeans.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:18.290-18.336">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2190618" n="18.290"><milestone ed="p" n="290" unit="line"/>So spoke Antinous, and his word was pleasing to them,

</s>

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2190626" n="18.299-18.300">And out of the house of lord Peisander, son of Polyctor, <milestone ed="p" n="300" unit="line"/> his squire brought a necklace, a jewel exceeding fair.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190628" n="18.302-18.305">But she thereafter, the fair lady, went up to her upper chamber, and her handmaids bare for her the beautiful gifts.
But the wooers <milestone ed="p" n="305" unit="line"/> turned to dance and gladsome song, and made them merry, and waited for evening to come on. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190629" n="18.306">And as they made merry dark evening came upon them. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190630" n="18.307-18.308">Presently they set up three braziers in the hall to give them light, 

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2190632" n="18.310-18.311">and in turn the handmaids of Odysseus, of the steadfast heart, kindled the flame. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190633" n="18.311-18.312">Then Zeus-born Odysseus, of many wiles, himself spoke among the maids, and said:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190634" n="18.313-18.314">Maidens of Odysseus, that has long been gone, go to the chambers where your honored queen abides,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190635" n="18.315-18.316"><milestone ed="p" n="315" unit="line"/> and twist the yarn by her side, and make glad her heart, as you sit in the chamber, or card the wool with your hands;</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190637" n="18.318-18.319">For if they wish to wait for fair-throned Dawn, they shall in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> outdo me. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190638" n="18.319">I am one that can endure much.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2190639" n="18.320"><milestone ed="p" n="320" unit="line"/>So he spoke, and the maids broke into a laugh, and glanced at one another. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190640" n="18.321-18.323">And fair-cheeked Melantho rated him shamefully, Melantho, whom Dolius begot, but whom Penelope had reared and cherished as her own child, and gave her playthings to her heart's desire. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190641" n="18.324-18.325">Yet even so she had at heart no sorrow for Penelope, <milestone ed="p" n="325" unit="line"/> but she loved Eurymachus and was <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to lie with him.

<s xml:id="sent2190642" n="18.326">She then rated Odysseus with reviling words:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190643" n="18.327-18.331">Wretched stranger, <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> but a crack-brained fellow, unwilling to go to a smithy to sleep, or to a common lodge, but <sic>pratest</sic> here continually, <milestone ed="p" n="330" unit="line"/> unabashed in the company of many lords, and <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> no fear at heart. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190644" n="18.331-18.332">Surely wine has mastered <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> wits, or else <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> mind is ever thus,

<s xml:id="sent2190759" n="19.85-19.87"><milestone ed="p" n="85" unit="line"/>But if, even as it seems, he is dead, and is no more to return, yet now is his son by the favour of Apollo such as he was—even Telemachus.

<s xml:id="sent2190760" n="19.87-19.88">Him it escapes not if any of the women in the halls work wantonness; for he is no longer the child he was.</s></q></p>

<s xml:id="sent2190767" n="19.100-19.101"><milestone ed="p" n="100" unit="line"/>So she spoke, and Eurynome speedily brought a polished chair and set it in place, and on it cast a fleece.

<s xml:id="sent2190777" n="19.118-19.120">Moreover it is not fitting <milestone ed="p" n="120" unit="line"/> that I should sit weeping and wailing in another's house, for it is ill to grieve ever without ceasing.

<s xml:id="sent2190780" n="19.124-19.128">Stranger, all excellence of mine, both of beauty and of form, <milestone ed="p" n="125" unit="line"/> the immortals destroyed on the day when the Argives embarked for <placeName key="tgn,7002329">Ilios</placeName>, and with them went my husband, Odysseus. <s xml:id="sent2190836" n="19.220"><milestone ed="p" n="220" unit="line"/>Then Odysseus of many wiles answered her, and said:

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2190873" n="19.277">So they all perished in the surging sea,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190874" n="19.278-19.282">but he on the keel of his ship was cast forth by the wave on the shore, on the land of the Phaeacians, who are near of kin to the gods. <milestone ed="p" n="280" unit="line"/>These heartily showed him all honor, as if he were a god, and gave him many gifts, and were fain themselves to send him home unscathed. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190875" n="19.282-19.283"><sic>Yea</sic>, and Odysseus would long since have been here,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190876" n="19.283-19.284">only it seemed to his mind more profitable to gather wealth by roaming over the wide earth;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190877" n="19.285-19.286"><milestone ed="p" n="285" unit="line"/> so truly does Odysseus beyond all mortal men know many gainful ways, nor could any mortal beside vie with him. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190878" n="19.287">Thus Pheidon, king of the Thesprotians, told me the tale. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190879" n="19.288-19.290">Moreover he swore in my own presence, as he poured libations in his halls, that the ship was launched and the men ready <milestone ed="p" n="290" unit="line"/> who were to convey him to his dear native land. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190880" n="19.291">But me he sent forth first, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190881" n="19.291-19.292">for a ship of the Thesprotians chanced to be setting out for Dulichium, rich in wheat. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190882" n="19.293">And he showed me all the treasure that Odysseus had gathered;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190883" n="19.294-19.295"><mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod> the tenth generation would it feed his children after him, <milestone ed="p" n="295" unit="line"/> so great was the wealth that lay stored for him in the halls of the king. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190884" n="19.296-19.299">But Odysseus, he said, had gone to <placeName key="perseus,Dodona">Dodona</placeName> to hear the will of Zeus from the high-crested oak of the god, even how he might return to his dear native land after so long an absence, whether openly or in secret.</s></p>



<p>

<s xml:id="sent2190885" n="19.300-19.302"><milestone ed="p" n="300" unit="line"/>Thus, as I tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, he is safe, and will presently come; he is very near, and not long will he now be far from his friends and his native land. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190886" n="19.302">Yet will I give <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> an oath. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190887" n="19.303-19.304">Be Zeus my witness first, highest and best of gods, and the hearth of noble Odysseus to which I am come,


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190888" n="19.305"><milestone ed="p" n="305" unit="line"/> that <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> all these things shall be brought to pass even as I tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190889" n="19.306-19.307">In the course of this very month shall Odysseus come <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod>, as the old moon wanes and the new appears.</s></p></q></p>


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2190890" n="19.308">Then wise Penelope answered him:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190891" n="19.309">Ah, stranger, I would that this word of <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> might be fulfilled.

<s xml:id="sent2190892" n="19.310-19.311"><milestone ed="p" n="310" unit="line"/>Then <mod n='shouldest'>should</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> straightway know of kindness and many a gift from me, so that one who met <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> would call <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> blessed. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190893" n="19.312">Yet in my heart I forebode it thus, even as it shall be. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190894" n="19.313-19.316">Neither shall Odysseus any more come home, nor <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> obtain a convoy hence, since there are not now in the house such masters <milestone ed="p" n="315" unit="line"/> as Odysseus was among men—as sure as ever such a man there was—to send reverend strangers on their way, and to welcome them.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:19.317-19.360">

<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2190895" n="19.317-19.319">But still, my maidens, wash the stranger's feet and prepare his bed—bedstead and cloaks and bright coverlets—that in warmth and comfort he may come to the golden-throned Dawn.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190896" n="19.320-19.322"><milestone ed="p" n="320" unit="line"/>And right early in the morning bathe him and anoint him, that in our house at the side of Telemachus he may <sic>bethink</sic> him of food as he sits in the hall.

<s xml:id="sent2190897" n="19.322-19.323">And worse shall it be for any man among them who vexes this man's soul with pain;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190898" n="19.323-19.324"><mod n="naught:simpsub">nothing</mod> thereafter shall he accomplish here, how fierce soever his wrath.

<s xml:id="sent2190899" n="19.325-19.328"><milestone ed="p" n="325" unit="line"/>For how <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> learn of me, stranger, whether I in any wise excel other women in wit and prudent counsel, if all unkempt and clad in poor raiment <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='sittest'>sit</mod> at meat in my halls? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190900" n="19.328">Men are but short-lived. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190901" n="19.329-19.331">If one be himself hard, and have a hard heart, <milestone ed="p" n="330" unit="line"/> on him do all mortal men invoke woes for the time to come, while he still lives, and when he is dead all men mock at him. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190902" n="19.332-19.334">But if one be blameless and have a blameless heart, his fame do strangers bear far and wide among all men, and many call him a true man.</s></q></p>



<p>

<s xml:id="sent2190903" n="19.335"><milestone ed="p" n="335" unit="line"/>Then Odysseus of many wiles answered her, and said:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190904" n="19.336-19.340">Honored wife of Odysseus, son of Laertes, <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> cloaks and bright coverlets became hateful in my eyes on the day when first I left behind me the snowy mountains of <placeName key="tgn,7012056">Crete</placeName>, as I fared on my long-oared ship. <milestone ed="p" n="340" unit="line"/><sic>Nay</sic>, I will lie, as in time past I was <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to rest through sleepless nights;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190905" n="19.341-19.342">for many a night have I lain upon a foul bed and waited for the bright-throned Dawn. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190906" n="19.343-19.344">Aye, and baths for the feet give my heart no pleasure,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190907" n="19.344-19.347">nor shall any woman touch my foot <milestone ed="p" n="345" unit="line"/> of all those who are serving-women in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> hall, unless there is some old, true-hearted dame who has suffered in her heart as many woes as I;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190908" n="19.348">such an one I would not grudge to touch my feet.</s></q></p>


<p>

<s xml:id="sent2190909" n="19.349">Then wise Penelope answered him again: <milestone ed="p" n="350" unit="line"/>

<s xml:id="sent2190910" n="19.350">Dear stranger,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190911" n="19.350-19.352">never yet has a man discreet as <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod>, of those who are strangers from afar, come to my house as a more welcome guest, so wise and prudent are all <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> words. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190912" n="19.353-19.356">I have an old dame with a heart of understanding in her breast, who lovingly nursed and cherished my hapless husband, <milestone ed="p" n="355" unit="line"/> and took him in her arms on the day when his mother bore him. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2190913" n="19.357-19.358">Come now, wise Eurycleia, arise and wash the feet of one of like age with <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> master.

<s xml:id="sent2190914" n="19.358-19.359">Even such as his are now <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> the feet of Odysseus, and such his hands,

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2190916" n="19.361-19.362">So she spoke, and the old woman hid her face in her hands and let fall hot tears, uttering words of lamentation:

<s xml:id="sent2190919" n="19.365-19.368"><milestone ed="p" n="365" unit="line"/>For never yet did any mortal burn to Zeus, who hurls the thunderbolt, so many fat thigh-pieces or so many choice hecatombs as <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='gavest'>gave</mod> him, with prayers that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='mightest'>might</mod> reach a sleek old age and rear <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> glorious son.

<s xml:id="sent2190921" n="19.370-19.374"><milestone ed="p" n="370" unit="line"/>Even thus, I <mod n="ween:simpsub">believe</mod>, did women mock at him too,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> in a strange and distant land, when he came to some man's glorious house, as these shameless creatures here all mock at <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>. </s>



<s xml:id="sent2190923" n="19.376-19.378">Therefore will I wash <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> feet, both for Penelope's own sake and for <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod>, for the heart within me is stirred with sorrow.

<s xml:id="sent2190924" n="19.378">But come now, <mod n="hearken:simpsub">listen</mod> to the word that I shall speak.

<s xml:id="sent2190925" n="19.379-19.381">Many sore-tried strangers have come <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod>, <milestone ed="p" n="380" unit="line"/> but I declare that never yet have I seen any man so like another as <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> in form, and in voice, and in feet art like Odysseus.

</q>

<s xml:id="sent2190926" n="19.382">Then Odysseus of many wiles answered her, and said: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190927" n="19.383-19.385">Old dame, so say all men whose eyes have beheld us two, that <milestone ed="p" n="385" unit="line"/> we are very like each other, even as <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod> <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> note and say.

<s xml:id="sent2190928" n="19.386-19.388">So he spoke, and the old dame took the shining cauldron with water <mod n="wherefrom:simpsub">from which</mod> she was about to wash his feet, and poured in cold water in plenty, and then added <sic>thereto</sic> the warm. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190929" n="19.388-19.389">But Odysseus sat him down away from the hearth and straightway turned himself toward the darkness,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190930" n="19.390-19.391"><milestone ed="p" n="390" unit="line"/> for he at once had a foreboding at heart that, as she touched him, she might note a scar, and the truth be made manifest.

<s xml:id="sent2190931" n="19.392">So she drew near and began to wash her lord,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190932" n="19.392-19.396">and straightway knew the scar of the wound which long ago a boar had dealt him with his white tusk, when Odysseus had gone to <placeName key="tgn,7011022">Parnassus</placeName> to visit Autolycus and the sons of Autolycus, <milestone ed="p" n="395" unit="line"/> his mother's noble father, who excelled all men in thievery and in oaths.

<s xml:id="sent2190933" n="19.396-19.397">It was a god himself that had given him this skill, even Hermes,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2190935" n="19.398">so Hermes befriended him with a ready heart. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2190936" n="19.399-19.400">Now Autolycus, on coming once to the rich land of <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName>, <milestone ed="p" n="400" unit="line"/> had found his daughter's son a babe new-born,

<s xml:id="sent2190940" n="19.405"><milestone ed="p" n="405" unit="line"/>Then Autolycus answered her, and said:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2190941" n="19.406">My daughter's husband and my daughter, give him whatsoever name I say.

<s xml:id="sent2190942" n="19.407-19.408"><sic>Lo</sic>, inasmuch as I am come <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod> as one that has been angered with many, both men and women, over the fruitful earth,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2190944" n="19.409-19.412">And for my part, <milestone ed="p" n="410" unit="line"/> when he is a man grown and comes to the great house of his mother's kin at <placeName key="tgn,7011022">Parnassus</placeName>, where are my possessions, I will give him <sic>thereof</sic> and send him back rejoicing.

<s xml:id="sent2190945" n="19.413">It was for this reason that Odysseus had come, that Autolycus might give him the glorious gifts.

<s xml:id="sent2190953" n="19.428-19.430">But as soon as early Dawn appeared, the rosy-fingered, they went forth to the hunt, the hounds and <milestone ed="p" n="430" unit="line"/> the sons of Autolycus too,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2190955" n="19.431-19.432">Up the steep mountain <placeName key="tgn,7011022">Parnassus</placeName>, clothed with forests, they climbed, and presently reached its windy hollows.

<s xml:id="sent2190956" n="19.433-19.435">The sun was now just striking on the fields, as he rose from softly-gliding, deep-flowing Oceanus, <milestone ed="p" n="435" unit="line"/> when the beaters came to a glade.

<s xml:id="sent2190959" n="19.439">Now thereby a great wild boar was lying in a thick lair,

<s xml:id="sent2190960" n="19.440-19.442"><milestone ed="p" n="440" unit="line"/> through which the strength of the wet winds could never blow nor the rays of the bright sun beat, nor could the rain pierce through it,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2190968" n="19.455-19.458"><milestone ed="p" n="455" unit="line"/>Then the dear sons of Autolycus busied themselves with the carcase, and the wound of noble, god-like Odysseus they bound up skilfully, and checked the black blood with a charm, and straightway returned to the house of their dear father.

<s xml:id="sent2190969" n="19.459-19.462">And when Autolycus and the sons of Autolycus <milestone ed="p" n="460" unit="line"/> had fully healed him, and had given him glorious gifts, they quickly sent him back with joy to his native land, to <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName>.

<s xml:id="sent2190986" n="19.485-19.486"><milestone ed="p" n="485" unit="line"/>But since <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> found me out, and a god has put this in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> heart, be silent lest any other in the halls learn hereof.

<s xml:id="sent2190987" n="19.487">For thus will I speak out to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, and <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> it shall be brought to pass:

<s xml:id="sent2190988" n="19.488-19.490">if a god shall subdue the lordly wooers <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod> me, I will not spare <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, my nurse though <corr n="thou art">you are</corr>, when <milestone ed="p" n="490" unit="line"/>I <mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod> the other serving-women in my halls.

<s xml:id="sent2190989" n="19.491">Then wise Eurycleia answered him:

<s xml:id="sent2190992" n="19.495"><milestone ed="p" n="495" unit="line"/>And another thing will I tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, and do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> lay it to heart.

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2190994" n="19.499-19.500">Then Odysseus of many wiles answered her, and said: <milestone ed="p" n="500" unit="line"/> Mother, why, pray, <mod n="wilt:simpsub">will</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> speak of them?

<s xml:id="sent2190998" n="19.503-19.504">So he spoke, and the old woman went forth through the hall to bring water for his feet,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191000" n="19.505-19.507"><milestone ed="p" n="505" unit="line"/>And when she had washed him, and anointed him richly with oil, Odysseus again drew his chair nearer to the fire to warm himself, and hid the scar with his rags.

<s xml:id="sent2191001" n="19.508">Then wise Penelope was the first to speak, saying:

<s xml:id="sent2191003" n="19.510-19.511"><milestone ed="p" n="510" unit="line"/> for it will soon be the hour for pleasant rest, for him at least on whom sweet sleep may come despite his care. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191004" n="19.512">But to me has a god given sorrow that is beyond all measure,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191005" n="19.513-19.514">for day by day I find my joy in mourning and lamenting, while looking to my household tasks and those of my women in the house,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191006" n="19.515-19.517"><milestone ed="p" n="515" unit="line"/> but when night comes and sleep lays hold of all, I lie upon my bed, and sharp cares, crowding close about my throbbing heart, disquiet me, as I mourn. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191007" n="19.518-19.529">Even as when the daughter of Pandareus, the nightingale of the greenwood,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> sings sweetly, when spring is newly come, <milestone ed="p" n="520" unit="line"/> as she sits perched <mod n="amid:simpsub">among</mod> the thick leafage of the trees, and with many trilling notes pours forth her rich voice in wailing for her child, dear Itylus, whom she had one day slain with the sword unwittingly, Itylus, the son of king Zethus; even so my heart sways to and fro in doubt, <milestone ed="p" n="525" unit="line"/> whether to <mod n="abide:simpsub">remain</mod> with my son and keep all things safe, my possessions, my slaves, and my great, high-roofed house, respecting the bed of my husband and the voice of the people, or to go now with him whosoever is best of the Achaeans, who woos me in the halls and offers bride-gifts past counting.

<s xml:id="sent2191008" n="19.530-19.531"><milestone ed="p" n="530" unit="line"/>Furthermore my son, so long as he was a child and slack of wit, would not suffer me to marry and leave the house of my husband;

<s xml:id="sent2191010" n="19.535"><milestone ed="p" n="535" unit="line"/>But come now, hear this dream of mine, and interpret it for me.

<s xml:id="sent2191011" n="19.536-19.537">Twenty geese I have in the house that come forth from the water<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> and eat wheat, and my heart warms with joy as I watch them.

<s xml:id="sent2191012" n="19.538-19.539">But forth from the mountain there came a great eagle with crooked beak and broke all their necks and killed them;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191013" n="19.539-19.540">and they lay strewn <milestone ed="p" n="540" unit="line"/> in a heap in the halls, while he was borne aloft to the bright sky.

<s xml:id="sent2191014" n="19.541-19.543">Now for my part I wept and wailed, in a dream though it was, and round me thronged the fair-tressed Achaean women, as I grieved piteously because the eagle had slain my geese.</s></q></p>

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191015" n="19.544-19.545">Then back he came and perched upon a projecting roof-beam, <milestone ed="p" n="545" unit="line"/> and with the voice of a mortal man checked my weeping, and said:

<s xml:id="sent2191018" n="19.548-19.550">The geese are the wooers, and I, that before was the eagle, am now again come back as <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> husband, <milestone ed="p" n="550" unit="line"/> who will let loose a cruel doom upon all the wooers.</s></q></p>

<s xml:id="sent2191019" n="19.551">So he spoke, and sweet sleep released me,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191021" n="19.554">Then Odysseus of many wiles answered her and said:

<s xml:id="sent2191022" n="19.555-19.557"><milestone ed="p" n="555" unit="line"/>Lady, in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> is it possible to wrest this dream aside and give it another meaning, since <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> Odysseus himself has shewn <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> how he will bring it to pass.

<s xml:id="sent2191023" n="19.557-19.558">For the wooers' destruction is plain to see, for one and all; not one of them shall escape death and the fates.

<s xml:id="sent2191024" n="19.559">Then wise Penelope answered him again:

<s xml:id="sent2191025" n="19.560-19.561"><milestone ed="p" n="560" unit="line"/>Stranger, dreams <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> are baffling and unclear of meaning, and in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> do they find fulfillment in all things for men.

<s xml:id="sent2191030" n="19.568-19.569">But in my case it was not from thence, methinks, that my strange dream came.

<s xml:id="sent2191032" n="19.570"><milestone ed="p" n="570" unit="line"/>But another thing will I tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, and do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> lay it to heart.

<s xml:id="sent2191039" n="19.582-19.584">Then Odysseus of many wiles answered her, and said: Honored wife of Odysseus, son of Laertes, no longer now do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> put off this contest in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> halls;</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191041" n="19.588">Then wise Penelope answered him:

<s xml:id="sent2191042" n="19.589-19.590">If <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> couldest but wish, stranger, to sit here in my halls <milestone ed="p" n="590" unit="line"/> and give me joy, sleep should never be shed over my eyelids.

<s xml:id="sent2191045" n="19.594-19.597">But I <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> will go to my upper chamber <milestone ed="p" n="595" unit="line"/> and lay me on my bed, which has become for me a bed of wailings, ever bedewed with my tears, since the day when Odysseus went to see evil <placeName key="tgn,7002329">Ilios</placeName>, that should never be named.

<s xml:id="sent2191048" n="19.600-19.601"><milestone ed="p" n="600" unit="line"/>So saying, she went up to her bright upper chamber, not alone, for with her went her handmaids as well.

<s xml:id="sent2191049" n="19.602-19.604">And when she had gone up to her upper chamber with her handmaids, she then bewailed Odysseus, her dear husband, until flashing-eyed Athena cast sweet sleep upon her eyelids.</s></p>

<s xml:id="sent2191050" n="20.1"><milestone ed="p" n="1" unit="line"/>But the <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus lay down to sleep in the fore-hall of the house.

<s xml:id="sent2191054" n="20.6-20.8">And the women came forth from the hall, those that had before been <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to lie with the wooers, making laughter and merriment among themselves.

<s xml:id="sent2191057" n="20.14-20.16">And as a bitch stands over her tender whelps <milestone ed="p" n="15" unit="line"/> growling, when she sees a man she does not know, and is eager to fight, so his heart growled within him in his wrath at their evil deeds;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191058" n="20.17">but he <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> his breast, and rebuked his heart, saying:

<s xml:id="sent2191066" n="20.25-20.30"><milestone ed="p" n="25" unit="line"/>And as when a man before a great blazing fire turns swiftly this way and that a paunch full of fat and blood, and is very eager to have it roasted quickly, so Odysseus tossed from side to side, pondering how he might put forth his hands upon the shameless wooers, <milestone ed="p" n="30" unit="line"/> one man as he was against so many.

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191079" n="20.44">Then the goddess, flashing-eyed Athena, answered him:

<s xml:id="sent2191080" n="20.45-20.46"><milestone ed="p" n="45" unit="line"/>Obstinate one, many a man puts his trust even in a weaker friend than I am, one that is mortal, and knows not such wisdom as mine;</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191096" n="20.83-20.87">Yet when a man weeps by day with a heart <sic>sore</sic> distressed, <milestone ed="p" n="85" unit="line"/> but at night sleep holds him, this brings with it an evil that may well be borne—for sleep makes one forget all things, the good and the evil, when once it envelops the eyelids—but upon me a god sends evil dreams as well. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191097" n="20.88-20.89">For this night again there lay by my side one like him, even such as he was when he went forth with the host,</s>

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191099" n="20.91">So she spoke, and straightway came golden-throned Dawn.

<s xml:id="sent2191100" n="20.92">But as she wept <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus heard her voice,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191101" n="20.93-20.94">and thereupon he mused, and it seemed to his heart that she knew him and was standing by his head.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191102" n="20.95-20.97"><milestone ed="p" n="95" unit="line"/>Then he gathered up the cloak and the fleeces on which he was lying and laid them on a chair in the hall, and carried the ox-hide out of doors and set it down; and he lifted up his hands and prayed to Zeus:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191103" n="20.98-20.101">Father Zeus, if of your good will <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> gods have brought me over land and sea to my own country, when <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> had afflicted me <sic>sore</sic>, <milestone ed="p" n="100" unit="line"/> let some one of those who are awaking utter a word of omen for me within, and without let a sign from Zeus be shown besides.

<s xml:id="sent2191104" n="20.102">So he spoke in prayer,

<s xml:id="sent2191105" n="20.102-20.104">and Zeus the counsellor heard him.  Straightway he thundered from gleaming <placeName key="tgn,7011019">Olympus</placeName>, from on high <corr n="from out">out of</corr> the clouds; </s>

<s xml:id="sent2191107" n="20.105-20.108"><milestone ed="p" n="105" unit="line"/>And a woman, grinding at the mill, uttered a word of omen from within the house hard by, where the mills of the shepherd of the people were set. At these mills twelve women in all were <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to ply their tasks, making meal of barley and of wheat, the marrow of men. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191108" n="20.109-20.110">Now the others were sleeping, for they had ground their wheat, <milestone ed="p" n="110" unit="line"/> but she alone had not yet ceased, for she was the weakest of all.

<s xml:id="sent2191112" n="20.115"><milestone ed="p" n="115" unit="line"/>Fulfil now even for wretched me the word that I shall speak.

<s xml:id="sent2191113" n="20.116-20.118">May the wooers this day for the last and latest time hold their glad feast in the halls of Odysseus.

<s xml:id="sent2191114" n="20.118-20.119">They that have loosened my limbs with bitter labour, as I made them barley meal,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191116" n="20.120-20.121"><milestone ed="p" n="120" unit="line"/>So she spoke, and <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus was glad at the word of omen and at the thunder of Zeus,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191117" n="20.121">for he thought he had gotten vengeance on the guilty.

<s xml:id="sent2191118" n="20.122-20.123">Now the other maidens in the fair palace of Odysseus had gathered together and were kindling on the hearth unwearied fire,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191121" n="20.126-20.127">and beneath his shining feet he bound his fair sandals; and he took his mighty spear, tipped with sharp</s>

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191124" n="20.129-20.130">Dear nurse, have <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> honored the stranger in our house <milestone ed="p" n="130" unit="line"/> with bed and food, or does he lie all uncared for? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191125" n="20.131">For such is my mother's way, wise though she is:</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191126" n="20.132">in wondrous fashion she honours one of mortal men, though he be the worse,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191140" n="20.155-20.156"><milestone ed="p" n="155" unit="line"/>For the wooers will not long be absent from the hall, but will return right early; for it is a feast-day for all men.

<s xml:id="sent2191143" n="20.160"><milestone ed="p" n="160" unit="line"/>Then in came the serving-men of the Acheans,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191145" n="20.162-20.163">After them came the swineherd, driving three boars which were the best in all his herd.

<s xml:id="sent2191172" n="20.204-20.207">The sweat broke out on me when I marked the man, and my eyes are full of tears <milestone ed="p" n="205" unit="line"/> as I think of Odysseus; for he, too, I <mod n="ween:simpsub">believe</mod>, is clothed in such rags and is a wanderer among men, if indeed he still lives and beholds the light of the sun.

<s xml:id="sent2191173" n="20.208-20.210">But if he is already dead and in the house of Hades, then woe is me for blameless Odysseus, who <milestone ed="p" n="210" unit="line"/> set me over his cattle, when I was yet a boy, in the land of the Cephallenians.</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191174" n="20.211-20.212">And now these wax past counting; in no other wise could the breed of broad-browed cattle yield better increase<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> for a mortal man.

<s xml:id="sent2191178" n="20.217-20.218">Now, as for myself, the heart in my breast keeps revolving this matter:</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191181" n="20.222-20.223">Aye, <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod>, long ago would I have fled and come to some other of the proud kings, for now things are no more to be borne;</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191226" n="20.294-20.295">for it is not well nor just to rob of their due <milestone ed="p" n="295" unit="line"/> the guests of Telemachus, whosoever he be that comes to this house. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191227" n="20.296-20.298"><sic>Nay</sic>, come, I too will give him a stranger's-gift, that he in turn may give a present either to the bath-woman or to some other of the slaves who are in the house of godlike Odysseus.</s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:20.299-20.344">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191228" n="20.299">So saying, he hurled with strong hand the hoof of an ox,

</s>


<s xml:id="sent2191229" n="20.300"><milestone ed="p" n="300" unit="line"/> taking it up from the basket where it lay. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191230" n="20.300-20.302">But Odysseus avoided it with a quick turn of his head, and in his heart he smiled a right grim and bitter smile;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191231" n="20.302">and the ox's hoof struck the well-built wall. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191232" n="20.303">Then Telemachus rebuked Ctesippus, and said:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191233" n="20.304">Ctesippus, <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> this thing fell out more to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> soul's profit.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191234" n="20.305"><milestone ed="p" n="305" unit="line"/>Thou <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> not <mod n="smite:simpsub">strike</mod> the stranger,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191235" n="20.305">for he himself avoided <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> missile,

<s xml:id="sent2191236" n="20.306-20.308">else surely would I have struck <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> through the middle with my sharp spear, and instead of a wedding feast <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> father would have been busied with a funeral feast in this land. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191237" n="20.308-20.309"><mod n="Wherefore:simpsub">For which reason</mod> let no man, I warn you, make a show of forwardness in my house;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191238" n="20.309-20.310">for now I mark and understand all things, <milestone ed="p" n="310" unit="line"/> the good and the evil,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191239" n="20.310">whereas heretofore I was but a child. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191240" n="20.311-20.313">But none the less we still endure to see these deeds, while sheep are slaughtered, and wine drunk, and bread consumed,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191241" n="20.313">for hard it is for one man to restrain many. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191242" n="20.314">Yet come, no longer work me harm of your evil wills.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191243" n="20.315-20.319"><milestone ed="p" n="315" unit="line"/>But if you are minded even now to <mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod> me myself with the sword, even that would I choose, and it would be better far to die than continually to behold these shameful deeds, strangers mishandled and men dragging the handmaidens in shameful fashion through the fair hall.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191244" n="20.320"><milestone ed="p" n="320" unit="line"/>So he spoke, and they were all hushed in silence,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191245" n="20.321">but at last there spoke among them Agelaus, son of Damastor:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191246" n="20.322-20.323">Friends, no man in answer to what has been fairly spoken would wax <mod n="wroth:simpsub">angry</mod> and make reply with wrangling words. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191247" n="20.324-20.325">Abuse not any more the stranger nor any <milestone ed="p" n="325" unit="line"/> of the slaves that are in the house of divine Odysseus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191248" n="20.326-20.327">But to Telemachus and his mother I would speak a gentle word, if <mod n="perchance:simpsub">perchance</mod> it may find favour in the minds of both. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191249" n="20.328-20.332">So long as the hearts in your breasts had hope that wise Odysseus would return to his own house, <milestone ed="p" n="330" unit="line"/> so long there was no ground for blame that you waited, and restrained the wooers in your halls; for this was the better course, had Odysseus returned and come back to his house. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191250" n="20.333">But now this is plain, that he will return no more. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191251" n="20.334-20.337"><sic>Nay</sic> then, come, sit by <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> mother and tell her this, <milestone ed="p" n="335" unit="line"/> namely that she must wed him whosoever is the best man, and who offers the most gifts; to the end that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='mayest'>may</mod> enjoy in peace all the heritage of <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> fathers, eating and drinking, and that she may keep the house of another.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191252" n="20.338">Then wise Telemachus answered him: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191253" n="20.339-20.342"><sic>Nay</sic>, by Zeus, Agelaus, and by the woes of my father, <milestone ed="p" n="340" unit="line"/> who somewhere far from <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName> has perished or is wandering, in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> do I delay my mother's marriage, but I <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> her wed what man she will, and I offer besides gifts past counting. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191254" n="20.343-20.344">But I am ashamed to drive her forth from the hall against her will by a word of compulsion. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191255" n="20.344">May God never bring such a thing to pass.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:20.345-20.394">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191256" n="20.345"><milestone ed="p" n="345" unit="line"/>So spoke Telemachus,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191257" n="20.345-20.346">but among the wooers Pallas Athena roused unquenchable laughter, and turned their wits awry. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191258" n="20.347-20.348">And now they laughed with alien lips, and all bedabbled with blood was the flesh they ate,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> </s>

<s xml:id="sent2191260" n="20.350"><milestone ed="p" n="350" unit="line"/>Then among them spoke godlike Theoclymenus:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191261" n="20.351">Ah, wretched men, what evil is this that you suffer? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191262" n="20.351-20.352">Shrouded in night are your heads and your faces and your knees beneath you;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191263" n="20.353-20.354">kindled is the sound of wailing, bathed in tears are your cheeks, and sprinkled with blood are the walls and the fair rafters.

<s xml:id="sent2191264" n="20.355-20.356"><milestone ed="p" n="355" unit="line"/>And full of ghosts is the porch and full the court, of ghosts that hasten down to Erebus beneath the darkness,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191265" n="20.356-20.357">and the sun has perished out of heaven and an evil mist hovers over all.

<s xml:id="sent2191266" n="20.358">So he spoke, but they all laughed merrily at him. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191267" n="20.359">And among them Eurymachus, son of Polybus, was the first to speak:
<milestone ed="p" n="360" unit="line"/>


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191268" n="20.360">Mad is the stranger that has newly come from abroad. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191269" n="20.361-20.362">Quick, <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> youths, convey him forth out of doors to go his way to the place of assembly, since here he finds it like night.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191270" n="20.363">Then godlike Theoclymenus answered him: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191271" n="20.364">Eurymachus, in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> do I <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> give me guides for my way.

<s xml:id="sent2191272" n="20.365-20.366"><milestone ed="p" n="365" unit="line"/>I have eyes and ears and my two feet, and a mind in my breast that is in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> meanly fashioned. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191273" n="20.367-20.370">With these will I go forth out of doors, for I mark evil coming upon you which not one of the wooers may escape or avoid, of all you who in the house of godlike Odysseus <milestone ed="p" n="370" unit="line"/> insult men and devise wicked folly.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191274" n="20.371-20.372">So saying, he went forth from the stately halls and came to Piraeus, who received him with a ready heart. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191275" n="20.373-20.374">But all the wooers, looking at one another, sought to provoke Telemachus by laughing at his guests.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191276" n="20.375"><milestone ed="p" n="375" unit="line"/>And thus would one of the proud youths speak:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191277" n="20.376">Telemachus, no man is more unlucky in his guests than <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod>,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191279" n="20.380"><milestone ed="p" n="380" unit="line"/>And this other fellow again stood up to prophesy. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191280" n="20.381"><sic>Nay</sic>, if <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> wouldst <mod n="hearken:simpsub">listen</mod> to me it would be better far:</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191282" n="20.384">So <mod n="spake:simpsub">spoke</mod> the wooers,</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191284" n="20.387-20.389">But the daughter of Icarius, wise Penelope, had set her beautiful chair over against them, and heard the words of each man in the hall.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191285" n="20.390-20.391"><milestone ed="p" n="390" unit="line"/>For they had made ready their meal in the midst of their laughing, a sweet meal, and one to satisfy the heart, for they had slain many beasts. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191286" n="20.392-20.394">But never could meal have been more graceless than a supper such as a goddess and a mighty man were soon to set before them. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191287" n="20.394">For unprovoked they were contriving deeds of shame.</s></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="book" n="21">
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:21.1-21.41">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191288" n="21.1-21.4"><milestone ed="p" n="1" unit="line"/>But the goddess, flashing-eyed Athena, put it into the heart of the daughter of Icarius, wise Penelope, to set before the wooers in the halls of Odysseus the bow and the gray iron, to be a contest and the beginning of death.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191289" n="21.5-21.7"><milestone ed="p" n="5" unit="line"/>She climbed the high stairway to her chamber, and took the bent key in her strong hand—a goodly key of bronze, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2191290" n="21.7">and on it was a handle of ivory. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191291" n="21.8-21.9">And she went her way with her handmaidens to a store-room, far remote, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2191292" n="21.9-21.10">where lay the treasures of her lord, <milestone ed="p" n="10" unit="line"/> bronze and gold and iron, <sic>wrought</sic> with toil. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191293" n="21.11-21.14">And there lay the back-bent bow and the quiver that held the arrows, and many arrows were in it, fraught with groanings—gifts which a friend of Odysseus had given him when he met him once in <placeName key="tgn,7011065">Lacedaemon</placeName>, even Iphitus, son of Eurytus, a man <corr n="like unto">like</corr> the immortals.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191294" n="21.15-21.16"><milestone ed="p" n="15" unit="line"/>They two had met one another in <placeName key="perseus,Messene">Messene</placeName> in the house of wise Ortilochus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191295" n="21.16-21.17">Odysseus <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> had come to collect a debt which the whole people owed him, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191296" n="21.18-21.19">for the men of <placeName key="perseus,Messene">Messene</placeName> had lifted from <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName> in their benched ships three hundred sheep and the shepherds with them.
