<s xml:id="sent2191297" n="21.20-21.21"><milestone ed="p" n="20" unit="line"/>It was on an embassy in quest of these that Odysseus had come a far journey, while he was but a youth; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2191298" n="21.21">for his father and the other elders had sent him forth. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191299" n="21.22-21.23">And Iphitus, on his part, had come in search of twelve brood mares, which he had lost, with sturdy mules at the teat;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191300" n="21.24-21.29">but to him thereafter did they bring death and doom, <milestone ed="p" n="25" unit="line"/> when he came to the stout-hearted son of Zeus, the man Heracles, who well knew<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> deeds of daring; for Heracles <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> him, his guest though he was, in his own house, ruthlessly, and had regard neither for the wrath of the gods nor for the table which he had set before him,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191301" n="21.29-21.30">but <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> the man thereafter, <milestone ed="p" n="30" unit="line"/> and himself kept the stout-hoofed mares in his halls. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191302" n="21.31-21.33">It was while asking for these that Iphitus met Odysseus, and gave him the bow, which of old great Eurytus had been <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to bear, and had left at his death to his son in his lofty house. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191303" n="21.34-21.35">And to Iphitus Odysseus gave a sharp sword and a mighty spear, <milestone ed="p" n="35" unit="line"/> as the beginning of loving friendship; </s>

<s xml:id="sent2191305" n="21.36-21.38">for <mod n="ere:simpsub">before</mod> that might be the son of Zeus had slain Iphitus, son of Eurytus, a man <corr n="like unto">like</corr> the immortals, who gave Odysseus the bow. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191306" n="21.38-21.41">This bow <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus, when going forth to war, would never <milestone ed="p" n="40" unit="line"/> take with him on the black ships, but it lay in his halls at home as a memorial of a dear friend, and he carried it in his own land.</s></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:21.42-21.79">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191307" n="21.42-21.48">Now when the fair lady had come to the store-room, and had stepped upon the threshold of oak, which of old the carpenter had skilfully planed and made straight to the line— <milestone ed="p" n="45" unit="line"/> thereon had he also fitted door-posts, and set on them bright doors—straightway she quickly loosed the thong<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">2</note> from the handle and thrust in the key, and with sure aim shot back the bolts. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191308" n="21.48-21.49">And as a bull bellows <milestone ed="p" n="50" unit="line"/> when grazing in a meadow, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191309" n="21.49-21.50">even so bellowed the fair doors, <mod n="smitten:simpsub">struck</mod> by the key; and quickly they flew open before her. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191310" n="21.51">Then she stepped upon the high floor,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191311" n="21.51-21.52">where the chests stood in which fragrant raiment was stored, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2191312" n="21.53-21.54">and stretched out her hand from thence and took from its peg the bow together with the bright case which surrounded it.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191313" n="21.55-21.56"><milestone ed="p" n="55" unit="line"/>And there she sat down and laid the case upon her knees and wept aloud, and took out the bow of her lord. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191314" n="21.57-21.60">But when she had had her fill of tearful wailing, she went her way to the hall, to the company of the lordly wooers, bearing in her hands the back-bent bow and the quiver <milestone ed="p" n="60" unit="line"/> that held the arrows,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191315" n="21.60">and many arrows were in it, fraught with groanings. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191316" n="21.61-21.62">And by her side her maidens bore a chest, <mod n="wherein:simpsub">in which</mod> lay abundance of iron and bronze, the battle-gear of her lord. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191317" n="21.63-21.65">Now when the fair lady reached the wooers, she stood by the door-post of the well-built hall, <milestone ed="p" n="65" unit="line"/> holding before her face her shining veil; </s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191319" n="21.67">Then straightway she spoke among the wooers, and said:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191320" n="21.68-21.70">Hear me, <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> proud wooers, who have beset this house to eat and drink ever without end, <milestone ed="p" n="70" unit="line"/> since its master has long been gone, </s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191322" n="21.73"><sic>Nay</sic>, come now, <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> wooers, since this is shewn to be your prize.<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191323" n="21.74">I will set before you the great bow of divine Odysseus,


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191324" n="21.75-21.79"><milestone ed="p" n="75" unit="line"/> and whosoever shall most easily string the bow in his hands and shoot an arrow through all twelve axes, with him will I go, and forsake this house of my wedded life, a house most fair and filled with livelihood, which, methinks I shall ever remember even in my dreams.</s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:21.80-21.117">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191325" n="21.80-21.81"><milestone ed="p" n="80" unit="line"/>So she spoke, and <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> Eumaeus, the goodly swineherd, set for the wooers the bow and the grey iron.

<s xml:id="sent2191326" n="21.82">And, bursting into tears, Eumaeus took them and laid them down, </s>

<s xml:id="sent2191328" n="21.84">Then Antinous rebuked them, and spoke, and addressed them:

<s xml:id="sent2191329" n="21.85-21.87"><milestone ed="p" n="85" unit="line"/>Foolish boors, who mind only the things of the day! Wretched pair, why now do you shed tears, and trouble the soul in the breast of the lady,

<s xml:id="sent2191331" n="21.89-21.91"><sic>Nay</sic>, sit and feast in silence, <milestone ed="p" n="90" unit="line"/> or else go forth and weep, and leave the bow here behind as a decisive<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> contest for the wooers;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191333" n="21.93-21.94">For there is no man among all these here such as Odysseus was, </s>

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191335" n="21.96-21.97">So he spoke, but the heart in his breast hoped that he would string the bow and shoot an arrow through the iron. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191336" n="21.98-21.100">Yet <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> he was to be the first to taste of an arrow from the hands of noble Odysseus, whom then he, <milestone ed="p" n="100" unit="line"/> as he sat in the halls, was dishonoring, and urging on all his comrades.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191337" n="21.101">Then among them spoke the strong and mighty Telemachus: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191338" n="21.102"><sic>Lo</sic> now, of a truth Zeus, son of Cronos, has made me witless.

<s xml:id="sent2191339" n="21.103-21.104">My dear mother, for all that she is wise, declares that she will follow another lord, forsaking this house;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191340" n="21.105"><milestone ed="p" n="105" unit="line"/> yet I laugh, and am glad with a witless mind. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191341" n="21.106-21.117">Come then, <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> wooers, since this is shewn to be your prize, a lady, the like of whom is not now in the Achaean land, neither in sacred <placeName key="perseus,Pylos">Pylos</placeName>, nor in <placeName key="perseus,Argos">Argos</placeName>, nor in Mycene, nor yet in <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName> itself, nor in the dark mainland. <milestone ed="p" n="110" unit="line"/><sic>Nay</sic>, but of yourselves you know this—what need have I to praise my mother? Come then, put not the matter aside with excuses, nor any more turn away too long from the drawing of the bow, that we may see the issue. <sic>Yea</sic>, and I would myself make trial of <sic>yon</sic> bow. If I shall string it and shoot an arrow through the iron, <milestone ed="p" n="115" unit="line"/> it will not vex me that my honored mother should leave this house and go along with another, seeing that I should be left here able now to wield the goodly battle-gear of my father.</s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:21.118-21.162">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191348" n="21.118-21.119">With this he flung the scarlet cloak from off his back, and sprang up erect; and he laid his sharp sword from off his shoulders.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191349" n="21.120-21.122"><milestone ed="p" n="120" unit="line"/>First then he set up the axes, when he had dug a trench, one long trench for all, and made it straight to the line, and about them he stamped in the earth. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191350" n="21.122-21.123">And amazement seized all who saw him, that he set them out so orderly,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191351" n="21.123">though before he had never seen them. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191352" n="21.124">Then he went and stood upon the threshold, and began to try the bow.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191353" n="21.125-21.127"><milestone ed="p" n="125" unit="line"/><mod n="Thrice:simpsub">Three times</mod> he made it quiver in his eagerness to draw it, and <mod n="thrice:simpsub">three times</mod> he relaxed his effort, though in his heart he hoped to string the bow and shoot an arrow through the iron. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191354" n="21.128-21.129">And now at the last he would <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> have strung it in his might, as for the fourth time he sought to draw up the string, but Odysseus nodded in dissent, and checked him in his eagerness.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191355" n="21.130"><milestone ed="p" n="130" unit="line"/>Then the strong and mighty Telemachus spoke among them again:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191356" n="21.131-21.133">Out on it, even in days to come shall I be a coward and a weakling, or else I am too young, and have not yet trust in my might to defend me against a man, when one waxes <mod n="wroth:simpsub">angry</mod> without a cause. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191357" n="21.134-21.135">But, come now, you that are mightier than I, <milestone ed="p" n="135" unit="line"/> make trial of the bow, and let us end the contest.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191358" n="21.136-21.139">So saying, he set the bow from him on the ground, leaning it against the jointed, polished door, and hard by he leaned the swift arrow against the fair bow-tip, and then sat down again on the seat from which he had risen.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191359" n="21.140"><milestone ed="p" n="140" unit="line"/>Then Antinous, son of Eupeithes, spoke among them: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191360" n="21.141-21.142">Rise up in order, all you of our company, from left to right, beginning from the place where the cupbearer pours the wine.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191361" n="21.143">So spoke Antinous, and his word was pleasing to them. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191362" n="21.144-21.146">Then first arose Leiodes, son of Oenops, <milestone ed="p" n="145" unit="line"/> who was their soothsayer, and ever sat by the fair mixing-bowl in the innermost part of the hall;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191363" n="21.146-21.147">deeds of wanton folly were hateful to him alone, and he was full of indignation at all the wooers. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191364" n="21.148">He it was who now first took the bow and swift arrow,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191365" n="21.149-21.150">and he went and stood upon the threshold, and began to try the bow; <milestone ed="p" n="150" unit="line"/> but he could not string it. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191366" n="21.150-21.151">Ere that might be his hands grew weary, as he sought to draw up the string, his unworn delicate hands;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191367" n="21.151">and he spoke among the wooers:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191368" n="21.152">Friends, it is not I that shall string it; let another take it. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191369" n="21.153-21.156">For many princes shall this bow rob of spirit and of life, since <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> it is better far <milestone ed="p" n="155" unit="line"/> to die than to live on and fail of that for the sake of which we ever gather here, waiting expectantly day after day. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191370" n="21.157-21.158">Now many a man even hopes in his heart and desires to wed Penelope, the wife of Odysseus; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2191371" n="21.159-21.161">but when he shall have made trial of the bow, and seen the outcome, thereafter let him woo <milestone ed="p" n="160" unit="line"/> some other of the fair-robed Achaean women with his gifts, and seek to win her;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191372" n="21.161-21.162">then should Penelope wed him who offers most, and who comes as her fated lord.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:21.163-21.204">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191373" n="21.163-21.166">So he spoke, and set the bow from him, leaning it against the jointed, polished door, <milestone ed="p" n="165" unit="line"/> and hard by he leaned the swift arrow against the fair bow-tip, and then sat down on the seat from which he had risen. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191374" n="21.167">But Antinous rebuked him, and spoke, and addressed him: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191375" n="21.168-21.171">Leiodes, what a word has escaped the barrier of <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> teeth, a <sic>dread</sic> word and grievous! <s xml:id="sent2191376" n="21.172-21.173">For, I tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> honored mother did not bear <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> of such strength as to draw a bow and shoot arrows;
</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191378" n="21.175"><milestone ed="p" n="175" unit="line"/>So he spoke, and called to Melanthius, the goatherd:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191379" n="21.176-21.180">Come now, light a fire in the hall, Melanthius; and set by it a great seat with a fleece upon it, and bring forth a great cake of the fat that is within, that we youths may warm the bow, and anoint it with fat, <milestone ed="p" n="180" unit="line"/> and so make trial of it, and end the contest.

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191380" n="21.181-21.183">So he spoke, and Melanthius straightway rekindled the unwearied fire, and brought and placed by it a great seat with a fleece upon it, and he brought forth a great cake of the fat that was within.

<s xml:id="sent2191381" n="21.184">Therewith the youths warmed the bow, and made trial of it, 
</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191383" n="21.186-21.187">Now Antinous was still persisting and godlike Eurymachus, leaders of the wooers,

<s xml:id="sent2191384" n="21.187">who were far the best in valiance; </s>

<s xml:id="sent2191386" n="21.190"><milestone ed="p" n="190" unit="line"/> and after them Odysseus himself went forth from the house.

<s xml:id="sent2191387" n="21.191-21.192">But when they were now outside the gates and the court, he spoke and addressed them with gentle words:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191388" n="21.193-21.194">Neatherd, and <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> too swineherd, shall I tell you something or keep it to myself?

<s xml:id="sent2191389" n="21.194"><sic>Nay</sic>, my spirit <mod n="bids:simpsub">commands</mod> me tell it.

<s xml:id="sent2191390" n="21.195-21.196"><milestone ed="p" n="195" unit="line"/>What manner of men would you be to defend Odysseus, if he should come from somewhere thus suddenly, and some god should bring him?

<s xml:id="sent2191393" n="21.199">Then the herdsmen of the cattle answered him: <milestone ed="p" n="200" unit="line"/>

<s xml:id="sent2191394" n="21.200-21.201">Father Zeus, oh that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='wouldest'>would</mod> fulfil this wish! Grant that that man may come back, and that some god may guide him. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191395" n="21.202">Then <mod n='shouldest'>should</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> know what manner of might is mine, and how my hands obey.

<s xml:id="sent2191396" n="21.203-21.204">And even in like manner did Eumaeus pray to all the gods that wise Odysseus; might come back to his own home.</s></p>

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191397" n="21.205-21.206"><milestone ed="p" n="205" unit="line"/>But when he knew with certainty the mind of these, he made answer, and spoke to them again, saying:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191398" n="21.207-21.208">At home now in truth am I here before you, my very self. After many grievous toils I am come in the twentieth year to my native land.

<s xml:id="sent2191399" n="21.209-21.210">And I know that by you two <milestone ed="p" n="210" unit="line"/> alone of all my thralls is my coming desired,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191401" n="21.212">But to you two will I tell the truth, even as it shall be. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191402" n="21.213-21.215">If a god shall subdue the lordly wooers <mod n="unto:simpsub">to</mod> me, I will bring you each a wife, and will give you possessions <milestone ed="p" n="215" unit="line"/> and a house built near my own, </s>

<s xml:id="sent2191404" n="21.217-21.220"><sic>Nay</sic>, come, more than this, I will <mod n="shew:simpsub">show</mod> you also a manifest sign, that you may know me well and be assured in heart, even the scar of the wound which long ago a boar dealt me with his white tusk, <milestone ed="p" n="220" unit="line"/> when I went to <placeName key="tgn,7011022">Parnassus</placeName> with the sons of Autolycus.

<s xml:id="sent2191405" n="21.221">So saying, he drew aside the rags from the great scar.

<s xml:id="sent2191406" n="21.222-21.225">And when the two had seen it, and had marked each thing well, they flung their arms about wise Odysseus, and wept; and they kissed his head and shoulders in loving welcome. <milestone ed="p" n="225" unit="line"/>And even in like manner Odysseus kissed their heads and hands.

<s xml:id="sent2191407" n="21.226-21.227">And now the light of the sun would have gone down upon their weeping, had not Odysseus himself checked them, and said:

<q>



<s xml:id="sent2191408" n="21.228-21.229">Cease now from weeping and wailing, lest some one come forth from the hall and see us, and make it known within as well.

<s xml:id="sent2191409" n="21.230-21.231"><milestone ed="p" n="230" unit="line"/>But go within one after another, not all together, I first and you thereafter,</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191411" n="21.232-21.233">All the rest, as many as are lordly wooers, will not suffer the bow and the quiver to be given to me;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191412" n="21.234-21.239">but do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod>, <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Eumaeus, as <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='bearest'>bear</mod> the bow through the halls, <milestone ed="p" n="235" unit="line"/> place it in my hands, and <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> the women bar the close-fitting doors of their hall. <s xml:id="sent2191413" n="21.240-21.241"><milestone ed="p" n="240" unit="line"/>But to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Philoetius, do I give charge to fasten with a bar the gate of the court, and swiftly to cast a cord upon it.

<s xml:id="sent2191414" n="21.242">So saying, he entered the stately house,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191416" n="21.244">And the two slaves of divine Odysseus went in as well.

<s xml:id="sent2191417" n="21.245-21.246"><milestone ed="p" n="245" unit="line"/>Eurymachus was now handling the bow, warming it on this side and on that in the light of the fire;</s>


<s xml:id="sent2191418" n="21.246-21.247">but not even so was he able to string it; and in his noble heart he groaned,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191420" n="21.249">Out on it! <mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod> I am grieved for myself and for you all.

<s xml:id="sent2191421" n="21.250"><milestone ed="p" n="250" unit="line"/>It is in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> for the marriage that I mourn so greatly, grieved though I am;</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191423" n="21.253-21.255">but I mourn if in truth we fall so far short of godlike Odysseus in might, seeing that we cannot string <milestone ed="p" n="255" unit="line"/> his bow. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191424" n="21.255">This is a reproach for men that are yet to be to hear of.</s></q></p>

<s xml:id="sent2191425" n="21.256">Then Antinous, son of Eupeithes, answered him:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191426" n="21.257">Eurymachus, this shall not be so,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191433" n="21.263-21.264"><sic>Nay</sic>, come, let the bearer pour drops for libation into the cups, that we may pour libations, and lay aside the curved bow.

<s xml:id="sent2191434" n="21.265-21.268"><milestone ed="p" n="265" unit="line"/>And in the morning <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> Melanthius, the goatherd, to bring she-goats, far the best in all the herds, that we may lay thigh-pieces on the altar of Apollo, the famed archer; and so make trial of the bow, and end the contest.

<s xml:id="sent2191435" n="21.269">So spoke Antinous, and his word was pleasing to them.

<s xml:id="sent2191436" n="21.270-21.272"><milestone ed="p" n="270" unit="line"/>Then the heralds poured water over their hands, and youths filled the bowls brim full of drink, and served out to all, pouring first drops for libation into the cups.

<s xml:id="sent2191438" n="21.275"><milestone ed="p" n="275" unit="line"/>Hear me, wooers of the glorious queen,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191440" n="21.277-21.279">To Eurymachus most of all do I make my prayer, and to godlike Antinous, since this word also of his was spoken aright, namely that for the present you cease to try the bow, and leave the issue with the gods;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191441" n="21.280"><milestone ed="p" n="280" unit="line"/> and in the morning the god will give the victory to <mod n="whomsoever:simpsub">whoever</mod> he will.

<s xml:id="sent2191443" n="21.285-21.286"><milestone ed="p" n="285" unit="line"/>So he spoke, and they all <mod n="waxed:simpsub">became</mod> exceeding <mod n="wroth:simpsub">angry</mod>, fearing lest he might string the polished bow.

<s xml:id="sent2191444" n="21.287">And Antinous rebuked him, and spoke and addressed him:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191445" n="21.288">Ah, wretched stranger, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> no wit, no, not a trace.

<s xml:id="sent2191446" n="21.289-21.291">Art <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> not content <milestone ed="p" n="290" unit="line"/> that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> feastest undisturbed in our proud company, and lackest <mod n="naught:simpsub">nothing</mod> of the banquet, but <mod n='hearest'>hear</mod> our words and our speech,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191448" n="21.293-21.294">It is wine that wounds <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, honey-sweet wine, which works harm to others too, if one takes it in great gulps, and drinks beyond measure.

<s xml:id="sent2191449" n="21.295-21.297"><milestone ed="p" n="295" unit="line"/>It was wine that made foolish even the centaur, glorious Eurytion, in the hall of greathearted Peirithous, when he went to the Lapithae:</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191450" n="21.297-21.298">and when his heart had been made foolish with wine, in his madness he <sic>wrought</sic> evil in the house of Peirithous.

<s xml:id="sent2191451" n="21.299-21.301">Then grief seized the heroes, <milestone ed="p" n="300" unit="line"/> and they leapt up and dragged him forth through the gateway, when they had shorn off his ears and his nostrils with the pitiless bronze,

<s xml:id="sent2191458" n="21.311">Then wise Penelope answered him: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191459" n="21.312-21.313">Antinous, it is not well nor just to rob of their due the guests of Telemachus, whosoever he be that comes to this house.

<s xml:id="sent2191460" n="21.314-21.316">Dost <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> think that, if <sic>yon</sic> stranger <milestone ed="p" n="315" unit="line"/> strings the great bow of Odysseus, trusting in his strength and his might, he will lead me to his home, and make me his wife?

<s xml:id="sent2191461" n="21.317"><sic>Nay</sic>, he himself, I <mod n="ween:simpsub">believe</mod>, has not this hope in his breast;

<s xml:id="sent2191463" n="21.320"><milestone ed="p" n="320" unit="line"/>Then Eurymachus, son of Polybus, answered her:

<s xml:id="sent2191466" n="21.323-21.326">but that we <sic>dread</sic> the talk of men and women, lest hereafter some base fellow among the Achaeans should say: <milestone ed="p" n="325" unit="line"/>

<s xml:id="sent2191467" n="21.327-21.328">But another, a beggar, that came on his wanderings, easily strung the bow, and shot through the iron.’ </s>

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191469" n="21.330"><milestone ed="p" n="330" unit="line"/>Then wise Penelope answered him again: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191470" n="21.331-21.333">Eurymachus, in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> can there be good report in the land for men who dishonor and consume the house of a prince.

<s xml:id="sent2191471" n="21.333">Why then do you make this matter<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> a reproach? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191472" n="21.334-21.335">This stranger is right tall and well-built, <milestone ed="p" n="335" unit="line"/> and declares himself to be born the son of a good father. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191473" n="21.336"><sic>Nay</sic>, come, give him the polished bow and let us see. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191474" n="21.337">For thus will I speak out to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, and this word shall <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> be brought to pass; 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191475" n="21.338-21.341">if he shall string the bow, and Apollo grant him glory, I will clothe him with a cloak and tunic, fair raiment, <milestone ed="p" n="340" unit="line"/> and will give him a sharp javelin to ward off dogs and men, and a two-edged sword;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191476" n="21.341-21.342">and I will give him sandals to bind beneath his feet, and will send him whithersoever his heart and spirit <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> him go.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191477" n="21.343">Then wise Telemachus answered her: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191478" n="21.344-21.347">My mother, as for the bow, no man of the Achaeans <milestone ed="p" n="345" unit="line"/> has a better right than I to give or to deny it to <mod n="whomsoever:simpsub">whoever</mod> I will—no, not all those who lord it in rocky <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName>, or in the islands towards horse-pasturing <placeName key="perseus,Elis">Elis</placeName>. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191479" n="21.348-21.349">No man among these shall thwart me against my will, even though I should wish to give this bow outright to the stranger to bear away with him.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191480" n="21.350-21.352"><milestone ed="p" n="350" unit="line"/>But do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> go <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> chamber, and busy <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod> with <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> own tasks, the loom and the distaff, and <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> handmaids ply their tasks. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191481" n="21.352-21.353">The bow shall be for men, for all, but most of all for me;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191482" n="21.353">since mine is the authority in the house.</s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:21.354-21.400">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191483" n="21.354">She then, seized with wonder, went back to her chamber,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191484" n="21.355"><milestone ed="p" n="355" unit="line"/> for she laid to heart the wise saying of her son. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191485" n="21.356-21.358">Up to her upper chamber she went with her handmaids, and then bewailed Odysseus, her dear husband, until flashing-eyed Athena cast sweet sleep upon her eyelids.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191486" n="21.359">Now the goodly swineherd had taken the curved bow and was bearing it,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191487" n="21.360"><milestone ed="p" n="360" unit="line"/> but the wooers all cried out in the halls. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191488" n="21.361">And thus would one of the proud youths speak:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191489" n="21.362-21.363"><mod n="Whither:simpsub">Where</mod>, pray, <corr n="art thou">are you</corr> bearing the curved bow, miserable swineherd, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> man distraught? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191490" n="21.363-21.365">Soon by <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> swine, alone and apart from men, shall the swift hounds devour thee—hounds <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod> <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> rear—if but Apollo <milestone ed="p" n="365" unit="line"/> be gracious to us, and the other immortal gods.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191491" n="21.366-21.367">So they spoke, and he set down the bow, as he bore it, in that very place, seized with fear because many men were crying out aloud in the halls. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191492" n="21.368">But Telemachus on the other side called out threateningly:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191493" n="21.369">Father, bear the bow onward—

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191494" n="21.369-21.371">soon <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> rue giving heed to all— <milestone ed="p" n="370" unit="line"/> lest, younger though I am, I drive <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> to the field, and pelt <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> with stones;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191495" n="21.371">for in strength I am the better. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191496" n="21.372-21.373">I would that I were even so much better in strength and might than all the wooers that are in the house;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191497" n="21.374-21.375">then would I soon send many a one <milestone ed="p" n="375" unit="line"/> forth from our house to go his way in evil case; for they devise wickedness.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191498" n="21.376-21.378">So he spoke, but all the wooers laughed merrily at him, and relaxed the bitterness of their anger against Telemachus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191499" n="21.378-21.379"><mod n="Howbeit:simpsub">However</mod> the swineherd bore the bow through the hall, and came up to wise Odysseus, and put it in his hands.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191500" n="21.380"><milestone ed="p" n="380" unit="line"/>Then he called forth the nurse Eurycleia, and said to her:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191501" n="21.381-21.382">Telemachus <mod n="bids:simpsub">commands</mod> <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, wise Eurycleia, to bar the close-fitting doors of the hall,</s>


<s xml:id="sent2191502" n="21.383-21.385">and if any of the women hear within groanings or the din of men within our walls, let them not <milestone ed="p" n="385" unit="line"/> rush out, but remain where they are in silence at their work.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191503" n="21.386-21.387">So he spoke, but her word remained unwinged; and she barred the doors of the stately halls. 


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191504" n="21.388-21.389">But in silence Philoetius hastened forth from the house, and barred the gates of the well-fenced court.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191505" n="21.390-21.391"><milestone ed="p" n="390" unit="line"/>Now there lay beneath the portico the cable of a curved ship, made of byblus plant, wherewith he made fast the gates, and then himself went within. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191506" n="21.392-21.393">Thereafter he came and sat down on the seat from which he had risen, and gazed upon Odysseus;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191507" n="21.393-21.395">now he was already handling the bow, turning it round and round, and trying it this way and that, <milestone ed="p" n="395" unit="line"/> lest worms might have eaten the horns, while its lord was afar. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191508" n="21.396">And thus would one speak with a glance at his neighbor:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191509" n="21.397"><mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod> he has a shrewd eye, and is a cunning knave with a bow. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191510" n="21.398-21.400">It may be <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> that he has himself such bows stored away at home, or else he is minded to make one, that he thus <milestone ed="p" n="400" unit="line"/> turns it this way and that in his hands, the rascally vagabond.</s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:21.401-21.434">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191511" n="21.401">And again another of the proud youths would say: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191512" n="21.402-21.403">Would that the fellow might find profit in just such measure as he shall prove able ever to string this bow.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191513" n="21.404">So spoke the wooers,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191514" n="21.404-21.409">but Odysseus of many wiles, <milestone ed="p" n="405" unit="line"/> as soon as he had lifted the great bow and scanned it on every side—even as when a man well-skilled in the lyre and in song easily stretches the string about a new peg, making fast at either end the twisted sheep-gut—so without effort did Odysseus string the great bow.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191515" n="21.410"><milestone ed="p" n="410" unit="line"/>And he held it in his right hand, and tried the string,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191516" n="21.411">which sang sweetly beneath his touch, like to a swallow in tone. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191517" n="21.412-21.413">But upon the wooers came great grief, and the faces of them changed color,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191518" n="21.413">and Zeus thundered loud, shewing forth his signs. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191519" n="21.414">Then glad at heart was the much-enduring, <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191520" n="21.415"><milestone ed="p" n="415" unit="line"/> that the son of crooked-counselling Cronos sent him an omen,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191521" n="21.416-21.417">and he took up a swift arrow, which lay by him on the table, bare,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191522" n="21.417-21.418">but the others were stored within the hollow quiver, even those of which the Achaeans were soon to taste. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191523" n="21.419-21.423">This he took, and laid upon the bridge of the bow, and drew the bow-string and the notched arrow <milestone ed="p" n="420" unit="line"/> even from the chair where he sat, and let fly the shaft with sure aim, and did not miss the end of the handle of one of the axes, but clean through and out at the end passed the arrow weighted with bronze. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191524" n="21.423">But he spoke to Telemachus, saying:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191525" n="21.424-21.426">Telemachus, the stranger <milestone ed="p" n="425" unit="line"/> that sits in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> halls brings no shame upon <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, nor in any wise did I miss the mark, or labour long in stringing the bow;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191526" n="21.426-21.427">still is my strength unbroken—not as the wooers scornfully taunt me. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191527" n="21.428-21.430">But now it is time that supper too be made ready for the Achaeans, while yet there is light, and thereafter must yet other sport be made <milestone ed="p" n="430" unit="line"/> with song and with the lyre;</s>


<s xml:id="sent2191528" n="21.430">for these things are the accompaniments of a feast.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191529" n="21.431">He spoke, and made a sign with his brows,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191530" n="21.431-21.434">and Telemachus, the dear son of divine Odysseus, girt about him his sharp sword, and took his spear in his grasp, and stood by the chair at his father's side, armed with gleaming bronze.</s></p>
</div>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="book" n="22">
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:22.1-22.41">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191531" n="22.1-22.4"><milestone ed="p" n="1" unit="line"/>But Odysseus of many wiles stripped off his rags and sprang to the great threshold with the bow and the quiver full of arrows, and poured forth the swift arrows right there before his feet, and spoke among the wooers:





</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191532" n="22.5"><milestone ed="p" n="5" unit="line"/><sic>Lo</sic>, now at last is this decisive contest ended;</s>


<s xml:id="sent2191533" n="22.6-22.7">and now as for another mark, which till now no man has ever <mod n="smitten:simpsub">struck</mod>, I will know<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> if <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> I may strike it, and Apollo grant me glory.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191534" n="22.8">He spoke, and aimed a bitter arrow at Antinous. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191535" n="22.9-22.11">Now he was on the point of raising to his lips a fair goblet, <milestone ed="p" n="10" unit="line"/> a two-eared cup of gold, and was even now handling it, that he might drink of the wine,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191536" n="22.11-22.12">and death was not in his thoughts. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191537" n="22.12-22.14">For who among men that sat at meat could think that one man among many, how strong soever he were, would bring upon himself evil death and black fate?

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191538" n="22.15-22.16"><milestone ed="p" n="15" unit="line"/>But Odysseus took aim, and <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> him with an arrow in the throat, and clean out through the tender neck passed the point;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191539" n="22.17-22.19">he sank to one side, and the cup fell from his hand as he was <mod n="smitten:simpsub">struck</mod>, and straightway up through his nostrils there came a thick jet of the blood of man; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2191540" n="22.19-22.20">and quickly <milestone ed="p" n="20" unit="line"/> he thrust the table from him with a kick of his foot, and spilled all the food on the floor,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191541" n="22.21">and the bread and roast flesh were befouled. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191542" n="22.21-22.24">Then into uproar broke the wooers through the halls, as they saw the man fallen, and from their high seats they sprang, driven in fear through the hall, gazing everywhere along the well-built walls;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191543" n="22.25"><milestone ed="p" n="25" unit="line"/> but nowhere was there a shield or mighty spear to seize. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191544" n="22.26">But they railed at Odysseus with angry words:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191545" n="22.27">Stranger, to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> cost <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> shoot at men;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191546" n="22.27-22.28">never again <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> take part in other contests;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191547" n="22.28">now is <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> utter destruction sure. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191548" n="22.29-22.30">Aye, for <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> now slain a man who was far the best <milestone ed="p" n="30" unit="line"/> of the youths in <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName>;</s>


<s xml:id="sent2191549" n="22.30">therefore shall vultures devour <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> here.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191550" n="22.31-22.32">So spoke<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> each man, for <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> they thought that he had not slain the man willfully;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191551" n="22.32-22.33">and in their folly they knew not this, that over themselves one and all the cords of destruction had been made fast. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191552" n="22.34">Then with an angry glance from beneath his brows Odysseus of many wiles answered them:





</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191553" n="22.35-22.40"><milestone ed="p" n="35" unit="line"/><mod n="Ye:simpsub">You</mod> dogs, <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> thought that I should never more come home from the land of the Trojans, seeing that <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> wasted my house, and lay with the maidservants by force, and while yet I lived covertly wooed my wife, having no fear of the gods, who hold broad heaven, <milestone ed="p" n="40" unit="line"/> nor of the indignation of men, that is to be hereafter. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191554" n="22.41">Now over you one and all have the cords of destruction been made fast.</s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:22.42-22.78">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191555" n="22.42">So he spoke, and <sic>thereat</sic><note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">2</note> pale fear seized them all,</s>


<s xml:id="sent2191556" n="22.43">and each man gazed about to see how he might escape utter destruction;</s>


<s xml:id="sent2191557" n="22.44">Eurymachus alone answered him, and said:





</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191558" n="22.45-22.47"><milestone ed="p" n="45" unit="line"/>If <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> indeed Odysseus of <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName>, come home again, this that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='sayest'>say</mod> is just regarding all that the Achaeans have wrought—many deeds of wanton folly in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> halls and many in the field. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191559" n="22.48-22.49">But he now lies dead, who was to blame for all, even Antinous; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2191560" n="22.49-22.53">for it was he who set on foot these deeds, <milestone ed="p" n="50" unit="line"/> not so much through desire or need of the marriage, but with another purpose, which the son of Cronos did not bring to pass for him, that in the land of settled <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName> he might himself be king, and might lie in wait for <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> son and <mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod> him. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191561" n="22.54-22.55">But now he lies slain, <milestone ed="p" n="55" unit="line"/> as was his due, but do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> spare the people


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191562" n="22.55-22.59">that are <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> own; and we will hereafter go about the land and get <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> recompense for all that has been drunk and eaten in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> halls, and will bring each man for himself in requital the worth of twenty oxen, and pay <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> back in bronze and gold until <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> heart be warmed;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191563" n="22.59">but till then no one could blame <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> that <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> <mod n="wroth:simpsub">angry</mod>.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191564" n="22.60"><milestone ed="p" n="60" unit="line"/>Then with an angry glance from beneath his brows Odysseus of many wiles answered him: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191565" n="22.61-22.64">Eurymachus, not even if you should give me in requital all that your fathers left you, even all that you now have, and should add other wealth <sic>thereto</sic> from whence <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> might, not even so would I henceforth stay my hands from slaying until the wooers had paid the full price of all their transgression.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191566" n="22.65-22.66"><milestone ed="p" n="65" unit="line"/>Now it lies before you to fight in open fight, or to flee, if any man may avoid death and the fates;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191567" n="22.67">but many a one, methinks, shall not escape from utter destruction.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191568" n="22.68">So he spoke, and their knees were loosened where they stood, and their hearts melted;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191569" n="22.69">and Eurymachus spoke among them again a second time:





</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191570" n="22.70-22.73"><milestone ed="p" n="70" unit="line"/>Friends, for you see that this man will not stay his invincible hands, but now that he was got the polished bow and the quiver, will shoot from the smooth threshold until he slays us all, come,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191571" n="22.73">let us take thought of battle. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191572" n="22.74-22.75">Draw your swords, and hold the tables before you against <milestone ed="p" n="75" unit="line"/> the arrows that bring swift death,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191573" n="22.75-22.77">and let us all have at him in a body, in the hope that we may thrust him from the threshold and the doorway, and go throughout the city, and so the alarm be swiftly raised;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191574" n="22.78">then should this fellow soon have shot his last.</s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:22.79-22.125">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191575" n="22.79-22.81">So saying, he drew his sharp sword <milestone ed="p" n="80" unit="line"/> of bronze, two-edged, and sprang upon Odysseus with a terrible cry,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191576" n="22.81-22.83">but at the same instant <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus let fly an arrow, and struck him upon the breast beside the nipple, and fixed the swift shaft in his liver. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191577" n="22.83-22.86">And Eurymachus let the sword fall from his hand to the ground, and writhing over the table <milestone ed="p" n="85" unit="line"/> he bowed and fell, and spilt upon the floor the food and the two-handled cup. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191578" n="22.86-22.88">With his brow he beat the earth in agony of soul, and with both his feet he spurned and shook the chair,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191579" n="22.88">Then and a mist was shed over his eyes.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191580" n="22.89-22.91">Then Amphinomus made at glorious Odysseus, <milestone ed="p" n="90" unit="line"/> rushing straight upon him, and had drawn his sharp sword, in hope that Odysseus might give way before him from the door. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191581" n="22.91-22.93">But Telemachus was too quick for him, and cast, and <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> him from behind with his bronze-tipped spear between the shoulders, and drove it through his breast;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191582" n="22.94">and he fell with a thud, and struck the ground full with his forehead.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191583" n="22.95-22.96"><milestone ed="p" n="95" unit="line"/>But Telemachus sprang back, leaving the long spear where it was, fixed in Amphinomus,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191584" n="22.96-22.98">for he greatly feared lest, as he sought to draw forth the long spear, one of the Achaeans might rush upon him and stab with his sword, or deal him a blow as he stooped over the corpse. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191585" n="22.99-22.100">So he started to run, and came quickly to his dear father, <milestone ed="p" n="100" unit="line"/> and standing by his side spoke to him winged words: 


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191586" n="22.101-22.104">Father, now will I bring <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> a shield and two spears and a helmet all of bronze, well fitted to the temples, and when I come back I will arm myself, and will give armour likewise to the swineherd and <sic>yon</sic> neatherd;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191587" n="22.104">for it is better to be clothed in armour.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191588" n="22.105"><milestone ed="p" n="105" unit="line"/>Then Odysseus of many wiles answered him and said: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191589" n="22.106-22.107">Run, and bring them, while yet I have arrows to defend me, lest they thrust me from the door, alone as I am.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191590" n="22.108-22.109">So he spoke, and Telemachus <mod n="hearkened:simpsub">listened</mod> to his dear father, and went his way to the store-chamber where the glorious arms were stored.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191591" n="22.110-22.111"><milestone ed="p" n="110" unit="line"/>Thence he took four shields and eight spears and four helmets of bronze, with thick plumes of horse-hair;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191592" n="22.112-22.113">and he bore them forth, and quickly came to his dear father. Then first of all he himself girded the bronze about his body,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191593" n="22.114-22.115">and even in like manner the two slaves put on them the beautiful armour, <milestone ed="p" n="115" unit="line"/> and took their stand on either side of Odysseus, the wise and crafty-minded.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191594" n="22.116">But he, so long as he had arrows to defend him,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191595" n="22.117-22.118">would ever aim, and <mod n="smite:simpsub">strike</mod> the wooers one by one in his house,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191596" n="22.118">and they fell thick and fast. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191597" n="22.119-22.124">But when the arrows failed the prince, as he shot, <milestone ed="p" n="120" unit="line"/> he leaned the bow against the door-post of the well-built hall, and let it stand against the bright entrance wall. For himself, he put about his shoulders a four-fold shield, and set on his mighty head a well-wrought helmet with horse-hair plume, and terribly did the plume wave above him;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191598" n="22.125"><milestone ed="p" n="125" unit="line"/> and he took two mighty spears, tipped with bronze.</s></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:22.126-22.169">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191599" n="22.126-22.128">Now there was in the well-built wall a certain postern door,<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> and along the topmost level of the threshold of the well-built hall was a way into a passage, and well-fitting folding doors closed it. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191600" n="22.129-22.130">This postern Odysseus <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> the goodly swineherd watch, <milestone ed="p" n="130" unit="line"/> taking his stand close by,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191601" n="22.130">for there was but a single way to reach it. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191602" n="22.131">Then Agelaus spoke among the wooers, and declared his word to all:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191603" n="22.132-22.133">Friends, will not one mount up by the postern door, and tell the people, that so an alarm may be raised straightway? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191604" n="22.134">Then should this fellow soon have shot his last.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191605" n="22.135"><milestone ed="p" n="135" unit="line"/>Then Melanthius, the goatherd, answered him: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191606" n="22.136">It may not be, Agelaus, fostered of Zeus,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191607" n="22.136-22.137">for terribly near is the fair door of the court, and the mouth of the passage is hard. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191608" n="22.138">One man could bar the way for all, so he were valiant. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191609" n="22.139-22.140">But come, let me bring you <milestone ed="p" n="140" unit="line"/> from the store-room arms to don,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191610" n="22.140-22.141">for it is within, methinks, and nowhere else that Odysseus and his glorious son have laid the arms.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191611" n="22.142-22.143">So saying, Melanthius, the goatherd, mounted up by the steps<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">2</note> of the hall to the store-rooms of Odysseus. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191612" n="22.144-22.145">Thence he took twelve shields, as many spears, <milestone ed="p" n="145" unit="line"/> and as many helmets of bronze with thick plumes of horsehair,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191613" n="22.146">and went his way, and quickly brought and gave them to the wooers. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191614" n="22.147-22.149">Then the knees of Odysseus were loosened and his heart melted, when he saw them donning armour and brandishing long spears in their hands,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191615" n="22.149">and great did his task seem to him;

</s>


<s xml:id="sent2191616" n="22.150"><milestone ed="p" n="150" unit="line"/> but quickly he spoke to Telemachus winged words:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191617" n="22.151-22.152">Telemachus, <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> some one of the women in the halls is rousing against us an evil battle, or <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> it is Melanthius.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191618" n="22.153">Then wise Telemachus answered him: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191619" n="22.154-22.156">Father, it is I myself that am at fault in this, and no other <milestone ed="p" n="155" unit="line"/> is to blame, for I left the close-fitting door of the store-room open:</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191620" n="22.156">their watcher was better than I. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191621" n="22.157-22.159">But go now, <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Eumaeus, close the door of the store-room, and see whether it is one of the women who does this, or Melanthius, son of Dolius, as I suspect.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191622" n="22.160-22.162"><milestone ed="p" n="160" unit="line"/>Thus they spoke to one another. But Melanthius, the goatherd, went again to the store-room to bring beautiful armour;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191623" n="22.162-22.163"><mod n="howbeit:simpsub">however</mod> the goodly swineherd marked him, and straightway said to Odysseus who was near:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191624" n="22.164-22.166">Son of Laertes, sprung from Zeus, Odysseus of many devices, <milestone ed="p" n="165" unit="line"/> <sic>yonder</sic> again is the pestilent fellow, whom we ourselves suspect, going to the store-room. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191625" n="22.166-22.169">But do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> tell me truly, shall I <mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod> him, if I prove the better man, or shall I bring him <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod> to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, that the fellow may pay for the many crimes that he has planned in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> house?</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:22.170-22.209">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191626" n="22.170"><milestone ed="p" n="170" unit="line"/>Then Odysseus of many wiles answered him and said: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191627" n="22.171-22.172"><mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod> I and Telemachus will keep the lordly wooers within the hall, how fierce soever they be,</s>

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191629" n="22.178-22.179">So he spoke, and they readily <mod n="hearkened:simpsub">listened</mod> and obeyed. Forth they went to the store-room, unseen of him who was within.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191630" n="22.180-22.181"><milestone ed="p" n="180" unit="line"/>He truly was seeking for armour in the innermost part of the store-room, and the two lay in wait, standing on either side of the door-posts. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191631" n="22.182-22.185">And when Melanthius, the goatherd, was about to pass over the threshold, bearing in one hand a goodly helm, and in the other a broad old shield, flecked with rust— <milestone ed="p" n="185" unit="line"/> the shield of lord Laertes, which he was <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to bear in his youth,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191633" n="22.187-22.191">then the two sprang upon him and seized him. They dragged him in by the hair, and flung him down on the ground in <sic>sore</sic> terror, and bound his feet and hands with galling bonds, <milestone ed="p" n="190" unit="line"/> binding them firmly behind his back, as the son of Laertes <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> them, the much enduring, <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191634" n="22.192-22.193">and they made fast to his body a twisted rope, and hoisted him up the tall pillar, till they brought him near the roof-beams. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191635" n="22.194">Then <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> mock him, swineherd Eumaeus, and say:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191636" n="22.195-22.196"><milestone ed="p" n="195" unit="line"/>Now <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod>, Melanthius, <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> watch the whole night through, lying on a soft bed, as befits <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>,</s>


<s xml:id="sent2191637" n="22.197-22.199">nor <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> fail to mark the early Dawn, golden-throned, as she comes forth from the streams of Oceanus, at the hour when <corr n="thou art">you are</corr> <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to drive <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> she-goats for the wooers, to prepare a feast in the halls.

<s xml:id="sent2191638" n="22.200"><milestone ed="p" n="200" unit="line"/>So he was left there, stretched in the direful bond,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191639" n="22.201-22.202">but the two put on their armour, and closed the bright door, and went to Odysseus, the wise and crafty-minded.

<s xml:id="sent2191640" n="22.203-22.204">There they stood, breathing fury, those on the threshold but four, while those within the hall were many and brave.

<s xml:id="sent2191641" n="22.205-22.206"><milestone ed="p" n="205" unit="line"/>Then Athena, daughter of Zeus, drew near them, <corr n="like unto">like</corr> Mentor in form and voice,</s>

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191643" n="22.208-22.209">Mentor, ward off ruin, and remember me, <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> dear comrade, who often befriended <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191644" n="22.209">Thou art of like age with myself.</s></q></p>

<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191645" n="22.210"><milestone ed="p" n="210" unit="line"/>So he spoke, deeming that it was Athena, the rouser of hosts.

<s xml:id="sent2191646" n="22.211">But the wooers on the other side shouted aloud in the hall,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191647" n="22.212">and first Agelaus, son of Damastor, rebuked Athena, saying:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191648" n="22.213-22.214">Mentor, let not Odysseus beguile <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> with his words to fight against the wooers and bear aid to himself.

<s xml:id="sent2191649" n="22.215"><milestone ed="p" n="215" unit="line"/>For in <corr n="this wise">this way</corr>, methinks, shall our will be brought to pass:
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191650" n="22.216-22.218">when we have killed these men, father and son, thereafter <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> too be slain with them, such deeds <corr n="art thou">are you</corr> minded to do in these halls:
</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191652" n="22.219-22.221">But when with the sword we have stripped you of your might, <milestone ed="p" n="220" unit="line"/> all the possessions that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> within doors and in the fields we will mingle with those of Odysseus,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191654" n="22.224-22.225">So he spoke, and Athena <mod n="waxed:simpsub">became</mod> the more <mod n="wroth:simpsub">angry</mod> at heart, <milestone ed="p" n="225" unit="line"/> and she rebuked Odysseus with angry words:

<s xml:id="sent2191655" n="22.226-22.230">Odysseus, no longer <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> steadfast might nor any valor, such as was <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> when for high-born Helen of the white arms <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> for nine years battle with the Trojans unceasingly, and many men <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='slewest'>slew</mod> in <sic>dread</sic> conflict, <milestone ed="p" n="230" unit="line"/> and by <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> counsel was the broad-wayed city of Priam taken.

<s xml:id="sent2191656" n="22.231-22.232">How is it that now, when <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> come to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> house and <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> own possessions, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> shrinkest with wailing from playing the man, and that against the wooers?

<s xml:id="sent2191657" n="22.233-22.235"><sic>Nay</sic>, friend, come <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod> and take <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> stand by my side, and see my deeds, that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='mayest'>may</mod> know what manner of man <milestone ed="p" n="235" unit="line"/>Mentor, son of Alcimus, is to repay kindness in the midst of the foe.

<s xml:id="sent2191658" n="22.236-22.238">She spoke, but did not give him strength utterly to turn the course of the battle, but still made trial of the might and valor of Odysseus and his glorious son;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191659" n="22.239-22.240">and for herself, <milestone ed="p" n="240" unit="line"/> she flew up to the roof-beam of the smoky hall, and sat there in the guise of a swallow to look upon.

<s xml:id="sent2191660" n="22.241-22.243">Now the wooers were urged on by Agelaus, son of Damastor, by Eurynomus, and Amphimedon and Demoptolemus and Peisander, son of Polyctor, and wise Polybus,</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191663" n="22.247">But Agelaus spoke among them, and declared his word to all:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191664" n="22.248">Friends, now at length will this man stay his invincible hands. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191665" n="22.249-22.250"><sic>Lo</sic>, Mentor has gone from him, and has but uttered empty boasts, <milestone ed="p" n="250" unit="line"/> and they are left alone there at the outer doors. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191666" n="22.251-22.253">Therefore hurl not now upon them your long spears all at once, but come, do you six throw first in the hope that Zeus may grant that Odysseus be struck, and that we win glory. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191667" n="22.254">Of the rest there is no care, once he shall have fallen.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:22.255-22.291">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191668" n="22.255-22.256"><milestone ed="p" n="255" unit="line"/>So he spoke, and they all hurled their spears, as he <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod>, eagerly;

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191671" n="22.260-22.261"><milestone ed="p" n="260" unit="line"/>But when they had avoided the spears of the wooers, first among them spoke the much-enduring <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus:

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191672" n="22.262-22.264">Friends, now I give the word that we too cast our spears into the throng of the wooers, who are minded to <mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod> us in addition to their former wrongs.

<s xml:id="sent2191679" n="22.274-22.275">One man <milestone ed="p" n="275" unit="line"/> <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> the door-post of the well-built hall, another the close-fitting door,</s>

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191688" n="22.290-22.291"><milestone ed="p" n="290" unit="line"/>This is <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> gift of welcome to match the hoof which of late <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='gavest'>gave</mod> to godlike Odysseus, when he went begging through the house.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:22.292-22.329">

<s xml:id="sent2191690" n="22.292-22.293">But Odysseus wounded the son of Damastor in close fight with a thrust of his long spear,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191693" n="22.297-22.298">Then Athena held up her aegis, the bane of mortals, on high from the roof,</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191696" n="22.300-22.301"><milestone ed="p" n="300" unit="line"/> that the darting gad-fly falls upon and drives along in the season of spring, when the long days come. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191697" n="22.302-22.303">And even as vultures of crooked talons and curved beaks come forth from the mountains and dart upon smaller birds, 
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191698" n="22.304-22.306">which scour the plain, flying low beneath the clouds, <milestone ed="p" n="305" unit="line"/> and the vultures pounce upon them and <mod n="slay:simpsub">kill</mod> them, and they have no defence or way of escape,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191699" n="22.306">and men rejoice at the chase; </s>



<s xml:id="sent2191700" n="22.307-22.308">even so did those others set upon the wooers and <mod n="smite:simpsub">strike</mod> them left and right through the hall. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191701" n="22.308-22.309">And therefrom rose hideous groaning as heads were <mod n="smitten:simpsub">struck</mod>, and all the floor swam with blood.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191702" n="22.310-22.311"><milestone ed="p" n="310" unit="line"/>But Leiodes rushed forward and clasped the knees of Odysseus, and made entreaty to him, and spoke winged words: 


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191703" n="22.312">By <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> knees I beseech <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, Odysseus,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191704" n="22.312">and do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> respect me and have pity. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191705" n="22.313-22.314">For I declare to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> that never yet have I wronged one of the women in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> halls by wanton word or deed;
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191706" n="22.314-22.315"><sic>nay</sic>, <milestone ed="p" n="315" unit="line"/>I sought to check the other wooers, when any would do such deeds. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191707" n="22.316">But they would not <mod n="hearken:simpsub">listen</mod> to me to withhold their hands from evil,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191708" n="22.317"><mod n="wherefore:simpsub">for which reason</mod> through their wanton folly they have met a cruel doom. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191709" n="22.318-22.319">Yet I, the soothsayer among them, that have done no wrong, shall be laid low even as they; so true is it that there is no gratitude in aftertime for good deeds done.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191710" n="22.320"><milestone ed="p" n="320" unit="line"/>Then with an angry glance from beneath his brows Odysseus of many wiles answered him: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191711" n="22.321-22.324">If <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> declare <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod> the soothsayer among these men, often, I <mod n="ween:simpsub">believe</mod>, must <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> have prayed in the halls that far from me the issue of a joyous return might be removed, and that it might be with <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> that my dear wife should go and bear <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> children;

</s>


<s xml:id="sent2191712" n="22.325"><milestone ed="p" n="325" unit="line"/> <mod n="wherefore:simpsub">for which reason</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> not escape grievous death.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191713" n="22.326-22.328">So saying, he seized in his strong hand a sword that lay near, which Agelaus had let fall to the ground when he was slain,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191714" n="22.328">and with this he <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> him full upon the neck. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191715" n="22.329">And even while he was yet speaking his head was mingled with the dust.</s></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:22.330-22.377">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191716" n="22.330-22.331"><milestone ed="p" n="330" unit="line"/>Now the son of Terpes, the minstrel, was still seeking to escape black fate, even Phemius, who sang perforce among the wooers. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191717" n="22.332-22.333">He stood with the clear-toned lyre in his hands near the postern door,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191718" n="22.333-22.337">and he was divided in mind whether he should slip out from the hall <milestone ed="p" n="335" unit="line"/> and sit down by the well-built altar of great Zeus, the God of the court, <mod n="whereon:simpsub">on which</mod> Laertes and Odysseus had burned many things of oxen, or whether he should rush forward and clasp the knees of Odysseus in prayer. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191719" n="22.338-22.339">And as he pondered this seemed to him the better course, to clasp the knees of Odysseus, son of Laertes.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191720" n="22.340-22.343"><milestone ed="p" n="340" unit="line"/>So he laid the hollow lyre on the ground between the mixing-bowl and the silver-studded chair, and himself rushed forward and clasped Odysseus by the knees, and made entreaty to him, and spoke winged words:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191721" n="22.344">By <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> knees I beseech <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, Odysseus,</s>


<s xml:id="sent2191722" n="22.344">and do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> respect me and have pity;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191723" n="22.345-22.346"><milestone ed="p" n="345" unit="line"/> on <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> own self shall sorrow come hereafter, if <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='slayest'>kill</mod> the minstrel, even me, who sing to gods and men. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191724" n="22.347-22.348">Self-taught am I, and the god has planted in my heart all manner of lays,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191725" n="22.348-22.349">and worthy am I to sing to <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> as to a god;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191726" n="22.349"><mod n="wherefore:simpsub">for which reason</mod> be not eager to cut my throat.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191727" n="22.350-22.353"><milestone ed="p" n="350" unit="line"/>Aye, and Telemachus too will bear witness to this, <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> dear son, how that through no will or desire of mine I was <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to resort to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> house to sing to the wooers at their feasts, but they, being far more and stronger, led me <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod> perforce.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191728" n="22.354-22.355">So he spoke, and the strong and mighty Telemachus heard him, <milestone ed="p" n="355" unit="line"/> and quickly spoke to his father, who was near:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191729" n="22.356">Stay <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> hand, and do not wound this guiltless man with the sword. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191730" n="22.357-22.360">Aye, and let us save also the herald, Medon, who ever cared for me in our house, when I was a child—unless <mod n="perchance:simpsub">perchance</mod> Philoetius has already slain him, or the swineherd, <milestone ed="p" n="360" unit="line"/> or he met <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> as <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> rage through the house.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191731" n="22.361">So he spoke, and Medon, wise of heart, heard him,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191732" n="22.362-22.363">for he lay crouching beneath a chair, and had clothed himself in the skin of an ox, newly flayed, seeking to avoid black fate. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191733" n="22.364-22.366">Straightway he rose from beneath the chair and stripped off the ox-hide, <milestone ed="p" n="365" unit="line"/> and then rushed forward and clasped Telemachus by the knees, and made entreaty to him, and spoke winged words: 


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191734" n="22.367-22.370">Friend, here I am; stay <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> hand and <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> father stay his, lest in the greatness of his might he harm me with the sharp bronze in his wrath against the wooers, who wasted his <milestone ed="p" n="370" unit="line"/> possessions in the halls, and in their folly honored <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> not at all.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191735" n="22.371">But Odysseus of many wiles smiled, and said to him: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191736" n="22.372-22.374">Be of good cheer, for he has delivered <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> and saved <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='mayest'>may</mod> know in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> heart and tell also to another, how far better is the doing of good deeds than of evil.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191737" n="22.375-22.377"><milestone ed="p" n="375" unit="line"/>But go forth from the halls and sit down outside in the court away from the slaughter, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> and the minstrel of many songs, till I shall have finished all that I must needs do in the house.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:22.378-22.429">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191738" n="22.378-22.380">So he spoke, and the two went their way forth from the hall and sat down by the altar of great Zeus, <milestone ed="p" n="380" unit="line"/> gazing about on every side, ever expecting death. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191739" n="22.381-22.382">And Odysseus too gazed about all through his house to see if any man yet lived, and was hiding there, seeking to avoid black fate. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191740" n="22.383-22.386">But he found them one and all fallen in the blood and dust—all the host of them, like fishes that fishermen <milestone ed="p" n="385" unit="line"/> have drawn forth in the meshes of their net from the grey sea upon the curving beach,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191741" n="22.386-22.387">and they all lie heaped upon the sand, longing for the waves of the sea,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191742" n="22.388">and the bright sun takes away their life;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191743" n="22.389">even so now the wooers lay heaped upon each other.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191744" n="22.390"><milestone ed="p" n="390" unit="line"/>Then Odysseus of many wiles spoke to Telemachus:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191745" n="22.391-22.392">Telemachus, go call me the nurse Eurycleia, that I may tell her the word that is in my mind.

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191746" n="22.393-22.394">So he spoke, and Telemachus <mod n="hearkened:simpsub">listened</mod> to his dear father, and shaking the door said to Eurycleia:





</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191747" n="22.395-22.396"><milestone ed="p" n="395" unit="line"/>Up and <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod>, aged wife, that <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> charge of all our woman servants in the halls. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191748" n="22.397">Come,</s>

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191750" n="22.398-22.400">So he spoke, but her word remained unwinged; she opened the doors of the stately hall, <milestone ed="p" n="400" unit="line"/> and came forth,</s>


<s xml:id="sent2191751" n="22.400">and Telemachus led the way before her. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191752" n="22.401-22.403">There she found Odysseus <mod n="amid:simpsub">among</mod> the bodies of the slain, all befouled with blood and filth, like a lion that comes from feeding on an ox of the farmstead,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191753" n="22.404-22.405">and all his breast and his cheeks on either side <milestone ed="p" n="405" unit="line"/> are stained with blood, and he is terrible to look upon;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191754" n="22.406">even so was Odysseus befouled, his feet and his hands above. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191755" n="22.407-22.408">But she, when she beheld the corpses and the great welter of blood, made ready to utter loud cries of joy, seeing what a deed had been <sic>wrought</sic>. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191756" n="22.409-22.410">But Odysseus stayed and checked her in her eagerness, <milestone ed="p" n="410" unit="line"/> and spoke and addressed her with winged words:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191757" n="22.411">In <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> own heart rejoice, old dame, but refrain <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod> and cry not out aloud:</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191758" n="22.412">an unholy thing is it to boast over slain men. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191759" n="22.413">These men here has the fate of the gods destroyed and their own reckless deeds,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191760" n="22.414-22.415">for they honored no one of men upon the earth, <milestone ed="p" n="415" unit="line"/> were he evil or good, whosoever came among them;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191761" n="22.416"><mod n="wherefore:simpsub">for which reason</mod> by their wanton folly they brought on themselves a shameful death. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191762" n="22.417-22.418">But come, name <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> over to me the women in the halls, which ones dishonor me and which are guiltless.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191763" n="22.419">Then the dear nurse Eurycleia answered him:




</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191764" n="22.420"><milestone ed="p" n="420" unit="line"/>Then <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod>, my child, will I tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> all the truth. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191765" n="22.421-22.423">Fifty women servants <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> in the halls, women that we have taught to do their work, to card the wool and bear the lot of slaves. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191766" n="22.424-22.425">Of these twelve in all have set their feet in the way of shamelessness, <milestone ed="p" n="425" unit="line"/> and regard not me nor Penelope herself. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191767" n="22.426-22.427">And Telemachus is but newly grown to manhood, and his mother would not suffer him to rule over the women servants. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191768" n="22.428-22.429">But come, let me go up to the bright upper chamber and bear word to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> wife, on whom some god has sent sleep.</s></q></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:22.430-22.464">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191769" n="22.430-22.431"><milestone ed="p" n="430" unit="line"/>Then Odysseus of many wiles answered her, and said: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191770" n="22.431-22.432">Wake her not yet, but do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> come <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod> the women, who in time past have contrived shameful deeds.

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191771" n="22.433-22.434">So he spoke, and the old dame went forth through the hall to bear tidings to the women, and <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> them come;
</s>


<s xml:id="sent2191772" n="22.435-22.436"><milestone ed="p" n="435" unit="line"/> but Odysseus called to him Telemachus and the neatherd and the swineherd, and spoke to them winged words:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191773" n="22.437">Begin now to bear forth the dead bodies and <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> the women help you,</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191775" n="22.440-22.445"><milestone ed="p" n="440" unit="line"/>But when you have set all the house in order, lead the women forth from the well-built hall to a place between the dome<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> and the goodly fence of the court, and there strike them down with your long swords, until you take away the life from them all, and they forget the love <milestone ed="p" n="445" unit="line"/> which they had at the bidding of the wooers, when they lay with them in secret.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191776" n="22.446-22.447">So he spoke, and the women came all in a throng, wailing terribly and shedding big tears. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191777" n="22.448-22.450">First they bore forth the bodies of the slain and set them down beneath the portico of the well-fenced court, <milestone ed="p" n="450" unit="line"/> propping them one against the other;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191778" n="22.450-22.451">and Odysseus himself gave them orders and hastened on the work,</s>
