</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191780" n="22.452-22.453">Then they cleansed the beautiful high seats and the tables with water and porous sponges. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191781" n="22.454-22.456">But Telemachus and the neatherd and the swineherd <milestone ed="p" n="455" unit="line"/> scraped with hoes the floor of the well-built house,</s>

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191783" n="22.457-22.460">But when they had set in order all the hall, they led the women forth from the well-built hall to a place between the dome and the goodly fence of the court, <milestone ed="p" n="460" unit="line"/> and shut them up in a narrow space, whence it was in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> possible to escape. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191784" n="22.461">Then wise Telemachus was the first to speak to the others, saying:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191785" n="22.462-22.464">Let it be by no clean death that I take the lives of these women, who on my own head have poured reproaches and on my mother, and were <mod n="wont:simpsub">accustomed</mod> to lie with the wooers.</s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:22.465-22.501">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191786" n="22.465-22.467"><milestone ed="p" n="465" unit="line"/>So he spoke, and tied the cable of a dark-prowed ship to a great pillar and flung it round the dome, stretching it on high that none might reach the ground with her feet. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191787" n="22.468-22.472">And as when long-winged thrushes or doves fall into a snare that is set in a thicket, <milestone ed="p" n="470" unit="line"/> as they seek to reach their resting-place, and hateful is the bed that gives them welcome, even so the women held their heads in a row, and round the necks of all nooses were laid, that they might die most piteously. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191788" n="22.473">And they writhed a little while with their feet, but not long.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191789" n="22.474">Then forth they led Melanthius through the doorway and the court,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191790" n="22.475-22.477"><milestone ed="p" n="475" unit="line"/> and cut off his nostrils and his ears with the pitiless bronze, and drew out his vitals for the dogs to eat raw, and cut off his hands and his feet in their furious wrath.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191791" n="22.478-22.479">Thereafter they washed their hands and feet, and went into the house to Odysseus, and the work was done.

<s xml:id="sent2191792" n="22.480"><milestone ed="p" n="480" unit="line"/>But Odysseus said to the dear nurse Eurycleia: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191793" n="22.481-22.482">Bring sulphur, old dame, to cleanse from pollution, and bring me fire, that I may purge the hall;</s>


<s xml:id="sent2191794" n="22.482-22.483">and do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> Penelope come <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod> with her handmaidens,</s>

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191796" n="22.485"><milestone ed="p" n="485" unit="line"/>Then the dear nurse Eurycleia answered him: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191797" n="22.486"><sic>Yea</sic>, all this, my child, <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> spoken aright. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191798" n="22.487-22.489">But come, let me bring <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> a cloak and a tunic for raiment, and do not <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> stand thus in the halls with <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> broad shoulders wrapped in rags;</s>

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191800" n="22.490"><milestone ed="p" n="490" unit="line"/>Then Odysseus of many wiles answered her: 

</s>

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191802" n="22.492-22.493">So he spoke, and the dear nurse Eurycleia did not disobey, but brought fire and sulphur;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191803" n="22.493-22.494">but Odysseus throughly purged the hall and the house and the court.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191804" n="22.495-22.496"><milestone ed="p" n="495" unit="line"/>Then the old dame went back through the fair house of Odysseus to bear tidings to the women and <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> them come;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191805" n="22.497">and they came forth from their hall with torches in their hands. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191806" n="22.498-22.500">They thronged about Odysseus and embraced him, and clasped and kissed his head and shoulders <milestone ed="p" n="500" unit="line"/> and his hands in loving welcome;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191807" n="22.500-22.501">and a sweet longing seized him to weep and wail, for in his heart he knew them all.</s></p>

<div type="textpart" subtype="book" n="23">
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:23.1-23.48">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191808" n="23.1-23.2"><milestone ed="p" n="1" unit="line"/>Then the old dame went up to the upper chamber, laughing aloud, to tell her mistress that her dear husband was in the house. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191809" n="23.3">Her knees moved nimbly, but her feet trotted along beneath her;<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note></s>



<s xml:id="sent2191810" n="23.4">and she stood above her lady's head, and spoke to her, and said:
<milestone ed="p" n="5" unit="line"/>


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191811" n="23.5-23.6">Awake, Penelope, dear child, that with <mod n="thine:simpsub">your</mod> own eyes <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='mayest'>may</mod> see what <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='desirest'>desire</mod> all <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> days. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191812" n="23.7">Odysseus is here, and has come home, late though his coming has been, 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191813" n="23.8-23.9">and has slain the proud wooers who vexed his house, and devoured his substance, and oppressed his son.

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2191814" n="23.10"><milestone ed="p" n="10" unit="line"/>Then wise Penelope answered her: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191815" n="23.11-23.13">Dear nurse, the gods have made <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> mad, they who can make foolish even one who is full wise, and set the simple-minded in the paths of understanding;</s>




<s xml:id="sent2191816" n="23.14">it is they that have marred <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> wits, </s>

<s xml:id="sent2191935" n="23.218-23.221"><sic>Nay</sic>, even Argive Helen, daughter of Zeus, would not have lain in love with a man of another <mod n="folk:simpsub">people</mod>, <milestone ed="p" n="220" unit="line"/> had she known that the warlike sons of the Achaeans were to bring her home again to her dear native land. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191936" n="23.222">Yet <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> in her case a god prompted her to work a shameful deed;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191937" n="23.223-23.224">nor until then did she lay up in her mind the thought of that folly, the grievous folly from which at the first sorrow came upon us too.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191938" n="23.225-23.230"><milestone ed="p" n="225" unit="line"/>But now, since <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> told the clear tokens of our bed, which no mortal beside has ever seen save <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> and me alone and one single handmaid, the daughter of Actor, whom my father gave me or ever I came <mod n="hither:simpsub">here</mod>, even her who kept the doors of our strong bridal chamber, <milestone ed="p" n="230" unit="line"/> <sic>lo</sic>, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> convince my heart, unbending as it is.</s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:23.231-23.262">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191939" n="23.231">So she spoke, and in his heart aroused yet more the desire for lamentation;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191940" n="23.232">and he wept, holding in his arms his dear and true-hearted wife. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191941" n="23.233-23.235">And welcome as is the sight of land to men that swim, whose well-built ship Poseidon <milestone ed="p" n="235" unit="line"/> has <mod n="smitten:simpsub">struck</mod> on the sea as it was driven on by the wind and the swollen wave,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191942" n="23.236-23.238">and but few have made their escape from the gray sea to the shore by swimming, and thickly are their bodies crusted with brine, and gladly have they set foot on the land and escaped from their evil case;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191943" n="23.239-23.240">even so welcome to her was her husband, as she gazed upon him, <milestone ed="p" n="240" unit="line"/> and from his neck she could in <corr n="no wise">no way</corr> let her white arms go. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191944" n="23.241-23.242">And now would the rosy-fingered Dawn have arisen upon their weeping, had not the goddess, flashing-eyed Athena, taken other counsel. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191945" n="23.243-23.246">The long night she held back at the end of its course, and likewise stayed the golden-throned Dawn at the streams of Oceanus, and would not suffer her <milestone ed="p" n="245" unit="line"/> to yoke her swift-footed horses that bring light to men, Lampus and Phaethon, who are the colts that bear the Dawn. 


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191946" n="23.247-23.250">Then to his wife said Odysseus of many wiles: Wife, we have not yet come to the end of all our trials, but still hereafter there is to be measureless toil, <milestone ed="p" n="250" unit="line"/> long and hard, which I must fulfil to the end;</s>

<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191947" n="23.251-23.253">for so did the spirit of Teiresias foretell to me on the day when I went down into the house of Hades to enquire concerning the return of my comrades and myself. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191948" n="23.254-23.255">But come, wife, let us to bed, that <milestone ed="p" n="255" unit="line"/> lulled now by sweet slumber we may take our joy of rest.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191949" n="23.256">Then wise Penelope answered him: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191950" n="23.257-23.259">Thy bed shall be ready for <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> whensoever <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> heart shall desire it, since the gods have indeed caused <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> to come back to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> well-built house and <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> native land.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191951" n="23.260-23.262"><milestone ed="p" n="260" unit="line"/>But since <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hast:simpsub">have</mod> bethought <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> of this, and a god has put it into <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> heart, come, tell me of this trial, for in time to come, methinks, I shall learn of it, and to know it at once is no whit worse.</s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:23.263-23.309">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191952" n="23.263">And Odysseus of many wiles answered her, and said: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191953" n="23.264-23.265">Strange lady! why <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> now so urgently <mod n="bid:simpsub">command</mod> me <milestone ed="p" n="265" unit="line"/> tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191954" n="23.265">Yet I will declare it, and will hide nothing. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191955" n="23.266"><mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod> <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> heart shall have no joy of it,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191956" n="23.266-23.270">even as I myself have none; for Teiresias <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> me go forth to full many cities of men, bearing a shapely oar in my hands, till I should come <milestone ed="p" n="270" unit="line"/> to men that know <mod n="naught:simpsub">nothing</mod> of the sea, and eat not of food mingled with salt;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191957" n="23.271-23.272">aye, and they know <mod n="naught:simpsub">nothing</mod> of ships with purple cheeks, or of shapely oars that serve as wings to ships. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191958" n="23.273">And he told me this sign, right manifest; nor will I hide it from <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191959" n="23.274-23.281">When another wayfarer, on meeting me, <milestone ed="p" n="275" unit="line"/> should say that I had a winnowing fan on my stout shoulder, then he <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> me fix my oar in the earth, and make goodly offerings to lord Poseidon—a ram and a bull and a boar, that mates with sows—and depart for my home, and offer sacred hecatombs <milestone ed="p" n="280" unit="line"/> to the immortal gods, who hold broad heaven, to each one in due order. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191960" n="23.281-23.283">And death shall come to me myself far from the sea, a death so gentle, that shall lay me low, when I am overcome with sleek old age, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2191961" n="23.283-23.284">and my people shall dwell in prosperity around me. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191962" n="23.284">All this, he said, should I see fulfilled.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191963" n="23.285"><milestone ed="p" n="285" unit="line"/>Then wise Penelope answered him: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191964" n="23.286-23.287">If <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> the gods are to bring about for <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> a happier old age, there is hope then that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wilt:simpsub">will</mod> find an escape from evil.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191965" n="23.288">Thus they spoke to one another;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191966" n="23.289-23.290">and meanwhile Eurynome and the nurse made ready the bed <milestone ed="p" n="290" unit="line"/> of soft coverlets by the light of blazing torches. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191967" n="23.291-23.294">But when they had busily spread the stout-built bedstead, the old nurse went back to her chamber to lie down, and Eurynome, the maiden of the bedchamber, led them on their way to the couch with a torch in her hands;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191968" n="23.295"><milestone ed="p" n="295" unit="line"/> and when she had led them to the bridal chamber, she went back. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191969" n="23.295-23.296">And they then gladly came to the place of the couch that was theirs of old. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191970" n="23.297-23.299">But Telemachus and the neatherd and the swineherd stayed their feet from dancing, and stayed the women, and themselves lay down to sleep throughout the shadowy halls.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191971" n="23.300-23.305"><milestone ed="p" n="300" unit="line"/>But when the two had had their fill of the joy of love, they took delight in tales, speaking each to the other. She, the fair lady, told of all that she had endured in the halls, looking upon the destructive throng of the wooers, who for her sake <milestone ed="p" n="305" unit="line"/> <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> many beasts, cattle and goodly sheep; and great store of wine was drawn from the jars. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191972" n="23.306-23.308">But Zeus-born Odysseus recounted all the woes that he had brought on men, and all the toil that in his sorrow he had himself endured,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191973" n="23.308-23.309">and she was glad to listen, nor did sweet sleep fall upon her eyelids, till he had told all the tale.</s></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:23.310-23.343">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191974" n="23.310-23.311"><milestone ed="p" n="310" unit="line"/>He began by telling how at the first he overcame the Cicones, and then came to the rich land of the Lotus-eaters,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191975" n="23.312-23.313">and all that the Cyclops <sic>wrought</sic>, and how he made him pay the price for his mighty comrades, whom the Cyclops had eaten, and had shown no pity. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191976" n="23.314-23.317">Then how he came to Aeolus, who received him with a ready heart, <milestone ed="p" n="315" unit="line"/> and sent him on his way; but it was not yet his fate to come to his dear native land, <sic>nay</sic>, the storm-wind caught him up again, and bore him over the teeming deep, groaning heavily. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191977" n="23.318-23.320">Next how he came to Telepylus of the Laestrygonians, who destroyed his ships and his well-greaved comrades

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191978" n="23.320"><milestone ed="p" n="320" unit="line"/> one and all, and Odysseus alone escaped in his black ship. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191979" n="23.321-23.325">Then he told of all the wiles and craftiness of Circe, and how in his benched ship he had gone to the dank house of Hades to consult the spirit of Theban Teiresias, and had seen all his comrades <milestone ed="p" n="325" unit="line"/> and the mother who bore him and nursed him, when a child. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191980" n="23.326-23.328">And how he heard the voice of the Sirens, who sing unceasingly, and had come to the Wandering Rocks, and to <sic>dread</sic> Charybdis, and to Scylla, from whom never yet had men escaped unscathed. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191981" n="23.329">Then how his comrades <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> the <mod n="kine:simpsub">cattle</mod> of Helios,

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191982" n="23.330-23.332"><milestone ed="p" n="330" unit="line"/> and how Zeus, who thunders on high, <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> his swift ship with a flaming thunderbolt, and his goodly comrades perished all together, while he alone escaped the evil fates. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191983" n="23.333-23.336">And how he came to the isle Ogygia and to the nymph Calypso, who kept him there <milestone ed="p" n="335" unit="line"/> in her hollow caves, yearning that he should be her husband, and tended him, and said that she would make him immortal and ageless all his days;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191984" n="23.337">yet she could never persuade the heart in his breast. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191985" n="23.338-23.341">Then how he came after many toils to the Phaeacians, who heartily showed him all honor, as if he were a god, <milestone ed="p" n="340" unit="line"/> and sent him in a ship to his dear native land, after giving him stores of bronze and gold and raiment. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191986" n="23.342-23.343">This was the end of the tale he told, when sweet sleep, that loosens the limbs of men, leapt upon him, loosening the cares of his heart.</s></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:23.344-23.372">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2191987" n="23.344">Then again the goddess, flashing-eyed Athena, took other counsel.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191988" n="23.345-23.348"><milestone ed="p" n="345" unit="line"/>When she judged that the heart of Odysseus had had its fill of dalliance with his wife and of sleep, straightway she roused from Oceanus golden-throned Dawn to bring light to men;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191989" n="23.348-23.349">and Odysseus rose from his soft couch, and gave charge to his wife, saying:





</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2191990" n="23.350-23.352"><milestone ed="p" n="350" unit="line"/>Wife, by now have we had our fill of many trials, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> and I, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> here, mourning over my troublous journey home,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191991" n="23.352-23.353">while as for me, Zeus and the other gods bound me fast in sorrows far from my native land, all eager as I was to return. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191992" n="23.354-23.358">But now that we have both come to the couch of our desire, <milestone ed="p" n="355" unit="line"/> do <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> care for the wealth that I have within the halls; as for the flocks which the insolent wooers have wasted, I shall myself get me many as booty, and others will the Achaeans give, until they fill all my folds;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191993" n="23.359-23.360">but I <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> will go to my well-wooded farm <milestone ed="p" n="360" unit="line"/> to see my noble father, who for my sake is <sic>sore</sic> distressed,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191994" n="23.361">and on <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, wife, do I lay this charge, wise though <corr n="thou art">you are</corr>. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191995" n="23.362-23.363">Straightway at the rising of the sun will report go abroad concerning the wooers whom I <mod n="slew:simpsub">killed</mod> in the halls. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191996" n="23.364-23.365">Therefore go <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> up to <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> upper chamber with <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> handmaids, <milestone ed="p" n="365" unit="line"/> and <mod n="abide:simpsub">remain</mod> there. Look <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> on no man, nor ask a question.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2191997" n="23.366-23.368">He spoke, and girt about his shoulders his beautiful armour, and roused Telemachus and the neatherd and the swineherd, and <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod> them all take weapons of war in their hands. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191998" n="23.369-23.370">They did not disobey, but clad themselves in bronze, <milestone ed="p" n="370" unit="line"/> and opened the doors, and went forth,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2191999" n="23.370">and Odysseus led the way. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192000" n="23.371-23.372">By now there was light over the earth, but Athena hid them in night, and swiftly led them forth from the city.</s></p>
</div>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="book" n="24">
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:24.1-24.34">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2192001" n="24.1-24.2"><milestone ed="p" n="1" unit="line"/>Meanwhile Cyllenian Hermes called forth the spirits of the wooers. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192002" n="24.2-24.4">He held in his hands his wand, a fair wand of gold, wherewith he lulls to sleep the eyes of whom he will, while others again he wakens even out of slumber;

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192003" n="24.5"><milestone ed="p" n="5" unit="line"/> with this he roused and led the spirits, and they followed gibbering. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192004" n="24.6-24.9">And as in the innermost recess of a wondrous cave bats flit about gibbering, when one has fallen from off the rock from the chain in which they cling to one another, so these went with him gibbering,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192005" n="24.9-24.10">and Hermes, the Helper, led them <milestone ed="p" n="10" unit="line"/> down the dank ways. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192006" n="24.11-24.13">Past the streams of Oceanus they went, past the rock <placeName key="tgn,7002712">Leucas</placeName>, past the gates of the sun and the land of dreams, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2192007" n="24.13-24.14">and quickly came to the mead of asphodel, where the spirits dwell, phantoms of men who have done with toils.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192008" n="24.15-24.19"><milestone ed="p" n="15" unit="line"/>Here they found the spirit of Achilles, son of Peleus, and those of Patroclus, of peerless Antilochus, and of Aias, who in comeliness and form was the goodliest of all the Danaans after the peerless son of Peleus.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192009" n="24.19-24.21">So these were thronging about Achilles, and near to them <milestone ed="p" n="20" unit="line"/> drew the spirit of Agamemnon, son of Atreus, sorrowing;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192010" n="24.21-24.22">and round about him others were gathered, the spirits of all those who were slain with him in the house of Aegisthus, and met their fate. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192011" n="24.23">And the spirit of the son of Peleus was first to address him, saying: 


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2192012" n="24.24-24.27">Son of Atreus, we <mod n="deemed:simpsub">thought</mod> that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <milestone ed="p" n="25" unit="line"/> above all other heroes <mod n="wast:simpsub">were</mod> all <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> days dear to Zeus, who hurls the thunderbolt, because <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wast:simpsub">were</mod> lord over many mighty men in the land of the Trojans, where we Achaeans suffered woes. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192013" n="24.28-24.29">But <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> on <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> too was deadly doom to come all too early, the doom that not one avoids of those who are born.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192014" n="24.30-24.31"><milestone ed="p" n="30" unit="line"/>Ah, would that in the pride of that honor of which <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wast:simpsub">were</mod> master <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="hadst:simpsub">had</mod> met death and fate in the land of the Trojans. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192015" n="24.32-24.33">Then would the whole host of the Achaeans have made <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> a tomb, and for <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> son too wouldst <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> have won great glory in days to come;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192016" n="24.34">but now, as it seems, it has been decreed that <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="shouldst:simpsub">should</mod> be cut off by a most piteous death.</s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:24.35-24.84">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2192017" n="24.35"><milestone ed="p" n="35" unit="line"/>Then the spirit of the son of Atreus answered him: 

</s>
<q><p>

<s xml:id="sent2192018" n="24.36-24.37">Fortunate son of Peleus, godlike Achilles, that <mod n="wast:simpsub">were</mod> slain in the land of <placeName key="perseus,Troy">Troy</placeName> far from <placeName key="perseus,Argos">Argos</placeName>,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192019" n="24.37-24.39">and about <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> others fell, the best of the sons of the Trojans and Achaeans, fighting for <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> body;</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192020" n="24.39-24.40">and <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> in the whirl of dust <milestone ed="p" n="40" unit="line"/> <mod n="didst:simpsub">did</mod> lie mighty in <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> mightiness, forgetful of <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> horsemanship. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192021" n="24.41">We on our part strove the whole day long,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192022" n="24.41-24.42">nor should we ever have stayed from the fight, had not Zeus stayed us with a storm. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192023" n="24.43-24.45">But after we had borne <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> to the ships <corr n="from out">out of</corr> the fight, we laid <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> on a bier, and cleansed <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> fair flesh <milestone ed="p" n="45" unit="line"/> with warm water and with ointment,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192024" n="24.45-24.46">and many hot tears did the Danaans shed around <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, and they shore their hair. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192025" n="24.47-24.48">And <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> mother came forth from the sea with the immortal sea-nymphs, when she heard the tidings,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192026" n="24.48-24.49">and a wondrous cry arose over the deep, and <sic>thereat</sic> trembling laid hold of all the Achaeans.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192027" n="24.50-24.52"><milestone ed="p" n="50" unit="line"/>Then would they all have sprung up and rushed to the hollow ships, had not a man, wise in the wisdom of old, stayed them, even Nestor, whose counsel had before appeared the best. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192028" n="24.53">He with good intent addressed their assembly, and said:</s></p>
<p><q>

<s xml:id="sent2192029" n="24.54">Hold, <mod n="ye:simpsub">you</mod> Argives; flee not, Achaean youths.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192030" n="24.55-24.56"><milestone ed="p" n="55" unit="line"/>
'Tis his mother who comes here forth from the sea with the immortal sea-nymphs to look upon the face of her dead son.</s></q></p>
<p>

<s xml:id="sent2192031" n="24.57">So he spoke, and the great-hearted Achaeans ceased from their flight. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192032" n="24.58-24.59">Then around <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> stood the daughters of the old man of the sea wailing piteously, and they clothed <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> about with immortal raiment.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192033" n="24.60-24.61"><milestone ed="p" n="60" unit="line"/>And the Muses, nine in all, replying to one another with sweet voices, led the dirge. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192034" n="24.61-24.62">There couldst <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> not have seen an <placeName key="tgn,5001993">Argive</placeName> but was in tears,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192035" n="24.62">so deeply did the clear-toned Muse move their hearts. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192036" n="24.63-24.64">Thus for seventeen days alike by night and day did we bewail <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, immortal gods and mortal men,

</s>

<s xml:id="sent2192068" n="24.129-24.130"><sic>Nay</sic>, she contrived in her heart this guileful thing also: she set up in her halls a great web, and fell to weaving— <milestone ed="p" n="130" unit="line"/> fine of thread was the web and very wide;</s>

<s xml:id="sent2192254" n="24.473-24.474">Father of us all, <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> son of Cronos, high above all lords, tell to me that ask <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> what purpose <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> mind now hides within <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>.

<s xml:id="sent2192255" n="24.475-24.476"><milestone ed="p" n="475" unit="line"/>Wilt <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> yet further bring to pass evil war and the <sic>dread</sic> din of battle, or <mod n="wilt:simpsub">will</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> establish friendship betwixt the <mod n="twain:simpsub">two</mod>?

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2192256" n="24.477">Then Zeus, the cloud-gatherer, answered her, and said: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2192257" n="24.478">My child, why <mod n="dost:simpsub">do</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> ask and question me of this? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192258" n="24.479-24.480">Didst <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> not <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod> devise this plan, <milestone ed="p" n="480" unit="line"/> that <mod n="verily:simpsub">truly</mod> Odysseus should take vengeance on these men at his coming? 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192259" n="24.481">Do as <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wilt:simpsub">will</mod>,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192260" n="24.481">but I will tell <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod> what is fitting. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192261" n="24.482-24.485">Now that <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus has taken vengeance on the wooers, let them swear a solemn oath, and let him be king all his days, and let us on our part <milestone ed="p" n="485" unit="line"/> bring about a forgetting of the slaying of their sons and brothers;</s>


<s xml:id="sent2192262" n="24.485-24.486">and let them love one another as before, and let wealth and peace abound.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2192263" n="24.487-24.488">So saying, he roused Athena, who was already eager, and she went darting down from the heights of <placeName key="tgn,7011019">Olympus</placeName>.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192264" n="24.489-24.490">But when they had put from them the desire of honey-hearted food, <milestone ed="p" n="490" unit="line"/> the much-enduring, <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus was the first to speak among his company, saying: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2192265" n="24.491">Let one go forth and see whether they be not now drawing near.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2192266" n="24.492">So he spoke,</s>


<s xml:id="sent2192267" n="24.492">and a son of Dolius went forth, as he <mod n="bade:simpsub">commanded</mod>;</s>


<s xml:id="sent2192268" n="24.493">he went and stood upon the threshold, and saw them all close at hand,</s>


<s xml:id="sent2192269" n="24.494">and straightway he spoke to Odysseus winged words:




</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2192270" n="24.495"><milestone ed="p" n="495" unit="line"/>Here they are close at hand. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192271" n="24.495">Quick, let us arm.</s></q></p>
</div>
<div type="textpart" subtype="card" n="urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg002.perseus-grc2:24.496-24.548">




<p>

<s xml:id="sent2192272" n="24.496-24.497">So he spoke, and they rose up and arrayed themselves in armour: Odysseus and his men were four, and six the sons of Dolius,</s>


<s xml:id="sent2192273" n="24.498-24.499">and among them Laertes and Dolius donned their armour, grey-headed though they were, warriors perforce.

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192274" n="24.500-24.501"><milestone ed="p" n="500" unit="line"/>But when they had clothed their bodies in gleaming bronze, they opened the doors and went forth, and Odysseus led them.


</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192275" n="24.502-24.503">Then Athena, daughter of Zeus, drew near them in the likeness of Mentor both in form and in voice,
</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192276" n="24.504">and the much-enduring, <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus was glad at sight of her,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192277" n="24.505"><milestone ed="p" n="505" unit="line"/> and straightway spoke to Telemachus, his dear son:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2192278" n="24.506-24.509">Telemachus, now <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> learn this—having <mod n="thyself:simpsub">yourself</mod> come to the place of battle, where the best warriors are put to the trial—to bring no disgrace upon the house of <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> fathers, for we have ever excelled in strength and in valor over all the earth.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2192279" n="24.510"><milestone ed="p" n="510" unit="line"/>And wise Telemachus answered him: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2192280" n="24.511-24.512">Thou <mod n="shalt:simpsub">shall</mod> see me, if <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n="wilt:simpsub">will</mod>, dear father, in my present temper, bringing no disgrace upon <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> house, even as <mod n="thou:simpsub">you</mod> <mod n='sayest'>say</mod>.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2192281" n="24.513">So said he, and Laertes was glad, and spoke, saying: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2192282" n="24.514">What a day is this for me, kind gods!

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192283" n="24.514"><mod n="Verily:simpsub">Truly</mod> right glad am I:</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192284" n="24.515"><milestone ed="p" n="515" unit="line"/> my son and my son's son are vying with one another in valor.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2192285" n="24.516">Then flashing-eyed Athena came near him and said: 

</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2192286" n="24.517-24.519">Son of Arceisius, far the dearest of all my friends, make a prayer to the flashing-eyed maiden and to father Zeus, and then straightway raise aloft <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> long spear, and hurl it.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2192287" n="24.520-24.523"><milestone ed="p" n="520" unit="line"/>So spoke Pallas Athena, and breathed into him great might. Then he prayed to the daughter of great Zeus, and straightway raised aloft his long spear, and hurled it, and <mod n="smote:simpsub">struck</mod> Eupeithes through the helmet with cheek-piece of bronze. 

</s>


<s xml:id="sent2192288" n="24.524-24.525">This stayed not the spear, but the bronze passed through, <milestone ed="p" n="525" unit="line"/> and he fell with a thud, and his armour clanged about him. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192289" n="24.526-24.527">Then on the foremost fighters fell Odysseus and his glorious son, and thrust at them with swords and double-pointed spears. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192290" n="24.528-24.530">And now would they have slain them all, and cut them off from returning, had not Athena, daughter of Zeus, who bears the aegis, <milestone ed="p" n="530" unit="line"/> shouted aloud, and checked all the host, saying:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2192291" n="24.531-24.532">Refrain, men of <placeName key="tgn,1007519">Ithaca</placeName>, from grievous war, that with all speed you may part, and that without bloodshed.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2192292" n="24.533">So spoke Athena, and pale fear seized them. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192293" n="24.534-24.535">Then in their terror the arms flew from their hands <milestone ed="p" n="535" unit="line"/> and fell one and all to the ground, as the goddess uttered her voice, </s>



<s xml:id="sent2192294" n="24.536">and they turned toward the city, eager to save their lives. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192295" n="24.537-24.538">Terribly then shouted the much-enduring, <mod n="goodly">brilliant</mod> Odysseus, and gathering himself together he swooped upon them like an eagle of lofty flight,</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192296" n="24.539-24.540">and at that moment the son of Cronos cast a flaming thunderbolt, <milestone ed="p" n="540" unit="line"/> and down it fell before the flashing-eyed daughter of the mighty sire. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192297" n="24.541">Then flashing-eyed Athena spoke to Odysseus saying:


</s>
<q>

<s xml:id="sent2192298" n="24.542-24.544">Son of Laertes, sprung from Zeus, Odysseus of many devices, stay <mod n="thy:simpsub">your</mod> hand, and make the strife of equal<note anchored="true" resp="Loeb">1</note> war to cease, lest <mod n="haply:simpsub">by chance</mod> the son of Cronos be <mod n="wroth:simpsub">angry</mod> with <mod n="thee:simpsub">you</mod>, even Zeus, whose voice is borne afar.

</s>
</q>

<s xml:id="sent2192299" n="24.545"><milestone ed="p" n="545" unit="line"/>So spoke Athena, and he obeyed, and was glad at heart. 

</s>



<s xml:id="sent2192300" n="24.546-24.548">Then for all time to come a solemn covenant betwixt the <mod n="twain:simpsub">two</mod> was made by Pallas Athena, daughter of Zeus, who bears the aegis, in the likeness of Mentor both in form and in voice.</s></p>
